HEADLINE: Real Estate

BYLINE: By Morris Newman 

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif.

 BODY:
THE Walt Disney Company has leased 170,000 square feet in an office building here, in a move that buttresses the company's position as the city's largest office tenant. The lease has also underscored the position of Burbank, which is 10 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles, as one of the tightest office markets in Southern California.
Disney already occupied 70,000 square feet of the Tower office building before it agreed late last year to take an additional 100,000 square feet in the same building, following a decision by Warner Brothers Inc. to vacate the space. 
 While the Disney lease is one of the largest office deals in recent months in the Los Angeles area, it appears small in comparison with the company's total commitment to office space in Burbank and in neighboring Glendale. In those cities alone, Disney has leased about 1.5 million square feet of office space, and a comparable amount of industrial space. That tally does not include company-owned buildings on Disney's studio lot.
Burbank, a city with an industrial ambiance and a population of 93,000, is arguably the nerve center of the entertainment industry in Southern California. The industry's rapid expansion has benefited the city, where entertainment companies occupy about one-third of the city's four million square feet of office space.
The high demand for office space in Burbank is an anomaly amid the otherwise slack office market of greater Los Angeles. Burbank's vacancy rate is about 7.9 percent, far less than the vacancy rates of 18.6 percent in downtown Los Angeles and 15.8 percent in the San Fernando Valley area, according to fourth-quarter 1994 figures compiled by CB Commercial Real Estate Group Inc.
While developers in other parts of the Los Angeles area are trying to find tenants for buildings, officials in Burbank are talking about a need for new office and industrial buildings, a topic little discussed elsewhere in Los Angeles County.
"We can't meet the demand," said Robert M. Tague, Burbank's director of community development. "We are referring users to other cities, such as Glendale and Pasadena, because we no longer have the space to house them. Believe me, it does not make us happy."
Entertainment companies are seeking space in surrounding cities, which previously held little attraction. Warner Brothers, itself one of the city's largest tenants, signed a lease in December for 100,000 square feet in neighboring Glendale at the 500 North Brand building because no comparable block of space was available in Burbank. Another company formerly based in Burbank, Lockheed Air Terminal Inc., recently signed a lease for 35,000 square feet in Glendale at 330 North Brand Boulevard.
The Glendale buildings are "the beneficiaries of the voracious appetite for space that Disney has," William Boyd, a CB Commercial broker, said. He and a fellow broker, Doug Marlow, negotiated the Disney lease on behalf of the landlord, Tochikogyo USA Inc.
The lack of space in Burbank, where no new office building has been completed since 1991, was one of the factors that has driven Disney's conquest of local office space. In 1992, the company formulated a plan to obtain space for its operations, "in anticipation of where we saw our business going, on a macro-economic level, and where we saw the real estate market going," George H. Garfield, Disney's director of asset strategy, said.
That strategy, in short, was to tie up as much space as Disney could possibly need, then "grow or contract within the envelope, so to speak, without being exposed to market factors," Mr. Garfield said.

HEADLINE: China's Known Brands Are Most Often Japanese

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
American companies eager to win allegiance from China's 1.2 billion people are fighting an uphill battle, according to a comprehensive new poll of consumer attitudes on the Chinese mainland that was released yesterday.
Six of the top 10 foreign brands identified by the survey's respondents were Japanese, even though those surveyed were asked to pick from a list containing twice as many American as Japanese names. Four of the Japanese brands -- Panasonic, Hitachi, Toshiba and Toyota -- were also the ones the respondents said they held in highest regard. 
 Coca-Cola was the most widely known American brand, finishing second with 62 percent recognition, just behind Hitachi's 65 percent. The next closest American finishers were Mickey Mouse, which is a distinct brand in China and was the seventh-most-recognized name, with 54 percent, and Marlboro, which was eighth, with 51 percent.
"U.S. multinationals have their work cut out for them," said Richard W. Burkholder Jr., director of worldwide operations for the Gallup Organization, which conducted the poll.
The survey showed that brand loyalty was relatively weak in China, where consumers are chiefly concerned with the price and quality of the goods they buy and where Chinese manufacturers are still favored in the countryside.
The poll was conducted to promote Gallup's entry into China and was partly financed by the Japan Management Association. Gallup said the survey was the first truly representative sampling of the habits and attitudes of Chinese adults.
Gallup representatives fanned out across China from May 2 to Sept. 15, asking more than 400 questions of a single individual in each of 3,400 households. In especially remote areas, like the Gobi Desert, Mr. Burkholder said, Gallup interviewers traveled on horseback or by camel.
The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.8 percent, he added.
"We're comfortable that these results project what all people in China would have answered if we could have asked each one of them," Mr. Burkholder said.
In a country buffeted by fierce political winds over the last five decades, the survey shows how deeply the free-market policies introduced in the late 1970's by Deng Xiaoping have permeated the national psyche.
Asked their personal philosophy, 68 percent of those polled said it could be summed up by the phrase "work hard and get rich." Only 4 percent summarized their personal belief with a Maoist credo: "Never think of yourself. Give everything in service to society."
The survey also shows a country that has grown relatively affluent, especially in urban areas. More than 90 percent of the homes in China's nine largest cities now have both a color television set and a refrigerator. That compares with 40 percent with color televisions and 25 percent with refrigerators nationwide.
China's distribution network is not sophisticated enough to allow most foreign companies to sell consumer products beyond the biggest markets around Beijing, Shanghai and in Guangdong province, near Hong Kong. So, changing tastes in those urban areas can be a barometer for what may develop throughout the country. For example, instant coffee was found in only 6 percent of the households nationally, but in 37 percent of the households surveyed in the country's nine largest cities.
Over all, the consumer items most likely to be owned in a Chinese home were a bicycle, an electric fan, a radio, a television set and a rice cooker. The most popular planned purchases were a color TV, a washing machine, refrigerator, tape recorder and videocassette recorder.
Those polled were about equally divided when asked if they were satisfied or dissatisfied with their jobs, income and the quality of their food. But a larger number expressed dissatisfaction when asked about the furnishings in their homes and their general standard of living.
"Clearly this is a very materialistic society, and not all the aspirations are being met, particularly in rural areas," Mr. Burkholder said.
The poll found that the habits of drinking alcohol and smoking were heavily dominated by Chinese men. More than 80 percent of the men said they smoked "regularly" or "occasionally," while the national average for women was 11 percent.
On the other hand, only 66 percent of the respondents said they drank alcohol, a lower percentage than was found in any Western country except the United States (53 percent) and Spain (64 percent).


GRAPHIC: A recent survey of 3,400 Chinese found that Japanese companies had higher brand-name recognition than U.S. companies, and that most Chinese wanted to be rich. Graph lists companies of brands with high name recognition and phrases that best reflect respondents' attitudes toward life. (Source: The Gallup Organization)

HEADLINE: Emilio Collado, a Creator of the World Money System, Dies at 84

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Emilio Gabriel Collado, an economist and oil company executive who helped design the international post-World War II monetary system and served as America's first executive director of the World Bank, died at the Jupiter Medical Center in Jupiter, Fla., on Feb. 9. A resident of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., since 1993, he was 84.
Mr. Collado died of heart failure, said his wife, Maria. 
 Mr. Collado, who was widely known as Pete, was born in Cranford, N.J., and lived most of his life in the New York area.
In 1934, Mr. Collado (pronounced coe-YAH-doe) joined the Treasury Department as an economist specializing in international monetary issues, after graduating from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard University, where he had earned a doctorate in economics. From 1936 to 1938 he worked at the New York branch of the Federal Reserve Bank, where he headed the Latin American and Far Eastern sections.
In 1938, he moved to the State Department and went on to hold several senior economic positions during World War II.
Most notably, he was a member of the American negotiating team at the Bretton Woods conference in 1944 at Bretton Woods, N.H. There, the United States and Britain effectively designed the postwar international monetary system, creating the International Monetary Fund to oversee a system of fixed but adjustable exchange rates between currencies and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, as the World Bank is officially called, to finance reconstruction after the Allies' victory.
The previous year, he took part in the international conference at Hot Springs, Va., which set up the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization.
In 1946, President Harry S. Truman nominated Mr. Collado to be the first American director of the World Bank, representing the United States on the bank's executive board.
In 1947, he joined the Exxon Corporation, rising to executive vice president and a director of the company at the time of his retirement in 1975.
Last October, President Clinton wrote to him to mark the 50th anniversary of the Bretton Woods agreement, saying the agreement he had helped frame had produced "five decades of international cooperation and the greatest economic growth in the history of the world."
He was also a trustee of the Hispanic Society in New York, a former director of J. P. Morgan & Company and a former chairman and director of the Americas Society of New York.
His first wife, Janet Gilbert, died in 1972. Besides his second wife, Maria, he is survived by a son, Emilio Gabriel, of Vienna, Va.; a daughter, Lisa Collado Ford of New York City; a stepson, Pedro M. Lopez-Tanco of Orlando, Fla., and five grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Emilio G. Collado. (The New York Times, 1971)

HEADLINE: Conservatives Forge New Strategy To Challenge Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15

 BODY:
An effort by two San Francisco-area academics to eliminate affirmative-action programs in California has set off a debate over civil rights that is rapidly spreading across the country and threatens to be one of the most divisive national dialogues in years.
The two professors, Glynn Custred and Thomas Wood, who describe themselves as "staunch conservatives," want the issue of affirmative action put to a popular vote in California sometime next year. It is an approach that poll takers and political analysts already say has a good chance of overturning the state's affirmative-action laws. 
 Mr. Custred, an anthropology professor at California State University in Hayward, said, "Affirmative action has been losing steam with the general public, and we think we've hit upon the sure way to finally reverse it and restore true color-blind fairness in the United States.".
To get their proposal on the ballot, Mr. Custred, Mr. Wood and their supporters will need to gather about a million signatures on petitions. That effort, which the two men say will begin in a matter of weeks, could cost upward of a million dollars.
Few political experts doubt they will exceed both requirements.
"The climate is now such that they'll just blitz through," said Mervin Field, the dean of California poll takers who runs the California Poll.
Recent surveys show the professors' effort may succeed, not just in California but elsewhere. It is an approach that is already being injected into the 1996 Presidential race and that is also beginning to spark some ugly exchanges, even among old friends and political allies.
Even some Democrats with impeccable liberal credentials are beginning to break with their party's traditional hard-line support for affirmative action. They suggest that the system of extending special preferences based on factors like race and sex has outlived its usefulness and should be abandoned or changed so that preferences are extended only on the basis of economic need.
As for Republicans, many who once hesitated to publicly criticize affirmative action are now openly attacking it, sensing a change in the national mood, particularly since the November 1994 elections.
Susan Estrich, a California law professor and veteran Democratic campaign strategist, sees political danger in continuing to argue on behalf of affirmative action.
"Affirmative action was never meant to be permanent, and now is truly the time to move on to some other approach," she said in an interview. "You can try to paint Republican opponents as having been captured by the far right and the like, but that's not going to make the Democratic Party the majority party again. In fact, there's a bad potential for this issue to drive a wedge right through the Democratic Party, if it doesn't yield some."
Government, schools and thousands of businesses rely on affirmative action as a tool of redress when hiring, promoting, awarding contracts or admitting students.
But to Mr. Custred and Mr. Wood, a former philosophy professor who now heads the California Association of Scholars, a Berkeley-based group of conservative educators, affirmative action is a corruption of the civil rights laws passed in the 1960's.
"The specific goal of those laws was to prohibit discrimination," Mr. Custred said. "The laws rightly encourage reaching out, but it's a perversion to say they permit the hiring of people by quota, or the admission of students without regard to academic merit, or the letting of contracts according to race-based formulas."
This is the proposed referendum that the professors hope to put on the ballot: "Neither the State of California nor any of its political subdivisions or agents shall use race, sex, color, ethnicity or national origin as a criterion for either discriminating against, or granting preferential treatment to, any individual or group in the operation of the State's system of public employment, public education or public contracting."
Mr. Custred and Mr. Wood hope to raise enough money and gather enough signatures to put the affirmative action question on the ballot in California, possibly for the March 1996 primary but more likely for the November 1996 general election. Then they plan to encourage ballot efforts in other states and, if their movement spreads, eventually press Congress to act.
If they succeed, next year's Presidential hopefuls will have to adjust accordingly when they come looking for votes in California, the so-called "must win" state. On the Democratic side, the adjustment will require special care, given the party's liberal history on civil rights.
Already the Custred-Wood proposal, which its authors call the California Civil Rights Initiative, has been labeled "Son of 187," a reference to Proposition 187, the immigration-control measure that California voters passed overwhelmingly in November but that the courts have mostly put on hold, citing concern over its constitutionality.
Recent opinion polls indicate that dissatisfaction with affirmative action has grown, with two of three Americans, including Californians, having serious doubts about the fairness of the concept, especially when remedial devices like hiring quotas and contract set-asides are used.
The Republican landslide last fall was attributed in part to pent-up anger in white men, many of whom told poll takers that they were fed up with affirmative action, whether mandated by law or voluntary.
"Count me among those angry men," said Mr. Wood. "I know the sting of affirmative action. I was once passed over for a teaching job because, I was told privately, I was white and male. The worm has turned."
Civil rights leaders fear the worst. Of particular concern is that many of their supporters are seeming to drift away as affirmative action becomes more controversial.
For example, Ward Connerly, a black member of the Board of Regents of the University of California, recently asserted that the state's college admissions officers were going too far with affirmative action, directly violating a 1978 United States Supreme Court ruling.
"What we're doing is inequitable," he said. "We are relying on race and ethnicity not as one of many factors but as a dominant factor to the exclusion of all others. To those who say, 'Affirmative action now, affirmative action forever as it is now' -- that's what George Wallace said about segregation."
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, has already traveled to California to voice opposition to the Custred-Wood proposal and to any retreat on affirmative action. He called for a "register and resist" voter campaign.
Noting that Gov. Pete Wilson, a potential Republican Presidential candidate, had offered kind words for the Custred-Wood initiative, Mr. Jackson said: "Pete Wilson is liken unto George Wallace of Alabama. He wants to stand in front of the schoolhouse door."
Elizabeth Toledo, the head of the California branch of the National Organization for Women, that group's largest branch, was more measured, as she, too, vowed to resist the Custred-Wood initiative, calling it "divisive scapegoating" and "one of the most significant attacks yet on our rights."
In Washington and elsewhere on the national political scene, members of Congress and prospective 1996 Presidential candidates are scrambling for position, some eager to run with the issue, others not sure whether to plunge into the coming fracas or to flee headlong from it.
Both President Clinton, who has supported affirmative action, and the Republican leaders on Capitol Hill, most of whom have long held doubts about it, have assigned aides to study the issue. Among suggested alternatives is replacing race-based and sex-based quotas with quotas based on economic need, as measured by income.
In Sacramento, some Democratic state legislators have also begun to study alternative approaches, with an eye toward taking the issue away from Republicans.
In an example of how the debate is beginning to divide old friends and allies, the Speaker of the California Assembly, Willie L. Brown Jr., perhaps the nation's best-known black state legislator, lashed out on Tuesday at those who would moderate employment and education considerations for women and members of minorities. "The attack on affirmative action is totally phony," he asserted during a press conference.
Mr. Brown was particularly harsh on Bill Press, the head of the California Democratic Party, who has suggested that Democrats consider alternative approaches to "protect" affirmative action and to head off the San Francisco academics and their Republican allies.
"Listen," Mr. Brown said, "I'm practical enough to know how Democrats love to try to survive. And I'm also practical enough to know that you don't survive unless you show some evidence of principle."
William Kristol, a leading Republican strategist in Washington, said: "The whole way the American people look at affirmative action has changed since last November's election results. It's no longer beyond the pale to be critical."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Campus Protest Against Slurs

 
 BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Some 200 students and faculty members from the University of California at Berkeley rallied today to denounce the distribution of fliers attacking affirmative action in derogatory and racist terms. The fliers, put in the mailboxes of 15 minority students at the Boalt Hall Law School, were discovered on Saturday.
"Rejoice, you crybaby niggers. It's affirmative action month," the flier said in part. "When I see you in class it bugs the hell out of me because you're taking the seat of someone qualified."
The University Chancellor, Chang-Lin Tien, promised to try to find those responsible.
"The older I get, the more convinced I become of the centrality of the issue of race in American society," he said at the rally. "The issues surrounding it never go away. They remain under the surface for a period of time, but inevitably, it seems the melting pot boils over. We are in one of those periods now."
Nicole Wong, a law student, said: "There are a lot of messages going out throughout the state saying racism is O.K. All those things send out these messages that people of color are an O.K. target."

HEADLINE: IRAQ SAID TO SELL OIL IN SECRET PLAN TO SKIRT U.N. BAN

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Iraq has set up a system over the past year to export crude oil and refined products and thus bypass United Nations sanctions barring such sales, senior oil industry executives and traders said today.
The executives said the sales had generated $700 million to $800 million in revenue for the Iraqi economy, which is crippled by sanctions imposed by the United Nations after the invasion of Kuwait in 1990. 
 The executives, some of whom are directly involved in the sales, said Iraq was relying on a growing network of traders motivated by big discounts. Traders said Iraq was selling the oil for as little as $8 a barrel, compared to a current market price of about $14 for Middle Eastern crude oil of that type.
Hundreds of trucks are carrying the oil through Kurdish territory in Iraq's northern region into Turkey or to Iran, where the oil can be sold quickly at a profit without being re-exported.
The advantage for the Iraqi Kurds or for Iran, normally adversaries of the Baghdad Government, is financial profit, said the traders, whose accounts were confirmed by senior oil executives in France and Britain.
Baghdad allows Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq to collect a tax on each truck passing through, with much of the revenue funneled to Kurdish political leaders who have previously fought against the Iraqi Army. And the Iranian Government has financial links to many of the middlemen who operate along Iran's long border with Iraq.
Dozens of small tankers are also sailing from Umm Qasr, an Iraqi port south of Basra and near the Kuwait border, to the Persian Gulf area near Dubai, where the oil is reloaded onto other tankers bound for markets in the Mediterranean.
The profits for the traders far outweigh the danger of occasional interception by United Nations vessels, mostly American warships, patrolling the Persian Gulf, the traders say.
"They are selling their oil at $8 to $10 per barrel," one trader based in London said. "That's a big discount, which explains why many of us are willing to take risks to move that oil."
By offering the discounts, Iraq has raised the total exports through these routes to about 200,000 barrels a day, bringing in revenue of more than $700 million in the past year, industry executives said.
That is less than 6 percent of the $12.7 billion Iraq would earn if it were still exporting 2.5 million barrels a day at world prices, as it did before the gulf war. Nonetheless, the income is significant for a country with few sources of revenue.
The oil-smuggling network, largely managed by senior Government officials related to President Saddam Hussein, including his son, Uday, and his brother-in-law, Industry Minister Hussein Kamil, shows every sign of expanding further as operators on both sides of Iraq's borders improve their logistics.
Oil executives and Iraqis say exports have expanded with the tacit support of Turkey, Iran, Jordan and others in the region that believe the sanctions against Iraq have been in place too long and are costing them too much in lost trade with Baghdad.
Dozens of international oil companies, including some from France, Italy, Russia, Britain, Spain, Canada, Asia and Latin America, are said to have concluded talks with Baghdad about plans to produce and export Iraqi oil once the sanctions are lifted. The goal would be to boost Iraq's production over the next few years to five million barrels a day.
This month an oil industry newsletter published in France, Petro strategies, quoted the chief executives of the two giant French international companies, Total and Elf-Acquitaine, as confirming that they had completed talks on a project to exploit some of Iraq's largest oil reserves as soon as the sanctions were lifted.
"If an opportunity arose to sign an agreement with Baghdad before sanctions are lifted for implementation afterwards, we would do so," Serge Tchuruk, the president of Total, was quoted as saying.
To advance such talks, Baghdad is planning a major international oil conference on March 11-12. Titled "The Future of the Oil Markets -- 2000-2010," the conference is expected to attract scores of industry representatives.
Last month Iraq's Oil Minister, Safa Hadi Jawad Habubi, was quoted by the Middle East Economic Survey, an oil industry newsletter, that the talks had produced "contracts" that "will be implemented once the sanctions are removed."
The United States has steadfastly refused to consider lifting the United Nations sanctions, saying Iraq has failed to comply with resolutions passed by the Security Council during the Persian Gulf war.
Washington also cited an Iraqi troop deployment near the Kuwaiti border last fall and accused President Hussein and his associates of living in luxury while ordinary Iraqis do without staples.
The United Nations currently allows Iraq to export only about 75,000 barrels of oil a day to Jordan. Under that arrangement, money is deposited in Jordan's central bank to cover Iraqi costs for the purchase of medicine and food. Iraq is now relying on the cash from the secret oil sales to buy additional necessities, one Iraqi official said.
The sheer size of Iraq's oil reserves, second only to Saudi Arabia's, has alone been a powerful incentive for international oil companies to stay in close touch with their Iraqi counterparts over the last few years of Baghdad's isolation. Iraq's oil reserves are estimated at 100 billion barrels, roughly 10 percent of known global reserves.
Current oil production is estimated at 750,000 barrels a day. The country refines a substantial amount into gasoline, fuel oil and other derivatives, some of which are now exported.
Many of Iraq's oil fields are located in the north near Kirkuk, close to the Turkish border, and in the south at Basra, near the border with Iran. From 1991 to 1993, the Iraqis were not able to use up all the oil and resorted to injecting some back into the oil fields. The growing export trade has now eliminated that surplus, the executives said.
Oil industry executives said the rush by French companies to seal new deals with Iraq was based partly on support from the French Government, which for some time has quietly indicated in talks with other membrs of the United Nations Security Council that it favored an end to sanctions against Baghdad.
The French Government's view, communicated in several private conversations with senior oil executives here, is that only the United States and Britain emerged from the Persian Gulf war of 1991 as major trading partners with the oil powers in the region like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.
According to this view, France, Germany, Italy and other Western allies were excluded from a bonanza of contracts for the purchases of oil, weapons and commercial construction in the region at a time when they were also deprived of Iraqi business.
One Iraqi official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said privately owned companies in Iraq linked to senior officials in President Hussein's Government were also involved in the oil sales. The Government's main purpose, he said, is to obtain the hard currency needed to support the country's food rationing system, which feeds most of Iraq's 19 million people.
According to Iraqi statements, it costs anywhere from $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion a year to keep the meager rations flowing. In its first three years under the trade embargo, Baghdad was able to rely on hidden Iraqi bank accounts in other countries operated by friendly investors.
Over the past year those hidden savings began to run out, forcing Iraq to come up with new sources of revenue.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Doubts Figures
 WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Special to The New York Times) -- A Middle East expert in the State Department cast doubt on industry estimates of Iraq's oil exports today and said that international sanctions continue to make a huge dent in Iraq's oil sales.
"The figure of 200,000 barrels per day is greatly exaggerated," the expert said. He estimated that Iraq was exporting "a maximum of 100,000 barrels a day and probably less."
"We recognize there are violations, but overall the international efforts are very successful," he said.
The Iraqi delegate to the United Nations, Nizar Hamdoon, dismissed the report, saying that any border trade with Iraq or Turkey had been minimal. "It is minute, and I don't think it really amounts to anything," he said.

HEADLINE: Europeans Shrug as Taxes Go Up

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DUSSELDORF, Germany

 BODY:
Johann Scholtz sits in his white smock, hunched over his workbench 10 hours a day, stringing viola bows, repairing the necks of cellos and, when he has time, carving the maple back and front panels of his handmade violins. He says that often during his quiet labor, he remembers that more than 30 minutes of every hour go toward paying his taxes.
"I have no idea how much I pay," the 55-year-old master violin maker said. "It's so much. Only my tax accountant really knows. And the depressing thing is, my taxes are going up again this year." 
 Mr. Scholtz, who works in this German city known for its affluence and attention to style, has plenty of company. As Americans look to the new Republican-controlled Congress to cut taxes this year, taxes are going up across most of Europe.
Although European economies are expanding at a slower pace, European countries are shying away from cutting expenses because of the political dangers of threatening the quality of life. This has left little recourse but to raise taxes, despite the damping effect on economic growth.
In Spain the value-added tax, a kind of broad-based sales tax, rose one percentage point on Jan. 1, to 16 percent. Levies on electricity, gasoline, tobacco, alcohol and stamps are also rising.
Switzerland introduced a 6.5 percent value-added tax to replace a 6.3 percent sales tax on a much smaller basket of goods. The change will cost the public $1.2 billion this year.
In Sweden, the highest income-tax bracket jumps to 56 percent, from 51 percent, affecting anyone earning more than $30,000 a year. And in Britain, excise taxes on wine and spirits, gasoline and diesel fuel are rising.
In Italy, economists predict that a ballooning budget deficit is almost certain to force higher taxes.
Even in France, where a presidential election this year has discouraged politicians from increasing taxes, critics say the country's deficit is growing so rapidly that an increase after elections is inevitable.
It is not that Europeans are happy about it. Recent studies of German taxpayer sentiment found that a growing number of Germans -- known in Europe for their honesty about tax compliance -- say they are willing to cheat because they feel they are getting less for their tax dollar.
But few are willing to stage a tax revolt that might risk big changes in their system of free medical and nursing home care, nearly free college educations and generous pension and unemployment safety nets.
"As long as you have a job and pay your taxes, you are protected and don't have to worry about your future," said Paul Breuer, a former manager of Merrill Lynch's Hamburg office, who left a year ago to open Bender Antiquariat, a rare book and manuscript dealer.
"The European knows that if he gets sick he can go to a good hospital and it won't bankrupt him," said Mr. Breuer, who added that his tax rate was approaching 60 percent. "He knows his child will get a good education. He knows if his old parent gets sick or they need someone to give them a bath or take them out for a walk, they're protected.
"To Americans, these can be financially disastrous. But we don't fear them. That is why we keep paying. That is why we say, we don't like it but the taxes are necessary."
Europeans also frequently refer to lower crime rates, cleaner streets, state-of-the-art mass transportation and less social instability in general, all of which they see as products of their willingness to pay higher taxes.
While tax revenues in the United States amount to 31.6 percent of the overall economy, the proportion paid by European taxpayers is more than 45 percent.
"There is a sort of an understanding that varies from country to country," said Richard Reid, chief economist for the Frankfurt office of the Union Bank of Switzerland. '
'If your system works correctly, there is a willingness to pay taxes as long as you see what you are getting for it. In the United States, they don't have this strong association that you get tangible benefits from the taxes you pay."
If there is a country that typifies the acceptance of higher taxes, it is Germany, where the tax burden is rising almost 10 percent this year, by far the largest increase in Western Europe.
Germany's private wealth taxes are doubling, insurance taxes are rising 25 percent and a special 1 percent income tax to pay for old-age nursing care began on Jan. 1. Perhaps most controversial, a 7.5 percent tax increase, called the solidarity surcharge, will be extracted to pay for the rebuilding of the former East Germany.
And despite the new taxes already imposed this year, the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl is debating another $6.6 billion in energy taxes next year to subsidize coal mining.
In all, analysts say the tax bill for Germans will rise by $25 billion this year, when they are just recovering from the setbacks of the worst recession in Europe since World War II.
Yet many are philosophical about such taxes, particularly the solidarity surcharge.
"These are our brothers in the east and they need our help," Mr. Scholtz said. "We have to pay to let all of Germany prosper, and you can't risk the social problems of not caring for the eastern states. We can live with it."
But despite these high rates, taxes are not about to go down. The reason is that European governments are saddled with huge budget deficits coming out of the recent recession.
"There will be hardly any tax cuts in Europe through the end of the century," said Alfred Boss, economist with the Kiel Institute, an economic research group.
The European willingness to pay high taxes, compared with the frequent tax revolts that sweep the United States, also reflects a difference in the level of risks that Europeans seem to be able to stand, versus their American counterparts -- attitudes that are seen clearly in their saving and investment behavior.
For example, while Americans readily live beyond their means, taking out large home mortgages, building up credit card debt and flocking to equities that carry a relatively high risk level, Europeans are quite different.
In general, they buy homes outright with no mortgage loans. They carry very little consumer debt and only reluctantly buy stocks, preferring the assured (though lower) rates of return offered by fixed-income securities.
The explanation is simple: most of today's American taxpayers did not witness the stock market crash of 1929 or the Depression years and have not known widespread financial calamity, whereas twice this century Europeans have seen their continent destroyed by war and felt its economic reverberations for years afterward.
"There is a perception in Europe that if you live beyond your means, that is bad," Mr. Reid said. "In the United States it is more growth mentality. Here it is control of inflation and preventing big deficits."
But such reliance on Government for cradle-to-grave care has its weaknesses, economists add. Europeans are producing fewer patents and fewer entrepreneurs than the United States.
And the "good life" in Europe may in the long run be threatened by such high taxes and such generous social benefits, economists say. For example, economists say high taxes are stifling consumer spending, leaving Europe possibly vulnerable to recession again.
The Government of Sweden, long known as the most generous social welfare state, had to calm financial markets by announcing plans to slash social spending, sending a sober warning that there are limits to the European welfare state.
"I think we are now at the threshold of pain," said Matina Miksits, a salesclerk at a book store here. "Any higher and you have to ask yourself, 'Why work?' "
Indeed, there is a rising tide of resistance to higher taxes, seen in more tax evasion. Evasion is rampant and growing in most Mediterranean countries, like Italy, Greece and Spain, economists say.
Even in Germany, public sentiment is turning toward ways to avoid taxes. The German Association of Taxpayers found in a recent survey that the attitude toward tax evasion was significantly less critical than in similar surveys in 1977 and 1984.
"Germans are well on the way to losing their reputation as the most honest taxpayers in the world," said Karl Heinz Dake, the association's president. "Two-thirds of the population sees tax evasion not as criminal behavior, but merely as clever."
But no fundamental changes are seen in the near future. Despite more audible grousing, Europeans are far from revolt.
"Look at the German railroads and you can see what our tax dollar does," Mr. Scholtz said. "Look at my career. I have no fear that I will go bankrupt. I pay my taxes and know that if I have problems, the state will help."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With taxes rising in most of Europe, taxpayers are grumbling, but most are willing to pay. Johann Scholtz, seen in his violin maker's workshop in Dusseldorf, says a levy to rebuild eastern Germany is worthwhile. (Karin Hill for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Piper Jaffray to Settle Suits for $70 Million

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Piper Jaffray, the Minneapolis investment firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $70 million to settle class-action lawsuits arising from the plunge in value of one of its mutual funds.
Shares of the mutual fund, Piper's Institutional Government Income Portfolio, fell by 28 percent last year, largely because of investments in complex securities backed by home mortgages that were unusually vulnerable to last year's sharp rise in interest rates. The suits contended that Piper Jaffray had misrepresented the risks of the fund. 
 The settlement appears to be the largest bailout to date of mutual fund shareholders. Last summer, Paine Webber bought $268 million in troubled securities from one of its mutual funds, causing it to take a $34 million after-tax loss.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Piper Jaffray shares rose $1.625, to $12.75, their highest point since August, as investors concluded that the firm had put the issue behind it.
"After the settlement, the financial condition of the Piper Jaffray Companies is strong," Addison L. Piper, the firm's chairman, said yesterday. "It will have no effect on our day-to-day operations."
After legal costs, the settlement will compensate the 7,000 investors for 40 to 46 percent of their losses, Richard A. Lockridge, a lawyer representing the shareholders, said. The lawyers will ask the court to award them an $11 million fee, he said.
 The deal will become valid only if it is approved by Federal court in Minneapolis and if shareholders representing more than 90 percent of the investments agree to participate.
The settlement, which will cost Piper $42 million after taxes, represents a stiff penalty for the brokerage firm, which earned $25 million in 1994 and $41 million in 1993.
 The firm agreed to pay $20 million of the settlement when it is approved, most likely later this year, and pay the remainder in two notes carrying 8 percent interest. The company plans to pay $27 million next year when it receives its income tax refund incorporating the deduction allowed for the settlement and the remaining $23 million in equal installments over three years.
The proposed settlement is meant to end about a dozen lawsuits relating to the Institutional Government Income fund. Piper still faces suits seeking to redress losses on several other funds it managed, and it has also been sued by shareholders who contend that Piper management made misleading statements that artificially inflated the company's stock price.
Mr. Piper said that the potential cost of those suits would be much less than the settlement announced yesterday. He declined to say whether the firm was negotiating a settlement in any of those cases.
Mr. Lockridge, the lawyer, agreed that the claim of the shareholders of the Institutional Government Income fund was stronger than those of other Piper clients, because that fund was marketed as an especially low-risk investment, and it moreover violated its investment restrictions.
A suit continues against KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm that audited the Institutional Government Income fund.

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S SPENDING PLAN: REACTION;
Giuliani Cuts Raise Issue Of City's Soul

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
In explaining his painfully austere vision of municipal life this week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said it was time New York became more like other cities, scaling back its traditionally generous services to something more like an American norm. But as New Yorkers confronted his spending plan yesterday, even those who found something attractive about those cities wondered whether the price of resemblance was too high.
City residents interviewed yesterday generally agreed with the Mayor's assertion that New York had been far too profligate for too long. But they also worried that by cutting government so deeply, Mr. Giuliani may have placed in jeopardy the city's soul, the urban largesse that has defined New York and made it the world's destination. 
 "These things that he's cutting -- the hospitals, the day care, the colleges -- have made New York special," said Vincent L. Hall Jr., the manager of the Gracie Station post office on the Upper East Side and a longtime civic worker in Bushwick, Brooklyn. "These are the reasons why New York is such a diverse place and such a great place. I know we have to cut back, but I don't want us to be the same as any other city."
Some residents, fed up with what they consider the city's declining quality of life, said they were solidly behind the Mayor's austerity measures. Christine Mundt, an account executive interviewed on a mid-Manhattan street yesterday, said the city's relatively high taxes seemed to be lost on wasteful spending, rarely directed to those who need it.
"The premium doesn't go to making the quality of life in this city any better," said Ms. Mundt. "I don't think the money goes where it's supposed to go; it doesn't go to keep the quality of life high. It's never going to go forward, to advance. It's only going backward to make up for previous deficits."
But Joannene Coppinger-Borock, a resident of Whitestone, Queens, said it was not just the museums and theaters that had given New York its singular character -- it was the accumulation of small generosities, like after-school programs so that parents can work, or day-care centers, or school bus service, that continued to make the city attractive to its middle-class residents. Most of those services would be heavily cut in the spending plan the Mayor proposed on Tuesday.
"I know he thinks after-school programs are a typical New York luxury that the taxpayers have gotten used to," said Ms. Coppinger-Borock, who is industrial coordinator for the Ridgewood Local Development Corporation and who voted for the Mayor. "But these things are the backbone of life here. Without them, working families are just going to pack up and move out."
Mr. Giuliani proposed cutting next year's budget by $1.3 billion, or 4 percent, from the current year's budget, the greatest proportional reduction in spending since 1933. Most of the cuts would be in welfare, health care, schools and sanitation.
In justifying his plans to fill a $2.7 billion budget gap, the Mayor talked at great length this week about New York's historical generosity, how it has traditionally provided far more services per capita than any other American city.
"We must confront the reality that we cannot continue spending substantially more money than other American cities," he said in an address broadcast Monday night.
But few other cities have tended to their less fortunate residents in the manner of New York, and those who were once poor and remember the city's extended hand urged the Mayor not to pull it back so far.
Jerome Charyn, the novelist and author of "Metropolis: New York as Myth, Marketplace and Magical Land" (Avon, 1987), said the immigrants who shaped the city's government in the first half of this century could not have imagined such a retreat.
"To me what's made New York City so great is that it's always been a champion of the poor," said Mr. Charyn, who grew up in the Bronx in the 1930's and 40's. "I was a kid from the street and my parents had no money at all, yet I still had good teachers and was able to go to school. It was the only way the poor had a chance, and now it's completely disappearing."
That sense of compassion -- what Mr. Charyn called "a softness, a belief in the instant of goodness" -- was a byproduct of a galloping local economy that has since slowed to a walk. Most of those interviewed yesterday said they understood that the city's lofty goals had been brought low by economic pressures, and sympathized with the Mayor's need to balance the budget.
But few seemed to share his relish in doing so. "This is an exciting opportunity to manage government more efficiently," Mr. Giuliani said on Tuesday, expressing an enthusiasm for the cutbacks that found few echoes yesterday.
But Jerry Lopez, 34, who works as a salesman for a toy store on East 116th Street in East Harlem, said his main concern was for the local economy. "The people that mostly live around here, that's what's supporting them," he said, referring to public assistance. "That's how they survive." He added, "If they don't get their money, there's no business around here."
Mr. Lopez said he thought too much of the cutting was falling on the poor. "There's a lot of people that don't have nothing, and a lot of people who have a lot," he said. "And I'm concerned about the people who have nothing."
Even those who expressed a need to attack government waste wondered about the balance in the cuts. "Maybe we haven't minded our fiscal house for too long," said Catherine Volpe, a member of Community School Board 30 in northwest Queens. "But isn't there some kind of middle ground, something that doesn't handicap the city? I don't know. I'm just worried."
Many residents said yesterday that there was at once something attractive about beginning to resemble other cities -- cleaner, more orderly cities -- and something disturbing. New York may need to slough off much of its activist governmental culture for budgetary reasons, but the psychological costs may be high, they said, particularly if the city's poor are devastated.
"I've always wondered when I'm in other large cities why the streets are so much cleaner, why people don't assume the city will just clean up after them," Ms. Volpe said. "It's probably overdue that we move in that direction, but I don't want it to be so severe that it starts to really hurt people."
Even those who agreed that the budget was bloated said Mr. Giuliani was moving much too fast, trying to overhaul an entire civic culture almost overnight. Carl Clay, director of the Black Spectrum Theater in Brooklyn, said the city might need to lose weight, but did not require the crash diet prescribed by the Mayor.
"We all know one of the basic principles of dieting is, you have to do it gradually," said Mr. Clay. "If you speed up that process, if you try to wean yourself too fast off something you've had for a long time, you will die. And that's what could happen to this city."

HEADLINE: A Default Worsens Mexico Ills

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Two weeks after the announcement of more than $50 billion in international loans to rescue the Mexican economy, a new wave of investor concern swept the markets here today as a tourism and construction conglomerate became the first big Mexican company to default on its debt since the financial crisis began.
Dragged down by a plunge of nearly 24 percent in the price of shares of the conglomerate, Grupo Sidek, values on the Mexican stock exchange plunged 123 points, or 6.41 percent. The market index fell to 1,798, its lowest level in 17 months. 
 With fears growing that even the huge-scale rescue plan might not be sufficient to pull the Mexican financial system out of its 10-week slide, annual interest rates on 28-day Mexican treasury bills shot up to 40 percent today.
The peso also fell -- to 5.965 to the dollar, its weakest since the loan package assembled by the Clinton Administration was announced on Jan. 31. The peso is now worth 16.76 cents, compared with 28.90 cents before devaluation eight weeks ago.
"What we had all hoped for is that investors would be so reassured by the existence of the $50 billion package that they wouldn't change their peso-denominated holdings into dollars," said Lawrence D. Krohn, senior economist for Latin America at UBS Securities. "That hasn't happened because there is deep anxiety about Mexico's ability to right itself quickly enough."
Mexican officials acknowledged that they were still bargaining with United States Treasury officials over terms for the $20 billion in American loans that form the cornerstone of the package. In particular, they said, the Americans had questions about the monetary policies Mexico proposed as part of a new economic-recovery plan.
Mexico has also hit some bumps in its negotiations with commercial and investment banks over the smaller loans those institutions agreed to contribute to the $50 billion, American bankers and Mexican officials said.
With Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz and Mr. Zedillo's chief of staff, Luis Tellez, expected to travel to Washington on Thursday for talks, Mexican officials said they hoped that a final loan agreement could still be reached by early next week.
But even some Mexican officials said they were worried that their Government had yet to outline the new policies. And market analysts said Grupo Sidek's failure to meet a $19.5 million debt payment today would only heighten the skepticism with which with a new plan was eventually received.
"The actual amount is not really that important," said Eduardo M. Cabrera, a Latin American analyst at Merrill Lynch. "The question is how many more corporations are going to miss their payments. What will the impact be on the banking system? Things are going to get worse before they get better."
Many Mexican companies have been squeezed badly by the 42 percent fall in the peso's value against the dollar since the Government devalued the currency on Dec. 20, and it came as little surprise that a company like Grupo Sidek would be the first to withhold debt payments.
The Sidek subsidiary that owed most of the money, a resort and real estate-development concern called Grupo Situr, has about $100 million in commercial paper maturing over the next two months and nearly $1 billion in total dollar-denominated debt. At the end of January, Duff & Phelps estimated the company's cash assets at $60 million.
In a statement released today, the company insisted that it had enough cash on hand to have met its obligations, but chose to use the money instead to finance continuing operations. It defaulted on commercial paper, the unsecured debt that companies use to cover daily expenses.
Mexican and foreign investors sent Grupo Sidek's stock price reeling, down 23.8 percent on the Mexico City exchange, and Situr's down 22.4 percent. Shares of the big Mexican bank and brokerage firm, Banacci, which is believed to own 16 percent of Sidek, fell by 14.3 percent.
Other industrial companies with large debts were also hit hard. Shares of Cemex fell 7.8 percent, while those of the steel company Hylsa dropped 10.4 percent.
Other Mexican stocks were battered by everything from confusion about Mr. Zedillo's abrupt halt of an army offensive in Chiapas state to rumors that the president of the nation's central bank, Miguel Mancera Aguayo, would resign.
Stock indexes tumbled elsewhere in Latin America today, too -- sharply in Argentina and Brazil, modestly in Chile, Venezuela and Peru.
Financial analysts attributed the selling of pesos by foreign investors, in particular, to deeper fears.
Although the markets seemed to understand that Mr. Zedillo has been busy -- the last week has brought troubles ranging from the Chiapas offensive to the governing party's biggest defeat ever in an election in the western state of Jalisco -- analysts said there was growing concern that Mexico could use up its new loans and loan guarantees without stabilizing the economy.
The Government has already drawn down $7.8 billion in credits from the International Monetary Fund, and Mexican brokers said the central bank spent heavily today to keep the peso's exchange rate from dropping below 6 to the dollar.
Mexican and American officials said their two countries' talks were focusing in part on Mexico's plan to limit the growth of its money supply, in line with the levels of its foreign-exchange reserves. One American official insisted that the talks were "moving along."
"There are going to be important conditions," the official said in a telephone interview from Washington. "There is going to be central bank transparency, and central bank policies that will prevent any recurrence of the mistakes of last year."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S SPENDING PLAY: CUNY;
Chancellor Says Pataki Cuts Will Raise Tuition and Force Layoffs of 1,000 Professors

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
The City University of New York will have to raise tuition by $1,000 a student and lay off more than 1,000 full-time professors, a quarter of the full-time force, if the state budget cuts proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki are enacted, CUNY Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds intends to tell Albany legislators at a budget hearing today.
Faculty leaders and educators say the system faces the worst financial crisis since the city's fiscal crisis 20 years ago, when the City University was forced to start charging tuition. The layoffs would be the first since 1992, when two dozen people were dismissed because of budget problems. 
 Last month, Governor Pataki's executive budget -- the first step in a long and tortuous budgetary process -- called for cutting $162 million from the CUNY budget, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's budget calls for an additional $40 million in cuts.
The senior, or four-year colleges, of the City University get most of their revenue from the state, while the community colleges get most of their money from the city.
Chancellor Reynolds immediately instructed the 18 City University presidents to prepare plans for the cutbacks that would be necessary if the Governor's proposal was enacted. Her testimony today, before the Senate Finance Committee and Assembly Ways and Means Committee, is based on the plans submitted by the presidents. She plans to ask the Legislature to restore funding for the schools to avoid these cuts.
When informed of Chancellor Reynolds's prepared testimony, Sandi Cooper, chairwoman of the University Faculty Senate, said: "If these cuts are made, we're going to have to find another name for this place. We couldn't call it a university. Maybe we'd call it a holding pen."
She added that the present situation is "infinitely worse" than any fiscal crisis of the past "because we don't have a state government with the moral and social will to support public higher education."
If tuition at the senior colleges -- presently $2,450 -- were raised to $3,450, it would be a 41 percent increase and the single highest one-year jump in the university's history.
Ms. Reynolds is to say that layoffs in the university's 12 senior colleges would total 928 full-time faculty and 1,500 adjuncts. Together they teach more than 10,000 class sections, or a fifth of the total, and they would be canceled.
Also, 736 non-teaching personnel would be dismissed, and a $9.6 million reduction would cut into library books and other instruictional equipment.
The City University's six community colleges would suffer a $10.6 million loss from the state on top of the proposed $28 million reduction in city funds, Chancellor Reynolds's statement declares.
The result would be the elimination of 501 full-time positions, 286 of them teachers and the rest support staff. Also, 2,574 class sections would be canceled.
The budget for adjunct professors would be cut by 16 percent, resulting in the cancellation of 1,800 class sections. Finally, 450 part-time positions in support services would be dropped.
Noting CUNY's contribution to the New York economy, Chancellor Reynolds's statement quotes Samuel Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, who recently said: "It would be difficult to overestimate the importance of CUNY in supplying New York's most important ingredient: a skilled labor force."
Chancellor Reynolds's report also expresses dismay over the projected elimination of the Search for Education, Elevation and Knowledge program which dates back to 1969.
The program provides intense remedial work, tutoring and counseling for promising students who are also economically and educationally disadvantaged. A similar program at the community colleges, called the College Discovery Program, also stands to be eliminated under the Governor's proposed budget.
The Chancellor's testimony appeals for the restoration of financial aid programs such as the Aid to Part Time Students, which is completely eliminated in the Governor's budget proposal; the Tuition Assistance Program, which is earmarked for a significant cut, and the Graduate Tuition Assistance Program, which is scheduled for complete elimination.
Asked if the cuts and consolidations specified in the Academic Program Planning Initiative adopted by the CUNY trustees in 1993 would lessen the impact of the cuts, Jay Hershenson, vice chancellor for university relations, said:
"It puts the university in a better position because the planning process preceded this request, but at the same time the magnitude of the proposed cuts has caused the university to seek assistance from the legislature."

HEADLINE: Serbia Has Earned No Reward

 BODY:
The five-power negotiating group on Bosnia, which includes the United States, is offering to suspend all remaining United Nations economic sanctions on Serbia. In return, it asks Belgrade to recognize the independence of Bosnia and Croatia and cut off supplies to rebel Serbian armies in both countries.
That might be a reasonable proposal if Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, had a record of honoring his commitments, or if the five-power group had a record of insisting on compliance with its deals. Neither is true. 
 The Clinton Administration, which portrays itself as a reluctant partner in Europe's pro-Serb strategy, should have rejected this latest diplomatic charade. The new humiliations it courts can only strengthen the hand of Senate critics like Bob Dole, the majority leader, who are already pushing Washington to ditch its European allies and independently lift the arms embargo on Bosnia.
The latest offer to Belgrade comes as evidence mounts that Serbia has not lived up to the last deal it made with the five powers, whose other members are France, Britain, Germany and Russia. Last year Mr. Milosevic pledged to stop supplying the Bosnian Serbs in exchange for a partial lifting of U.N. sanctions against Serbia. Recently Serbian helicopters have been brazenly flying supplies across the supposedly sealed border. Yet instead of reimposing the lifted sanctions there is an offer to suspend those that remain. The sanctions lifted last year were symbolic. Those now being discussed affect Serbia's ability to wage protracted war.
Washington's motive in going along with the five-power plan was apparently fear that Croatia would expel U.N. forces from its territory, perhaps triggering a wider war. Serbian recognition of Croatian independence, in theory, might allow the U.N. troops to stay. It is a worthy, if elusive, objective, but the price is too high.
Bribing Mr. Milosevic to make peace was never the Clinton Administration's preferred policy. Washington long and correctly argued that the world should let Bosnia defend itself by lifting the unfair arms embargo that tilts the battlefield balance toward the Serbs. Regrettably, the Administration has all but dropped its efforts on the arms embargo in the name of NATO unity.
Instead of strengthening NATO, the Administration's passivity toward Europe has weakened it. American lawmakers are becoming disenchanted with an alliance in which American dollars and troops are welcome, but American ideas are not.
Washington needs to reconsider this latest proposal to court the Serbs. Instead it should start pressing its allies to move together toward lifting the Bosnian arms embargo before the Senate forces separate American action. The time to talk about lifting more sanctions on Serbia will come when Serbia starts honoring its commitments.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Essay;
Iraq's Threat: Biological Warfare

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
With Iraq's nuclear and poison-gas production capability limited by the scrutiny of U.N. inspectors, Saddam Hussein is developing the means to produce a terror weapon much harder to find: the deadly micro-organisms of biological warfare.
Thirty quarts of cultures of cholera, tuberculosis and plague bacteria were discovered in the past few months. At the Sepp Institute in Methana, in underground storage at the Ghazi Research Institute in Amiria, at Salman-Pak and Al-Hakem, the necessary fermentors, lyophilizers for freeze-drying and centrifuges for separation of bacteria are in place. 
 Hundreds of biologists are kept on Iraq's payroll awaiting orders from a woman named Rihab Rashid Taha al-Azawi. Dr. Taha, 42, trained in toxicology in Britain, is known to some Iraqis as "Dr. Germs."
Though Western intelligence agencies knew Dr. Taha to be the developer of Saddam's botulinum toxin stockpile in the 80's, she now pretends to be developing innocent vaccines. Under this cover, she regularly seeks to mislead four members of the U.N. Special Commission (UNSCOM) investigating germ warfare.
Ambassador Rolf Ekeus of Sweden, who heads the commission, is frustrated by the foot-dragging, belated admissions about sites and deliberate withholding of facts about experiments on animals that typifies the stonewalling of Dr. Taha and her toxic colleagues.
"It's like '1001 Nights,' " he told me at his U.N. office in New York before flying to Baghdad today. "We say, 'Do you have cages for monkeys?' They say, 'No, never any experiments on primates.' We say, 'What about these cages, with animal hair?' They say, 'Oh, those cages -- we planned to use them for medical research.' Their story changes every night. They admit only what we can prove."
Sources inside Iraq say that hidden equipment for the growth of anthrax, botulinum toxin and pasteurella, causative agent of the plague, includes 50-liter fermentors and sterile mixing tanks made by the Italian company Olsa and 150-liter fermentors supplied in the 80's by the Swiss company Chemak. Because anthrax spores resist re-entry heat, those are the germs of choice for use in missile warheads.
Such terror-war seems too horrible to contemplate. But Saddam readily reintroduced poison gas in the 80's, raining death on 5,000 Kurds in Halabja (and Ambassador Ekeus was one of the few diplomats to denounce that at the time). Rod Barton, the Australian who heads UNSCOM's bio-warfare section, notes that Russia only recently admitted that the 1979 outbreak of anthrax in Sverdlovsk was caused by an accident at a bio-war plant at which more than 100 workers died.
Reluctant to confirm specifics about sites, Mr. Ekeus states unequivocally: "We face our greatest problems in accounting for Iraq's past and present biological program." Dr. Taha insists her past military-financed research was purely to protect against disease, but the UNSCOM report of two months ago concluded: "the indications all point to an offensive program."
The U.N. commission thinks the Iraqis are not now producing germs for delivery, but is certain Saddam has the equipment, material and expertise on hand to begin production of biological warfare agents as soon as inspectors are thrown out. The facility in Dura now innocently producing hoof-and-mouth vaccines is set up for immediate changeover to bio-war production.
With such a capability at hand; with the will to use terror-weaponry already demonstrated by Saddam; with the means of production and delivery awaiting only oil income and a few months' secrecy -- is this the moment to suspend the world's economic sanctions on Iraq?
France, Russia and China, eager for business, think so. The U.S. and Britain think not. Germany wavers.
To encourage Iraq to let his team stay, Mr. Ekeus's April report may cite some progress in inspections. A drumbeat of stories will follow about how poor Iraqis are suffering from the denial of oil income.
Don't fall for it. If the world lets heavy money flow to Baghdad while Saddam rules, at least one weapon of mass destruction will soon be in the hands of a proven killer. He would delight in being the first to use it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rise After Early Selling Is Reversed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities advanced yesterday for the second consecutive day after a batch of Government reports that first raised, than eased investor concerns about economic growth and inflation.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond increased 15/32 , to 10027/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.55 percent, from 7.59 percent on Tuesday, but up 2 basis points from its low for the day. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. 
 Traders said early selling was prompted by Government data that showed inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index was up three-tenths of 1 percent in January, and up four-tenths of 1 percent excluding volatile food and energy prices. Economists had expected an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent for both the index and the so-called core number.
But the early selling was reversed after a report by the Federal Reserve showed a smaller-than-expected increase in the operation of plants, mines and utilities. The data eased concerns that the economy's momentum would cause inflation to rise and compel the Fed to raise interest rates in March.
The report showed plant use rose to 85.5 percent, instead of the expected 85.6 percent, from 85.4 percent in December. Economists usually associate increases in plant-use rates with bottlenecks that prompt suppliers to charge higher prices.
Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, said, "January data showed that the consumer price inflation rate is edging higher, but no more than is already built into bond market expectations."
He noted that the industrial production data showed some moderation in manufacturing growth, especially when combined with recent weakness in several industrial commodity prices. "These data, taken together with weakness in the Tuesday's retail sales report lead me to believe there is little chance that the Fed will move rates up again at its meeting next month," Mr. Hoffman said. "A move up in rates at the May Fed meeting is still probable, but even then the odds may have diminished just a little in light of these recent reports."
Traders said the market's strong rally was thwarted by comments yesterday from the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan. Speaking before a meeting of the Independent Bankers Association in Hawaii, he said, "U.S growth must slow if inflation is to be avoided," adding that the country was "close to price stability, but not there yet." According to traders, the market took that to mean that the Fed was not finished raising interest rates.
The Treasury announced yesterday that it planned to sell $28.25 billion of new two-year and five-year notes next week.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's note sales, dealers were offering the notes at prices to yield 7.12 percent for a two-year note, and 7.35 percent for a five-year note.
Municipal bond yields dropped once again even as ratings on the District of Columbia's bonds were lowered to junk-bond status by Moody's Investors Service, from Baa to Ba for uninsured general obligation debt. Yesterday, Standard & Poor's lowered the District's ratings to one notch above junk, from A- to triple-B-.
The jump in prices renewed concerns that the demand for tax-exempt securities would increase, making it harder to find bonds later this year. About 32 percent fewer bonds are scheduled to be sold in the next 30 days than were scheduled last year during the same period. According to the Bond Buyer, there are $2.13 billion in bonds scheduled for sale.

HEADLINE: What Readiness to Fight Two Wars Means

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Two-War Fantasy" (editorial, Feb. 5) suggests that the United States would never face two major regional conflicts at once. In fact, twice last year President Clinton was prepared to commit troops against well-armed adversaries to protect foreign policy goals. 
 In June, North Korea was on the verge of producing enough plutonium to make up to five nuclear weapons. We were ready to seek economic sanctions against North Korea, something Pyongyang said it would consider an act of war. As a result, we were also preparing for a substantial military buildup in South Korea, where we already have 37,000 troops. Fortunately, North Korea agreed to negotiations that ultimately led to an agreement to halt its current nuclear program. The crisis ended without conflict.
United States security interests faced another threat in October, when elite Iraqi divisions suddenly started moving toward Kuwait. We feared another invasion and quickly mobilized significant ground, air and naval forces to repel Iraq. In the face of our resolve, Saddam Hussein withdrew.
In both cases deterrence worked because the United States had a ready force and was prepared to use it. But consider what might have happened if deterrence had not worked in North Korea. At the very least we would have been engaged in a tense standoff with a country that has a well-trained and forward-deployed army of 1.1 million men. At worst, we could have faced a war requiring a major commitment of force.
And what if Saddam Hussein, seeing that we were occupied in North Korea, had chosen this moment to launch a new attack against Kuwait?
The United States strategy to maintain a force that can fight two nearly simultaneous major regional conflicts is designed to prevent just this type of adventurism.
You quote me as saying that the prospect of fighting two wars is "entirely implausible." The two words that you surgically lifted from my testimony to Congress distorted my point: fighting two wars is implausible precisely because we have the capability to respond to two challenges at once. If we only had the capability for one major conflict, our weakness could invite a second conflict, thereby making plausible what would otherwise be an implausible scenario.
 
WILLIAM J. PERRY
Secretary of Defense
Washington, Feb. 10, 1995

HEADLINE: Let's Just Look at Who Wants U.S. Leadership

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Look Who Wants U.S. as a Leader" (Week in Review, Feb. 12): 
 It is not "India" or "Indonesia" or "Sri Lanka" that wants the United States to lead the world, but increasingly desperate governments that have risked their political fortunes on International Monetary Fund-styled liberalizations that are not reaping the promised economic results who now turn to the promoter of the I.M.F. to help them face their own unhappy populations. If the crisis with the Mexican regime has not taught us that, nothing will.
The people who live in India are frustrated and angry with their Government's concern for the well-being of multinational corporations, rather than for the well-being of its citizens. In the last elections in four states, the ruling party was mauled. Protests in Bangalore two years ago resulted in the departure of Cargill, one of the agribusiness companies whose policies worked in opposition to the interests of Indian farmers.
These farmers are not asking the United States to lead the world. United States leadership has resulted in the production of I.M.F.-induced economic basket cases (Eastern Europe, Mexico, Pakistan). That sort of leadership is not in the interests of working people anywhere.
Indian intellectuals are still worried that an unfettered Uncle Sam will be telling the world what to do. But what worries us is that the orders are now being given through public agencies that are not accountable to anyone.
Democracy is founded on accountability: no one voted the United States to be the world's policeman or the I.M.F. to run the world's economy. Let us first mend our own cities before we tell the rest of the world what to do.
 
VIJAY PRASHAD
Asst. Prof. of History, Cornell U.
Ithaca, N.Y., Feb. 14, 1995
