HEADLINE: Index Shows A Slight Rise For Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
A whiff of inflation hit consumers in January just as the industrial economy was clearly starting to slow down from its breakneck 1994 pace, Government reports showed today.
Consumer prices climbed three-tenths of 1 percent, the most since summer, as housing costs accelerated, and clothing, air fares and home furnishings turned up after prolonged declines. 
 Ignoring the erratic food and energy components, the price index rose an even faster four-tenths of 1 percent. Nevertheless, economists remained calm, and securities traders paid more attention to a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in industrial production for January that confirmed a welcome letup in the economic growth.
After an initial setback, the bond market advanced and helped propel the stock market, as gauged by the Dow Jones industrial average, to a record, flirting with the 4,000 mark.
"Inflation should start ticking up modestly, but I don't see any major rise," said Mickey D. Levy, chief financial economist at Nationsbank in New York. He described the economy as having begun a classic slowdown, with housing and retail sales already softening.
For months, price pressures have been building at various stages of the production process, and it has been widely assumed that at least some of this would eventually reach consumers at the end of the pipeline, despite a yearlong drive by the Federal Reserve to head off an inflationary surge.
Analysts were reassured today not only by a halving of industrial output growth from the November and December pace, but also by a negligible one-tenth of a point rise in the operating rates of both factories and American industry as a whole, suggesting that capacity is not being strained unduly.
Still, the rise in the so-called core inflation was the most for a single month since October 1992, and it remains possible, analysts said, that the Consumer Price Index will rise this year by more than the half-point that is widely projected -- to about 3 1/4 percent from 2 3/4 percent.
The Labor Department introduced some new methodology in calculating the January index, but this had no noticeable effect, officials said. The change was not directly related to the recent contention by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that the index overstates inflation by as much as 1 1/2 points.
The report also showed steep price increases for all five of the metropolitan areas for which January changes were published today. These jumps, which are not adjusted for recurring seasonal patterns, were six-tenths of 1 percent for New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, eight-tenths of 1 percent for Philadelphia and nine-tenths of 1 percent for Chicago. Shelter and apparel were particularly important factors in the New York rise.
Nationally, it was the housing component, which accounts for 41 percent of the index, that had the biggest impact; it rose four-tenths of 1 percent following no change in December. Rents, utilities, maintenance and repairs, cable television and local telephone charges all climbed, and the 10.3 percent rise in postage rates -- part of household operations -- was also included here.
Apparel prices surged seven-tenths of 1 percent after falling for three straight months, reflecting earlier-than-usual discounting of cold-weather clothing, which meant smaller discounts in January, the department said.
Much of a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in transportation charges last month was from a 2.2 percent jump in airline fares after four straight declines at the end of 1994 totaling 10.8 percent.
But in an unusual action for a trade group, the Air Transport Association challenged the department's calculation, insisting in a letter to Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, that fares fell by about 8 percent, according to its quick calculation.
"You'd have a hard time convincing me that my prices are up," said David A. Swierenga, the chief economist of the association.
In response, Patrick C. Jackman, a department official who supervises the Consumer Price Index, said the difference could not represent either seasonal factors or an inadequate survey and speculated that the association was making an annual rather than a monthly comparison.
Another jump in automobile finance charges, 4 percent in January, and a 2.6 percent rise in used-car prices also lifted the price index.
Services, which make up about 57 percent of the index, jumped five-tenths of 1 percent last month, while commodities, at 43 percent, edged up one-tenth of 1 percent.
The Federal Reserve's production report showed that the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 85.5 percent of capacity last month, up one-tenth of a point, another 15-year high.
The rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in output compared with increases revised today to eight-tenths of 1 percent and nine-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, for November and December.
Output growth at factories, with a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent, slowed even more as nondurables actually posted a small decline.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Getting credit for deficit-cutting, or the onus for not doing it.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON'S 1996 budget, disclosed last week to a chorus of sighs and worse, seems destined to be the least-read best seller since "The Bell Curve."
But before all 1,100 pages are erased from the nation's memory banks, they are surely worth one quick look. For while this budget has been dismissed as a political place marker, it is also the opening gambit in what promises to be a battle over who gets credit for cutting the deficit -- or, more likely, the onus for not cutting it. 
 The President's arithmetic offers a little something for everyone. It would consolidate hundreds of programs with weak constituencies and would reduce the Federal payroll by 170,000. The resulting savings (plus modest spending cuts in future years) would allow a small tax reduction for the middle-income Americans without increasing the deficit or clipping a penny from retirees' pension and medical benefits.
What could be wrong with that? The standard political answer is that it imitates the opposition's promises rather than trumping them. After all, Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, is proposing bigger tax cuts, bigger spending cuts and -- miracle of miracles -- a balanced budget by 2002. In the words of Robert D. Reischauer, the departing director of the Congressional Budget Office, the Administration's budget is merely "Republican lite."
Barry P. Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution and former adviser to President Jimmy Carter, sees deeper flaws. For one thing, some $80 billion of the $144 billion in spending reductions would come from unspecified cuts in "discretionary" outlays. Mr. Clinton, it seems, wants frugality much the way St. Augustine wanted chastity: not now.
More important, Mr. Bosworth suggests, the President's bean counters are falling back on the sort of creative accounting that served Ronald Reagan so well. The most obvious examples are projections of faster growth of overall output and slower growth in medical costs. The differences, roughly three-tenths of 1 percent a year in the gross domestic product and 1 percent in Medicare, seem modest enough. But they go a long way toward explaining why the Clinton deficit is some $40 billion smaller than the budget office's estimate by the year 2000.
Less obvious -- and therefore more objectionable, in Mr. Bosworth's view -- is that the President's budget plays games with inflation. The Government keeps tracks of several different indicators of changing prices, among them the Consumer Price Index and the broader, but less familiar, G.D.P. deflator. Both are conceptually flawed and both are being revised. What irritates Mr. Bosworth is that the Administration has chosen to use the revisions selectively to reduce deficit projections.
In 1994 the Consumer Price Index rose a half a percentage point more than the G.D.P. deflator, a gap that the budget office assumes will widen to six-tenths of 1 percent in 2000. By contrast, the White House assumes the difference will narrow to just one-tenth of 1 percent in 2000.
What's the big deal? A lower Consumer Price Index tends to reduce the deficit because it reduces increases in entitlement spending and reduces the rate of adjustment of income tax brackets. By the same token, a higher G.D.P. deflator generates more revenue. Put them together -- as the Administration has -- and the deficit shrinks by tens of billions between now and 2000.
Such criticism may seem like carping. Mr. Clinton, after all, is the first President to reverse the trend toward rising deficits that began with Ronald Reagan, and his Administration will certainly remain ahead of the deficit curve during his four-year term. At very least, the harsh words are ironic: many Americans learned of Mr. Clinton's achievements in the first two years of his Presidency only because he has been so fiercely criticized for abandoning the goal of further reductions in the third and fourth.
What's more, it ignores the reality that Democrats have been more conservative on deficit issues than Republicans, but the Republicans have won the public relations battle as the party of fiscal responsibility. President Clinton has apparently decided to stick the opposition with the blame for cutting spending, since they are likely to get the credit for any deficit reduction.
The catch: With military, Social Security and tax increases off the table, Mr. Bosworth reckons Congress will have to find $400 billion in cuts from roughly $1 trillion in spending in order to balance the budget by 2002. If neither party will play fall guy, then the prospect of eliminating the deficit is more remote than ever. The best hope, at least from the public's perspective, is that the politics of deficit reduction change radically once the consequences of ignoring entitlement spending are more widely understood. Nobody in Washington, however, seems to be thinking that far ahead.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Despite a Rally in Stocks, Dollar's Advance Is Fitful

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished little changed yesterday, as traders focused on Mexico's financial woes and shrugged off a rally in American stocks.
In late New York trading, the dollar edged down to 1.5090 German marks, from 1.5091 marks on Tuesday, but inched up to 1.2755 Swiss francs from 1.2740 francs. The dollar also slipped against the Japanese yen, to 98.33 yen from 98.50 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5611 from $1.5623. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average surged yesterday, at one time less than 3 points shy of 4,000, after the Federal Reserve reported a downturn in United States manufacturing activity last month. Gains in American stocks tend to support the dollar.
But the positive effects of the stock market rally were offset by a turn for the worse in Mexico's troubled economy.
"We ended up trading the dollar sideways today," said Bob Near, a vice president at the Bank of New York. "There are forces pulling both ways. It's a bit of a standoff."
The peso weakened sharply, closing at 5.965 pesos to the dollar, compared with 5.845 peos on Tuesday, after a poor auction of Mexican Treasury bills showed a continued lack of foreign investor confidence in the country's financial markets.
Because of the United States' close trade and investment ties to the southern neighbor, many investors in recent months have come to view Mexico's financial crisis as trouble for the American economy. "The dollar is guilty by association in the eyes of foreign investors," said Carol Stone, senior economist for Nomura Securities in New York.
In other currency trading, the German mark advanced broadly, briefly setting a record high against the Italian lira, on prospects for an interest rate increase in Germany. Higher rates raise returns on deposits and short-term assets and tend to bring investment flows into a currency.
The IG Metall metalworkers' union has been ordering a series of three-hour strikes to support demands of pay increases of 5.5 to 6 percent. Currency dealers speculate that if German employers accede to the powerful industrial union's demands, the central bank may feel compelled to raise interest rates.
"That's being seen as bullish for the mark, since it would pull funds into Germany," said Belal Khan, senior currency dealer at the Bank of Tokyo Ltd.'s office in New York. "The mark is being bought, and the dollar isn't the currency of choice at this time."

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Falls

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus plunged more than 50 percent in January, and analysts said today that the gap would probably continue to shrink as reconstruction after the Kobe earthquake last month drew in imports.
The trade surplus fell to $2.88 billion in January from $6.03 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier. But the surplus with the United States rose to $3.19 billion, from $3.09 billion a year earlier. 
 Economists said the earthquake that struck the city of Kobe on Jan. 17 was likely to push imports higher on new demand for materials used in the reconstruction.
Japan's overall exports in yen terms shrank by 6.1 percent in January from a year earlier, mostly because of damage to Kobe's port operations, an official at the Ministry of Finance said.
Though imports were also affected by the damage to Kobe, those cargoes were able to be quickly moved through other ports like Tokyo, Yokohama and Osaka, helping to minimize the effect on Japan's overall imports, the official said.
Exports rose 4.9 percent in January from a year earlier, to $27.24 billion, and imports rose 22.2 percent, to $24.36 billion.
Economists said exports were also affected by slowdowns and temporary stoppages at some factories after the earthquake because of shortages of parts.

HEADLINE: The Once And Future Brush

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN 

 BODY:
THE rendezvous site was perfect: the men's room at the Paramount Hotel on West 46th Street.
Finally, the two would meet again face to face: Philippe Starck, the French superstar designer, and Alan J. Heller, an American housewares manufacturer. 
 For two years the pair had been jousting by telephone and fax over a joint venture: the design and manufacture of a high-profile (and economically priced) toilet brush. Now it was time to review the final prototype.
"It was a product I wanted to do for 20 years," said Mr. Starck, 46, the famed designer of toothbrushes and ashtrays, restaurants, hotel interiors and furniture (some of which have adorned the presidential rooms of Elysee Palace in Paris). "I've always thought it would be the apotheosis of my career," he said.
Seriously.
"I've always said that I was always interested in the human being who uses the object," he added. "To design a toilet brush would be the most humble service I could give."
Mr. Starck designed the interiors of the Paramount, including the striking conical stainless steel sinks and jazzy multicolor ceramic tile in the men's and ladies' rooms. "My bathrooms are always an important moment, because they are a way to show respect to those who some call consumers, but I call friends," said Mr. Starck, who on occasion enjoys taking the high ground.
He said it had taken him about two years to come up with the idea that would justify putting yet another toilet brush on the market (at least a couple of dozen already exist). And, he said, it would take a special one to appeal to Americans who are "obsessed by cleanliness." The result: a sleek, totemic two-part plastic design that has a sword's handle and ends in a round tufted brush that fits neatly into its scabbard.
"It's an object that protects the hand, like the guard on a sword, but that also retains a certain elegance," Mr. Starck said.
Like many of his other designs, his toilet brush has a memorable name: Excalibur -- after King Arthur's sword, of course. And it will come in a panoply of pastel shades -- pale yellow, pink, green and gray -- but not basic bathroom white, because, Mr. Starck said, that would make it invisible. "It's an object that must be present but remain discreet," he said.
Excalibur has already made an appearance in France in the hefty 3 Suisses spring-summer 1995 mail-order catalogue, alongside Mr. Starck's small Miss Sissi table lamp and his Oye Oye portable radio and Ray Hollis ashtray.
In turning his talents on the toilet brush and holder, Mr. Starck is in the tradition of architects' and designers' rethinking ordinary objects. Remember Michael Graves's 1985 tea kettle? Or Morison Cousins's newfangled Tupperware? Or even last year's star toilet brush? That one was designed for Alessi by Stefano Giovannoni, a designer in Florence. Metropolis, a design magazine, called the zany plastic cactus-in-a-pot "a toilet brush with greatness."
Jack Markuse, Alessi's American importer, said people don't usually show off their toilet brushes. "But this one is not content to remain in that corner," he said.
Maybe that's because most people don't know what it is. "If you had a glass wall in your bathroom, I'm guessing that you would see people lifting the brush out and looking at it, the same way they sneak a look into the medicine cabinet," Mr. Markuse said.
While Alessi has sold over 100,000 of the toilet brushes worldwide since it was introduced in 1993, only 5,000 have made it into bathrooms in the United States.
While Mr. Starck was putting the finishing touches on his new design, Mr. Heller, 54, was developing the new technology necessary to produce it at a low enough price. Mr. Heller said he spent more than $100,000 developing special molds.
Mr. Heller, who has also produced plastic dinnerware by Massimo and Lella Vignelli, saw the brush as a way of "going back to my roots when I started manufacturing plastic dinnerware in Italy 20 years ago."
The Starck brush, which will make its debut at the Frankfurt Fair this weekend, is to retail for under $30 when it is available in the United States, at the end of April -- the list of stores has yet to be fixed. "I see it as a sort of Swatch of home furnishings," Mr. Heller said.
But unlike the Swatch, which was suddenly everywhere, Excalibur might prove to be a hard sell in the United States. In Europe, a brush is standard equipment next to every toilet, but in the United States, it is less likely to be on view unless it is a decorative accessory.
But not for lack of choice. From supermarkets to the MOMA Design Store, there are plenty to choose from, including ones that fit into holders shaped like dogs and cats. Gracious Home, the Upper East Side housewares store, carries about 10 different styles, including one trimmed in gold and another of bone china. Philip Choo, the visual merchandise director, says the store sells about 200 toilet brushes a month.
At Ikea, the home furnishings supermarket chain, toilet brushes are considered a major impulse purchase and are displayed accordingly: next to the cash registers.
But at ABC Carpet and Home, where you can find almost anything else you can think of, there is nary a brush in sight. "We actively don't sell them," said Loren Pack, a company spokeswoman, "even though people are always telling us we could make so much money with them."
Designer or no designer, some things may be just too humdrum to display.

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD;
A Week Without TV

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
WHAT would Americans do without television?
TV-Free America, a newly established national organization, wants Americans to switch off their sets for a week and find out for themselves. 
 The organization, which seeks to raise awareness about the harmful effects of excessive viewing on productivity and literacy, for example, and encourages Americans to watch less television, is sponsoring National TV-Turnoff Week, April 24 to 30.
And what does it suggest people do without Oprah, the Power Rangers and the N.B.A. games of the week?
"We're recommending 40 suggested substitute activities," said Henry Labalme, the codirector of the Washington organization, which is financed through grants and private donations. They include "contemplating, interacting with family, playing sports, taking part in community affairs and volunteering."
"Americans collectively watch 120 billion hours of television a year. This is an enormous productivity sink," added Mr. Labalme, 33, who is single and doesn't own a television set.
On the average, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company, preschoolers watch 30 hours of television a week. Experts in child development and behavior suggest that more than 10 hours a week canhave a detrimental effect on children's attention spans, language and communications skills and creative abilities.
Television turnoffs have been held in individual towns and counties around the country since the early 1980's. The most successful was a monthlong turnoff held in Farmington, Conn., in January 1984, when a quarter of the residents either didn't watch or watched less. Follow-up surveys indicate that most participants reduced their viewing or became more critical of what they watched.
TV-Free America's effort marks the first time the entire nation has been asked to pull the plug. The crusade has been endorsed by groups like the American Federation of Teachers, the American Medical Association, Literacy Volunteers of America, the National Parenting Association and The Weekly Reader magazine, whose Feb. 17 cover story promotes the idea. Thousands of schools, libraries, churches and community organizations will also join in an effort to encourage families and individuals to turn off their sets.
Broadcasters and, for the most part, major advertisers have turned away from the turnoff which, if successful, could become a ratings nightmare.
Winston H. Cox, the chairman and chief executive of the Showtime Cable network, was ambivalent. "I'm in favor of the broad objective here, that being children watch too much television and parents need to take a role in controlling that," Mr. Cox said. "But there is a lot of good TV out there. We tend to demean television in our country. But it is also an incredibly powerful and important information medium."
Mr. Labalme agreed. "Good programs do exist," he said recently. But, he added, "it's just that all TV watching is passive, sedentary and nonexperiential and, as Americans, we watch so much of it."
The success of the campaign may be directly tied to social, economic and age factors, its organizers said. Many single-head households, low-income families, families with young children and the elderly rely on television for entertainment, solace and companionship. Turning it off may be easier said than done.
Six months ago, for example, Andy and Marjan Shallal of Fairfax, Va., were concerned that their daughter, Laela, 6, was watching too much television. They decided to put their set in a closet for two weeks.
"Initially, she thought it was fun," recalled Mr. Shallal, a bookstore owner who, with his wife and daughter, is coordinating the local turnoff effort. "By that afternoon, she was asking us to get the TV out of the closet."
On the second day, he said, she became more aggressive, accusing her parents of child abuse. "For two weeks," he said, "there was hell to pay."
But by the third week, Laela was reading more, doing artwork and playing with her sister, Nina, 2. The television is still in the closet.
"I miss it, maybe a little bit," said Laela, in a phone interview. "But I think it's good to turn off the TV for a while. It makes your brain small."
"I think parents are in denial about the effects of TV," said Benjamin Lev, a kindergarten teacher at Roseland Elementary School in Santa Rosa, Calif., and an organizer of this year's Sonoma County TV Turnoff, which will coincide with the national turnoff. "Studies have found that parents routinely underestimate the amount of TV their children watch by 50 percent."
Steve Bennett, the coauthor with his wife, Ruth, of "365 TV-Free Activities You Can Do With Your Child (Bob Adams Inc., 1991), attributes people's hesitation to go without television to a kind of fear of the unfamiliar.
"Over the last 30 years, we've forgotten how to play," said Mr. Bennett, who wrote the book after seeing the number of hours his son, Noah, who was then 2, spent watching television. "It's a sad statement when I hear people say, 'What will we do without TV?' We are raising kids with an imagination impairment."
Mitch Greenwood, the principal at Flynn Park Elementary School in University City, Mo., said viewing was also creating problems in the classroom.
"We're seeing all the karate kicks from kids mimicking the Ninja Turtles and Power Rangers," he said. "They expect teachers to do all the wonderful exciting things they see on television."
TV-Free America, which hopes to make the national turnoffs annual, acknowledges that a one-week blackout is unlikely to result in major shifts in viewing.
"Some will go back to watching as much as before, but a lot won't," Mr. Labalme predicted. "We've found that individuals and families who participated ended up looking at TV in a different way."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Laela Shallal, 6, shows classmates a fish she made instead of watching television. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
A man suspected in a long spree of computer theft was arrested by F.B.I. agents. The capture of Kevin D. Mitnick, a 31-year-old computer expert, came after a search of more than two years. He is suspected in the theft of thousands of data files and at least 20,000 credit card numbers from computer systems nationwide. "He was clearly the most wanted computer hacker in the world," said Kent Walker, a United States assistant attorney. [Page A1.]
 
Tsutomu Shimomura was the cybersleuth who assisted the F.B.I. in its inquiry that led to the arrest of Kevin Mitnick. [D17.] 

Consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in January, indicating higher inflation. But a report on industrial production confirmed economic growth was slowing. [D1.]
 
Washington's bond ratings were cut to junk status by Moody's, raising doubts about a balanced budget for the capital city. [A16.]

Mexican markets were again shaken as Grupo Sidek, a big tourism and construction company, defaulted. [D1.]

HEADLINE: ROWLAND'S SPENDING PLAN: TAXES;
Keeping Vow, in Deed Not Magnitude

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 15

 BODY:
In the modest tax cut proposals announced during his budget presentation to the General Assembly today, Gov. John G. Rowland fell short of the dramatic oratory of his gubernatorial campaign. A big reason the cuts didn't approach the revolutionary levels some residents were expecting is Connecticut's economy, which has still not come back to life.
Politically, Mr. Rowland is already compared regularly with other Republican governors in the Northeast, from Christine Todd Whitman in New Jersey to George E. Pataki in New York to William F. Weld in Massachusetts, all of whom have promised or succeeded in pushing through cuts in taxes and spending. 
 But those states either felt less pain in the recession, or have rebounded more quickly than Connecticut, making it easier for governors to follow through with more dramatic budget cuts. Slower growth means that tax collections here are going up slowly, if at all, making tax cuts harder to pay for and spending cuts more painful.
"Connecticut never had the benefit of getting its recovery off the ground," said Don Klepper-Smith, the corporate economist at Southern New England Telecommunications. "If we need anything it's a recovery with legs."
The numbers tell much of the story. New Jersey, for example, has regained 51.5 percent of the jobs it lost in the recession as of December, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Massachusetts has regained 41.6. Even New York, which was hit as hard in the recession as any place, has recovered 21.8 percent of its lost jobs.
Connecticut, by contrast, after two years of paltry recovery, has brought back only 7.1 percent of the 156,000 jobs that were lost from 1989 to 1992.
The weakness is also evident when Connecticut is compared with the nation as a whole. In 1994, the United States economy grew at a rate of about 4 percent, sparking fears of inflation and a raising of interest rates by the Federal Reserve. In Connecticut, growth did not exceed 1 percent, which means the state was hit with the full braking effect of higher interest rates imposed by the Federal Reserve without having first enjoyed any acceleration.
And even before the income-tax cuts promised in Mr. Rowland's budget, state budget officials were warning that collections were coming in below the amounts projected last year. Economists, while expecting some modest growth and job creation in 1995, also say there will probably be continued erosion in two of the state's economic pillars -- insurance and military contracting, which led the downturn in the first place.
All of that leads to two major implications.
Since tax collections and economic growth are so weak, Mr. Rowland was under greater pressure than his Republican gubernatorial colleagues to pay for his tax cuts with equivalent spending cuts. And economists say that in a weak economy, if spending cuts do in fact cancel out tax cuts, the bounce from putting more money in consumer's pockets is just about nil.
There may be an element of inherent cautiousness on Mr. Rowland's part as well. His state's budget is essentially on sound footing, with no large budget gap expected this year, even with a weak economy. Mr. Pataki's first budget in New York, by contrast, is an exercise in finding the fiscally possible in a budget full of holes.
"One of the challenges with a slow recovery in Connecticut is that you have to lean all the harder on the spending cuts," said Nicholas S. Perna, the chief economist at Shawmut National Corporation, a bank based in Hartford. On the other hand, he added, "Economics 101 teaches that if you cut taxes and offset that by cutting spending, you don't get any immediate bang for the buck -- it's in one pocket and out the other."
Mr. Rowland's proposals also represent more of a continuation, than a sharp break, with the pattern of tax legislation established by former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
Mr. Weicker, who authored and pushed through an income tax in his first year in office in 1991, justified the move by saying it would pay for cuts in corporate taxes that would, in turn, stimulate the economy and create jobs.
Today, Mr. Rowland, who has promised to eliminate the income tax over five years, kept his promise to begin whittling away at Mr. Weicker's tax, while cautioning that business taxes and costs were just as much of a priority.
His budget would reduce resident's tax payments by a maximum of $157 in the first year, or about $3 a week, for a family filing jointly and earning more than $94,000 a year. People earning less would get a smaller tax break, though, it would be a larger reduction in percentage terms.
The largest promised tax cuts in the budget would come for business, though they are mostly still in the future. Mr. Rowland said he wanted to accelerate a corporate-tax reduction plan passed under Mr. Weicker, speeding up by a full percentage point a year the rate at which the corporate tax rate would fall.
The tax would decline from the current 10.5 percent rate to 8 percent by 1999. He also proposed cutting the tax on hospitals' gross receipts from 11 percent to 8 percent by 1999.
Mr. Perna, the Shawmut economist, said the great achievement of the Rowland budget may be in cutting where pragmatism allows.
"You can't give away what you don't have," he said.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Need Options to Cuts? Find Real Labor Savings

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
IF you don't like my budget ideas, let me hear yours, says Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
O.K., here's one: Solve the case of the disappearing labor savings. If he did, maybe Mr. Giuliani wouldn't have to cut so much from health and welfare programs for the poor, slated to account for more than 40 percent of his budget reductions. 
 The Mayor talks tough about the unions and his Labor Commissioner, Randy Levine, wrested real concessions from the sanitation and custodians' unions. But now, the Mayor is asking for only $600 million in labor savings, which gradually shrivels from $600 million to $200 million in three years.
The Mayor, who's already reduced the work force by about 14,000, says there's more attrition to come. But shrinking the work force may not save money in the long run, given New York's propensity for rehiring the minute the economy smiles. And sometimes when it doesn't. A graph charting the size of the city work force since 1975 looks like a bad electrocardiogram.
In fact, only "recurring" productivity savings, like reducing the number of firefighters on a truck, can have a lasting impact. Cutting the city's contribution to union pension funds -- said to be under consideration at City Hall -- would indeed save money. But that kind of saving can't help for long.
IF he is as committed to reforming government as he claims, the Mayor could come up with significantly more than $600 million in real, recurring savings. The possibilities are no mystery. The Citizens Budget Commission, the business-supported nonprofit group, submitted ideas to the administration just two months ago at the budget director's request. Maybe this time will be different, suggests Raymond D. Horton, the group's ever-optimistic president. "You have a fiscal crisis, a determined Mayor, a resourceful labor relations director, and a divided set of Civil Service unions," he said.
The Budget Commission's ideas will be duly considered, said a noncommittal Mr. Levine. Here are some of the Commission's proposals, along with suggestions others have made:
End release time.
The city pays about 200 employees full city salaries to work for their unions full time. It's a tradition that goes back to the 1950's, when the new unions were trying to establish themselves. They have.
Increase the workweek of civilian workers.
Now most work 35 hours a week. If they worked 37 1/2 hours, as state workers do, or 40-hour weeks, as Federal employees do, the city could reduce overtime and night differential pay.
Reduce the time police officers spend on administrative duties.
If officers assigned to enforcement jobs spent 11 instead of 21 days on administrative and clerical duties, the department could, the Budget Commission contends, add the equivalent of 1,400 full-time officers to street patrol.
This only saves money if the city reduces police hiring. It would have to renegotiate the agreement with the State Legislature requiring that the city have 38,310 officers in its three police forces. Mr. Giuliani opposes a renegotiation.
Reduce paid sabbaticals for teachers.
It costs the city about $20 million a year to pay for teacher sabbaticals. After seven years, teachers can get 60 percent of their full salaries while on sabbatical, and 70 percent after 14 years.
Eliminate double time and Fresh Kills pay in the Sanitation Department.
Workers get double pay for garbage collections on Sundays, and for hauling refuse to the Fresh Kills landfill.
Restructure health insurance.
City workers do not contribute to their health care. Adding a co-payment of $300 a person or $550 for a family could save $200 million a year for the city, which proposed this last year.
Eliminate built-in overtime for firefighters and vary firehouse staffing.
Each firefighter is guaranteed 96 hours of overtime a year because of an arbitration decision. The city could renegotiate that, and could also save money by having neighborhood firehouses share equipment during slow periods.
Revamp police and fire pensions.
Police officers and firefighters can get tax-free disability pensions if they say they injured themselves on the job, even if the injury was slight and they continue to work. Those with heart ailments can get disability pensions on the presumption that the condition is work-related. The Legislature would have to revise these laws.
Those are just a few proposals, and there are others. Saving $1 billion in labor costs would not, in an ideal world, be that difficult. But it is. Most of these ideas are yellow with age, too impolitic to succeed. Then again, Mr. Giuliani, agile enough to endorse the liberal Mario M. Cuomo in the fall, and embrace the conservative ideology of the new Republican Governor come winter, seems to excel at being impolitic.

HEADLINE: When Government Goes on Autopilot

BYLINE: By Peter Schrag; Peter Schrag is editorial page editor of The Sacramento Bee.

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Americans have looked longingly at California for all sorts of reasons: for the climate, for the natural beauty, even, at one time, for our unmatched system of higher education. But as far as can be determined, of late no American has lusted for our contorted government structure, our declining public services or our penchant for fiscal gridlock. So why is the new Congress rushing so resolutely to copy the mess California has created for itself?
At the core of California's mess is a constitutional provision (one of two in the nation, and unique among the major states) that requires a two-thirds majority in each house of the Legislature to approve the state budget, any appropriation and any tax increase. 
 The balanced budget amendment steaming through Congress would require only a three-fifths supermajority for Congress to pass an unbalanced budget, but its effects would surely be similar.
If the states ratified the amendment, Congress could approve balanced budgets by majority vote, but since no one has proposed a politically acceptable way that can be done, the operative provision is the three-fifths majority, which, as in California, would give the most determined (and often most irresponsible) political minority in each house the power to hold the budget hostage to extract concessions from the majority.
In California, the supermajority requirement has often made it harder, not easier, to eliminate dubious spending practices. In 11 of the last 16 years, California has spent more than it has taken in. During the past several years of recession, the Legislature and Governor, unable to muster the necessary two-thirds vote for stringent budget medicine, have repeatedly resorted to fiscal gimmicks and outside borrowing. As a result, the state's credit rating plunged from AAA in the late 1980's to A, one of the lowest in the nation.
 And sometimes it brings government to a halt. In two of the past five years, the Legislature ran a month or more into the new fiscal year before it managed to get a budget approved. In 1992, the delay forced the state to issue i.o.u.'s to government employees and contractors.
One would expect such delays to generate a certain amount of public consternation, but since supermajority requirements make it hard to determine which party or group of politicians is ultimately responsible, the voters have no way to know which rascals to throw out. Which, of course, is one reason why they always want to throw out all of them.
But that's only one of California's cautionary tales. The larger one comes from our passion for constitutional quick fixes and our efforts to run government on autopilot.
And while even the new Republican Congress couldn't go as far as we have, its flirtation with term limits and its seeming determination to put entitlements like Social Security permanently beyond the budget process -- and to put other limits on the choices of the voters and the budgetary discretion of their representatives -- point it very much in California's misguided direction.
Part of California's story ought to be familiar. Since 1978, California has been engaged in an orgy of constitutional reform: each time the system fails, appears to enter gridlock or generates voter frustration, we pass another initiative.
Consider these: the Proposition 13 property tax limitation measure in 1978, itself in part the result of the Legislature's failure to muster a supermajority in the mid-70's for much-needed property tax reform; a prohibition on unfunded mandates (largely ignored in practice) in 1979; spending limits for state and local government also in 1979; a measure requiring the state to spend at least 40 percent of its general-fund budget on schools in 1988; term limits and limits on legislative spending and staffs in 1990, plus scores of secondary modifications and reforms.
All that reforming has produced a Rube Goldberg machine of truly baroque proportions in which fiscal authority is divided so uncertainly between state and local governments and among scores of agencies that it's beyond even the most devoted citizen to understand.
And as reform is piled on reform and major programs are put beyond budgetary discretion, it becomes increasingly hard for state and local officials to set priorities and deal with the issues that they were presumably elected to address.
This in turn has led to scores of dubious fiscal expedients -- escalating permit fees, special-assessment districts and other devices, many of them leading to further distortions of priorities -- to get around local and state tax and spending limits. In some ways, even Orange County's bankruptcy resulted indirectly from the shortage of reasonable fiscal options.
A constitutional revision commission is now trying to figure out how to disentangle the mess into which California has voted itself.
How does all this bear on what Congress is doing? Congress, after all, is proposing to restore authority to the states, not centralize it, as many of California's reforms have inadvertently done. But Congress's autopilot solutions are just as mechanistic as those we've pursued, and just as inimical to legislative discretion and accountability.
The great irony of Proposition 13 and its successors in California is that initiatives that were first hailed as great victories of citizen action in recapturing control of government have inadvertently moved authority from local to state government and produced further alienation and frustration.
In 1990, for example, California became the first major state to enact legislative term limits -- three two-year terms for members of the Assembly and two four-year terms for the Senate. This year, term limits began kicking in, leading to a new class of inexperienced Republican Assembly members. The initial result was six weeks of gridlock in a narrowly divided Assembly whose control the Republicans had thought they had won. Now that that issue is temporarily resolved with the Democratic legislative coup that led to the re-election of Willie Brown as Speaker, the Assembly faces the prospect of what appears to be a long round of recalls, special elections and indefinite instability.
Perhaps none of those outcomes is inherent in term limits. No one could have foreseen the narrow margin between Democrats and Republicans in the Assembly. But it was easy to foresee that the members of a Legislature limited to three terms -- a sort of glorified bus station waiting room, where one-third of the members are always just arriving and one-third are always packing to leave -- would be chronically short on experience and even shorter on loyalty to the institution. This winter, it was the experienced Democrats who picked clean the Republican rubes just off the bus. Although all those slickers will soon be gone, a house of bumblers is hardly a cheering prospect. Beware the law of unintended consequences. California has a Constitution full of them.

HEADLINE: Gulf Nations Balk at Proposal for Mideast Development Bank

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 16

 BODY:
A proposal championed by the Clinton Administration and Israel to create a regional Middle East Development Bank appears to have been dealt a major blow by Arab countries, with officials saying they will neither finance such a bank nor take part in it.
The unusually forceful position from the diplomatically timid Persian Gulf countries appears to be part of an Arab retreat from further normalization with Israel. 
 The bank proposal was a key part of the American approach to the Middle East peace effort, intended to integrate Israel into regional Arab economies through joint developmental projects.
The idea was resisted for months by several Arab countries that had been expected to be donors to the bank, mostly the members of the Gulf Cooperation Council, which is led by Saudi Arabia and whose members are Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates and Oman.
It was supported by others, mostly Egypt, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization, along with Israel, all of which expected the bank to be a source of additional financing for their economies.
Now, officials and columnists in the gulf countries are going further in their resistance, arguing in statements and editorial commentary that wider economic cooperation with Israel will have to wait until full peace has been established.
In a weekend news conference timed to coincide with a visit by the American Secretary of Commerce, Ronald H. Brown, to the United Arab Emirates, Ahmad bin Humayd al-Tayir, the United Arab Emirates Minister of State for Financial and Industrial Affairs, said, "The Arab world is not in need of an institution or a development bank in which Israel participates."
Mr. Tayir added, "Before talking or thinking of establishing a common Middle East market, some balance in security and economic interests between the Arabs and Israel must be established, and the Arab world's interests must be assured in political, social and economic areas against plans to dominate us and impose facts upon us."
On Monday, a Saudi official who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in a telephone interview, "Our position has been stated repeatedly in the meetings of the Gulf Cooperation Council, which is that any talk of regional cooperation with Israel is premature until Israeli troops leave Arab lands in the West Bank, Gaza, Syria and Lebanon."
Writing in the Saudi daily Asharq Al Awsat on Monday, Abdelrahman al-Rashid, an influential Saudi political columnist, argued that Arab gulf countries feel the bank project "is another financial tax imposed upon them which they cannot accept, and even if they accepted it, they will not be able to fulfill it because of their difficult financial circumstances."
Similar objections were raised during a major Middle East economic conference in October in Casablanca, Morocco, where the idea of the bank first surfaced, along with other projects for regional economic cooperation that would involve Arab countries, Israel and Turkey.
The development reflects palpable cooling of an earlier enthusiasm after Israel signed peace treaties with the P.L.O. and Jordan last year. Then several Arab gulf countries, including Oman, Qatar, Bahrain, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, lifted an economic boycott against companies doing business with Israel and allowed officials to meet with their Israeli counterparts in several Arab and world capitals.
But on Saturday, Hamad bin Jasim bin Jabir al-Thani, the Foreign Minister of Qatar, which was one of the first gulf countries to hold public talks with Israel on economic and political cooperation, told Qatar television that his country would not "rush to establish ties to Israel." He denied there were plans to export natural gas to Israel.
Israeli officials had said several months ago that they were in the final stages of negotiating a deal to import natural gas from Qatar.
The Qatari Foreign Minister also denied in an interview that there were plans to open representational offices in Israel. "Such a step can only be taken at the appropriate time," he said.
After the Morocco meeting, the United States said it was scaling down the project, which was first proposed with a initial capital of $10 billion. But Washington insisted that the idea continued to enjoy support among several Arab countries, including those in the Gulf region, and that it would be pursued.

HEADLINE: Razors, Soap, Cornflakes: Pirating Spreads in China

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Inside a bare, dimly lit concrete building on the outskirts of town, five workers at the Huaxing Razor Blade Factory sit hunched over noisy machines that spit ordinary razor blades into a row of blue kerosene cans.
Upstairs, lounging in an oversized black leather chair, Yin Jiande, the factory manager, snorts at accusations by the Gillette Company that he had made more than 50 million counterfeit copies of razor blades produced by Gillette's joint venture here and sold them in look-alike packaging. 
 "If they say we can't do it anymore, O.K., we won't do it anymore," said Mr. Yin, who promised to stop last year when he was caught copying Gillette's packaging, only to continue copying it until he was caught a second time and finally stopped.
"No one told us about this law," he said, alluding to a 1993 rule that bans the copying of a competitor's wares or packaging.
Factory managers like Mr. Yin are at the core of a fight that has pushed the United States and China to the brink of a trade war over intellectual property rights, including copyrights and trademarks. A final round of talks began Wednesday in Beijing.
Both countries have mixed heated accusations with stern promises to stand tough, and it is unclear if either will soften in time to reach a last-minute accord before Feb. 26, when trade sanctions threatened by both countries are set to begin.
Yet whether or not peace is made in Beijing, the struggle over piracy is unlikely to stop anytime soon in factories in the back alleys of Shanghai, and in hundreds of small towns in southern China, where counterfeit versions of everything from Lux soap to Kellogg's cornflakes to Shell Oil lubricants are being churned out.
American trade negotiators like to cite pirated compact disks and computer software as the kind of items that could easily be controlled. But the counterfeiting of ordinary consumer goods has become so widespread that restraining it appears to be far beyond Beijing's grasp.
Counterfeiting in China ballooned in the last two years as factory managers like Mr. Yin operated in an environment of speedy economic growth coupled with a weak legal system, seeing quick profits and little risk of punishment. The infringement of trademarks -- the symbols and design that identify a product -- now involves billions of dollars worth of goods produced in China, trademark lawyers estimate.
Counterfeit goods in a developing country are nothing new, and items like fake Rolex watches and Gucci bags are sold on the streets of New York City. But the recent growth of consumer piracy in China has been so fast and the volume so large that Western businessmen say they are alarmed by how big a bite is being taken out of their bottom line.
After Gillette discovered that Huaxing Razor was pirating the packaging and perhaps the contents of Gillette's Flying Eagle brand razor, it presented evidence to the local authorities, who raided the premises. But the action led only to broken promises from the factory and to legal action so minimal that it virtually invited more counterfeiting.
At the Huaxing factory, a modest operation with 100 workers who are paid $50 to $90 a month, Mr. Yin expresses nonchalance about his dispute with Gillette, apparently out of confidence that local officials will continue to go easy on him.
"I'm friends with most leaders in the district government," said Mr. Yin, a boyish-looking man of 40 who wears a black leather coat with a fur collar. Although he said he was paid a salary of less than $200 a month, the sleek black Audi and the Mitsubishi pickup truck parked outside his office suggested a broader income.
"The cars belong to the factory," he said.
Although Huaxing did stop counterfeiting after a second raid and fine, it left Gillette without a penny of compensation from lost sales estimated at more than $1 million. As in other parts of China, the economic police in Shanghai may often have little incentive to penalize factories that generate local tax revenue and are run by acquaintances.
Xing Dongsheng, a deputy section chief at the Shanghai Administration of Industry and Commerce, which is responsible for enforcing trademark violations, insisted that the Gillette case was an example of good government work because fines were collected, twice, and handed over to the central Government. He denied that any favoritism had been shown to Mr. Yin.
"The key question is whether the local government is enforcing the law," said Mr. Xing, dressed in the blue military-style uniform that investigators wear when they check on stores in Shanghai. "Our Government is determined to take action, and last year we held one conference after another to discuss the problem."
When not attending meetings, or conducting spot-checks, Mr. Xing said he relied on companies like Gillette to bring claims forward and to present hard evidence.
"You can't say that just because something is selling cheaply that it is counterfeit, he said. "You need evidence. The United States should not ask us to prosecute every case. No one can prosecute every case."
Tony Au Yeung, general manager of Gillette (Shanghai) Ltd., the joint venture, estimates that counterfeiters now sell Gillette look-alikes worth more than $10 million, or roughly one-third of the annual sales at his Shanghai operation. Du Pont, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, S. C. Johnson and McDonald's are among the dozens of other companies that are fighting trademark infringements.
In downtown Shanghai, a mere hundred yards from a McDonald's outlet on Huai Hai Road, another fast-food restaurant uses a sign with golden arches on a red background in a way that looks like a McDonald's "M" but with a leg partly missing, making it an "N," for Nancy's Expres. A lawyer for McDonald's said legal action was being considered.
Legal action in China is rarely easy, but trademark cases are now being handled regularly in courts and by administrative means. Under pressure from American negotiators, China agreed in 1992 to expand its legal framework for intellectual property rights and has set up special courts and assigned more investigators, especially in large cities like Shanghai and Guangzhou.
"I think the central Government recognizes that this is really a problem," Mr. Au Yeung said of Gillette. "But because the local authorities are so unwilling, it is difficult to do anything about it."
Gillette opened its joint venture with the Shanghai Razor Blade Factory in 1992, and produces both the Chinese Flying Eagle brand as well as Gillette's Atra and Sensor brands. Gillette owns 70 percent and has management control.
In late 1993, Mr. Au Yeung learned from his Chinese business partner that the Huaxing factory was making an imitation of the Flying Eagle single-edged razor and selling it for 1.3 cents each, or 20 percent less than the joint venture's price. He persuaded local investigators to raid the factory in January 1994.
Mr. Yin, the factory manager, insisted that his razors, sold under the brand name Sea Gull, were different from Gillette's. But he acknowledged that packaging he began using more than a year ago was the same color and design as the joint venture, down to the white bird with wings spread wide.
"It was a coincidence," Mr. Yin said.
The district authorities decided that the packaging, but not the razors, violated Gillette's trademark, though Mr. Au Yeung said he thought the razors were copied, too.
Five months later, after the authorities fined Huaxing $3,500, an amount that Mr. Au Yeung considers paltry, he learned that the factory was still using the same packaging. But the district authorities would not do anything about it, saying they had already done their job.
Undeterred, Mr. Au Yeung went up a rung in the city bureaucracy, appealing to the Shanghai Administration of Industry and Commerce. Their investigators led a second raid, in August 1994, which led to a second fine, $3,300, in December.
Asked why he kept using the same packages after the first raid, Mr. Yin, the factory manager, said he did not want to throw away packaging that had already been printed. "We didn't want to waste it," he said.
In the eight months before Huaxing was stopped, Mr. Au Yeung estimates, the factory sold more than $1 million worth of imitations, most of it in exports to Southeast Asia. "That's revenue that we should have gotten," he said.
Mr. Au Yeung said he thought the fines on Huaxing were so small they could simply be considered the cost of doing business, even in a factory like Huaxing, where Mr. Yin said annual profit was $120,000 in 1994, before taxes.
Mr. Xing of the Shanghai Administration of Industry and Commerce said there was a formula for fines: a maximum of 50 percent of the value of the counterfeit goods, or five times the profits derived from them.
But he conceded that the total fines of $6,800 in the Gillette case were less than 1 percent of the $1 million worth of pirated goods. The Government has to consider other factors, Mr. Xing said, such as putting people out of work.
"If a factory only makes $100,000 a year, we can't fine them $1 million," Mr. Xing reasoned. "One million dollars -- that is a very small amount for a big American company, but to a small Chinese factory, it could put them into bankruptcy."
Joseph T. Simone, a lawyer at Johnson Stokes & Master in Hong Kong, who has represented several American companies in trademark disputes in China, argued that the situation would not improve until stiffer penalties were enforced.
"If nobody's going to jail and fines are negligible, you're not going to get in front of the problem," Mr. Simone said. "And you just invite more piracy."
Although a factory like Huaxing stopped counterfeiting after it was caught red-handed twice, Mr. Simone said its example showed other factory managers that they could counterfeit other products with impunity and the worst that would happen was a minimal fine.
"In most countries, if you have 10 pirates, you can go after one, expect seven to stop, and then figure out how to get the remaining two," Mr. Simone said. "But in China, when you go after one, the other nine see exactly what you're doing. Not only do they keep pirating, but you invite 10 more to join in."

HEADLINE: For Law Firms, the Shakeout in the Business World Has Finally Hit

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
It has finally happened: Law firms are going through the same wrenching changes that their corporate clients have endured. Big firms are getting bigger, small firms are finding niches, medium-sized firms are feeling squeezed.
And the legal world is reacting to the recent demise of Shea & Gould, a blue-chip law firm if ever there was one, with the same shocked horror that corporate America felt when it saw the seemingly invincible International Business Machines Corporation run into financial and marketing troubles. 
 "The crashing of Shea & Gould has sensitized all law firms to the importance of managing, planning, monitoring partners, acting like a business," said Joel A. Rose, a Cherry Hill, N.J., management consultant and chairman of the Large Law Firm Committee of the American Bar Association's Law Practice Management Section.
The shakeout has already begun. Shea & Gould, which at its peak seemed the epitome of legal prestige and opulence, was not the only firm to dissolve amid partner acrimony. Other firms, including the New York-based Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith and Bower & Gardner, also expanded too quickly or changed too slowly, and imploded. Other firms then picked their carcasses. Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, for one, picked up nearly 60 Lord, Day lawyers and now has more than 750 lawyers.
Legal experts predict more of the same as the larger firms rethink collegial structures that worked when 25 lawyers were scrunched together but that cannot accommodate hundreds of lawyers dispersed around the world.
"Big general-practice firms will merge with big Wall Street firms, and we'll all go the way of the accounting firms," said Eugene Anderson, one of the founders of Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, P.C., a 240-lawyer firm based in New York. "We'll have a Big 6 or Big 8, with offices in every major city, handling huge cases for huge clients. And we'll have 100,000 tiny firms, offering personal service to tiny clients and handling the bulk of the tort cases."
This will mean lots of obstacles for lawyers with ambitions to become partners. It will be harder for individuals to stand out in the huge merged firms. And small firms rarely have the same partnership opportunities.
But more is changing than just firm size:
* Morgan, Lewis, once firmly ensconced in Philadelphia, has distributed partners and associates fairly equally among its Philadelphia, New York and Washington offices. "This structure gives us a better chance of hanging on to the star performers in the regional offices," said the firm's Washington-based chairman, John Quarles.
* Anderson, Kill, where each lawyer is a partner, is rethinking its one-man, one-vote structure. "We will continue to give all our lawyers access to financial information, but it doesn't work for everyone to vote on every issue now that we're big," Mr. Anderson said.
* Bickel & Brewer, the Dallas-based law firm, has abandoned the billable hour. It now charges clients a flat fee based on what their cases are expected to yield, and a percentage of any money above that amount. "The billable hour puts incentives in the wrong place," William A. Brewer 3d, a co-founder, said.
The changes are being driven as much by outside forces as by introspection. The costs of doing business -- like office rents, salaries, and computer hardware and software -- have skyrocketed. And the fabric of relationships between lawyers and clients, and among lawyers themselves, is unraveling.
Clients no longer believe in one-stop shopping, but are parceling out their business to numerous firms. Well-known firms are being forced to participate in what lawyers call beauty contests -- sessions in which several firms vie for a client's business. But even getting invited to compete is hard these days.
Omer S. J. Williams, managing partner of the New York firm Thacher Proffitt & Wood, said, "We now have a full-time marketing person whose job is to get us on panels, to arrange seminars, to basically get our name known."
Divorces between young lawyers and old firms are becoming common. Sometimes lawyers leave for better pay; often, they are forced out. Robert W. Gordon, a professor at Stanford Law School, said that 20 years ago a talented associate had a 50-50 chance to make partner. By 10 years ago, that was down to 10 percent. Today, he said, only 1 in 15 or 20 will get the brass ring.
"Partners are expensive, and there isn't enough work to promote everybody," Mr. Gordon said.
Associates who do make it to partner hold their seniors in little awe. Mr. Rose tells of one law firm that has been forced to rethink its longstanding policy of providing retiring partners with one-and-a-half times their average earnings in the prior four years, as well as their capital interests in the firm.
"The younger and midlevel partners insisted that this drain on their own revenues end," Mr. Rose said.
Few firms are ignoring the upheaval around them. Instead, they are looking for ways to appease associates without hurting senior partners, to control growth rather than be controlled by it. Many no longer pay partners strictly on seniority, but have incentive systems that reward the partners who bring in the most business.
The big firms are also bowing to the era of specialization. Morgan, Lewis, for one, is reorganizing its litigation section into a group of practice specialists. "Clients no longer believe that any good trial lawyer can try any case," Mr. Quarles said.
Already, some specialties have turned into hot areas. For example, several firms are adding practices in environmental law and white-collar crime. And if they do not have the expertise on staff, they hire it in. The New York firm Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson has home-grown its new environmental-law specialty. But it hired its white-collar crime specialists from Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon.
Other law firms are looking for ways to specialize without adding lawyers to their permanent staffs. Increasingly, they are subcontracting parts of a big case to smaller specialty firms or bringing in lawyers from legal temporary agencies to handle bursts of business.
Even tiny firms are slowly embracing that concept. When David M. Perlmutter formed his own New York firm three years ago, he quickly realized he needed a bigger library and more legal expertise than he and his two partners could realistically afford. So he arranged with Rogers & Wells, a larger firm in his office building, to use its library and some of its lawyers on an as-needed basis. He shares legal fees accordingly.
Mr. Perlmutter says it is a classic win-win situation. "I can take on more complex cases," he said. "And Rogers & Wells gets access to my clients, with personnel they can spare at that time."
Computers may yet prove the leveling force among different-sized firms. But so far, they have been a mixed blessing for the profession.
On the plus side, technology has enabled law firms to generate standardized documents and build easily accessible electronic libraries of their own cases and public-domain precedents. It even lets them take advantage of cheap labor: Bickel & Brewer, for example, often hires lawyers in India, where fees are a fraction of those here, to enter documents into its data base.
But the technology itself does not come cheap. "Putting a P.C. on everyone's desk, tying it into an enormous client-service network, these are huge costs," said David W. Maher, a partner in the Chicago firm Sonnenschein Nath & Rosenthal, and chairman of the Extra Large Law Firm Committee of the American Bar Association's Law Practice Management Section.
Lawyers generally must eat those costs. When a manufacturer automates, it can usually keep most of the savings for itself. When lawyers gain efficiency through technology, clients insist that they pass the savings on in the form of fewer billable hours. So, in a sense, computerization has reduced, not enhanced, law firm income.
At the same time, firm revenues have been increasingly squeezed. Many corporate clients have general counsels who themselves once worked for law firms and can easily recognize where fat is built into fees.
"Clients are definitely asking for more itemized bills," said Arthur Fleischer Jr., chairman of Fried, Frank.
Indeed, many clients are insisting that outside firms dispense with the open-ended billable-hour system altogether and stay within a given budget for a case. Firms are struggling for ways to respond.
"Clients say they hate hourly billing, but even they can't think of a good alternative," said Mr. Anderson of Anderson, Kill.
But all the Sturm und Drang, draining as it may be, has yielded some trends to gladden legal hearts.
A young lawyer's life may soon become more livable. Much of the drudge work has devolved to computers. Some firms, hoping to keep costs down and talent rosters up, are allowing some partners to take reduced earnings in exchange for reduced workloads. And communications technology can cut down on obligatory travel. "We can now have lawyers in three cities working on a document with as much efficiency as if they were sitting together," said Mr. Quarles of Morgan, Lewis.
Still, some of the more endearing of the old ways may yet resurface.
"Awarding jobs to the most specialized or lowest-bidding firm, one that doesn't know your company, isn't always a great idea," Professor Gordon said. "I wouldn't be surprised to see some of the bigger corporations try to re-establish long-term relationships with legal advisers."

GRAPHIC: Photos: As law becomes more of a business, firms have begun applying management principles to their practices. David M. Perlmutter, left, economizes by sharing library space with a large firm in his building. Eugene Anderson, right, of Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, P.C., predicts that "big general-practice firms will merge with big Wall Street firms, and we'll all go the way of the accounting firms." (Photographs by Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls On Fears in Peso Crisis

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday to a 16-week low against the German mark and dropped sharply against the Japanese yen on fears that United States financial institutions could be hurt if President Clinton's $50 billion rescue package for Mexico did not restore confidence in that country's battered economy.
There was also continued concern that Germany might raise interest rates as its economy picked up steam, making its currency more attractive to investors seeking higher returns. 
 Trading followed a recent pattern, with the dollar suffering from "peso contagion" as investors shunned North American currencies in favor of havens like the mark, the Swiss franc and, to a lesser extent, the yen.
The dollar, which closed on Wednesday in New York at 1.5089 marks, fell to 1.4880 marks, its lowest level since Oct. 25, before ending the day yesterday at 1.4902. Against the yen it fell to 97.42 late yesterday from 98.33 on Wednesday.
The mark also benefited from a flight out of the perennially weak Italian lira, as well as from the French franc and the British pound. The move was initiated after a board member of the German central bank had warned that a threatened strike by the huge metal workers' union, I. G. Metall, could lead to an inflationary wage settlement that would send interest rates higher.
The franc was also hurt by political uncertainty as the French presidential election neared. The pound is suffering from Prime Minister John Major's weak political standing and growing talk of rising inflation in London financial markets.
As the dollar dropped against major currencies, the news was bad, too, for the Mexican peso. The peso took a further fall against the dollar, closing at 6.075 to the dollar in New York yesterday, from 5.965 on Wednesday. Ten days ago, the peso traded just under 5.30 to the dollar.
The dollar's latest troubles stem from a lengthening list of doubts about the effectiveness of the American-organized rescue package for Mexico and the willingness of President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon to impose the austerity measures he has promised in return for international help. "Confidence is weakening," said Geoffrey Bell, president of a New York investment advisory firm. "The Mexican bailout may not be working."
In addition, traders say that the Mexican Government is drawing down some of its dollar swap lines to support the peso, but that many of these dollars are flowing into Europe and the Far East, increasing the supply of dollars on those markets and helping to depress their value. "There was always a danger the provision of public capital would serve as a cover for private capital to leave the country," said Ravi Bulchandani of Morgan Stanley.
Another source of pressure on the dollar is the knowledge that Mexicans' appetite for United States goods will sharply diminish this year. That may widen the United States' trade deficit, adding even more dollars to those that must be absorbed by currency markets.
While currency traders remained nervous about the Mexican rescue package, the stock exchange in Mexico City staged a late rally yesterday afternoon. Optimism returned as Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz opened talks in Washington with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin aimed at overcoming obstacles to the promised $20 billion American contribution to the rescue package.
The Mexico City stock market's key index had fallen 3.6 percent in early trading, but recovered in the final minutes to close at 1,831.50, up 33.50 points, or 1.86 percent.
There should "soon be major announcements from Washington about an agreement on the loan conditions," said Geoffrey E. J. Dennis, chief of Latin American equity research at Bear, Stearns in New York. "This will finally eliminate the residual fear that this loan package is in trouble. It is not."
Other Latin American stock markets also suffered yesterday from the uncertainty over Mexico as some foreign investors began moving their money elsewhere. The Merval index in Buenos Aires dropped 6.96 percent to close at its lowest level in two years. Chile's Selective index was down 2.93 percent. In Sao Paulo, the Bovespa index fell 6.70 percent.

HEADLINE: Democratic Governors Oppose Plan Shifting Welfare to States

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Democratic governors said today that they opposed a bill devised by House Republicans to overhaul the nation's welfare programs. They asserted that it would undermine state efforts to help poor people.
House Democrats said they would draft their own alternative, different from the Republican bill and from one proposed last year by President Clinton. 
 Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association, and Gov. Thomas R. Carper of Delaware, a Democrat, denounced the House Republicans' bill, which is generally supported by Republican governors.
Mr. Carper said, "The bill will undercut my own efforts to reform the welfare system in Delaware."
It would, he said, reduce the amount of Federal money provided to the states for cash assistance and for the protection of children who have been abused or neglected.
The Republican bill would eliminate a longstanding Federal requirement that states put up money of their own to match Federal welfare payments. Mr. Carnahan said this change was "not particularly good policy."
The governors also complained that the Republican bill would leave states exposed to severe fiscal hardship in a recession, and they said it would impose new mandates on the states to achieve conservative policy goals.
The Republicans' welfare bill, a keystone of their legislative agenda, would pare social welfare programs established over the last 60 years in favor of block grants that the states could spend as they wished to aid the poor.
The bill was approved by a House subcommittee on Wednesday. Under its provisions, the main cash assistance program would no longer be an entitlement available to everyone who met certain eligibility criteria. The Republican bill would prohibit the use of Federal money to provide cash assistance to unmarried mothers under the age of 18.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said the cash assistance program had roots in the Social Security Act of 1935. Of the Republican bill, he said: "This is not welfare reform. It is an attack on Social Security. I don't believe that either this Congress or this nation will support it. The answer to our problems is not to turn children out into the street."
On a related subject, the Acting Secretary of Agriculture, Richard Rominger, told Congress today that the Administration opposed the House Republicans' effort to replace the food stamp program, the school lunch program and other nutrition programs with a new block grant to the states. The Administration has made no such categorical statement opposing a block grant for the main cash assistance program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, though it has objected to many details of that proposal.
Republican members of Congress said they were not impressed by the arguments of the Democratic governors. Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., the Florida Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means subcommittee, said Democrats on the panel had repeatedly suggested that governors could not be trusted to take care of their poor citizens.
"Listen to the inconsistency of this," Mr. Shaw said. "We have battled the Democrats for three days, trying to put much of this program down there at the state level, and the Democrats have fought us. If you look at their amendments, you'll see that they are trying to put straitjackets on the states. Then they march in a couple of governors who say that we're trying to manage them and putting too many strings on it. It's nuts."
Representative Mac Collins, Republican of Georgia, said it served the political interests of Democrats to keep poor people dependent on the Government.
"This is politics," Mr. Collins said. "We have a welfare system that has made a portion of our population dependent on the Federal Government, and that dependency has been very rewarding to the Democratic Party for quite some time. But it got so costly to the taxpayer that on Nov. 8 the politically incorrect working people of this country rose up and said, 'Enough is enough,' and they voted for change."
Democrats said the suggestion that they had purposely encouraged dependency was absurd. Representative Harold E. Ford, Democrat of Tennessee, said the Republicans were waging a "campaign of hate" against children.
Representative John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, said the Republicans were seeking "a cultural revolution to take back the morality that we have in this country, so it becomes unacceptable again to have kids out of wedlock."
"You are looking at 30 to 40 years of a system of Government programs that have helped create a moral decline in this country," Mr. Ensign said. "It is not going to turn around in one, two, three years. This has to take a complete cultural change."
