HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
For Couples in Politics, Power (and Immunity)

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Since the earliest days of the Republic, prominent senators and representatives have found Government jobs for their friends.
Nowadays, it is not just cronies who get posts in the executive branch but sometimes the lawmakers' spouses. And that has led to situations for which no protocol exists. 
 Consider two incidents this month.
Two weeks ago, an inspector for the Federal Aviation Administration said his agency had improperly destroyed documents that might have embarrassed Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, the minority leader. The Senator's wife, Linda Hall Daschle, is the agency's Deputy Administrator. She said she knew nothing about the documents.
Then, on Tuesday, a Federal judge here rejected the Clinton Administration's settlement of its antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation and rebuked the Justice Department for having been too lenient. The chairman of Microsoft, Bill Gates, played golf with President Clinton on Martha's Vineyard last summer while negotiations were under way. The Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Antitrust Division is Anne K. Bingaman, the wife of Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico.
At a time when the political crossfire is so intense that Washington sometimes resembles a verbal Sarajevo, one might have thought that these incidents would have sparked a barrage of criticism from Republicans about nepotism.
But the Daschles and Bingamans have been immunized from political attack on this ground, as have other Democratic lawmakers with spouses in the Clinton Administration like Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, whose wife, Ruth, is president of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, and Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, whose husband, James, is a Deputy Under Secretary of Agriculture.
The main reason is that the wives of Senators Bob Dole of Kansas and Phil Gramm of Texas, the two most-visible Republicans in the Senate and candidates for the party's 1996 Presidential nomination, had top jobs in the Bush Administration. Elizabeth Hanford Dole was Secretary of Labor. Wendy Lee Gramm was chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
The qualifications of the spouses are not at issue. Mrs. Bingaman, Mrs. Harkin, Mr. Schroeder and Mrs. Dole had distinguished careers as lawyers before going into the Government. Mrs. Gramm has a doctorate in economics. Mrs. Daschle had worked in the aviation industry in various capacities for 20 years.
Still, it is doubtful that any of them would have gotten their Federal appointments had it not been for their spouses' political influence.
Stephen Hess, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and a student of the mores of Washington, put the matter this way: "Anne Bingaman is a fine person and a fine lawyer. But it is certainly clear that she was not the most distinguished antitrust lawyer in the United States. She was not even the most distinguished one in Washington. She was not even the most distinguished one among those who wanted the job. But obviously she wanted it, and her husband could deliver it for her."
This kind of arrangement is probably inevitable in these times of two-career couples. For many spouses, especially if they are lawyers, not much is left of a career in Washington if they cannot work in the Government and cannot lobby Congress. And when their spouse is, say, a senator and their party wins control of the White House, it is not surprising that they want jobs in the Government and that some arms get twisted on their behalf.
Dennis F. Thompson, who runs an ethical studies program at Harvard, observed that since most elected officials are men, rigid rules against their spouses holding Government jobs would discriminate against women. "That in itself is unethical," he said. "It is not so bad if the one who gets the job is eminently qualified but not the most qualified."
Businesses, law firms and newsrooms began coping with the situation years ago, and guidelines for proper conduct are now more or less understood. But politics somehow lagged behind.
So such questions arise as how much influence can a lawmaker properly apply to get a spouse a job. Or which spouse should withdraw from cases and in which circumstances. Or what kind of political favors can the one in the executive branch be expected to perform for colleagues of the spouse in Congress.
"These are delicate questions, but it is not beyond our intelligence to deal with them," said Ruth B. Mandel, director of the Center for the American Woman and Politics at Rutgers University. "New norms, some protocols, some guidelines -- all of these will develop the way they develop in any part of society as it undergoes change."

HEADLINE: Congress Drafts Bill on Financial Overseers for Washington, Based on New York Plan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
In the face of the severe municipal budget crisis here, Federal lawmakers are drafting legislation that would create for the District of Columbia the kind of financial oversight board that guided New York City out of bankruptcy in the 1970's.
Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District's delegate to Congress, said today that the downgrading this week of the city's bond rating coupled with a $631 million budget deficit, made a powerful argument for establishing a temporary independent body to improve the fiscal condition of the city. 
 "The financial and management oversight board that I envision would be small in size but not in scope because of the dimensions of the problem," she said at a news conference, adding that the board would have full authority over all aspects of the city's budget and financial planning.
Mrs. Norton, a Democrat, said that the legislation was being developed as a bipartisan effort, led by the chairmen of the two House subcommittees that oversee the District's affairs, James T. Walsh, Republican of upstate New York, and Thomas M. Davis 3d, Republican of Virginia, and through consultations with city officials, the White House and outside experts in urban fiscal policy.
She also said she favored introducing legislation as soon as next week. But Mr. Davis said that while the creation of an oversight board was likely, it was only one option available to lawmakers. And he added that no legislation would be proposed until after Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and other city officials testify before a joint meeting of the subcommittees on Wednesday on the District's financial situation, which has been eroding for years.
"Walsh's and my position is to let things play out before we weigh in," Mr. Davis said in an interview. "We have a number of options available to us. But have we begun drafting something? Yes. It would be naive for us not to put pen to paper with this burgeoning crisis."
Whatever action Congress takes is certain to reduce the authority of Mr. Barry, who won election last fall campaigning as the only candidate capable of drawing the city out of its fiscal mess.
Today Mr. Barry scorned the notion of an oversight board, saying it was unjustified because the deficit had grown to its present size under a previous administration and he should not be held responsible.
He also asserted that any solution that failed to generate new revenue would be "a waste of time."
"Eleanor told me about this plan this morning," Mr. Barry said in an interview, "and that's exactly what I told her: Any plan that does not bring in revenue is not going to work. It's a waste of time."
As he has on other occasions, Mr. Barry defended his own deficit-reduction plan announced two weeks ago, even though Federal lawmakers have virtually ignored it while waiting for the results of an analysis of the city's finances by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress.
On Wednesday Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating of the district's general obligation bonds to junk status, and on Tuesday the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its rating to one level above junk-bond status. Officials at both companies cited not only the city's budget problem but the lack of a sound rescue plan.
As part of his proposal to reduce the deficit and a projected $91 million cash shortfall in the current fiscal year, Mr. Barry had proposed that Congress assume the District's Medicaid costs of $267 million. He said he would save another $70 million by imposing a 10 percent wage cut on city workers.
While Mrs. Norton provided few details of the board she is proposing, she described its broad powers, which are designed only to deal with the short-term issues of balancing the budget. Specifically, she said, the board would be authorized to take over many of the responsibilities that now belong to the Mayor, including devising spending plans, creating access to financial markets and correcting city government inefficiencies. The board could also audit the city's books.
But long-term issues, like altering the city's relationship with Congress under Home Rule, the 21-year-old law that gave the District government limited autonomy, would not be addressed by the oversight board. Those questions would be addressed after the current crisis had passed.
Mr. Walsh, a former president of the Syracuse City Council, said that if Congress was going to create an oversight board, he favored one similar to the Municipal Assistance Corporation developed 20 years ago for New York City. At the time, New York City's debt exceeded $7 billion, and private lenders were no longer willing to give the city credit.
By assuming control over all fiscal matters, the new corporation and a second agency later created to give the state control of the city budget, helped to restructure New York's debt and to balance the budget within six years.
But Mr. Davis cautioned that any proposed plan "that looks like a D.C. bailout," could be a tough sell in the Republican-controlled House. He pointed out that the last Congress -- controlled by Democrats and generally more sympathetic to the city's leaders -- passed the annual District appropriation by only three votes.
"And Newt Gingrich," he said of the new Speaker of the House, "was one of them."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Mixed Day In Trading of Treasuries

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Prices of short- and intermediate-term Treasury issues rose yesterday after a Federal Reserve official raised hopes among bond traders that the central bank would not raise interest rates again soon.
But the price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell, dropping 3/32 of a point. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.57 percent, from 7.55 percent on Wednesday. 
 Treasury notes and bills rose after Robert P. Forrestal, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, said Fed officials hoped the central bank had raised rates enough to keep inflation in check.
Peter Hirsch, head trader at Salomon Brothers, said that "the market's taking a lot of this to mean that the Fed's kind of done" raising interest rates. Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities.
The remarks by Mr. Forrestal touched off "lots of buying" of Treasuries, Mr. Hirsch said.
At the same time, turmoil in the currency markets, where the dollar plunged to its lowest level against the German mark in nearly four years, prompted investors to sell long-term bonds amid concerns that the weaker dollar would spur inflation by driving up the cost of imported goods.
Mr. Forrestal is a nonvoting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, the arm of the Fed that determines interest rate policy.
Yields of Treasury notes and bills fell even as bond yields rose. The yield for the two-year note fell 7 basis points, to 7.01 percent, its lowest yield since November. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Investors are betting that the Fed's final interest rate increase for now "either just happened, or is within three months of happening," said Mark Taborsky, who manages $130 million in bonds at Abacus Financial Group in Chicago.
The Fed last raised the Federal funds rate for overnight loans between banks on Feb. 1, the seventh increase in a year.
Economic reports yesterday suggested that the rate increases had caused the economy to slow enough to subdue inflation.
The Commerce Department, for example, said housing starts fell much more than expected last month: 9.8 percent instead of 2.7 percent. The larger-than-expected drop suggests higher mortgage rates are starting to lead to a slowdown in the housing market.
Meanwhile, the American Home Products Corporation doubled the size of its two-part note offering, to $2 billion.
The five-year notes of American Home Products were priced at $998.74 per $1,000 bond to yield 7.73 percent, or 44 basis points more than the when-issued five-year Treasury note. The 10-year notes were priced at $998.05 per $1,000 bond to yield 7.928 percent, or 54 basis points more than the 10-year note.
At these levels, analysts said, the bonds, which are rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, would offer a lower yield than similarly rated bonds.

HEADLINE: Democrats Challenge Tax Cut Plan As More Debt

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 16

 BODY:
A day after Gov. John G. Rowland released his budget, top Democrats today began their attack, saying that Mr. Rowland wants to finance his proposed tax cuts by delaying payments on state bonds.
"How can a Republican borrow money to do a tax cut?" Thomas D. Ritter, the top Democrat in the State Legislature, said. "It's like taking out a mortgage on a house to take a trip to Hawaii." 
 It was the first salvo in what is likely to be a long and contentious battle for Mr. Rowland, as he tries to push his budget through a Legislature in which Democrats control the House of Representatives and Republicans the Senate. And it began a debate on whether Mr. Rowland's budget is as revolutionary as he claims.
On Wednesday, in his address to the General Assembly, Mr. Rowland hailed his budget as a "complete revision and revitalization" of government. He said it would lower spending from the previous year's budget for the first time in 35 years, that as many as 2,500 state employees would be laid off and that the income tax and the corporate tax would be reduced.
But Democratic legislators, union leaders, women's groups and hospitals questioned the viability of the budget. And in the coming weeks, the number of groups lobbying against Mr. Rowland's proposal is sure to multiply.
At a news conference this morning, Mr. Ritter, the Speaker of the House; Moira K. Lyons, the House majority leader, and William A. DiBella, the Senate minority leader, tried to link Mr. Rowland's income tax cut -- which they referred to as "tax relief lite" because it was smaller than expected -- to his proposal to delay paying off bonds that were issued in 1991 to cover a deficit.
Under Mr. Rowland's plan, the state would not meet the 1996 deadline for retiring the remaining $328.1 million in Economic Recovery Notes, the five-year bonds used to balance the budget in 1991. Instead, Mr. Rowland has recommended refinancing the debt and putting off the final payment until 1999. This postponement would add another $28 million in interest, Democrats said.
Lorraine M. Aronson, Mr. Rowland's deputy budget chief, said the refinancing was no more related to the tax reduction than any other cut in the budget. The decision to extend payment on the bonds, she said, was made because it was too large a payment to handle in one year.
But Mr. Ritter, a state representative from Hartford, and other Democrats said that the refinancing of the bonds was just one of several examples of how the tax cut was not financed by spending cuts, as Mr. Rowland claims. And they questioned whether the sacrifices required from such steps were a reasonable compromise to achieve an income tax cut that was worth no more than $2 a week per taxpayer.
In the campaign, Mr. Rowland had pledged to veto any budget that did not cut the income tax to 3 percent, from 4.5 percent. What he offered Tuesday was a one-third reduction for only 20 percent of income-tax filers, the lowest wage earners. The remainder would only be able to take a one-third deduction on the first $6,000 of earned income for individuals and $12,000 for joint filers.

HEADLINE: Dow Inches to Record, But Falls Short of 4,000

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average, which came within two points of the 4,000 mark on Wednesday, failed again to break through it yesterday. But the Dow still closed at another record high, reaching 3,987.52, up 1.35 points.
Despite the slight gain in the Dow, declining stocks far outnumbered advancing stocks on the New York Stock Exchange, with 886 winning stocks and 1,334 losers. 
 Unlike its performance during Wednesday's session, when the Dow crossed over 3,995 at least six times before pulling back, the Dow was at its highest point at the close yesterday. It had been off by as much as 21 points during the day.
Other leading indexes were mixed. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index also closed at another record high of 485.22, up 0.68 point.
But the Nasdaq composite index fell 2.32 points, to 793.31, and far from its record high of 803.93 last March 18.
The prolonged crisis in the Mexican financial markets, which caused volatility in the currency market, weighed on stocks and bonds.
On Wednesday a large tourism conglomerate, Grupo Sidek, alarmed international investors by defaulting on $19.5 million in debt and prompting fears that the Clinton Administration's $50 billion rescue package was too little, too late. There were fears in the currency market that American financial institutions could be hurt if Mexico's economy remained unstable, and that helped pull down the dollar against the German mark and the Japanese yen.
That Mexico could keep the stock market from rising underscores the argument of some analysts that investors lack conviction in the market's prospects.
Up to now traders have been interpreting recent economic data as favorable to stocks, and bidding up the Dow on the beliefs that the economy will grow at a slower pace and the Federal Reserve will not need to raise interest rates much more to keep inflation in check. But some analysts said the financial markets could be in for a rude surprise.
"The market wants to believe that the soft landing is here and now, and the Fed doesn't have to tighten," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers. "I am on the other side of that."
Yesterday, technology stocks rallied. Hewlett-Packard rose 10 1/2, to 115 7/8, after reporting a rise of 64 percent in first-quarter profit. Another technology stock, Veritas Software, a developer of computer software, reached a 52-week high of 24 1/2, before closing at 24 3/8, up 4 5/8.
Microtouch Systems, a supplier of touch-screen systems for computers, rose 3 1/8, to 31 1/4, after reporting that fourth-quarter net income rose to 24 cents a share from 10 cents.
The declining stocks yesterday included Lin Broadcasting, which fell 10 1/4, to 130 1/4, after Morgan Stanley valued Lin's shares at $105, rather than the $155 a share that Lin is seeking. AT&T, which acquired a 52 percent stake in Lin when AT&T acquired McCaw Cellular Communications last fall, is considering buying the remaining stake in Lin.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was far above normal, with 362.2 million shares changing hands, about 9 percent higher than the daily average of 332 million shares this year.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.08 point, to 263.27, and the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 1.67 points, to 447.68.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Realizing that the world does not sing in perfect harmony, YAR marches to each culture's drum.

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane 

 BODY:
WHILE the global marketplace has become almost a cliche these days, a less-noted parallel trend is the growth of multicultural marketing geared to individual cultures. And one New York-based agency is finding success as it devotes its attention to developing campaigns for clients in many languages to reach ethnic groups in the United States and consumers in foreign countries.
The agency, YAR Communications, now creates print and broadcast ads in Polish, Chinese, Ukrainian, Spanish, Greek and dozens of other languages. It follows the school of thought that people in any market will respond best to communications from advertisers with cultural authenticity -- an authenticity that goes beyond language to encompass core values and traditions. The other main school of thought in global advertising reasons quite differently: It maintains that one message universal enough to be understood in any language is the most powerful. 
 Yuri Radzievsky, president of YAR and its co-founder with his wife, Anna, said: "Understanding the culture comes before understanding the language. Our advertising is developed from within the culture that says to consumers, 'We really understand you.' "
This approach has afforded YAR a prominence in the realm of agencies that specialize in foreign-language campaigns. Today YAR has billings of close to $120 million, 130 employees who together speak 30 languages and clients like Merrill Lynch, Citibank and the Discovery Channel.
YAR's more intimate approach to global advertising can be seen in the ads it created for the AT&T Corporation for use in Poland and Russia. The ads use different visual and verbal cues to signal consumers in a tone that Mr. Radzievsky and his staff believe is appropriate to each culture. In Poland the ads are laden with sentiment and poetry, and in Russia a similar ad contains more sarcasm and music.
Sandra Shellenberger, a district advertising manager for AT&T, said that she and her colleagues backed this approach to the hilt. "You've got to develop the concept in the culture," she added. "Translating English ads into Polish or Russian just doesn't work."
The Radzievskys fled to the United States from the former Soviet Union in 1973, where they had worked in television, and started an agency called Euramerica two years later. Their aim from the start was to adopt advertising materials to the culture of their audiences, rather than merely translate ads originally created in English.
Euramerica was sold to Ogilvy & Mather in 1981 and sold again to Macmillan in 1989, after which Mr. Radzievsky left the company. Soon afterward, the couple established YAR, a name that represents their initials; Mrs. Radzievsky is executive vice president.
Over the years, the Radzievskys have discovered they have to sell each ad campaign twice. "First we have to explain it to the client, who does not understand the language of the ad," Mr. Radzievsky said. "Then we have to sell it to the audience."
For Merrill Lynch, YAR created print ads for Russian readers who were unfamiliar with the concept of individual investing. In one of its cultural-based campaigns, it redesigned the brokerage firm's stylistic bull logo -- the American version reminded Russians more of food than finance -- and used the slogan "Your Personal Interpreter of the Free Economy Language" to impress them with Merrill Lynch's expertise.
Ads for Citibank in Mandarin and Cantonese, featuring expressions with which viewers could identify, were run on Chinese-language TV stations in New York and California. For Mack Trucks, the bulldog logo could not be used in China because dogs are considered an inferior species there. YAR substituted a symbol of a horse, which the agency's Chinese experts realized would also give a sense of the trucks' horsepower.
Perhaps it was only fitting that Mr. Radzievsky, who became a citizen of the United States in 1978, opened an office of his agency last year in Moscow, his hometown in what is now the independent nation of Russia. "Now we can provide our bank of knowledge there, too," he said.

HEADLINE: McCall Warns of Deficit Ahead

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 16

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall warned today that Gov. George E. Pataki's budget and tax proposals could lead to large deficits in the coming years.
Among other things, Mr. McCall, a Democrat, said the Republican Governor had "back-loaded" the first phase of his four-year income tax plan so that about $180 million of its $720 million value would be pushed into next year. 
 "What has been presented is only a small down payment on a large multi-year tax reduction program," Mr. McCall said.
The eventual value of the tax-cut plan balloons to $6.8 billion after four years.
Mr. McCall said the state would be faced with a potential deficit of $2.8 billion already built into the 1996-97 state fiscal year.
"As a result, the spending cuts needed next year may be proportionally larger than those included this year," the Comptroller said.
In his first budget proposal, a $32.4 billion plan for the 1995-96 state fiscal year that begins April 1, Governor Pataki has already called for some sharp spending cuts. He wants more than $1.2 billion trimmed from Medicaid and would cut some welfare benefits up to 25 percent.
There was no immediate comment from Governor Pataki on the Comptroller's report.
Mr. Pataki has not denied that the cost of his tax-cut plan increases greatly in future years, but he has argued the cuts will stimulate the economy so much that everything will more than balance.
Mr. McCall's warning came as he issued the first of several planned reports on the Governor's budget, a move by the Comptroller to become more involved in the budgeting.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Falls by Daily Limit On Decline in New Housing

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Lumber futures plunged their daily trading limit yesterday after the Government reported that housing construction had dropped to its lowest level in a year.
On other commodity markets, cotton futures surged to 14-year highs while energy futures advanced. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.14 point, to 234.22. 
 The Commerce Department said housing starts plunged 9.8 percent in January to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.38 million. The weakness was seen in every region. Analysts attributed the decline to rising interest rates and predicted that the slide would continue in the coming months.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, lumber for March delivery fell the $10 limit, settling at $318.30 for 1,000 board feet.
January's decline in housing starts was the largest since a 21 percent plunge in January 1994, when winter storms curtailed construction. But this January, weather conditions were more favorable over much of the country.
"There was no question that the market was not looking for a 10 percent drop," said Curt Cunningham, president of the Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle. "When people saw those figures, they said, 'Just get me out; those numbers look horrible.' "
Elsewhere, cotton futures soared to 14-year highs after a prominent cotton merchant, William Dunavant of the Dunavant Commodity Corporation, predicted that United States supplies would run out in August.
Cotton for March delivery rose 0.99 cent, to 95.95 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange; the actively traded May contract soared 1.94 cents, to 95.23 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Nynex, Ending Monopoly, Would Let Cable Business Offer Home Phone Service

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 16

 BODY:
In a move that would end its monopoly on local telephone service in the metropolitan area, Nynex said today that it would cooperate with the Cablevision Systems Corporation's efforts to enter the residential phone market.
If approved by state regulators, the agreement would create the nation's first head-to-head battle for telephone customers between a telephone giant and a major cable television provider. 
 Regulators and investment analysts say the agreement, the first between a cable operator and one of the seven regional Bell operating companies, is a breakthrough in efforts to spur competition in the residential phone business. They say it could not only lead to lower rates for customers, but it could compel other telephone companies to follow Nynex's lead.
"When you have an agreement between two such major players in the market, it's a breakthrough for competition," said Lisa Rosenblum, deputy chairwoman of the New York State Public Service Commission.
Officials of Cablevision Lightpath, a subsidiary of Cablevision Systems, said that after tests are completed this year, they could start offering telephone service to residential customers next year. Yonkers -- where Cablevision has been experimenting with a number of upgraded services to its customers -- would probably be the first place where phone service would be offered, they said.
"What this means for us is that we now can proceed with more confidence down the path we want: to offer residential customers and small businesses a choice and value in local telephone service," said Joseph Cece, president of Cablevision Lightpath. The agreement is subject to the approval of the Public Service Commission, which has been seeking to increase competition in the telephone business and other industries it regulates.
Last year, Time Warner Inc., another major cable company, announced plans to offer phone service to its customers in Rochester through a similar arrangement with Frontier Corporation, an independent telephone company. But the pact between Nynex and Cablevision is much more significant because the market in which the two companies would compete is so much larger.
While Nynex has 7.5 million business and residential customers throughout the state, Cablevision, based in Woodbury, L.I., has about one million subscribers, concentrated on Long Island and in New York City.
W. John Aronsohn, a consumer communications analyst with the Yankee Group of Boston, said the agreement announced today was a harbinger of immense changes in the telecommunications industry. For as phone companies are looking to carry cable television transmissions over their wires, so are cable providers seeking to do battle over the dial tone.
"We're on the cusp of a major groundswell of cable operators entering the competitive telephone business," he said.
Mr. Aronsohn said there were advantages to both companies in forging the agreement. For Cablevision, he said, the pact is a matter of practicality: its phones must be connected to a large network to provide customers with reliable service that reaches everywhere.
For Nynex, the agreement has more political advantages: The company, Mr. Aronsohn said, wants to show Federal regulators that it encourages competition, in hopes the Government will relax some of the restrictions on the aspects of the phone business in which the regional Bells are permitted to operate.
"Nynex wants to get into the long-distance business, and in order to do it, they need to show good faith to the F.C.C. that they are willing to work with other companies that are trying to get into the local phone business," Mr. Aronsohn said, referring to the Federal Communications Commission, which regulates the long-distance business.
Jack Goldberg, vice president for network interconnection marketing and sales for Nynex, said the company wanted to remove the obstacles for other companies seeking to enter its business so that the Government would do the same for Nynex.
"We are deliberately and pro-actively eliminating the technological and economic barriers that prevent others from becoming full local telephone service providers so that sooner rather than later we can be a full-service provider," Mr. Goldberg said.
Under the agreement, the companies would pay each other for calls ending in each other's networks, although Cablevision officials say that the way the payments would be structured is under review by the Public Service Commission. And in what regulators and analysts regard as a crucial provision, Nynex would allow customers to keep the telephone numbers assigned them by Nynex, even if they switched local service to Cablevision.
Mr. Aronsohn said that the agreement carried possible pitfalls for both companies. Because Cablevision holds a virtual monopoly on cable service on Long Island, where a majority of its New York customers live, "the risk for Nynex is losing a significant portion of their local franchise," he said.
Cablevision, on the other hand, might encounter resistance from its own customers, who might not trust the company with their telephone service.
"Cable operators historically have a bad reputation for service," Mr. Aronsohn said. "Cable customers who are used to having trouble getting through to a customer representative may be reluctant to entrust a service to their cable operator as vital as the telephone."

HEADLINE: Homes and Jobless Data Indicate a Slowdown

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Construction starts on new homes fell in January and new unemployment claims jumped last week, the Government said today, sure signs that rising interest rates are slowing the economy down.
The Commerce Department said starts of new homes and apartments dropped 9.8 percent in January to a seasonally adjusted rate of 1.38 million a year. 
 It was the biggest decline in building activity since a 21 percent drop in January 1994, and it was accompanied by an 8.6 decline in applications for building permits, pointing to further weakness for housing in coming months.
Separately, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing new applications for unemployment pay jumped by 20,000 last week, to 338,000, the biggest weekly rise since mid-1994 and the highest level in a month.
Analysts said seven interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve in the last year were clearly showing up as corporations and consumers faced stiffer borrowing charges.
"The economy is going over the edge of the table now to a lower growth rate as a result of the cumulative impact of these interest-rate rises," Robert R. Davis, an economist at the Savings and Community Bankers Association of America, said.
Housing traditionally is the most interest-rate sensitive sector of the economy. The fact that building has fallen sharply in every region of the country and permit applications have fallen in three of the last four months show the January plunge was "not a fluke," Mr. Davis added.
It was the second consecutive month that starts declined, though December building was down only a revised six-tenths of 1 percent instead of the previously reported 1 percent fall.
Michael Carliner, economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said builders had grown more cautious and the industry already anticipated a significant drop in construction from 1994 levels.
Part of the January decline in activity "reflects the fact that the cost of carrying inventory is up, and the inventory itself is up," Mr. Carliner said, referring to the growing supply of finished but unsold homes on the market.
The drop in January building occurred entirely in single-family homes: starts fell 12.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.07 million units.
It was the lowest level for the important single-family-home category in nearly two years.
The Labor Department said that the 338,000 new jobless claims were the most since 339,000 claims were filed during the week ended Jan. 14. But the four-week moving average of weekly jobless claims fell for the fourth straight week, dropping to 326,750 from the previous week's average of 327,000.

HEADLINE: 3 Hotels for the World's Crossroads;
Dollars, Not Design, Will Decide the Choice for Times Sq.

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
To some, it may look like the ninth circle of hell, but for others, Times Square is money. And dollars, not design, are likely to be the deciding factor in the competition to build a new hotel on Eighth Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets.
Designs for three proposals were submitted yesterday to the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the New York City Economic Development Corporation, the agencies responsible for the redevelopment of 42d Street. In April, the project is scheduled to be awarded to the developer who can persuade these agencies that his is the most attractive financial package. Even so, the competition's three contenders are worth considering on the basis of design. Assuming that one actually gets built, it's a building, not a bank account, that we will have to look at. 
 The 57,500-square-foot project site, which was acquired last October with $35 million in city money, extends about halfway east along 42d Street, toward Seventh Avenue, in addition to the Eighth Avenue parcel between 42d and 43d Streets. The design guidelines call for a mix of retail and entertainment along the 42d Street extension.
All three finalists -- Arquitectonica, Michael Graves, Zaha Hadid -- are distinguished architects, all have yet to complete a building in New York City, and any one could be counted on to raise the city's sagging architectural profile. And for this project, each architect has the advantage of working with an unofficial collaborator, Robert A. M. Stern, the architect primarily responsible for drafting the design guidelines for the redevelopment of 42d Street. If nothing else, the hotel competition demonstrates that the guidelines have succeeded in their goal of discouraging architectural uniformity. Variety is the spice of Times Square, and the three architects have created a savory range of designs.
Michael Graves's plan, designed for the development of Marriott International and Triarc Equities, is appealingly democratic. Most of the hotel's 945 rooms would be run as a Courtyard Inn, Marriott's low-cost chain, a plan that would certainly honor the spirit of Times Square as a popular tourist attraction. Appealing, too, is the idea of hiring an architect of Mr. Graves's stature to design a low-cost venture.
The hotel part of the plan is a classical skyscraper, sheathed in a soft palette of colored brick: pink, ochre, blue and green. Rising 470 feet in a series of gentle setbacks, Mr. Graves's midtown campanile is a laid-back landmark, dignified but unassertive. A large square illuminated clock is the tower's most flamboyant feature.
Things get livelier at the street level, starting with a big red apple at the corner of Eighth Avenue and 42d Street. Housing a subway entrance at its base, a cafe upstairs, the giant fruit recalls a similar proposal put forward some years back by Robert Venturi as a symbolic Times Square centerpiece. And Mr. Graves's design for the 42d Street part of the site is also Venturian in its pop sensibility. A parade of signs and billboards marches along the street, creating a facade for shops and for what is perhaps the plan's most ambitious feature, a 2,000-seat theater.
Mr. Graves's is the most traditional of the schemes, not only because his tower is classical in spirit, but also because the plan replicates the traditional Broadway pattern of subordinating buildings to signs.
Yet to continue the tradition of masking buildings with signs is to miss one of the major opportunities offered by the design guidelines: the chance to create architecture that is in itself a sign. The other two proposals accomplish this in strikingly different ways.
The most visionary of the three proposals is undoubtedly that prepared by the London-based architect Zaha Hadid for the development team of Milstein Properties and Weiler Arnow Management. The developers have taken a breathtaking risk by hiring Ms. Hadid, an architect who, though immensely gifted, has thus far built little.
Beyond that, this team has grasped a critical challenge facing developers in Times Square. The retail and entertainment uses envisioned for 42d Street are mostly geared toward consumption. What is usually overlooked is the opportunity to make Times Square an entertainment production center as well. Ms. Hadid's plan meets this challenge by incorporating HBO production studios into the 42d Street extension. Stores would be housed on the extension's ground floor.
For the hotel, to be managed by Hilton, Ms. Hadid has come up with a dazzlingly original concept. Her 48-story, glass-sheathed tower would become, in effect, a vertical street. Public rooms -- cocktail lounges, health clubs, restaurants -- would be threaded through the entire height of the tower, interspersed with blocks of hotel rooms. The building's different uses would be expressed architecturally by the shaping of the exterior into a powerful composition of angular, crystalline forms.
Signs, too, would be scattered over the surface of the tower's height. Ms. Hadid envisions that most of the signs will consist of images projected onto the tower's glass surfaces. But this concept raises a major problem with her design. Ms. Hadid is an exceedingly meticulous architect. And the beauty of her design depends to a large extent on an idea for signage that may be difficult to realize technically, and hard to sell to commercial advertisers. Even if these problems were solved, the result is likely to have an esthetic uniformity that the design guidelines were expressly devised to overcome. In short, the level of this project's architectural sophistication is extraordinarily high. Too high, perhaps, for gaudy, bawdy 42d Street.
Two decades ago, the architecture critic Peter Blake half-jokingly suggested that the best way cities could deal with urban problems was to turn all or part of them over to the people at Disney. Since then, those who value urban diversity have had good reason to fear the conversion of cities into theme park versions of themselves. But when a plan comes along that's as good as the one submitted by the Disney Development Company, in a joint venture with the Tishman Urban Development Corporation, one wants to send out for mouse ears.
Arquitectonica, the Miami firm primarily responsible for the design, has already demonstrated considerable talent for creating popular, snazzy buildings without sacrificing its reputation for serious architecture. In New York, Arcquitectonica offers a jazz version of the apocalypse: a stylized architectural image of a comet crashing at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.
The comet, or meteor shape, as the architects call it, is a 10-story building with a jagged roof line, covered with glass mosaics depicting the Statue of Liberty, the Guggenheim Museum and other New York landmarks. Contained behind this tourist's scrapbook are 50 time-share apartments.
The tower rising above is a glass slab split into two sides by a slim, illuminated curve. Shooting light up into the sky at night, the curve will resemble a comet's streaking tail. There's no impact crater here, just shopping and entertainment. A 400-foot commercial complex, designed by D'Agostino, Izzo, Quirk, Architects, stretches along 42d Street, heavily encrusted with signs.
The entire design is remarkably intelligent in the way it fits the pieces together. The changes in scale, function and esthetic approach; the transition from the abstract forms of the tower to the figurative images of the signs: these elements adhere strictly to the design guidelines, but kiss them with inspiration. Forty-second Street, in its present form, already looks like a meteor has struck, but this design is an explosion of life.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The finalists in a competition to design a hotel on Eighth Avenue and 42d Street submitted their proposals yesterday. The architect Zaha Hadid would build a glass-sheathed tower, above left. The building by Arquitectonica, a Miami firm, evokes a crashing comet, right. Michael Graves, below, proposes a classical tower. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York's Health and Economy Will Feel Home-Care Cuts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gov. George E. Pataki proposes to slash the New York Medicaid budget by $1.2 billion. His proposals would eviscerate the long-term home care system by eliminating or seriously limiting many programs that provide community-based care. 
 The home care agencies of New York City provide home attendant services to more than 65,000 clients yearly and employ an equal number of full- and part-time home attendants. Singled out by the Governor for the budget ax, these services may be lost despite their vital importance as an interrelated part of the health care delivery system.
For many years New York State policy has limited nursing home space and has encouraged nursing facilities to take only patients with high-skill needs. Many patients who would be placed in nursing homes in other states -- including those with Alzheimer's disease and other chronic illnesses requiring long-term care -- are in the home attendant program here.
About 6,000 of these patients in the city require 24-hour home care. Under the Governor's proposal these patients would have to be institutionalized -- or manage with 100 hours or less of personal care a month.
The cuts in personal care -- coupled with elimination of the assisted living program, adult day care in nursing homes, the long-term home health care program and housekeeping for the home-bound elderly and disabled -- inevitably would increase the number of patients in need of nursing home beds. But the Governor has also called for a moratorium on new nursing home beds. Where are these sick people to go?
Either the result will be high hospital costs, as patients are hospitalized more frequently and for longer periods, or acutely and chronically ill poor people will suffer. The proposed budget creates the potential for a health care crisis in New York of unprecedented proportions.
Half of the home attendant program is financed by the Federal Government, and the people who work as home attendants -- nearly all New York residents -- paid $28 million in state taxes and $15 million in city taxes in 1994.
Ninety percent of the budgets of the agencies that provide these services go to wages and benefits for home attendants. These wages are pumped into the city's poor and working-class neighborhoods, where desirable jobs with good wages and health benefits are critically needed.
Moreover, last year, 1,000 people on welfare became productively employed as home attendants. Where does the Governor think the welfare clients he wants to put to work will find jobs if he eliminates these?
Costs can be controlled while providing safe, cost-effective health care to all who need it. Home attendant agencies are working with city officials on programs that have saved tens of millions. Much more can be done, and the saving proposed by the Governor can probably be met or exceeded without harming patients.
 
JAMES V. CAREY
President, Home Care
Council of New York City
New York, Feb. 7, 1995

HEADLINE: For Children

BYLINE: By Dulcie Leimbach 

 BODY:

'How the World Got Wisdom'
 On Stage Productions
 Emily Dickinson Theater at P.S. 75
 735 West End Avenue (at 95th Street)
 (212) 666-1716
 Recommended ages: 3 and up
 Through March 12
If only all greetings were as generous as the one at this show of West African stories. The audience is greeted with a funga, a traditional welcome dance, in which Tambu, a musician, plays drums and creates an irresistible warm mood. When the six dancing actors then come across the stage in their earth-colored African costumes, the collective mood flies higher. 
 The exuberance continues through the telling of four tales and several story-songs from the Ivory Coast. Children will be mesmerized (drums work wonders) and humored, as will adults.
The first tale, "How Man and Woman Were Made," is conveyed through two characters, Moon and Toad. They bicker like siblings and grow vicious (Moon kills Toad, but this is actually a funny moment). In all this rivalry, a man and a woman are created. In the second tale, "Talk," objects and animals speak to a befuddled farmer ("Leave me alone," a yam says), but he wises up by realizing that everything -- a stone, a dog, the yam -- is sacred.
The story-songs are brief messengers of music. In "Toumou," an actor becomes a caterpillar by wrapping himself in green cloth. Then he sings an African song and afterward children in the audience are beckoned onto the stage to prance around. At the end of the show, the actors do a lamba, a celebratory dance in which they show off their skills.
The company has wisely chosen humorous tales with bold characters that teach moral lessons about tolerance and getting along with people. Children learn through the characters' actions and dialogue how certain behaviors can be boorish; one chief, for example, is awfully officious and children see through him very quickly.
Tickets to the 70-minute program are $8 for adults and $6 for students and children. Performances are Saturdays and Sundays at 3 P.M.; there will be special holiday performances on Wednesday and Thursday at 11 A.M.
 
'Where's the Birdie?'
 Sesame Street Live
 The Paramount
 33d Street and Seventh Avenue
 Manhattan
 (212) 465-MSG1 or (212) 307-7171
 Recommended ages: 1 to 5
 Through Feb. 26
The Birdie is the 8-foot-tall, hypersensitive Big Bird, who has disappeared because he mistakenly thought his friends had forgotten his birthday.
Big Bird's friends -- Elmo, Cookie Monster, Ernie, Bert, Oscar, Prairie Dawn and others -- try to find him in six short Broadway-style numbers. In a scene with the inimitable Bert and Ernie, Bert is "naked," as he says, in a tub and Ernie sings "Rubber Duckie" (which the audience sings, too). Then the lights go out and everyone with a Big Bird flashlight, which cost $5, flashes it.
To thicken the feathery plot after Big Bird is found, a Muppet named P. T. Barnswallow schemes to turn him into a caged bird in a vaudeville show. In another scene, a scary moment occurs when the Count polkas against a backdrop of spooky trees. At the end, a surprise party for Big Bird features a gigantic cake.
The show is 90 minutes, about half an hour too long for toddlers. The people in the audience get to clap, tug on their ears, flap their arms and jump in their seats. During a "13-minute" intermission, you can chase after your children and spend money on extras like balloons ($3), the flashlights and cotton candy ($5). The annual program used to be held in Madison Square Garden's arena, but is now in the Paramount, where the stairs in the tiered seating area are troublesome for parents with children who like to wander. The Muppets rarely ventured past the most expensive seating around the stage, ignoring about two-thirds of the audience, but the children had a great time anyway.
The Paramount entrance is at Seventh Avenue and 32d Street. Tickets are $11.50 to $19.50; performances this weekend are tonight at 7 and tomorrow and Sunday at 10:30 A.M. and 2 and 5 P.M. Performance schedule: Wednesdays through Sundays in the morning, early and late afternoon.
 
'How to Buy Your Own Bike'
 Brooklyn Children's Museum
 145 Brooklyn Avenue (at St. Marks Avenue)
 Crown Heights
 (718) 735-4400
 Recommended ages: 8 to 15
 Sunday
They're thinking about bicycles in Brooklyn. How to raise the money to buy them, that is. Byron Perry teaches children the art of being an entrepreneur, even without start-up capital. His series of lectures are called Kids Inc., and they're about running your own business.
"The bicycle is a metaphor," Mr. Perry explained. "I'm really talking about how to have goals and achieve them." Most children would agree that the goal of buying a bicycle is an excellent place to start, nevertheless.
Children are naturally ambitious, Mr. Perry said, especially when it comes to money. Last time he taught this class, there were junior entrepreneurs in the audience who shared their experiences, which Mr. Perry encourages (there is also a question-and-answer period).
Mr. Perry tells the story of one boy who bought candy and hired his cousin to sell it to classmates, neighbors and family at a higher price. But the boy dismissed the cousin because he ignored work rules. (First lesson: Don't hire kin.)
"Children have to be creative to enhance their income," Mr. Perry added. "There are many ways beside selling lemonade: like making arts and crafts and selling them at shows; doing odd jobs for neighbors." Children feel independent and comfortable if they have economic clout.
The 45-minute workshop, at 1:30 and 3 P.M., is free with admission to the museum, suggested at $3.

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Sally Field in Three Nights and Seven Decades

 BODY:
Sally Field continues to do remarkably well by television. She got started 30 years ago as "Gidget" and followed that closely with "The Flying Nun," which she might understandably want to forget. Then in 1977 her Emmy-winning performance in the drama "Sybil" paved the way for a film career that would earn two Oscars, in 1979 for "Norma Rae" and in 1984 for "Places in the Heart." Sunday she returns to television in the kind of bravura role coveted by actresses everywhere.
"A Woman of Independent Means," a six-hour, three-part mini-series based on a 1978 novel by Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey, follows for some seven decades the story of Bess Alcott, from her Dallas marriage to her fourth-grade sweetheart to the birth of three children to the fussings with grandchildren. It's a panoramic portrait, crammed with moments of joy and tragedy, all arranged around Bess's getting to the point where she is "finally beginning to understand nothing is given to us for keeps." 
 But there is continuity, and that theme is amplified in devices like a wedding ring that keeps being passed from mother to daughter or a song like "You Tell Me Your Dream, I'll Tell You Mine," which becomes a standard at family occasions. Robert Greenwald, the director, conveys the passage of time not by a clutter of "three years later" graphics but by changes in fashion and the appearance of new products like cars and cameras. In fact, each two-hour segment is shot in different camera styles, beginning with old-fashioned dolly shots and ending with hand-held techniques.
To some extent, Bess is less a woman of independent means than a woman of privilege. Raised in a well-to-do Texas family, she inherits her mother's considerable fortune at an early age. There are setbacks, but someone always seems to be around to make sure that Bess's stocks and bonds lose none of their value. In fact, by the final installment, spirited Bess gets just a wee bit tiresome with her knowing-what's-best-for-you antics. Viewers might be forgiven wanting to know less about Bess and more about her patient, self-effacing maid.
Make no mistake: this is Ms. Field's party, and she makes the most of it, especially in some wrenching scenes of heartbreaking loss. This actress can be powerful. The rest of the cast largely labors in roles that are decidedly supporting, though an unusually subdued Ron Silver gives Mr. Fineman, Bess's special friend, a most effective turn. Only the remarkable Brenda Fricker ("My Left Foot") manages to steal scenes from Ms. Field with a matriarchal impunity that is stunning. Even a star can't have everything. JOHN J. O'CONNOR
 
FREEDOM TO HATE
Tomorrow, WLIW, 5 A.M.
(Channel 21 in New York)
The main interest of this somewhat scattered report about anti-Semitism in Russia lies in the interviews with heads of hate groups that are now cultivating the country's old tradition of Jew-bashing and its current political and economic turmoil. The spokesmen focused on here, like leaders of Pamyat, the right-wing party that has done unsettlingly well in elections, seem slightly mad and more than slightly clownish. But as the program suggests, history warns against discounting the horrors that clowns and madmen can inflict. WALTER GOODMAN

HEADLINE: Babbitt Likens Move to Kill Science Agencies to 'Book Burning'

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said tonight that a Republican-backed proposal to abolish the United States Geological Survey and two other science agencies in the Interior Department was tantamount to "book burning."
"In 17th-century Portugal, after a major earthquake devastated that country, the political leaders responded by burning a few more heretics at the stake," Mr. Babbitt said in remarks prepared for the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which opened here this evening. "Today, the response to California earthquakes is to burn the United States Geological Survey." 
 In a "crude and misguided attack," Mr. Babbitt said, the Republicans' Contract With America also proposed to eliminate the National Biological Service and the United States Bureau of Mines.
Asked for a response, Tony Blankley, press secretary for Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, said: "Mr. Babbitt has always been a little odd. How closing down some bureaucratic agency constitutes book burning is only a conclusion that the good Mr. Babbitt can reach. I am baffled by Babbitt."
The main reason for seeking to eliminate the three science agencies is reportedly to cut the budget deficit by an estimated $3.3 billion over five years. Some Republicans have also declared war on what they see as a bloated Federal bureaucracy.
Mr. Babbitt said the attack on science was motivated by politicians who wanted to prevent "overregulation of our natural resources" under statutes like the Endangered Species Act and the Clean Water Act."
"While I may disagree with their goals, the content and form of regulatory policy is always a proper subject for political debate," he said. "Let's have at it. But proclaiming that good science should take the fall for political differences amounts to a declaration that there should be no science except that science which produces politically correct answers."
Mr. Babbitt acknowledged that Federal science agencies were sometimes biased toward the attitudes of politically appointed regulators who supervised them. Such criticisms should be "taken seriously," he said.
In defending the use of science to protect natural resources, Mr. Babbitt described a comprehensive forest plan developed recently for the Pacific Northwest. It abandons the old policy of exploiting 10 acres of land for every 1 that is preserved, he said, in favor of providing biological diversity and sustainable economic activity over the entire landscape.
Mr. Babbitt stressed that the three agencies under attack were limited to analyzing data to provide information on natural resources and development. "They don't regulate, they don't enforce and they don't take actions against people or businesses," he said. "What they do is insulate science from the regulators and the politicians."

HEADLINE: Governor Rowland Meets Reality

 BODY:
Connecticut's new Governor, John Rowland, has yielded to fiscal reality and toned down his promise of instant tax relief for all. His budget offers instead a quick cut -- on borrowed money -- for people with low and mid-level incomes.
He made no mention of his principal campaign pledge, to repeal the state income tax altogether, though his spokesman says repeal is still the goal. Perhaps in time the Governor will yield the rest of the way and leave that sensible tax in place. The alternative is a return to dependence on sales taxes, a far less dependable source of revenue. 
 Economic recovery from the recession has been slower in Connecticut than elsewhere in the Northeast, in large part because the state was too heavily dependent on defense contracts, already shrinking when the recession hit. Limited economic expansion means limited revenue growth, which leaves little scope for tax cuts beyond those that can be paid for by reasonable cuts from a budget of roughly $9.5 billion -- or by costly borrowing. Indeed, fiscal responsibility lost out to politics in Governor Rowland's proposal to keep the budget balanced with borrowed money while he cuts taxes. The Governor boasts that his plan cuts spending for the first time in decades -- symbolically significant, perhaps, but in dollar terms only $80 million. This is a two-year plan, and in the second year spending rises again, by twice that amount.
The political balance in Connecticut is the same as in New York; a Republican is now Governor, but control of the Legislature is split. Thus there is no certainty that Mr. Rowland can prevail. The heavy cuts he wants in welfare programs are particularly onerous. Some aid to local governments would be cut and compressed into block grants instead of specifically earmarked as aid payments, but this may hurt less than feared because he would also eliminate some state mandates. One smart innovation is an incentive -- more aid -- for communities that pool social services regionally.
The limited income tax reduction that Governor Rowland proposes would at least make the tax mildly progressive -- 4.5 percent at the top, 3 percent lower down. That's the right way to go. Repeal is the wrong way.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Pressure Rises For N.A.A.C.P. To Oust Chief

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
With critics of William F. Gibson claiming that nearly half the board members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People have turned against him, the group's former executive director, Benjamin L. Hooks, has added his voice to those who would like to see Dr. Gibson step down as chairman.
Mr. Hooks termed Dr. Gibson an "inept leader" who allowed the debt of the civil rights organization to soar. His comments, the first time he has publicly expressed dissatisfaction with Dr. Gibson's leadership, come at a time when the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization is $ 4.5 million in debt, faces an audit of its top officers' spending and is being torn apart by internal bickering. 
 Dr. Gibson is up for re-election as chairman of the 64-member board when it meets on Saturday in New York. He is being challenged by Myrlie Evers-Williams, widow of the slain civil rights figure Medgar Evers.
Today, with both sides stepping up the pressure in the re-election battle, the organization was hit by a new lawsuit, this one by a former female employee of the organization who accused six current or former N.A.A.C.P. officials, including Dr. Gibson, of sexual harassment and sexual discrimination.
Stephanie Rones, a former lawyer in the N.A.A.C.P.'s legal department, claimed in a $ 2.8 million suit filed in District of Columbia Superior Court that she was passed over for promotions, that she was subjected to advances that ultimately led to sexual relations with an official in the organization and that she was unfairly dismissed.
Mr. Hooks, who retired as executive director in 1993, said Dr. Gibson allowed the debt of the civil rights organization to balloon during the 15-month tenure of Benjamin Chavis, Mr. Hook's successor.
Moreover, Mr. Hooks contended that Dr. Gibson presided over disastrous financial losses stemming from management of a Hollywood awards program sponsored by the N.A.A.C.P. The program, known as the Image Awards, was run by some of Dr. Gibson's closest associates on the board.
As a result, Mr. Hooks said, Dr. Gibson should be replaced even if charges of financial impropriety that have been leveled against the chairman prove unfounded.
"As far as I am concerned, if a chairman gets hold of the Image Awards and loses that much money, hires a Chavis and gives him no supervision and we go into that much debt, and has allowed all this to fester, you don't have to say that he has a defect in his moral character," Mr. Hooks said.
The lawsuit filed today is certain to add to the problems that have plagued the organization in recent months. No search has yet been started for a new executive director to replace Mr. Chavis, who was dismissed last August after being accused of financial mismanagement and sexual harassment.
Roger Wilkins, a history professor at George Mason University and the nephew of Roy Wilkins, a former executive director of the organization. said, "My view is that if the board re-elects Gibson, then it is pretty close to sounding the death knell of the N.A.A.C.P."
Dr. Gibson's position on as chairman was dealt another blow this evening when it was announced that two candidates who oppose him were elected to the board as a result of balloting by the N.A.A.C.P. branches. The two were Julian Bond, a former board member, and Jesse Turner Jr., the son of the group's former treasuer.
Also re-elected to the board was Hazel Dukes, the former head of New York Off Track Betting Corp., whose term on the board had expired.
Ms. Dukes also filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in New York today asking that the election for board chairman not take place until an accounting firm retained to audit the spending of top N.A.A.C.P. officials is allowed to present at least a preliminary report to the board. A judge has scheduled a hearing on the matter Friday morning.
In October, the board voted to have an outside company conduct the audit, but the work had been delayed until recently because of lack of funds to pay for the work and, Dr. Gibson's critics charge, because he sought to limit the audit's scope.
This week Dr. Gibson's supporters said that since the company had been at work for such a short period, it would be allowed only to present a status report to the board and not provide any details concerning spending by top officials, including Dr. Gibson.
Dr. Gibson has been under fire since last August, when the columnist Carl Rowan said the organization's chairman had charged nearly $ 500,000 in airline tickets, hotels, car rentals, meals and other items on an American Express card provided by the N.A.A.C.P. since 1986.
In the same period Dr. Gibson also received nearly $ 300,000 in expense checks, according to Mr. Rowan. Inspection of some of the canceled checks indicate they were for "board travel and office expenses"
Mr. Hooks and other former N.A.A.C.P. officials said the checks to Dr. Gibson constituted a stipend that averaged about $ 3,000 a month. Although paying a monthly stipend to the organization's chairman has been a common practice, former officials said previous chairmen received far less than Dr. Gibson, and provided detailed accounting of how the money was spent.
Dr. Gibson has fought back. Today he announced that the organization had signed an agreement with Don Cornelius, the television producer, to put on the Image Awards show. The contract with Mr. Cornelius, a former producer of the show "Show Train," is being cited by Dr. Gibson's supporters as an example of his ability to raise money.
The chairman also sent a letter to all board members denying the charges that have been leveled against him and urging the board to support him.
But Dr. Gibson's effort was strained again today when Ms. Rones named him in her lawsuit. She also named Mr. Chavis; Earl Shinhoster, the acting executive director; Fred Rasheed, the acting deputy; Dennis C. Hayes, the group's general counsel, and Lewis Meyers, a former deputy director with whom Ms. Rones maintained that she had had a one-time sexual liaison.
In a telephone interview today, Mr. Myers said he knew nothing of the lawsuit but found the charges "scurrilous and defamatory." He denied having any sexual relationship with Ms. Rones and said he would be talking to a lawyer to explore the possibility of filing a countersuit charging her with libel.
The other officials named in the suit could not be reached for comment. But some current and former officials dismissed the accusations of Ms. Rones, saying that they thought her relationship with Mr. Myers was consentual and that she had expressed a desire last May to leave the organization to establish an institute on race and gender.
And the officials, including some who have been critical of the current leadership, questioned the timing of the lawsuit just days before the board meeting in New York.
Ms. Rones, a 37-year-old Georgetown Law School graduate who had worked for the Washington City Council before joining the N.A.A.C.P., charges that a pervasive atmosphere of intimidation existed in the organization's Baltimore headquarters. Inequalities there, her lawsuit contends, ranged from gross imbalances in pay between male and female employees to the creation of "an atmosphere in the workplace where it was considered permissible to take sexual advantage of women employees."
In an interview today, Ms. Rones said she had been considering leaving the organization at the time of her termination because she hoped to work on women's issues among blacks. "I was thinking of starting a separate organization, and I had talked to a couple of people about that."
Ms. Rones's lawsuit maintains that her job was terminated because of her outspokenness on women's issues and that at least one other staff member, Ann Taylor, of the N.A.A.C.P.'s economic development department, was also dismissed because of her views on women's rights.

The program was "Soul Train," not "Show Train."

HEADLINE: Slash Welfare Benefits -- for Bureaucrats

BYLINE: By Steven Craig and James Taranto; Steven Craig, associate professor of economics at the University of Houston, conducted the 1992 study "A Report Card on State Spending" for City Journal. James Taranto is senior editor of the magazine.

 BODY:
Coming on top of Gov. George Pataki's proposed cuts in welfare and Medicaid, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's new budget, which calls for even more, has drawn predictable cries of outrage from advocates for the poor. With the state and city facing budget gaps in the billions of dollars, the Governor and Mayor have little choice. But even if they did, these cuts would be overdue.
Spending on aid to the poor, which accounts for more than a quarter of all government outlays in the state, is vastly disproportionate to that in other states. And the evidence shows that Albany and the city are spending neither wisely nor effectively. 
 In 1992, we published a study in City Journal showing that in 1989 Albany and local governments spent $1,401 for every man, woman and child in the state on four categories of low-income assistance: welfare (including Medicaid), housing, public hospitals and other health programs. This amount was well over twice the average spent by governments in the other 47 contiguous states and one-quarter more than the second-highest-spending state, Massachusetts, which has since embarked on aggressive welfare cuts.
In the welfare and Medicaid category alone, New York spent $795 for each resident, almost two and a half times the national average of $327. (More recent data show that although the gap between New York and other states has narrowed slightly, the study's basic findings still hold.)
Of course a state's expenditures vary in accordance with its economy, poverty rate and the amount of Federal aid it receives. But the 1992 study accounted for such differences in welfare and Medicaid spending. It was able to determine how much of New York's welfare spending was driven by forces beyond the control of Albany or City Hall: not just Federal aid and poverty but also demographic factors (like the percentage of female-headed households and college graduates) and economic conditions (like average income and cost of living). After all these adjustments, New York's state and local governments still spent $152 more for each resident on welfare and Medicaid than those of the average state. Add it all up, and that's $2.7 billion in welfare and Medicaid spending that we can explain only as a result of conscious policy choices in New York.
This extraordinarily high spending wouldn't be hard to justify if New York could boast of great strides in alleviating poverty and underclass pathologies. Sadly, no one has plausibly made such a claim.
More surprising, preliminary data for 1993 suggest that there's less to New York's generosity than meets the eye -- that its high spending is driven by inefficiency as much as compassion. New York's administrative costs for Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main state-administered cash welfare program, are $1,285 for each recipient family each year, the highest in the nation. (The average state spending is $593.) Yet New York's average A.F.D.C. benefit -- the money that goes directly to poor families -- is lower than that in six other states, including California, Connecticut and Massachusetts.
These three states spend as much on administrative costs in a year as they do on one month's worth of benefits; in New York, a year's administrative costs equal two and a half months of benefits. Just cutting overhead to the equivalent of one month's benefits would save almost $335 million a year.
These administrative costs don't vanish into thin air: they pay the salaries of thousands of bureaucrats statewide. Therein lies a hint of why welfare politics in New York is so contentious. New York's welfare state supports not only the poor but also a vast cadre of administrators, advocates, social workers and executives of nonprofit organizations that are paid by the government to provide social services.
 Private social-service organizations alone employ 288,500 people statewide, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The number of such jobs grew rapidly even during the recession of the early 1990's, not because of a surge in charitable impulses but because private-sector contracting became the most politically expedient way to expand the welfare state.
Such cynicism notwithstanding, it is indisputable that New Yorkers have big hearts and deep misgivings about cutting help to the poor. But they can no longer afford a huge, inefficient welfare state. We must spend less, and we must spend it smarter.
