HEADLINE: Ex-Mayor Returns From Prison Undaunted

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 17

 BODY:
Fourteen years ago, a spirited young mayor named Gerald McCann began transforming the desolate waterfront in this working-class city into a blend of high-rise offices, condominiums and retail outlets. Today Mr. McCann's personal transformation took a significant turn, as he returned to his hometown after serving more than two years in Federal prison, where his aggressive win-at-all-costs approach to economic development ultimately landed him.
 Expressing an unswerving devotion to Jersey City and unbridled optimism about his own future, Mr. McCann, a 44-year-old Democrat, said he plans to become an integral part of the city's future -- perhaps even mayor again. "I would like to be the Mayor again," he said in an interview just 12 hours before his release from a Manhattan halfway house where he spent the last four months. "But that doesn't mean I currently have plans to run." . 
 Whether inspired by the recent political resurrection of Mayor Marion Barry in Washington, or simply committed to returning to the life he once knew, Mr. McCann is wasting little time reclaiming support among the 240,000 residents in this Hudson County city. (If he doesn't run for mayor, he might need backing anyway -- he also talked about running for the state legislature or Congress.)
 Right after his release today, he sat down to lunch with the president of the Hudson County Chamber of Commerce, Peter Murphy. And in the past two days, Mr. McCann says he has spoken by telephone with two congressmen from New Jersey and received notes and telephone calls from constituents wishing him well. "A lot of people are loyal to me, and that's something the Federal Government couldn't take away," says the former Mayor, who still proclaims his innocence. "Winning again would be the best revenge."
 However, some people -- including those in the state attorney general's office -- say that Mr. McCann can't seek office again because of the nature of the crimes he committed. Mr. McCann says his legal advisers disagree.
 Michael Chertoff, the former United States District Attorney who prosecuted Mr. McCann, expressed another kind of doubt about Mr. McCann's political future. "I believe the public is looking for integrity in elected politicians, and I trust that the people of Jersey City or any other jurisdiction will exercise their judgment accordingly," said Mr. Chertoff, who is now in private practice in Newark.
 In February 1992, three months after he was convicted of defrauding a now-defunct Florida savings and loan, a New Jersey Supreme Court ruling forced Mr. McCann from office.
 In the special election that followed, city residents took a sharp and surprising turn by electing Bret Schundler, a young, conservative Republican. Mr. Schundler's success, in a city where only 6 percent of the voters registered as Republicans, catapulted him onto the national stage. The fact that Mr. Schundler spends so much time carrying the Republican banner around the country rankles people like Eugene Napolitano, a construction worker who has spent all of his 54 years in Jersey City.
 Complaining that people "need an appointment" to see Mr. Schundler, he said: "Anybody could walk in and talk to McCann. People still like him for that."
 Indeed, as one of five children and the only one to attend college, Mr. McCann easily connected with Jersey City's working-class voters. In 1977, he won a seat on the City Council, and four years later, at age 31, he became Mayor.
 As he set about helping to transform the city's economy from manufacturing to services -- courting companies and pursuing Federal grants, Mr. McCann's brash and abrasive style sometimes offended others. For example, when the Colgate-Palmolive Company announced that it was closing its Jersey City operations, Mr. McCann won no points with workers who were displaced by the move. Instead of commiserating, he said the Colgate move was good for Jersey City because it would free valuable land for redevelopment.
 Soon, a joke made its way around town, recalls Robert Sacks, president of the Hudson County Taxpayers Association. "You know, cowboys shot from the hip in the old days," Mr. Sacks says. "Well, everyone in the community said that Gerry shot from the lip."
 Those loose lips helped sink Mr. McCann's re-election bid in 1985, but by then the groundwork for economic growth in the city was in place.
 Since 1980, some six million square feet of offices, 1,800 residences and a 1.2 million-square-foot shopping mall have been built in the waterfront redevelopment district. According to the Hudson County Improvement Authority, from 1982 until 1990, the number of jobs in the city increased by 17.3 percent. Over the same period, manufacturing jobs dropped by 38 percent, but the number of retail jobs increased by 27 percent, hotel jobs increased by 46 percent and in financial services the number of jobs jumped by 80 percent.
 "None of it would have happened without Gerry McCann," said Charles Simburg, chief executive officer of the Harborside Financial Center, a two million-square-foot office building developed during the late 80's. "He was Jersey City's greatest salesman."
 Before he regained the mayor's office in 1989, Mr. McCann tried to become a private developer and businessman. After failed bids to develop a sports arena in Scranton, Pa., and to buy a savings and loan in Jersey City, he entered a partnership to develop a marina at the Liberty State Park.
 In 1986, Mr. McCann's partner in the venture, a unit of Boca Raton-based Southern Floridabanc Savings and Loan, sent him $300,000 to develop a proposal for the marina. However, the government produced witnesses and documents showing that in little over a year Mr. McCann spent most of the money on lavish items, including rare coins and a leased Mercedes Benz. A proposal for the project was never submitted. As he did during his trial, Mr. McCann still contends that the money he spent was a pre-approved salary for his services.
 On the morning of Sept. 30, 1992, before he left for prison, Mr. McCann, who had separated from his wife, picked up his oldest daughter, Tara, 16. Driving her to school that day, he recalls, "was the worst of all the feelings I've had over this whole thing," he says. "My children were so upset. I worried how it was going to affect them."
 For the next three years Mr. McCann must visit his probation officer, remain drug free, receive permission to travel outside the state, and pay the government $170,000 to replace the assets of the failed savings and loan. He is working as an accountant and mortgage financier at DMS Financial Services, a small Jersey City company.
Mr. McCann was forced to sell his condominium, so he lives with his parents in the city's Greenville section. And once again, he is dating his wife. "The moment you get out" of prison, he said, "you forget all about it. It instantly becomes a blank spot. Like it never was there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gerald McCann, the former mayor of Jersey City, is out of prison. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: LUMP-SUM GRANTS FOR NUTRITION AID PROPOSED BY G.O.P.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
House Republicans today unveiled a bill that would scrap the national school lunch program and a separate Federal program that feeds pregnant women and preschool children, in favor of lump-sum grants to the states. But senior Republicans are balking at Speaker Newt Gingrich's plan to do the same with food stamps.
The bill, drafted by Republican members of the House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities, would give states vast new discretion to design their own food programs in place of the school lunch program and the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children, or WIC. 
 Under the bill, to be considered by the committee next week, children from low-income families would no longer be entitled to school meals subsidized by the Federal Government, and there would be no uniform national standards for the nutritional content of such meals. Further, there is no guarantee that the lump-sum payments, or block grants, would increase in hard times, when more people apply for food assistance of all kinds.
The changes, which go far beyond those once proposed by President Ronald Reagan, are described in draft legislation obtained today from Republican members of Congress.
Republicans said the new proposals would reduce the paperwork burden on local officials and permit them to feed more people at lower cost. But the proposals have stirred furious opposition from educators, from groups that combat hunger and from farmers who fear they would lose income.
Gordon M. Ambach, executive director of the Council of Chief State School Officers, said, "School-based nutrition programs should be dropped from the welfare reform block grant." Robert J. Fersh, president of the Food Research and Action Center, a nonprofit anti-hunger group, said: "A block grant cannot keep up with the real needs of real people. It's almost impossible to devise a formula that responds to changing circumstances like population growth, recession, migration, unemployment and natural disasters."
The National Farmers Union said that spending on milk and other commodities would fall significantly if Congress approved the bill.
The proposals are part of an ambitious Republican effort to pare social welfare programs established during the last 60 years. The first step came when a House Ways and Means subcommittee voted on Wednesday to replace the main cash-assistance program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, with a block grant, which states could use in any way they wanted to help poor people.
The Republican campaign manifesto, the Contract With America, also proposed to eliminate the individual entitlement to food stamps and replace it with a nutrition block grant. That proposal has found few supporters in either party.
Republicans on the Ways and Means subcommittee said repeatedly this week that there was no reason to worry about the end of the A.F.D.C. cash-assistance program because welfare recipients could still get food stamps. Now the chairman of the Agriculture Committee, Representative Pat Roberts of Kansas, and the chairman of its nutrition subcommittee, Bill Emerson of Missouri, are suggesting that the Federal Government should preserve food stamps as the ultimate safety net for low-income people.
In an interview last month, the chairman of the Economic and Educational Opportunities Committee, Representative Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania, who is a former school superintendent, expressed grave doubts about creating a block grant for child nutrition programs. He said the Federal Government had a responsibility to insure proper use of Federal money for national purposes like child nutrition. But he came under intense pressure from Mr. Gingrich to fulfill his part of the Republican contract.
Under the plan unveiled today, the school lunch and breakfast programs would be consolidated into one block grant. WIC and other nutrition programs would be combined in another block grant.
States would be required to use at least 80 percent of the block-grant money for low-income people, particularly children, pregnant women and new mothers. Each state could define low income as it wanted, but the threshold could not be more than 85 percent above the poverty level. Under Census Bureau guidelines, a family of three was classified as poor if it had less than $11,817 of cash income last year.
Under the Republican proposal, legal immigrants would remain eligible for the food and nutrition programs, contrary to earlier plans in the party's contract.
The school lunch program, established in 1946 after the Government found evidence of malnutrition among military recruits, now serves more than 25 million children a day. Ten million are so poor they qualify for free meals. WIC serves 6.5 million women and children a month.
In September 1981, the Reagan Administration touched off a furor when it proposed nutrition standards that would have allowed schools to count ketchup and pickle relish as vegetables. Mr. Reagan withdrew the proposals three weeks later. The House Republican bill this year says simply that states must set "minimum nutritional requirements" based on the most recent research available.
An aide to Mr. Goodling said: "We trust the states. No school will serve hot dogs and potato chips every day."
The Republican bill would repeal the National School Lunch Act of 1946 and the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 and establish the two new block grants.
Money for the school lunch program and the school breakfast program would be combined in a new "school-based nutrition block grant," set at $6.5 billion in 1996. The amount could increase by a maximum of 4.5 percent a year, somewhat less than needed to keep pace with expected increases in food prices and the number of eligible children.
Initially, each state would get a portion of the block grant equal to its proportional share of current Federal spending on the school lunch and breakfast programs. But the formula would gradually change over five years to reward states that increased the number of meals served in schools.
Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, who was head of the Food and Nutrition Service in the Carter Administration, said that formula "would shift large amounts of money from poor states to affluent states because it takes no account of whether a meal is served to a poor child or a middle-class child." At present, poor children get free meals, and the Federal subsidy, $1.90 for each lunch, is six times that for a child from a middle-income family.
The second block grant would be established to replace WIC and other programs that provide food to homeless children, to school-age children in the summer and to preschool children with working parents. The Republicans would earmark $4.5 billion for that grant next year.
States would have to file annual reports with data showing how they used the Federal money under both block grants.
Richard Rominger, the Acting Secretary of Agriculture, said, "The Administration opposes block grants for the nation's nutrition programs." By any measure, he said, these programs have contributed to significant gains in public health and nutrition.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 33.98 On a Retreat From Record

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average, which came tantalizingly close to 4,000 on Wednesday, went into sharp reverse yesterday, falling 33.98 points to close at 3,953.54.
 The Dow fell past not only its Thursday record of 3,987.52, but even past its Jan. 31, 1994, peak of 3,978.36. Even so, for the week, the Dow finished ahead by 14.47 points. 
 Traders cautioned that yesterday's performance was distorted by the expiration of two kinds of stock options, which prompts the huge volume and volatility known as the "double witching hour."
 In quarterly options expirations, traders are under enormous pressure to buy or sell in a use-it-or-lose-it clamor that typically flares at the beginning or end of the session.
 Such buying or selling pressure is often tied to options designed to mimic the action of the 30 blue-chip stocks of the Dow or stocks in the Standard & Poor's 100.
 But apart from such technical concerns, there were plenty of other reasons for traders to sell.
 The crisis in Mexico is being identified by a growing number of currency, bond and stock traders as a North American crisis that drags down the United States and Canada, as well, and leads foreigners to dump dollars.
 Lower values for a currency make foreigners uneasy about buying stocks or bonds priced in that currency. For example, the Dow has risen 3.11 percent this year in dollars, but because of the currency's weakness, its rise is only 0.85 percent when converted to Japanese yen, and it actually has a loss of 0.85 percent in German marks.
 Regardless of the state of the United States economy, possible deep recessions that may be imminent in Canada and Mexico are sure to hurt stock and bond prices in the United States, some analysts say.
 As the stock and bond markets were closing yesterday, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz of Mexico were negotiating the details of the $20 billion federally backed portion of the Clinton Administration's $50 billion rescue package for Mexico. The balance comes from the International Monetary Fund and others.
 The Rubin-Ortiz talks seem likely to continue through the weekend, with the possibility of some joint announcements before trading opens on Tuesday. Financial markets are closed Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday. The economic uncertainty over a three-day weekend is itself a damper on the market.
 "Nobody wants to be long on stocks over a weekend like this," said Todd Clark, managing director of equity trading at Mabon Securities. "It's like trader folklore."
 Hence the dash to sell in the last moments of trading yesterday. The Dow plunged nearly 26 points in the last 25 minutes.
 The other leading indexes also fell yesterday. The broader Standard & Poor's 500, which also set a record this week of 485.22 points, fell below its Feb. 2, 1994, record of 482, closing at 481.97, down 3.25 points.
 The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index closed at 786.97, down 6.34 points, even further away from its March 18, 1994, record of 803.93.
 Motorola, the most active stock at 19.7 million shares, also had the most striking fall, plunging 6 3/8, to 57 7/8, after the company said in the morning that unsold cellular telephones were piling up in its warehouses and that sales were slowing. Cellular telephones have largely accounted for Motorola's strong profits in recent years.
 White River, an investment adviser company, posted one of the day's stronger gains after it reported a fourth-quarter profit of $1.27 a share after a loss of $1.45 in the comparable period a year earlier. The share price rose 3 3/8, to 33 1/8.
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal with 354.6 million shares changing hands, about 6 percent more than this year's daily average of 333 million shares.
 The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.44 points, to 261.83, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks by 913 to 1,240. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.08 point, to 447.60.
 In Tokyo, stocks closed higher yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 239.92 points, or 1.35 percent, to 18,020.51. But for the week, the Nikkei was down 270.84 points, or 1.5 percent.

HEADLINE: New Gas Arouses Grass-Roots Ire

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
When customers buy gasoline at the C-Store station in Louisville, Ky., they are asked to sign a petition opposing a cleaner-burning fuel that was introduced this year to reduce pollution in many smog-infested urban areas.
 "People are upset," Bob Fagin, who owns three gas stations in Louisville, said this week. "We've had hundreds sign. Customers are complaining about the price and the possibility that it's a health hazard." 
 The protests are not limited to Kentucky. Many drivers in other states are also complaining about the new fuel, known as reformulated gasoline. For one thing, it often costs 5 to 15 cents a gallon more than conventional gasoline. There are concerns that fuel economy may suffer. Some people say its fumes make them sick.
 The outcry over the new fuel has become so loud that all of Pennsylvania other than the Philadelphia region has withdrawn from the program. So have nine counties in New York, including the Albany and Buffalo areas. The Governor of Wisconsin has asked the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to allow the most heavily populated area of that state to escape the requirement until at least April. Politicians in New Jersey and several other states are being pressured by grass-roots protests aimed at curbing use of the new fuel.
 The reformulated gasoline -- intended to cut smog by a fifth and sharply reduce emissions of some toxic cancer-causing substances -- burns more thoroughly, evaporates more slowly and smells differently from the gasoline in use elsewhere.
 The new fuel uses oxygenates, or molecules that contain oxygen, aiding combustion and reducing pollution. It is not the same as oxygenated gasolines that have been used in winter months in some areas, including the New York City region. The reformulated gasoline is similiar to the winter fuel in its use of oxygenates, but the reformulated gasoline also uses less of some toxic substances like benzene.
 As of Jan. 1, it has been required in most of the Boston-New York-Washington megalopolis, extending south to Richmond and north to coastal Maine. It is also imposed in the Chicago region, including eastern Wisconsin and northwestern Indiana; the Louisville and Cincinnati areas in Kentucky; the Houston and Dallas-Fort Worth urban areas, and the Los Angeles and San Diego regions.
 Some places within those boundaries, as well as other areas of the country, have a choice as to whether to use the costly new fuel as part of their efforts to comply with the Clean Air Act of 1990. Use of the fuel is mandated in some other regions with high pollution levels.
 The complaints against reformulated gasoline have taken the form of thousands of phone calls to hot lines set up by state environmental agencies, hundreds of call-ins to local radio talk shows and dozens of petition drives at gas stations.
 The grass-roots protest has caught the Environmental Protection Agency and most clean-air groups by surprise. In the past, they say, consumers have generally been willing to pay a little extra and accept modest inconveniences to help improve the environment.
 "My sense is that a lot of this has been caught up in the overall climate of anti-Washington, anti-big government," said Deborah Shprentz, an expert on the issue at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a prominent environmental group.
 The protest against reformulated gasoline comes as people in states from Maine to Texas to California are up in arms over other requirements of the Clean Air Act, including tougher vehicle inspections.
 The oil industry is worried about the backlash because it has spent about $14 billion in recent years to upgrade its refineries and distribution systems to produce reformulated gasoline, which is now sold to about 30 percent of the nation's motorists. The National Petroleum Council estimates that the extra cost of making and distributing the fuel is about 5.4 cents a gallon.
 Apart from the higher cost, a wave of health complaints in the Milwaukee area led Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin to ask the E.P.A. to suspend use of the new fuel until April so that its health effects could be studied further.
 In response, the E.P.A. Administrator, Carol M. Browner, deferred a decision, saying she would send experts to Milwaukee for a public meeting on Monday to discuss the issues. In a letter sent Thursday, Ms. Browner said that several previous health studies did not find "the types of reactions that people in Milwaukee have been experiencing."
 She added, "Nevertheless, I appreciate that some people may be sensitive to certain fuels or additives."
 Elsewhere, protests have been prompted by the higher prices for the new gasoline. "People are mad down here because of the price," said Donald Satterly, executive director of the Kentucky Gas Dealers Association, which has found that some motorists are driving to outlying rural areas where gasoline is less expensive. His group plans to present its petitions to Gov. Brereton C. Jones, who so far has supported the use of reformulated gasoline.
 Pressure from station owners and drivers is also a reason that former Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, who stepped down this year, allowed 28 counties to pull out of the program. The controversy has been fanned by fears that an additive in the new gasoline -- methyl tertiary butyl ether, or MTBE -- may pose a health risk.
 Barry Grossman, who works at an employment agency in Plainsboro, N.J., has formed a protest group called Oxy Busters, which he says has gathered 10,000 signatures for a petition he hopes to present to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. He says he has received phone calls from hundreds of drivers complaining of headaches and nausea.
 Environmental and health groups are now responding with publicity campaigns defending the clean-air efforts, including the introduction of reformulated gasoline.
 "There has not been much said about why these programs have been put in and what the benefits are," said A. Blakeman Early, environmental consultant for the American Lung Association.
 Reformulated gasoline is the latest and most far-reaching of efforts -- begun in 1974 with the introduction of unleaded fuel -- to reduce the health-damaging consequences of burning gasoline. In 1988, oil companies began adding oxygenates to fuel sold in some particularly smoggy areas, to improve combustion and thereby cut emissions.
 The first major nationwide step was taken in November 1992 when 36 metropolitan areas in 15 states were required to begin using oxygenated gasoline in the winter. MTBE has been used along the East Coast to bolster the oxygen content of gasoline because it was cheaper than adding ethanol, a corn byproduct produced in the Midwest farm belt.
 Animal studies from the 1980's found no significant adverse effects from oxygenated gasoline that includes MTBE. But after it was introduced in Alaska and New Jersey in 1992, complaints about dizziness and nausea led to further research.
 The E.P.A., after reviewing the research, concluded that MTBE did not pose a serious health hazard and that it provided an overall benefit by reducing levels of carbon monoxide.
 "MTBE may cause certain side effects, such as nausea and headaches, for a limited number of people," said Richard Stapleton, a spokesman for the New York regional office of the E.P.A. "For the vast majority of people it does not even pose an irritant threat."
 In the New York City region, both New York and Connecticut will continue selling oxygenated fuels through April 30, at which point they plan to switch to reformulated gasoline in most areas. In New Jersey, Governor Whitman wants to switch from the oxygenated fuel, which uses a slightly higher level of MTBE's, on March 1. From then on, gas stations in the state would sell the reformulated gasoline.

HEADLINE: In the Middle: New York on $38,000 a Year -- A special report.;
Free From Want, but Just Getting By

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
Brenda, Amancio, Michelle and Amelia Irizarry are a family of four living in the Bronx, and at first glance, their lives seem to mirror the middle-class ideal.
Brenda heads the parents' association at the local middle school. Her husband, Amancio, bustles off to work early each morning. Their younger daughter, Amelia, 13, accents her jeans with Nikes and Timberland boots. Their older daughter, Michelle, 20, attends college and hopes to become a social worker. 
 But the Irizarrys have no savings. They rent an apartment, because they cannot afford to buy a home. The family has never taken a vacation trip together, or owned a new car. They go out to dinner at most once a year.
Sometimes Mrs. Irizarry wonders what would happen if there were an accident or death, and her family had to survive on even less.
The Irizarrys live on $38,000 a year, an income that places them in the financial middle of a city where the gap between rich and poor is among the widest in the nation. The median family income in New York, adjusted for inflation, is $41,600, based on 1990 census figures. But to be in the middle in New York City, as the Irizarrys' life attests, is not necessarily to have either the security or the comforts so often associated with being middle class.
"I think that the median in New York is probably at the low end of what you'd call the middle class," said Dr. Andrew A. Beveridge, who directs the Program for Applied Research at Queens College of the City University of New York.
Often it is the extraordinarily wealthy and the destitute who seem to define New York City. But the Irizarrys of Bainbridge Avenue are more typical, and for them life is neither glamorous nor miserable. But it does contain a kind of quiet drama nonetheless, with the modest triumphs and heartbreaks that define so many families who are on the cusp of hard times and of making it.
Mr. and Mrs. Irizarry have enjoyed a measure of success. They are better off than their parents were. But they have been unable to improve their fortunes beyond a modicum of comfort they achieved several years ago. In fact, they began slipping back after Mr. Irizarry was laid off by a company to which he had devoted much of his life.
Everyone in the Irizarry family works. Mrs. Irizarry, 41, brings in the most money, as an assistant teacher at a nearby day care center. Mr. Irizarry, 52, holds two jobs, stocking goods in a school kitchen by day and cleaning classrooms in another school by night. Michelle spends her evenings doing telephone surveys for a company in New Rochelle. And even Amelia sometimes sweeps floors at her middle school to earn pocket change.
Their household in the northwest Bronx, held together by the industry of the parents, is buoyed by the youthful dreams of the children. And the only real suspense for the Irizarrys is whether their daughters will realize their bittersweet aspirations to rise above their parents' lot.
"I don't want to live like this the rest of my life," Michelle said. "I feel sorry for my mother. I mean, they have morals and are trying to make it. But unless they hit the Lotto, this is how it's going to be the rest of their lives. And that's sad, to think that's it. This is as good as it's going to get."
 
The Parents
Constant Struggle For a Simple Life
 It was Sunday, and at last Amancio Irizarry had a day to rest. He turned on the TV in the kitchen, and prepared to fry codfish fritters and cook a pot of vegetable soup.
Mr. Irizarry looks younger than 52, with his burnished bronze skin and shock of white hair. As his wife, Brenda, headed out the door to the market, he boasted playfully about the lunch he was preparing and reminded her to pick up some bread.
They have been married 21 years. And though Mrs. Irizarry's dark brown hair is flecked with gray, she still has the laugh of a schoolgirl.
Mrs. Irizarry grew up poor, in the Walt Whitman housing project in Brooklyn. As an adult, she lived in relative comfort for a time when she and her husband made more than $50,000 a year. And during a two-year period when her husband was unemployed, she struggled to keep her family afloat.
"I know I'm not low income," Mrs. Irizarry said. "And I guess we have a car and that puts me ahead of someone who doesn't. But if I consider myself middle class it would be the lower bracket, because the lifestyle we have is very simple."
Mrs. Irizarry drove the family's 1984 Ford LTD, as every weekend, to Edwards Super Food Store. She perused the aisles, checking sale stickers and chuckling softly when she passed the fillet of sole ($9.49 a pound). "Not this week," she laughed, as she headed toward the chicken.
When she is not teaching at the Mosholu-Montefiore Community Center in the Bronx and doing volunteer work in her neighborhood, Mrs. Irizarry is often out hunting for bargains, trying to balance the desires and needs of a household that includes two young daughters.
She makes $21,000 a year, and her husband makes $17,000.
The family has a tight budget for predictable expenses: $675.85 a month for rent, $60 for electricity, $100 for the phone, $400 for groceries. They sometimes rely on their four credit cards, and are unable to save any money at all. So they have learned to cut corners, turning leftover steak into beef-fried rice, spending no more than $10 on any one Christmas gift.
Mrs. Irizarry's job provides health insurance. And the family pays only a $300 annual deductible -- giving them one less expense to worry about from month to month.
But there are always unexpected setbacks -- like Amelia's braces, which cost $3,400, or the burial of Mr. Irizarry's father, which cost $4,000.
Mrs. Irizarry said she has never had grandiose dreams. But she has had to modify even modest aspirations. Not so long ago, for instance, she and her husband considered buying a home. But they decided that a down payment and monthly mortgage were beyond their means. And Mrs. Irizarry's dream of finishing college is permanently on hold. They can barely afford to send Michelle to Kingsborough Community College, where the $2,100 in yearly tuition is low compared with private schools. Once the City University of New York was free. Now, Michelle gets $50 in state financial aid, which is little more than "a tease," Mrs. Irizarry said. Michelle had to take out a loan this school year, and Mrs. Irizarry once resorted to putting the tuition on her credit card.
"We didn't have a college fund for Michelle," she said. "You see commercials on television saying to start when the baby is born. But because of the unforeseen things that happen in life, it's impossible to save money."
 
The Home
Fewer Luxuries, Smaller Comforts
 The Irizarry's five-room apartment is filled with pets and small comforts. There are two unnamed finches roosting in the kitchen, and two family dogs, Polo and Champ. A VCR and stereo sit in the simply furnished living room, and Michelle has her own compact disk player.
Such conveniences have become more affordable and thus ubiquitous in American homes, but the larger luxuries, like a house and college education, have become harder to attain, making it difficult for many middle-class families to achieve the American dream. It often takes two people to make an income comparable to that brought home by one person a generation ago.
The median price for a home in the New York metropolitan area more than doubled between 1980 and 1990, to $168,600 from $69,600, according to the National Association of Realtors. The median family income in New York City rose only 20 percent during the same period.
The Irizarrys are "better off than their immigrant parents," John Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the CUNY Graduate Center, said. "They're certainly solid in the middle as far as the numbers tell us, but they probably are not going to move much higher in the income distribution. And the question is, do their kids have a shot?"
One night recently, Mrs. Irizarry reflected on the economic ups and downs of her husband's life. During 15 years with Stewart Sandwiches, he worked his way up from driver to route supervisor. By the time he was laid off, he was making $30,000 a year. Now, after two years of searching for work, he has ended up mopping floors and stocking shelves.
"I think my husband deserved better, especially for a man of his experience and his capabilities," said Mrs. Irizarry. "But you do what you have to. He's no longer a supervisor. He's a food helper and a maintenance worker. And I don't think there's any disgrace in that. He's out there trying to make an honest living. The only thing I regret is he has to work so hard."
Mr. Irizarry is a proud man. Asked what he pines for, he says he has all that he ever wanted.
"I got my wife, I got my kids," he said. "I don't need no Porsche, no Lexus. I'm not into being a millionaire. I'm comfortable where I'm at. But If I can get it, I'll take it, like anybody else."
Still, when pressed, he admits there are a few pleasures he would not mind. He is a Vietnam veteran and would love to see Arlington National Cemetery. He'd like to go back to Puerto Rico and visit his birthplace for the first time in more than 20 years.
"I'd love to take a vacation and leave everything behind," he said. "I'd love to have a house."
Perhaps most of all, he wishes that his wife did not have to work outside the home. "I'd rather have her be at home," he said.
Still, he is doing better than his parents. When his family moved to New York City from Puerto Rico in 1952, his father found work in a hotel kitchen, and his mother worked as a seamstress. Together they brought home $58 a week.
"I have much more," he said. "We were dirt-poor and we only thought about survival day by day. That's why my motto is 'one day at a time.' "
He finds the good in most things. The family's apartment, where they have lived nearly 13 years, could use new wiring and better plumbing. The neighbors sometimes get a little rowdy. But he says he will not leave it, or New York City.
"I'm not moving," he said. "I sleep O.K. here."
 
The Children
Daughters Share Bittersweet Hopes
 When Amelia entered the sixth grade at Middle School 80, other children teased her because of what she wore, and the memory still stings. "They'll look at your sneakers, look at your face, and they'll remember your sneakers," said Amelia, now an eighth grader. "Some people don't tease you, but they make sure they make you jealous of what they've got. They know they're getting on your nerves. And they like it."
Amelia has felt her parents' financial struggles sharply. When her father was unemployed, she said, "every time the family had a conversation, it was always about money."
Last Christmas, she decided she wanted a part-time job. Now she sometimes earns $50 a week, helping her father sweep classrooms and doing chores for her grandfather on Saturdays.
Working is just one of the ways she tries to be a big girl; she also protects her mother. "I really don't talk to her about things I want," Amelia said. "She knows she can't get it for me. And I don't want to make her feel bad."
Michelle often thinks about all she does not have when she strolls down Fifth Avenue.
"Sometimes I'll see a Mercedes," she said. "And I always wonder, how it must feel to be that person's child."
She is not ashamed to admit that she is materialistic -- and impatient. "You want so much, but it takes so long to get it, and you feel like it's never going to happen."
When Michelle was attending the High School of Fashion Industries in Manhattan, she said, many of her friends' families were better off than hers. "I was at a point where I didn't want to bring people to my house," she said. "I go to other people's houses and see what they have, and it kind of burns me."
But Michelle has ambitions; she is determined to become a social worker and live in a beautiful apartment in Manhattan.
Her mother also has dreams -- of going back to college and finishing her degree, or perhaps buying a mobile home when she and her husband retire.
But if none of that happens, she said, reality is not so bad.
"There's an old movie, 'It's a Wonderful Life,' " she said. "I look at my life like that. The movie makes a point. That sometimes what you do have is a lot greater than what you don't."

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widened Last Year

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
The United States last year posted its largest overall trade deficit in seven years, more than $108 billion in goods and services, and set record deficits with Japan and China, the two countries that confront Washington with its most persistent trade problems.
 The Clinton Administration said that while the numbers looked disturbing -- the deficit widened 42 percent, or $32.4 billion -- they also reflected the underlying strength of the American economy. The fast-paced expansion in the United States sucked in a tremendous volume of imported computers, electrical machinery and clothing. That probably helped contain inflation at a time when American factories were running at nearly full speed. 
Most economists expect the trade gap to narrow this year, as the American economy slows and the economic recoveries in Japan and Europe accelerate. But there are worries that Mexico, while a smaller trading partner than Europe or Japan, will start contributing to the trade deficit next year because of its peso woes.
 The trade gap did close significantly in December, to $7.3 billion for the month from $10 billion in November.
 Still the figures underscore the challenges facing President Clinton as he presses his argument that an expansion of free trade, especially in Asia, will benefit American companies and workers. The numbers also seem likely to fuel criticism on Capitol Hill that two years of intensive trade talks with Tokyo -- talks that American officials say have given them a case of "Japan fatigue" -- have failed to affect the most politically sensitive figure in the relationship, the merchandise trade deficit with Japan.
 That statistic, which excludes trade in services, topped $65 billion last year, a historic high.
 Worldwide, the United States' merchandise trade deficit also set a record, at $166.3 billion, an increase of more than 25 percent from 1993. Exports of goods were a record $502.8 billion, up 10 percent, while imports climbed 13.5 percent, to $669.1 billion, according to the Commerce Department.
 Today's accounting of the nation's performance in international markets also provided further evidence that China is now posing trade quandaries for the United States of nearly Japan-like proportions. Providing American consumers with a growing supply of low-cost goods, China ran a surplus with the United States last year of $29.5 billion. That was an increase of nearly 30 percent from the previous year's figure.
 In many ways, the deficit with China is more troublesome than the one with Japan because it is growing so much faster, and because the gap between America's exports and imports is proportionately much larger. Trade problems with China could soon dwarf the two decades of economic confrontation with Japan.
 "There is a profound sense in which the China deficit is worse than the Japan deficit," C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics, said today. "To even the accounts with Japan, our exports there have to grow twice as fast as our imports. In the case of China, they would have to grow four times as fast as imports. That is almost inconceivable."
 A reversal of that magnitude is particularly difficult to imagine given the wide range of trade barriers in China, some of which are the subject of tense negotiations that have been under way in Beijing since Wednesday.
 The talks are a last-minute attempt to avoid the imposition of $1 billion in trade sanctions next weekend as punishment for China's continued pirating of American software, compact disks and movies. But part of the talks center on Chinese restrictions that allow the importing of fewer than a dozen American movies each year -- cutting off a major American product. And the pirating of goods has spread to cars, Kellogg's cereals and razor blades, among other consumer items, costing American companies untold millions in lost sales.
 If today's figures had come out several years ago, when the United States' economy was in the doldrums and Japan's was booming, it undoubtedly would have caused a political uproar. But on Capitol Hill today, they were barely noticed. That nonchalance reflects a low American unemployment rate and the sense that few jobs are being lost to foreign trade.
 The change in attitude is particularly clear in the talk of American auto makers, who have always been the most vocal in calling for action against Japan. "They don't pose the threat they used to," Peter Pestillo, an executive vice president of Ford, said today. "I don't think the situation is worsening."
 While Detroit is satisfied that it can easily sell as many cars as it churns out, the numbers show that Japanese auto makers are continuing to increase sales to Americans. Measured by value, nearly $24 billion worth of new cars were imported from Japan last year, up from $21.5 billion in 1993. Exports of vehicles to Japan climbed to $1.7 billion last year from $982 million the year before.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Track Dollar, Falling a Bit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices showed little change yesterday after tracking the dollar through a shortened session.
 Bonds and the dollar "synchronized a little bit today," said Gerald Thunelius, who manages $1.5 billion in bonds at the Dreyfus Corporation "As the dollar strengthened, the bond market also strengthened." 
 The Treasury's 30-year bond slipped 5/32 of a percentage point, while its yield edged up to 7.58 percent, from 7.57 percent on Thursday.
 The Public Securities Association, the public debt industry's main trade group, recommended trading stop at 2 P.M. Markets will be closed on Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday.
 Bond prices slipped early in the session as the dollar weakened against major currencies on concern that fallout from the Mexican financial crisis would affect all North American markets, traders said. A weaker dollar makes dollar-denominated securities less attractive to international investors.
 "The dollar is tainted and is guilty by association with two other weak North American currencies," the Mexico peso and the Canadian dollar, said Tom Carpenter, chief economist at ASB Capital Management, a Washington firm with $6 billion in bonds. The Canadian dollar has fallen to about 71 United States cents from about 75 cents in September.
 Since Dec. 20, when Mexico devalued the peso to address a trade imbalance, the currency has lost more than 40 percent of its value in dollar terms.
 Yesterday, the dollar dropped one pfennig, to 1.4802 marks, after trading as low as 1.4770 marks, its lowest level against the German currency since October 1992.
 Despite the bond market's weakness yesterday, traders said it did not signal an end to a rally that has lowered yields from 8.16 percent on Nov. 7 on mounting confidence the Federal Reserve's seven interest rate increases since Feb. 4 of last year would be enough to subdue inflation. Yields on the 30-year bond, a sensitive barometer of inflation expectations, fell to 7.55 percent this week, the lowest since September.
 "The most important thing that's going on in the market is that people have taken the Fed out" of their projections, said Terrence Piggott, head trader at Daiwa Securities America. Instead of expecting a series of rapid rate increases, traders now expect the Fed will act "maybe once a quarter," he said.
 One sign that traders and investors grew more confident this week that the Fed had almost raised rates enough came from the yield spread between the note and the bond. The spread, up one basis point from yesterday at 55 basis points, had widened from 38 basis points last Friday. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
 The Commerce Department reported yesterday that the United States trade deficit narrowed more than expected in December, to $7.3 billion, even though it widened for the year.
 A reduction in imports could suggest brisk economic growth is slowing, reducing the risk that inflation will accelerate, some analysts said. "The U.S. economy is going to slow and start to pare this deficit," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Company International.
 Meanwhile, the University of Michigan said its index of consumer sentiment fell to 97.1, from 97.6 in January.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Takes Tumble Again On Concerns Over Mexico

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar plunged against most major currencies for the second day yesterday, hit by the strong German mark and worries over Mexico's financial stability.
 The dollar was beaten to lows against the mark not seen in almost two and a half years, falling a full pfennig, to 1.4802 marks. At the same time, it slipped to 97.4 yen, from 97.42 on Thursday. 
 Early in the day the dollar had had some rebound, leading to widespread speculation that there had been discreet central bank intervention to support it.
 "There might have been an official connection to the dollar's rise, but it was never confirmed," said Craig Larimer, head of international market analysis at First Chicago Capital Markets.
 Some dealers attributed the dollar's early rebound to buying interest among large investment funds, and to an improved American trade picture. The Commerce Department reported that an expansion in exports pared the large trade deficit to $7.34 billion in December from $10.04 billion the previous month.
 America's large trade deficit has been of concern to foreign investors. A narrowing of the trade gap helps shore up the dollar by reducing the need for foreign capital.
 But the glowing trade report provided only a brief luster to the tarnished dollar because of lingering expectations that Mexico's peso devaluation will slow United States exports in coming months. Mexico accounts for roughly 10 percent of America's total exports, and trade makes up about 15 percent of gross domestic product.
 While questions over the unfinished loan package to Mexico continued to burden the dollar, a stronger peso helped stem the dollar's losses. The new Mexican peso ended sharply higher at 5.70 to the dollar, compared with 6.10 Thursday.
 "The market has calmed down for now," one trader said. "But if Mexico heats up, the dollar will sell off again."
 Once the dollar veered back toward its lows, dealers said a flood of buying interest from institutional to retail concerns seeking value helped to prop it up.
 Another day of losses in stocks and bonds also hindered the dollar's chances for advancement. "The market is watching stocks and bonds," a major bank dealer said. If those two markets sell off, we could see the dollar test new lows."
 The German mark also continued its advance against other European currencies, especially the Italian lira, British pound, French franc and Portuguese escudo.
 By late yesterday, the dollar had settled again near its lows. The pound gained on the dollar to $1.5820, from $1.5780 late Thursday. Against Canada's dollar, it slipped to $1.4028, from $1.4124 Thursday. In late New York trading the dollar had dropped to 1.2520 Swiss francs, from 1.2588 Swiss francs Thursday, and to 5.1520 French francs, from 5.1755 francs.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
For Mr. Buffett's Stocks, The Business Is the Key

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
DO you study the stock market? Do you puzzle over interest rates? Do you plumb the depths of modern portfolio theory?
 No doubt you hope to profit from your hard work. Well, here's some disturbing news. Warren E. Buffett, the investing phenomenon whose Omaha holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, was trading at yesterday's close at an eye-popping $23,450 a share, does none of these things. 
 Mr. Buffett has said, "As far as I am concerned, the stock market doesn't exist." He has said, "If Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan were to whisper to me what his monetary policy was going to be over the next two years, I wouldn't change a thing." He has even said, "Lethargy bordering on sloth remains the cornerstone of our investment style."
 What Mr. Buffett does with his time is look long and hard at the companies, the businesses, behind the stocks. Experts spend much time debating if he still hews to the "value," or bargain-hunting, approach of his mentor, Benjamin Graham. But for Mr. Buffett, whose company has had compounded average annual returns of 23.2 percent from 1965 through 1993, that issue is off the point. "The nine most important words ever written about investing," he has said, are Graham's adage, "Investing is most intelligent when it is most businesslike."
 But what does that phrase mean? Drooling investors want to know.
 "The Warren Buffett Way," a best seller written by Robert G. Hagstrom Jr., a Philadelphia money manager, and published by John Wiley & Sons, describes well how Mr. Buffett grades businesses. The highest marks, Mr. Hagstrom writes, go to managers who put shareholders first when allocating capital.
 Managers with good rates of return should plow cash back into their companies to get more good returns, Mr. Buffett believes. But if returns are average or worse, reinvestment makes no sense. Even though companies may hope that their luck will turn or that an acquisition will make the difference, he says, most underperformers should return extra cash to shareholders, who can then seek higher returns elsewhere. Managers who do so, through increased dividends or stock buybacks, tend to be low on ego and high on shareholder interests, he believes.
 Berkshire Hathaway has invested in many such enterprises. A hallmark of its holdings are companies that have done stock buybacks, reducing the shares outstanding and raising their value. Capital Cities/ABC, in which Berkshire has a $1.7 billion stake, bought back nearly 2 million of its 18 million outstanding shares between 1988 and 1992. Other Berkshire holdings that are big on buybacks are the Washington Post Company, Geico and the PNC Bank.
 Mr. Buffett also likes businesses that are shielded from competition and can earn higher profits. And these ventures include more than just his well-known brand holdings, like Coca-Cola and Gillette.
 Geico, for instance, has carved out an insurance franchise with a simple idea. It finds a group of statistically safe drivers -- like government employees -- and sells them auto insurance by mail. Using the mails cuts out agent commissions and makes low-priced policies possible, while the chosen pool of drivers keeps costly claims down. No insurer does exactly what Geico does, and Mr. Buffett knows it. The company is his third-largest holding.
 Then come low costs. Berkshire, with 11 employees and no legal or press offices, keeps overhead at less than 1 percent of operating earnings. If it was 10 percent, Mr. Buffett has said, returns would drop nine percentage points.
 Mr. Buffett's holdings are equally parsimonious. Even when Geico became the nation's seventh-largest insurer, Mr. Hagstrom says, its chief executive still shared a secretary with two other managers. And it "warmed my heart," Mr. Buffett said, to learn that executives at the H. H. Brown Shoe Company, another Berkshire holding, get a base salary of just $7,800 a year. The rest comes from profits -- if there are any.
 Mr. Buffett asks other business questions. Can the industry's earnings grow without great outlays? Are the managers impressive? And, of course, is the stock cheap?
 And is the business understandable? Despite high regard for Microsoft, Mr. Buffett avoids its stock because the field puzzles him. Ignorance, he says, increases danger.
 This belief is a departure from the common wisdom about stock diversification. Owning many different stocks -- good, bad and mediocre -- depresses the returns a more selective portfolio would achieve, he believes, and makes it impossible to understand all that you own. Thus, in 1987, his $2 billion portfolio had just three companies. Today, nearly $15 billion is spread among just 10.
 Mr. Buffett is not the only investor to recognize that the business behind a stock is the important factor in the long term. But he is rare in remaining deaf to the roars on Wall Street. He has no stock-quote machine in his office, and he describes the market as a slough of fear and greed untethered to corporate realities. As Mr. Hagstrom writes: "When Buffett invests, he sees a business. Most investors see only a stock price."

LENGTH: 250 words

HEADLINE: Robert Clancy, 80, Institute's Founder

 BODY:
Robert Clancy, an educator who was director of the Henry George School of Social Science from 1946 to 1970 and founder of the Henry George Institute, died on Feb. 9 in Jackson Heights Hospital in Queens. He was 80 and lived in Jackson Heights.
 The cause was colon cancer, said George L. Collins, the executive director of the Manhattan school. 
 Founded in 1932, the school teaches the economic and social philosophy of the 19th-century economist and philosopher Henry George, who saw land speculation as the scourge of the time and the cause of poverty and inequality.
 George argued that society, not the landowner, was responsible for the increase in land value, and that the increase should be taxed and thereby returned to society. He saw such a levy as the only tax necessary and, thus, was an early proponent of a single tax. George twice ran unsuccessfully for mayor of New York City in the late 1800's.
 Mr. Clancy expanded the school's role in adult education and through establishment of the institute set up a worldwide network of correspondence courses in subjects related to George's social and economic concepts. Students from more than 200 countries enrolled in courses.
 In 1952 he wrote a biography of the founder of the school, "A Seed Was Sown: The Life of Oscar Geiger." He was co-founder and chairman emeritus of the Council of Georgist Organizations, an international association of Georgist schools.
 He is survived by a sister, Norma Hempe of Massapequa, L.I.

HEADLINE: ON TENNIS;
The Business Decision Could Hurt the Business

BYLINE: By Robin Finn 

 BODY:
If the WTA Tour divined that it would save face, and local sponsors, by refusing a $10 million-plus offer from Tampax to become the new title sponsor of women's professional tennis, its hierarchy ought to think again.
 What the tour's chief executive officer, Anne Person Worcester, had considered a safe business decision, albeit a distinctly nonfeminist message about just how unenlightened the marketplace remains, appears to have backfired. "Now we're hearing that women are planning to boycott our tournaments because they're ticked off that we walked away from the Tampax deal," an unhappy tour executive said yesterday. 
 And perhaps that will hurt worse than any comedians' one-liners and male hecklers combined.
 But the WTA Tour, which began sponsorship negotiations last October with Tambrands Inc. after being turned down by Diet Coke and Diner's Club, is not retracting its position.
 "I stand by the decision," said Worcester, who insisted the rejection of Tampax as title sponsor for 1996-98 was grounded in economic reality, not backward thinking.
 "Women's tennis is at a critical juncture, and we approached 1995 with a single-mission statement, to increase our popularity and enhance our health and image on a global basis," said Worcester. "But our research told us we unfortunately would not be able to do that had we accepted this sponsor. We're a conservative sport with a high-profile sponsorship, and we've got to represent ourselves in 22 countries, not just this one."
 A spokesman for Tambrands, Bruce Garren, said the sponsorship negotiations had been preliminary at best. "We were in the very early stages when they told us they'd decided to take a different direction," said Garren, who noted that his company has previously been a sponsor for United States women's swimming and for track and field events as far afield as Russia.
 Worcester said a marketing survey conducted by her office revealed a 75 percent negative backlash from tennis officials, tournament directors, broadcasters, and marketing experts, all of whom thought that Tampax was an inappropriate and potentially damaging global sponsor. The disapproval was particularly strong in Asia, she said, where the tour holds 10 events.
 Martina Navratilova, president of the Tour's Players Association, recalled being asked to film a tampon commercial in Japan. "One stipulation from the manufacturer was that the woman in the advertisement not be Asian," said Navratilova.
 "I have mixed emotions about all of this," said Navratilova, for whom marketplace viability has long been a sore subject because of her being routinely blackballed because of her homosexuality. "On the one hand, you'd like to take a strong stand for a product whose integrity is unquestioned, not to mention that, unlike tobacco, it's a product we actually use. But even in the best of times, accepting and promoting this sponsorship would be iffy, and these are not the best of times."
 Navratilova said she was convinced that the presence of Tampax would have an adverse impact on local event sponsorships from which the tour derives its $35 million in yearly prize money. While various banks, car dealerships, and other local businesses seemed unconcerned about the presence of Virginia Slims cigarettes, the Philip Morris product synonymous with the birth of the circuit, feminine hygiene products were supposedly taboo.
 Advantage International, the agency that brought the Tampax deal to the WTA Tour, said Navratilova's opinion was a perfect example of the negative spin placed on the prospective deal by its competing agency, the International Management Group.
 "Anybody who talked to us last felt the deal was a positive step, and anybody who talked to I.M.G. last felt just the opposite," said Harlan Stone, an executive vice president at Advantage. "Martina had told us in November that she felt good about the deal; she said she didn't eat cheese, she didn't smoke, and she didn't drink soda, but finally, with Tampax, the tour had a sponsor whose product actually helped players perform 365 days a year."
 Instead of accepting a cutting-edge sponsor, the WTA Tour took what it assumed would be the path of least resistance, dismissed Advantage, and hired I.M.G., the same behemoth that last September attempted a hostile takeover of the tour and complicated the tour's sponsorship negotiations with Diner's Club, as its exclusive marketing agent. Where Tambrands guaranteed a $3 million investment even if public outcry wound up causing the deal to be squelched, I.M.G. has reportedly guaranteed $4 million if it fails to deliver a sponsor.
 "I.M.G. has put X millions on the table, and if they come back to us without a sponsor for 1996, they'll be obligated to write us a check," said Worcester, who reiterated that the decision not to take the Tambrands deal had nothing to do with I.M.G.'s proposal.
 I.M.G. seems to have the ear of everyone in the women's tennis business except its own clients, Monica Seles and Jennifer Capriati, whose continuing absence is one of the reasons selling the sponsorship has been so difficult.
 "We don't have anything up our sleeve, and believe me, I wish we had a sponsor waiting in the wings," said Bob Kain, I.M.G.'s senior executive vice president. "But we have a real stake in women's tennis, and we want to see the sport thrive even if we have to go into the red at first to do it."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Fiscal Plan Puts Health Care Jobs at Risk

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
By calling for huge cuts in Medicaid and social service programs, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to reduce city spending by $1.3 billion is likely to lead to the loss of tens of thousands of jobs in the health care industry, the segment of the New York City economy that has been the strongest source of job growth for more than a decade.
In an interview, David R. Rubenstein, assistant director of the Mayor's Office of Management and Budget, estimated that Medicaid cuts alone would lead to job reductions of 10,000 to 30,000 at hospitals, nursing homes, mental health clinics and other medical centers, and remove $1 billion a year in wages. 
 Since 295,000 people now work in New York City health care jobs, the loss could trim up to 10 percent of the industry's work force. But since health care has been adding about 10,000 jobs a year, Mr. Rubenstein said, the Medicaid cuts might mean a temporary halt in the industry's growth.
Still, the proposed Medicaid cuts would be combined with a sharp reduction in direct city spending in the Department of Social Services, which contracts out foster care and other services to hundreds of private organizations, which themselves employ thousands of workers. Under the Giuliani plan, its budget would be reduced by over $100 million beginning in the fiscal year that begins next July.
In announcing his financial blueprint, Mr. Giuliani said it would lead to a more vibrant economy -- and ultimately job growth -- as banks, advertising firms and other businesses gain confidence in the city's fiscal stability and expand. Hospitals, clinics and social service agencies, he and his advisers said, will be expected to do more with less government support.
"Health care needs may grow, but we can't supply them in the same expensive way," Mr. Rubenstein said. "The Mayor is saying that the choice is not there to continually tax to raise spending."
But the plan has provoked vehement opposition from union leaders and hospital executives, who say it will decimate an industry whose growth is vital to the economy as well as the social fabric of the nation's largest city.
"It's going to be catastrophic," said Dennis Rivera, president of Chapter 1199 of the National Health and Human Services Employees Union, which has 117,000 members in New York state. He estimated that the Mayor's proposal, combined with a plan by Gov. George E. Pataki for even deeper Medicaid cuts, would lead to 100,000 health care job cuts in the state, 80,000 of them in New York City.
If the Governor's budget is adopted and all the elements of Mr. Giuliani's proposals are accepted, the city's health care industry could lose an estimated $5.4 billion. The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which operates 11 public hospitals, would stand to lose more than $1 billion of its $3.4 billion budget.
Experts say it is impossible to predict how the burden of caring for poor people would be shifted, particularly at a time when AIDS, widespread drug abuse and an aging population continue to create demands for medical care and social services. Although many health care and social service workers say there are ways to improve efficiency, they maintain that the Mayor's plan would cut deep into the bone.
"This could almost force us to close up the shop," said Humberto L. Martinez, a psychiatrist and director of the South Bronx Mental Health Council, which provides counseling to over 1,600 patients a year suffering from drug addiction, alcoholism or mental illness. The proposed cutbacks would be a double blow to his organization, since 90 percent of its patients receive Medicaid reimbursements that would be cut, and it has several contracts with the city's Department of Mental Health, which would lose 4 percent of its $91.3 budget under the Mayor's plan.
Economists say the spillover of job loss in health care and social services is difficult to predict. At City Hall, Mr. Rubenstein said the ripples would be "minimal" compared to cutbacks in other, higher wage industries, where lost jobs mean deep reductions in consumer spending and income taxes.
Still, many experts say medical care and social services have a special role in New York City, because hospitals, mental health clinics and social service centers provide outposts of economic activity in poor neighborhoods.
And wherever they are situated, health and social service centers have provided entry-level employment to thousands of New Yorkers, replacing the garment makers and other manufacturers who had traditionally served as the point of entry into the city's workforce.
"The sad irony is that many of our employees are now going to go on Medicaid and welfare themselves," said Thomas O'Brien, executive director of the Family Care Services of Brooklyn and Queens, which employs 1,800 home care workers who aid sick and elderly Medicaid recipients in their homes.
Many experts outside City Hall applaud the effort to hold down Medicaid costs, saying that health care and social service organizations have grown inefficient, in part because of the relative largess of Medicaid subsidies to New York patients. They maintain that the cuts proposed by the Mayor and the Governor reflect the national campaign to contain medical costs.
"At a time when most of the economy is being forced to become more efficient, these not-for-profit medical and social service folks will have to do the same thing," said Emmanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and planning at New York University. Health and social service industries "should have prepared for radical changes, but they didn't," he added.
As Mayor Giuliani has said repeatedly since announcing his plan for Medicaid cuts, the average reimbursement of patients in the state is higher than in any other state.
Still, whatever the potential long-term benefits of his cuts, there is little dispute over the potential short-term impact on jobs.
"The Mayor is saying that one of the major engines of growth of the last decade is about to konk out," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
He said New York City health care employment had grown by 102,500 since 1980, to 295,300 at the end of last year. The most rapid growth has been since 1988, when overall employment in the city has sunk by 30,000 jobs, and when health care jobs grew by just over 50,000.
Social services, although a smaller sector of the city economy, has grown more rapidly. Since 1980, the number of social service jobs has soared to 148,000 from 66,000, according to Federal figures.
Mayor Giuliani's advisers offer little hope that other industries will pick up the slack. Indeed, in announcing his cuts, the Mayor released a grim economic analysis that concluded that job growth in the city would be far less vigorous than elsewhere in the country.
As a result, even as the mayor predicts that his spending cuts will revitalize the economy, his financial plan forecasts that job growth in the city will not exceed 1 percent a year in each of the next four years, a pace less than half that of the nation.

HEADLINE: CRIME

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio 

 BODY:
The corruption that pervades Indian society in THE GANJA COAST (Fawcett Columbine, $22.50) beggars the imagination -- unless you come prepared by "Season of the Monsoon," Paul Mann's powerful earlier novel about the decay of civil order and moral spine in Bombay. "Corruption is our biggest employer," according to one cynical civil servant. "It is the only part of the economy that works."
George Sansi, the half-Indian, half-English hero of this bold, seductive series, has resigned in disgust from the Bombay police to go into private law practice. But a veiled threat from his former boss sends Sansi undercover to Goa, a sybaritic haven for foreign hippies that is about to become an international free port. For all his experience in human degradation, Sansi is aghast to find the local cops up to their eyes in dope dealing, land grabbing and an exotic new racket involving fresh corpses. 
 "Sometimes India was too much and the coddled Western mind recoiled," writes Mr. Mann, who is English by birth, but who does not himself recoil. On the contrary, he sets astoundingly vivid scenes of a decadent city in the throes of life, the better to draw sharp, grim portraits of characters flirting with bizarre forms of death.
Specimens of New York's flawed humanity -- a low-down crowd that takes in two-bit politicians, mob flunkies, burned-out cops and various bums from the outer boroughs -- always get a fair hearing in Ken Gross's gritty crime novels. But in FULL BLOWN RAGE (Forge/Tom Doherty, $21), this magnanimous author has to do some fancy tap-dancing to find a redeeming quality in Eric Miller, who is running around the city deliberately passing on the AIDS virus.
This atypical serial killer was infected at the medical laboratory where he works, so you have to admit that he has a beef with the world. That's still not enough to sustain his warped but basically monochromatic character. As the author himself acknowledges, "The only truly distinctive thing about Eric Miller was his rage."
The suicide of a young female victim brings a police detective named Maggie Van Zandt into the case. This new protagonist is not as jaded as Jack Mann (the hard-bitten detective who keeps another procedural series by Mr. Gross in fighting shape), giving her a less jaundiced perspective and the possibility of a longer career on the force.
But for now, Maggie is still learning the ropes, and her case doesn't give the author much room to do what he does best: mining the humor and the pathos and, in some cases, the honor of underworld characters the rest of society has written off as pretty much beneath contempt.
Has anyone ever been able to read "Gulliver's Travels" without labeling his friends and foes as Yahoos, Houyhnhnms, Lilliputians or Brobdingnagians? Brian Herrick, the victim in Bartholomew Gill's witty literary mystery THE DEATH OF AN ARDENT BIBLIOPHILE (Morrow, $20), was not one to resist that temptation. The curator of Marsh's Library in Dublin and an idolater of Jonathan Swift, Herrick affected the writer's cutting tongue as well as his golden curls and 18th-century dress. "The moment he called me his 'gentle and reasonable Houyhnhnm,' " an archivist notes, "I should have known that the man was deranged."
Herrick made a point of emulating his hero's foibles as well as his intellect; but one seriously doubts that the Dean of St. Patrick's Cathedral sat around naked in his conservatory, swilling whisky and casting exotic physical specimens in amateur porn videos. Before someone slipped a lethal poison into his Glenfinnan, the rogue librarian was even pilfering Swift's manuscripts for his own collection.
As he did in "The Death of a Joyce Scholar," another clever puzzle mystery for the brainy detective Peter McGarr, Mr. Gill knows how to have fun with books and bibliophiles. And unlike the abominable Herrick, the author finds cunning ways to work Swiftian literary themes without parroting, parodying or otherwise robbing the master satirist of his robust style.
Outcasts, outlaws and other dysfunctional types have a friend in Laurie R. King, whose first mystery, "A Grave Talent," took a sympathetic view of a child murderer. TO PLAY THE FOOL (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $21) extends this compassion to the bands of aimless wanderers who congregate in Golden Gate Park in San Francisco.
Kate Martinelli, the scrappy cop who keeps this new series honest and interesting, can't pick up a coherent clue from these people to the killing and cremation of a homeless man, known as John, and his dog, known as Theophilus. But she has a hunch that a beloved local character who calls himself Brother Erasmus knows more than he's saying -- and that is enigmatic enough, since he speaks only in biblical and literary quotations.
Through dogged police work and with some research assistance from accommodating souls at the Graduate Theological Union in Berkeley, Kate learns that the charismatic Erasmus is involved in a modern-day "fools movement" of people who cultivate their lunacy for subversive purposes.
Although Kate, her lover and her partner tend to talk in the same flat idiom, eccentric characters like Brother Erasmus and a philosophical bag lady named Beatrice express themselves in a much richer language. If these be fools, then pass out the caps and bells to the rest of us.
Self-serving political factions have weakened the stability of the state, perfidious advisers plot to undermine the nation's leader, and the barbarians are howling at the gate. No, it's not present-day Washington but ancient Egypt in the fifth year of the reign of Tutankhamen. Lynda S. Robinson, who made spirited work of re-creating Theban court life in her first mystery, "Murder in the Place of Anubis," makes history live and breathe again in MURDER AT THE GOD'S GATE (Walker, $19.95) by exposing the ruthless rivalries among the boy Pharaoh's priests, courtiers and relatives.
Lord Meren, "the Eyes and Ears of Pharaoh," gets his first inkling that some treachery is afoot when one of his spies, a priest at the Temple of Amun, is shoved from the colossal statue of Tut that the young pup has presumptuously placed on the threshold of this sacred place. Because "the secrets of the temple are as hidden as the underworld," Meren must conduct his investigation in stealth. But when someone silences another priest by slipping a handful of cobras among his writing implements, the court detective suspects a conspiracy against the King himself.
Ms. Robinson is an archeologist by training and a storyteller by inclination. Using her scholarship to penetrate the inner precincts of court and temple, she has written a complex and exciting narrative that reflects the twisted machinations of politicians -- royal and otherwise.
