HEADLINE: TOUGH TEXAN;
Phil Gramm

BYLINE: By Richard L. Berke; Richard L. Berke is the national political correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
YOU'RE GONNA BE AMAZED," boasts Senator Phil Gramm as the lights dim and he proceeds to demonstrate to a roomful of potential supporters on a recent Saturday in Columbia, S.C., how -- step by step -- he will win the Republican nomination for President of the United States.
The show, featuring colorful graphics flashing across a screen, might well be called Gramm the Invincible. It is meant to scare rivals into thinking they have no chance to catch up in fund raising and organization, and to convince Republicans that they had better join the juggernaut. 
 The barrage of figures is daunting, as intended: A green sack of money with a dollar sign pops on the screen as Gramm details precisely how he will raise $44,706,512 for the nomination. Then come the names of every person Gramm says he has met in the last four years. There are 164,454, including 62,359 in Iowa, site of the first caucuses a year from now, broken down by date, time and place. Punch in the names Jack and Patti Barnette of Marietta, Ga., on a computer and up flashes their photograph and a file that includes even their car phone number.
When Gramm declares his candidacy this week, he will be the first major contender to do so formally. But already, he argues gleefully if not presumptuously, the field is down to himself and Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, because the logistical demands are so overwhelming that "there are probably not more than two campaigns that can do this."
It is an impressive, unapologetically raw display of political might that he takes around the country. And it leaves no doubt how a two-term Senator from Texas who is known as more bully than charmer, who looks more like a round-faced, stoop-shouldered Muppet than a stately public servant, has propelled himself into the top tier of Republican contenders, at least at this early stage. His motto is simple: "There's only one speed on my motor -- and that's all out."
But the qualities that make Gramm seem unstoppable have long aroused suspicion among his colleagues, Republican and Democratic, that could ultimately unhinge his quest to win over Republican primary voters. His unvarnished hustle and zest for savaging rivals is awe-inspiring to some; to others it is off-putting. He is a clear-headed man of ideas, but not of compassion. He has an undignified stridency that can make Bob Dole seem gentlemanly.
"Dole is in many ways more restrained, more measured," says former Senator Warren B. Rudman, a Republican from New Hampshire who worked closely with the Texan on the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing bill in the 1980's and supports Dole. "He has a certain calmness that you don't find in Phil particularly. If you want to go one afternoon and relax, don't go with Phil Gramm."
From the earliest days of his political career, Gramm, 52, has been in a hurry -- and always in attack mode. In 1986, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York was so outraged by Gramm depicting him as weak on the military that he scolded Gramm: "You're one year in the Senate, fella, you don't do that to another Senator."
The message didn't sink in. A year later, during the Supreme Court confirmation battle over Robert Bork, Gramm savagely cut off two opposing Democrats, Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Joseph Biden of Delaware. Referring to accusations that they cheated as students, he snapped, "The American people know what the people who cheated in college think." Last summer, Gramm tore into Roger C. Altman, then the deputy treasury secretary, at Whitewater hearings, saying, "You didn't tell the truth."
This is a man who once sent a longtime foe, Representative Chet Edwards, a Democrat from Waco, a card that proclaimed, "I feel so sorry for your many problems, but you deserve them."
Braggadocio comes easily to Gramm. True to his professorial roots, he tends to lecture rather than talk. Gramm has perfected the art -- widely known on Capitol Hill as "Gramm-standing" -- of opposing a project for his state on the grounds of cost, then, after the project was approved over his objections, calling a news conference to take the credit.
Gramm delights in playing the bad boy. "One of the problems today is we have a President who wants desperately to be loved," he says. He once assured a dinner audience that he did have a heart, though. "I keep it in a quart jar on my desk."
The image that Gramm will stop at nothing to win is steeped in more than his mordant oratory. He has hired R. J. (Duke) Bodisch, a handgun-toting Texas police officer turned political consultant, to conduct campaign research. Gramm says Bodisch's assignment, for now, is to computerize clippings. But Bodisch says his role is to "look under rocks and see if anything's there" on Gramm's Republican rivals.
In the world of Presidential politics, where there is a premium on opportunism, arrogance and hunger for power and publicity, Gramm has those traits in abundance. But is it too much? Is he too calculating, too consumed, too ruthless -- too, well, mean to be elected President? John B. Connally, a former Texas Governor, learned that outspending his rivals in the 1980 primaries did not buy him the voters' affection. His $12 million netted only one delegate.
But maybe the public will again yearn for a no-nonsense leader. Maybe Gramm epitomizes a new political climate, in which the take-no-prisoners rhetoric of a Rush Limbaugh -- or a Phil Gramm -- are popular. "He's mean. But I like mean," Carmen McNew says after hearing Gramm speak at a cocktail reception for Louisiana Republicans in Baton Rouge.
Richard Bond, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee, dismisses the notion that personality matters. "Since when has meanness or niceness been one of the qualifications?" he asks. "Do I want him to be the godfather to my children? That's not how you evaluate a Presidential candidate."
Even harsh critics like Representative Jim Chapman, a Democrat from Sulphur Springs, Tex., speak admiringly of Gramm's political shrewdness. It will get him the Republican nomination, he predicts, but not the White House because "under the microscope and scrutiny that a serious Presidential contender gets, the meanness will ultimately come through."
PHIL GRAMM IS MORE complicated than the rabidly partisan, classic good ol' boy who looked oddly out of place during the State of the Union: Like a boisterous frat boy, he leapt from his seat to lead the hoots and hollers when President Clinton appropriated Republican language about shrinking Government.
Gramm failed the third, seventh and ninth grades yet became an economist with a Ph.D. and a Senator recognized as one of the brightest. Up north, his deep Southern drawl makes him sound like Gramm the cracker, unsophisticated, yet he is partial to Gilbert and Sullivan. His snarling facade masks a man who loves dogs, who in the divorce settlement with his first wife kept their two Saint Bernards.
Though he can be intimidating, Gramm has a disarming ability of serving up complicated proposals in a folksy manner. His trademark is the story of Dicky Flatt, a print-shop owner from Mexia, Tex., who struggles for a living and "never quite gets the ink off the end of his fingers." Before lawmakers vote for a program, he says, they should ask if "it's worth taking money away from Dicky Flatt."
Gramm, notably, is consistent in his beliefs. Two decades ago, in his first, failed Senate bid, Gramm sounded the identical themes about "the threats of uncontrollable Government" that he sounds today. He thinks he can beat Dole by presenting himself to the hard-right Republicans who vote in primaries as the only candidate who was "conservative before conservative was cool." Gramm tries to out-conservative Dole at every turn. Unlike Dole, he opposes welfare even for legal immigrants and favors a limit on additional benefits for welfare mothers who have more children. And Gramm parted company with Dole and Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich to oppose Clinton's initial plan to support the peso, saying there were financial risks not addressed. He also takes a hard line against abortion and other social issues, though some religious conservatives worry that he is more committed to economic matters.
A sense of purpose, and great sense of himself, has allowed Gramm to be an influential, sometimes blaring, voice on issues that were not in the purview of his committees, as with his early ridicule of Clinton's health care proposal. When other Republicans were counseling compromise, he said the plan would pass over "my cold, dead political body."
Gramm says his ability to see things starkly comes from his mother, Florence, an 81-year-old retired practical nurse who has two other sons from a first marriage. She now lives just over the Georgia border in Phenix City, Ala. Don White, one of Gramm's half brothers, says her philosophy was: "Take a stand. Don't weasel. Everything was basically black and white. A guy was either honest or a crook."
As appealing as it may be compared with a President known for his waffling, Gramm's unwavering posture contributes to a perception that he is unduly rigid. Given his belief that the Gramm way is always the right way, he often is controlling and demanding.
"I certainly remember in the '84 campaign getting calls at 2 or 3 in the morning to the point that we moved our phone from my wife's side of the bed to my side," says John Weaver, a consultant on several Gramm campaigns.
On occasion, Gramm's power plays backfire. At last summer's Texas Republican Convention, he tried to have his handpicked candidate, Representative Joe Barton, installed as the state chairman. While both Barton and his opponent, Tom Pauken, were backed by religious conservatives, the rank-and-file resented the interference and chose Pauken, who says, "We don't want to be told from the top who ought to run the party."
Often, it seems, Gramm cannot help but meddle. Sitting back in his office surrounded by trophy footballs, R. C. Slocum, the Aggies football coach at Texas A & M University, allows how the Senator calls him after every game to register his critique. "He'll say, 'You know, coach, you know we weren't very good today on the offensive line,' " Slocum says. "He's got a real honest quality about him. That may not be a good trait for a politician, but where I come from they take a little pride in toughness."
WILLIAM PHILIP GRAMM'S feelings of superiority were apparent during his early years growing up in Columbus, Ga., where another future Republican rebel, Newt Gingrich, also attended high school. Gramm's half brother, Don White remembers that when the Senator was in grade school, he played the colonel in an Army of neighborhood kids. "The youngest kid, little Henry, went to my mother in tears, saying, 'I'm the only sergeant, and they're all colonels or captains.' So my mother said, 'I'll talk to the colonel,' " White recalls.
Young Gramm had a solution: He promoted Henry to lieutenant -- and himself to major general.
Gramm's independence arose from necessity. His father, Kenneth, a career Army sergeant who had been stationed at nearby Fort Benning, became partly paralyzed soon after Gramm was born because of a stroke and heart condition. He died when Gramm was 14. With her husband in and out of veterans hospitals, Florence Gramm worked double shifts to support the family, leaving White, five years older, to write checks, buy groceries and sign Gramm's report card.
Resisting both authority and schoolwork, Gramm preferred to cavort with friends. After Gramm took his mother's Plymouth on a joyride when he was 16, she dispatched him to the Georgia Military Academy.
He underwent a transformation there. "In the America I grew up in," he says in his stock campaign speech, "mothers' dreams don't die easily." He got degrees in economics at the University of Georgia. In 1963, when he was a 21-year-old bank teller by day and student by night, Gramm married a fellow student, Sherry Kinney. They divorced in 1969, two years after arriving at Texas A & M. Asked about the divorce, he clams up, saying, "It's personal." But, eager to stanch any notion that his past could haunt his ambitions, he adds, "I am certain she will support me for President."
Despite Gramm's compelling personal story, there are contradictions in it. For instance, Gramm succeeded in large part by the grace of Federal assistance but is now an outspoken critic of Government social programs. He defends himself, saying, "I've never said Government was all bad."
Then there is the draft. Gramm received deferments from serving in Vietnam. "As a 26-year-old Ph.D. in economics I could have quit my job at A & M and joined the Army," he said. "I would have probably ended up working in some library somewhere or maybe teaching at West Point or working in the Pentagon. But I thought what I was doing at Texas A & M was important." In fact, his first deferment was granted when Gramm was still in Georgia. That did not stop Gramm from vigorously campaigning on behalf of a fellow Republican against Chet Edwards in 1990, declaring that Edwards "didn't serve in the military and I don't know where he will run next." Gramm tells audiences that his father and brothers served. But there will be the inevitable comparisons with Dole, a hero of World War II.
TO UNDERSTAND WHY PHIL Gramm thinks he will be President is to understand his history of going after the impossible so relentlessly that, sooner or later, he gets what he wants. A case in point is how he courted his second wife, Wendy Lee Gramm, a former chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission with whom Gramm has two college-age sons. They met in 1969, when she was at a conference in Manhattan, interviewing for a job as an economics professor at Texas A & M, where he was already teaching. He sat quietly watching the interview and then ushered her out. "He gets my coat," she recalls, "he holds it on and he says in a very thick Southern accent, 'As a single member of the faculty, I'd be very interested in having you come to Texas A & M.' And I turn around and say, 'Oh, yuck!' " She got the job; the Gramms were married six weeks after she arrived at College Station. "He was very persistent," she says.
Charles Maurice, an A & M economics professor, recalls: "I thought he was pushing a little too hard at the time. This was a sophisticated girl. It's hard for you to imagine Phil being charming, but, doggone, he can be."
Gramm has always been in a hurry. He threw himself so single-mindedly into his work and his research that he was appointed A & M's youngest full professor at age 30.
Having conquered academics, Gramm tried politics -- and set his sights high. Then a conservative Democrat, he took on Senator Lloyd Bentsen in the 1976 primary. Democrats were aghast that Gramm did not wait his turn. But it was a pattern that would mark his career. Gramm went after Bentsen for running for the Senate while toying with a Presidential bid, saying he "so shamelessly put his own self-interest above those of his state and nation." (There is no talk from Gramm these days about the propriety of running for the Senate and President simultaneously, as Gramm plans to do in 1996.)
Gramm lost miserably, but he never stopped running. Two years later, he was elected to the House, where he quickly made a name for himself with proposals to balance the budget that would become his rallying cry. Gramm quit his seat in early 1983 after the Democrats ousted him from the Budget Committee, branding him a traitor for secretly scheming with Reagan Administration officials on a substitute budget plan. He ran for re-election eight weeks later, as a Republican, and won decisively.
The next year, he leaped at the opportunity to run for the seat held by Senator John Tower, who was retiring. He defeated his Democratic rival, Lloyd Doggett, after relentlessly attacking him for accepting a donation from a male strip show sponsored by gay men in San Antonio.
Unlike Jack Kemp, Dick Cheney and Dan Quayle, who spent years thinking about running for President but ultimately lacked the stomach for it, the race has been practically inevitable for Gramm. He has out-organized other contenders in states where Republican parties have held nonbinding straw polls. Gramm's biggest coup so far was getting elected chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee from 1990 to 1994. The post enabled him to travel the country on behalf of candidates, building contacts, and adding his name to the committee's statewide polls.
Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky had challenged Gramm for the Senatorial committee, accusing him of using it to further his Presidential aspirations. That is just what Gramm did; and he is unapologetic.
While there is little affection for Gramm among his colleagues, there is grudging respect. "I guess he proved me wrong," McConnell now says. "He was able to lead us back to the majority in the Senate and to promote himself for the Presidency."
HOLDING HIS HAND aloft to a volunteer driver after a campaign stop, Gramm concedes that sometimes the vaunted campaign machine can break down. "My little finger hurts all the time from shaking hands," he says. "I have to be very careful so I don't grimace."
Wendy Gramm may help soften her husband's image. Affable and engaging, she was not, however, featured prominently in the earliest campaigns out of fear among some advisers that her Korean-American descent might turn off voters.
But Gramm is undeterred. As his small chartered King Air prop plane jerked violently through tornado weather over South Carolina recently, the politician turned ashen, suggesting that he knew more about flying than the pilot. "Look at the altimeter!" he says, jabbing his finger toward the pilot. "They don't know how to fly these things."
The plane came to a bumpy landing and the pilot turned to apologize to Gramm. But the Senator was already opening the plane door, anxious to jump into the driving rain. Once again he was due to present his formula for victory to another group of Republicans, this time in Greenville.
The candidate who vows to outsmart, outpace and outspend his rivals did not want to be late.

HEADLINE: Stretching Your Money in Mexico

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR; SYLVIA NASAR is an economics reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
IF the Mexican peso stays near its current level it will cost a mere 19 cents on Presidents' Day vs. 29 cents last Thanksgiving.
Great news for potential travelers north of the border, you think. But while the cheaper peso boosts Americans' purchasing power dramatically in theory, actually reaping the benefits will require some planning, a bit of extra legwork and a willingness to go somewhere other than the large beach resorts. 
 The basic rule of thumb is that to get a bargain -- a 35 percent discount, in effect -- you have to pay in pesos. And many parts of a trip from the United States to Mexico automatically come with a dollar price tag: a round-trip ticket from your hometown (though some carriers have lowered fares because they can buy cheap fuel in pesos), a room at a big resort hotel, an all-inclusive package tour that wraps up meals, hotel and transportation, a stay at most spas with an international clientele.
"It all really depends on the kind of trip you're taking," says Kirk Whisler, publisher of Mexico Events and Destinations, a travel quarterly with a circulation of 100,000 in the United States and Canada. It is based in Escondido, Calif.
Outside the glitzy international resorts like Ixtapa or Cancun, anyone who has visited Mexico can tell you, most merchants, restaurateurs and innkeepers who cater to tourists' needs, even in Mexico City, charge in pesos.
So the key is to plan your trip to pay for the minimum (your air fare to and from Mexico) in dollars and the maximum (just about everything else from in-country flights to three-course dinners to dangly silver earrings) in pesos.
Here are some tips for seizing the peso's low moment:
 
Avoid prepaid packages. You won't get many breaks if you buy a package in the United States that includes air fare, hotel, ground transportation and meals, convenient as one-stop shopping may be. Tour operators haven't trimmed their dollar prices yet. And you'll only get a break on meals and purchases if you buy a package that includes just air fare and hotel.
"Package prices haven't gone down yet," said Richard A. Ellis, senior vice president of marketing for Lib/Go, parent company of Liberty Travel and Gogo Tours, America's biggest tour operator. "The business is being driven more by perception that it's cheaper than by reality."
He added, "But we'd expect many of our most popular packages to go down about 15 to 20 percent this summer."
Dolores Avelos, a spokeswoman for Camino Real Hotels and Resorts, a chain of 20 hotels clustered in Mexico's most popular beach resorts said, "We've always quoted the prices of our rooms and packages in dollars and we haven't changed the prices in dollars."
 
Pay in Pesos. Book the bulk of your nights at hotels and travel within Mexico and pay in pesos, including flights on Mexicana and Aeromexico. Doing so will save you $25 to $50 a night in a typical hotel in Mexico City, or $30 to $55 on round-trip flights from Mexico City to popular destinations like Oaxaca, Guadalajara or Merida. The fares to these places now range from $55 to $82.
Bud Mertens, a Californian retiree who flew to Guadalajara first, then Mexico City and is thinking about visiting some of the colonial cities next, is adopting this model.
"I've been to the beach resorts, but this time I wanted a more cultural experience. So when the news of the devaluation came it helped prompt the trip," he said.
Finding rooms and flights shouldn't be too taxing. Travel agents can be found at the airport or in the lobby of any large hotel. And you probably won't have to worry about finding a room. Mexico's economic crisis has hit leisure and business travel by Mexicans very hard and empty hotels and restaurants abound.
If, for the sake of convenience, you want to book a night or two in a hotel in Mexico City from home, doing so should cost about $75 to $125 a night.
 
Skip the hot spots. Travel experts call the top resorts -- Cancun, Puerto Vallarta, Cozumel, Ixtapa -- dollar destinations for a reason. Half of all American travelers wind up there, prices are comparable to Miami's, and everything is so geared to dollars that Americans rarely have to change money into pesos.
Big resorts are also the places that will draw the biggest increase in travelers from the United States and elsewhere -- bookings are already up 18 percent this season, according to Mexican tourism officials -- and where peso prices of everything from cab rides to embroidered blouses will catch up the fastest. If you're wedded to the idea of staying at a big resort, consider Acapulco, which has increasingly become a destination for Mexican travelers.
 
Head for the hinterlands. Colonial cities within a few hours' drive of Mexico City -- San Miguel de Allende, Cuernavaca, Taxco, for example -- or a short plane ride -- Guadalajara, Merida or Oaxaca in the south -- are packed with small independent hotels, excellent restaurants and bountiful shopping opportunities. What makes them a bargain is that they are geared primarily to Mexicans. Except for a scattering of the big international chain hotels, they are cheaper than Mexico City, you pay in pesos and prices aren't apt to shoot up immediately to compensate for the cheaper currency.
"If they go to these places, Americans will get bargains," says Raul Feliz Ortiz, an economist at El Colegio de Mexico.
Take Cuernavaca, an airy Spanish town in the mountains an hour's drive from Mexico City and much favored by the capital's professional elite. The price of lodging at the luxury Las Mananitas Hotel ranges from 460 pesos (about $85 as of mid-February) for a standard double to 635 pesos ($123) for a midsized suite. At the Hacienda de Cortes, another small, independent hotel, the price of a double room is 314 pesos ($58).
Also consider San Miguel de Allende, three hours from Mexico City, a cobblestoned city with a church on every corner, often described as one of the prettiest in Mexico. The upscale Hotel de Sierra Nevada offers a standard double for 535 pesos a night ($99, $31 cheaper than if you booked the same room from the United States). And room prices at the simple Hotel Sautto, favored by art students, are even more modest, 90 pesos ($17) a night.
In most colonial cities, says Mr. Whisler of Mexico Events and Destinations, visitors should generally expect to pay $40 to $50 a night for a hotel room, on average, and $5 to $10 for a meal at such destinations. Many of the colonial cities specialize in one set of wares or another. In Oaxaca it's textiles, in Puebla pottery and, of course, in Taxco silver.
 
Use your credit card. Better restaurants and hotels and even Fonart shops, the state-run crafts stores, let you charge. Anything you charge goes on your card in pesos. Charging saves you the trouble of worrying about whether you're converting at the best rate. Of course, you're only getting the best rate that obtains when the card company records the transaction, which might be better or worse than the rate on the day of your purchase.
 
Change your money at the airport or at an A.T.M. Stop in at a Casa de Cambio right at the airport as you clear customs. You'll do far better than at your hotel or at home. A.T.M.'s, which can be hard to find, have good rates too.
 
Travel sooner, not later. Inflation could eat away at the savings, if you wait too far beyond the summer.
Prices in Mexico rose a full 5 percent in the month after the devaluation, suggesting that the Government's 19 percent inflation target for 1995 may prove too optimistic. Economists who have studied past devaluations in Latin America say that, on average, roughly half of the effects are offset within a year by higher domestic prices.
The good news is that the price increases tourists face may turn out to be more modest, says Mr. Feliz Ortiz. Many restaurants have agreed to abide by the Government's price freeze, he points out. More important, given the big drop in travel by Mexican vacationers and businessmen, most restaurants and hotels are eager to attract foreign travelers.
Even in Mexico City, recent travelers say, the overwhelming majority of hotels, restaurants, shops and taxis haven't raised prices much if at all. And, in smaller cities and towns, according to Mr. Cerda of La Mananitas, prices haven't yet budged. So, unless Mexico slides into hyperinflation, in which case all bets are off, the bargains could last well into the summer season and even until next winter.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-DATE: February 19, 1995

SECTION: Section 2; Page 30; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1358 words

HEADLINE: JAZZ VIEW;
A Small Club's Role as Arbiter of Hipness

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous 

 BODY:
FOR DECADES, THE VILLAGE Vanguard, which is celebrating its 60th anniversary this week by giving itself a party, has been an important outpost in a continuing American cultural experiment. Unrepentantly partisan, it has glorified the homegrown and avoided pretension in its mission to frame the humor, poetry and music of what is sometimes called the street, defined as anything American, anything separate from the academy. And the party, which runs Tuesday through Sunday, explains where the club has been: Allen Ginsberg, Shirley Horn, Bobby Short, Dick Gregory, Pete Seeger and Professor Irwin Corey are all showing up to pay tribute and to perform.
That list -- and the staggering lineup of performers over the years, from Barbra Streisand and Woody Allen to John Coltrane and Thelonious Monk -- also suggests that the Vanguard, small, underground and unprepossesing, has been a witness to and participant in a startling transformation: the elevation of its esthetic from the marginal and hip to the mainstream. The Vanguard has been a shrine for what is good about this century, and the century has caught up with it. 
 Much of the credit belongs to the elfin Max Gordon, who started the club in 1935. Gordon ran what he called a "joint." But he was the consummate talent scout. And he was open-minded, mixing poetry readings with cabaret, jazz with folk music and comedy with everything. (Gordon himself could be funny; once, when two men with baguettes were holding mock military maneuvers in front of the club's door, he suggested that someone ask them if they needed butter.) The Vanguard was one of a handful of clubs in the Village that had a relationship to jazz, and one of an even smaller minority that had an eclectic booking policy. It was the prototypical Village bohemian club.
When Gordon opened the club's doors at 178 Seventh Avenue South, bohemia and the Village actually meant something, holding a special place in the intellectual history of the city and in the imagination of the country. Patrons usually came from the neighborhood, attracted by the spectacle as well as by the nonexistent cover charge. Gordon knew what people wanted to hear, and audiences also knew to trust his taste. Putting on special shows like Lenny Bruce and Roy Eldridge, or Professor Irwin Corey, Sylvia Syms and the Clarence Williams Trio, the Vanguard drew an audience of cognoscenti who were defining the culture of the city. New York was king, jazz was its music, and sophisticated humor and politics were the oil that ran its machinery.
In 1957, Gordon changed the booking policy, limiting it to jazz. Rock-and-roll was becoming the dominant popular music, but Gordon kept the Vanguard on the jazz path. It was home (and recording studio) to the likes of John Coltrane, Sonny Rollins, Gerry Mulligan, Bill Evans, Cannonball Adderley and Charles Mingus. All across the city, clubs folded, but the Vanguard thrived because of Gordon's exceptional sense of talent.
A list of just a few of the albums recorded at the club suggest why it is without equal. The saxophonist Sonny Rollins recorded "A Night at the Village Vanguard" there; the pianist Bill Evans, "Sunday at the Village Vanguard"; John Coltrane recorded several albums there, including "Live at the Village Vanguard," and the saxophonist Dexter Gordon celebrated his return from exile in Europe by recording "Homecoming, Live at the Vanguard." All these albums either influenced the course of jazz or had a significant impact on the careers of the artists.
The Vanguard was, and remains, the club that musicians who can fill concert halls come to to feel again an intimate connection with an audience. Miles Davis, Sonny Rollins, Wynton Marsalis, Dexter Gordon, Harry Connick Jr. and more have all spent weeks there when they could easily have opted for the concert hall.
Part of the attraction is the space itself. It's an odd room, shaped like a pie wedge. It has bad sight lines; the drummer usally sits behind a column, and nowhere in the club can one see the entire band. But it is the best-sounding club in the city, the Carnegie Hall of jazz clubs.
One of the great pleasures of the place is to wander around, to experiment with the sound; it's an exercise in sensuality, and regulars have their favorite spots. Back by the air conditioner the sound is as clear as a snow-fed mountain stream. Toward the bar it becomes thicker, richer. And to understand what really goes on during a set, one can sit in the last seat on the right-hand banquette, next to the drummer. It is there that one hears exactly what the musicians hear, every hiss and shudder, the drums responding to the feints of a horn player, all the rhythmic workings, the shades and colors -- everything that makes small group jazz thrilling.
The closeness to the musicians does more than allow audiences to understand the music; it also returns the music to a more democratic place. Musicians have to pass through the audience on their way back to their dressing room, formerly the club's legendary kitchen, often talking to patrons and shaking hands as they go. (The dressing room hasn't been used as a kitchen since sandwiches and hamburgers were prepared there until sometime in the late 1950's or early 1960s; like much of the Vanguard's history, specifics are obscured in the haze of cigarettes and liquor). The process of moving from the band stand to the audience makes the musicians approachable and real, in a way that's rarely seen in popular music. It's open and friendly as opposed to elitist and standoffish.
Home of debate and camaraderie, the kitchen itself is a place worthy of a doctoral dissertation. For years, musicians would come to listen to their peers and occasionally sit in on a third set late at night. The bandstand is a great lectern, but between sets -- or before or after them -- musicians congregated in the kitchen to discuss music, make plans, spread the news and joke around. Jazz musicians are usually busy, traveling constantly, and they rarely have a chance to talk shop with one another. The Vanguard's kitchen has always served as a meeting ground.
Entering the kitchen meant entering territory controlled by musicians; it was a nerve center of musicians' culture: funny, literate, a place of wisdom. To feel comfortable in it, one has to know the musicians. And it was the place that Thelonious Monk practiced the dance steps he used on stage.
Neither recessions nor changing tastes in jazz have affected the Vanguard's success, and the club seems to be doing better now than it did in the last decade. When Mr. Gordon died in 1989, the club was taken over by his wife, Lorraine, who has preserved her husband's vision while keeping the club afloat financially. Mrs. Gordon has not only regularly booked established musicians like Bobby Hutcherson, Charles McPherson, Cecil Taylor and Tommy Flanagan; she's also given top young musicians like Jacky Terrasson and Terence Blanchard their first weeklong engagements in an important club and provided a stage for jazz-related, avant-garde performers like the guitarist Bill Frisell and the clarinetist Don Byron.
She has also sustained her husband's adventurousness; for the last two years, for example, she has brought in a rhythm section of Kenny Barron, Buster Williams and Ben Riley for three weeks while changing the featured soloist with the band every week. Not all the adventures have been successful, but there are few club owners in New York as eager to experiment as she is.
And despite her openness to innovation, Mrs. Gordon has kept the club the most consistent jazz spot in New York. (She has also kept it uncorrupted, minimizing dependency on record-company handouts and turning down potentially lucrative licensing deals to set up Village Vanguards all over the world.) Such steadfastness has made the club a kind of shrine, and on any given night of the week one is likely to see tourists from farflung places, suffering various degrees of jet lag and sobriety, but all clearly happy to experience something that can only be experienced in one place, the Village Vanguard.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Back-Country Greenwich;
Winding Roads and Deep Pockets

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THE farmers and shoemakers who settled the lonely northern reaches of Greenwich in the 18th and early 19th centuries would be astounded to see what has become of their neighborhood.
Renowned as one of America's most prestigious addresses, the back country of this Connecticut Gold Coast community is not for everyone who is rich. Families of highly placed executives who traditionally shun publicity gravitate to its silent woods and quiet, winding roads, while celebrities tend to prefer the waterfront and a livelier atmosphere. 
 As a recent example, the television and sports personalities Kathie Lee and Frank Gifford recently moved from the back country to a waterfront location.
The legendary great estates are investments that hold their value in recessions and appreciate when times are good. But other back-country homes are equally resilient, whether they are antique farmhouses expanded into handsome residences, large homes on the minimum four-acre lots, or modest houses in the Banksville section on the New York State border.
The term great estates is reserved for exceptional homes on the shore, in the mid-country and the back country. The latter covers an area bounded by the Merritt Parkway to the south, Westchester County to the west and north, and Stamford to the east.
Among the most famous of the back country's 13 great estates is Dunnellen Hall, currently owned by Leona and Harry Helmsley. Completed in 1918, it was built for Daniel Grey Reid, a New York financier, as a gift for his daughter, Rhea, and her husband, Henry J. Topping, son of the president of Republic Steel.
Situated at one time on 208 acres, the 28-room Elizabethan mansion had additional accommodations for 23 servants. The lake was stocked with perch and black bass, and there was an eight-car garage, stables, pool, tennis court, greenhouse, a working farm and specimen gardens.
It was used to advantage by the Toppings' sons, who entertained lavishly and enjoyed the company of movie stars. Don and Henry Jr. each married the actress Arlene Judge, at different times of course; Don was also married to Sonja Henie, and Henry Jr. was wed to Lana Turner.
It usually takes a year or more for estates to be sold because the market is obviously limited and the owners can afford to wait for the right buyer. The Nuckols Estate, for example, on 14 acres, is for sale at $18 million, the highest current price on the market.
"It is seldom shown," said Linda Hodge, vice president of Preferred Properties of Greenwich, a company that specializes in marketing high-priced homes. "The price reflects the value of scarce prime land close to New York," she said.
THERE are no restaurants or shops except in Banksville, where a tannery once served a shoemaking cottage industry. But the Uptown Deli and Finch's serve breakfast and lunch to people who work on the estates, and an IGA market, dry cleaner, pharmacy and hardware store are patronized by area residents.
There is also a general store on Round Hill Road opposite the firehouse. The firehouse, which is home base for about 20 volunteer firefighters, and its equipment are maintained by a $5,000 annual stipend from the town and major contributions from the wealthy residents it serves.
An open house fund-raiser is held there each October when children are given rides on the fire engines.
Brad Hvolbeck, owner of Prudential Hvolbeck Real Estate, sold a 3,800-square-foot house on one acre in Banksville this year for $525,000.
Almost half of back-country children attend private schools, two of which are located in the area. The Whitby Montessori School enrolls children from 1 year old through the eighth grade, with annual tuition ranging from $7,250 to $11,250. The Convent of the Sacred Heart accepts children of all faiths from age 3 through 12th grade. Tuition is $6,000 to $13,900.
The only public school in the area is Parkway Elementary School, where the curriculum includes art, music, science, physical education and a computer lab, all in separately equipped rooms.
CHILDREN maintain their own word-processing files and write stories that are published in the school newspaper or adapted into dance, drama, art or choral music. Almost 300 pupils in kindergarten through the fifth grade are bused for 15 to 40 minutes each way depending on where they live.
"They are not only from wealthy homes," said Dr. Sandra Mond, the principal, "but from families of stable grooms and housekeepers who live on the estates."
The Convent of the Sacred Heart is in the main house of what was once Overlook Farm, built in 1916. It is typical of several conversions of back-country estates in recent years. Together with zoning laws that allow homes to be built on 2-acre lots provided that 40 percent of the total property is dedicated to open space, conversions signal a significant departure from the otherwise rigidly enforced four-acre minimum single family zoning.
In the 70's the American Can Company bought Knob Hill Farm, built in 1916, retaining the main house as a guest house for its new corporate headquarters on the 154-acre King Street parcel.
Faircroft, completed on King Street in 1905 by James Rich Steers, whose construction company built Pennsylvania Station, was owned briefly by Clare Boothe Luce and expanded considerably in the 60's for AVCO Corporation headquarters.
It had a succession of office tenants over the years but has been vacant for two years partly because town zoning allows only 150 employees in the 90,000-square-foot building.
One of the subdivided estates is Conyers Farm, comprising 60 lots on 1,300 acres along North Street. Four homes are on the market through Mr. Hvolbeck. A colonial on 12 acres is listed at $3.35 million, and $8.2 million is the price of a Scottish-style castle, also on 12 acres. Building lots start at $1.2 million.
Conyers Manor -- once on the property, but demolished in the mid-80's -- was built in 1904 by Edmund Cogswell Converse. His farm was a highly profitable enterprise employing dozens of local people in its dairy, produce farm, stables, garages, orchards and stone quarries. The manor was subsequently demolished.
In 1981, the estate of Lewis Rosenstiel, the late chairman of Schenley's, sold the property to Peter Brandt who redeveloped the property into deed-restricted lots of a minimum of 10 acres, some of which have been purchased as horse farms.
Local zoning permits one horse for every half acre. Residents belong to a private association and have sole use of a luxurious clubhouse. In June, July and September there are Sunday afternoon polo matches that are open to the public for $20 a car.
Also under development on King Street, by John and Michael Fareri, is Chieftains, owned through two generations by the Gimbel department store family. It was built in 1911 and occupied until 1925 by Alfred Whitney Church, heir to the Borden milk fortune.
The 15,000-square-foot main house with its 65- by 40-foot living room will be retained as a single-family dwelling on three-plus acres; it is priced at $2.5 million and needs repairs. Several outbuildings will be remodeled as homes and 23 single-family homes will be constructed on the 97-acre tract, where 60 acres will be set aside for open space.
Sales are expected to begin in June; prices range from $975,000 for 2,300 square feet to $1.25 million for 3,600 square feet.
Last June a great estate was actually saved rather than subdivided when the estate of Herbert Mayer sold Old Mill Farm on 78 acres for $9.25 million to an undisclosed owner who registered the sale in the name of two trustees. The estate had a four-lot subdivision approved by the town in the event that it could not find a buyer for the entire property.
FAIRVIEW, Stanwich and Tamarack, three of Greenwich's seven private country clubs, are in the back country, offering golf, tennis, swimming pools and dining rooms. Initiation fees range from $10,000 to $15,000. Bruce Golf Course is public, operated by the town for seasonal memberships of $40 and greens fees of $12.50. Guests of residents may play for $25 a day.
Anyone who owns or has access to a horse may pay $90 a year to join the Riding and Trails Association, which maintains more than 150 miles of trails and must deal diplomatically with the occasional new resident who does not appreciate the time-honored custom of allowing horses to cross his or her property.
The golf course and the country clubs are part of some 5,453 acres of the back country preserved as open space and owned variously by the town, by land trusts, the Audubon Society, schools, the state or householders who dedicate land to conservation.
While public gatherings are rare, one event that draws even the most reclusive of residents is the Christmas Fair held in December in the Round Hill Community House.
"It started as a meeting place for people who worked on the estates," said Cindy Lalor, executive vice president of the 200-member, all-women Round Hill Community Guild. "Now the dominant tone is one of down-to-earth Yankee willingness to pitch in and work for the community, and be careful about money."

GENTLY, BUT FIRMLY: In the 1930's when the Merritt Parkway was in its design stage, it was planned to cut a speedway straight across the estate section of Greenwich. When the route was made public, a contingent of influential back-country residents and fox-hunting groups persuaded the authorities to change the configuration, creating the loop that peaks at four and a half miles north of the original course, avoiding damage to many significant properties.

HEADLINE: For Suburban Homes, Modest Recovery

SERIES: Next week: The market in New York City

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
A RECOVERY that was reserved in most areas and robust in some reigned over the residential real estate market in the New York suburbs last year. Home sales surged in much of Connecticut and Long Island and in Westchester and Rockland Counties and parts of Northern New Jersey -- but fell short of their mid-1980's peaks. Sale prices, in most places, were flat or rose only slightly, barely bouncing off the bottoms hit during the recession in the early 90's.
The increase in sales was sparked, largely, according to real estate brokers and housing analysts, by a slowly receding wave of young, first-time home-buyers, many of whom had been priced out of the market in the 80's. 
 Buyers were also spurred by rapidly rising interest rates -- which climbed last year more than two percentage points, or about $200 a month, for many $150,000 mortgages.
The lack of substantial appreciation, brokers believe, was linked, at least in part, to the large number of homes on the market.
"It wasn't like there was a lot of demand and no property available," said Charles M. Staro, executive vice president of the New York State Association of Realtors. "As long as you have the inventory, demand won't push up prices. It's when you have demand and you don't have the inventory that you get a bidding up in prices like in 1987."
The regional outlook for 1995, according to many brokers, lenders and housing analysts, is for home prices to rise slightly, in tandem with inflation; many economists are projecting that the Consumer Price Index will rise 3 to 3.5 percent this year after rising each of the past two years by 2.7 percent.
The price gains, however, are expected to come not so much from increased sales or consumer demand but thanks to higher interest rates, which have slowed construction of new housing and will help shrink inventories. There may be an increase in trade-up sales in 1995 -- and a decline in the starter home market -- which could lead to rising median sale prices in some surveys of the suburbs.
The overall number of homes sold in the suburbs in 1995 is expected to decline slightly from 1994 levels or remain about the same if the economy slows down, as many believe it will. The Federal Reserve Board's six interest rate increases in the last 12 months appear to have made borrowing expensive enough to discourage many potential home buyers, even if rates rise no further this year.
Some in the real estate industry also believe, perhaps optimistically, that mortgage rates could start to decline later this year in response to a weaker economy and subsiding fears of inflation.
"The market will be strong, but not as strong as the last two years," said Peter L. Mosca, a spokesman for the New Jersey Association of Realtors.
In 1994, sales of single-family homes were strongest on Long Island and in Westchester and Fairfield Counties; the number of homes sold in those areas rose 19 to 22 percent last year compared with 1993, despite an unusually cold winter in the first quarter that kept many home shoppers at home.
Many of the buyers that emerged in the spring and summer were baby boomers fleeing the urban frictions and public schools of New York City. Some of these new suburbanites have moved to affluent communities because they have children or are expecting to in the near future. Others, though, were simply tired of the bright lights of the big city.
"I wanted a backyard," said Joseph C. Maya, a 32-year-old lawyer who last November bought a $380,000 split-level home on one acre in Westport, Conn.
Mr. Maya and his wife, Susan, 28, a merchandiser for London Fog, had been living in a one-bedroom apartment at 87th Street and Lexington Avenue in the Carnegie Hill section of Manhattan.
"It was unbelievable," Mr. Maya said. "When we were looking, we were just blown away by how fast homes were going."
Mrs. Maya noted that they had originally singled out five other homes in the area to buy. "By the time we wanted to put in an offer, they weren't available," she said.
Home sales, however, were also strong in less expensive areas, like Bridgeport, Conn., where they rose by 13 percent, and in Hudson County, N.J., where they rose by 11.5 percent.
Real estate brokers and bankers attributed the increases in these areas to the continuing availability of relatively inexpensive homes, rising rents and a greater willingness among lenders to make loans to low-and moderate-income borrowers.
Mortgage rates, at least during the first half of the year, were also near 20-year lows, which helped make buying a home even more affordable.
"Prices have reached the low ebb," said Thomas E. Hylinski, senior vice president for residential lending at People's Bank in Bridgeport. "At the present, the ability to purchase a condominium unit or a single-family home at reasonable price and, in 1994, at very good interest rates, made it very affordable and comparable with renting."
"In 1994, people came to the conclusion that prices are not going down any more, and they are safe from any further depreciation in value," he added. "In the previous few years, people were afraid that prices would continue to go down."
Though pockets of strong appreciation -- 4 percent or more -- occurred throughout the region, with the exception of Suffolk County, on Long Island, the greatest increases were in Monmouth and Hudson Counties in New Jersey.
In a computer analysis of home-sale price trends in most of the New York suburbs, Case Shiller Weiss of Cambridge, Mass., found that the largest one-year increases for a typical single-family home, excluding condominiums and co-ops, occurred in ZIP codes in five New Jersey communities: Rumson, 11 percent; Long Branch, 10 percent; Jersey City, 10 percent; Eatontown, 8 percent and Holmdel, 8 percent. Further out, sale prices increases in the Princeton, N.J., zipcodes ranged from zero to 4 percent. (Increases of at least 4 percent also occurred in several other towns in Northern New Jersey, in Fairfield and Westchester Counties and along the North Shore of Long Island in Nassau County in places like Manhasset and Port Washington.)
Much of the strength in Monmouth County is attributed to a highly desirable quality of life of the area: It's bucolic in many places yet close to the Jersey Shore and Manhattan and the mansion-filled communities like Rumson are also more affordable than comparable communities like Greenwich, Conn. The area is also linked to Wall Street via high-speed commuter ferry in Highlands, N.J.
As for Jersey City, Jeff Kaplowitz, a vice president of Bardack Realty in Jersey City, noted that a 10 percent increase in sale prices may sound like a miniboom; in fact, he said, it represents less than a third of the estimated 35 percent that homes lost in value between 1988 and 1991. He added that it appeared that many of the areas that soared in value in the mid-80's and then plunged during the recession have the most to gain back in the 1990's.
"We are starting to inch ourselves back up," he said. "Will these increase keep up? Yes, but probably not by minimal amounts."
The greatest declines found in the study, however, also took place in New Jersey. In Paterson, the sale price of the typical home fell 4 or 5 percent, depending on the ZIP code, and in Bogota it dropped 5 percent. (Sale prices in some communities along the South Shore of Long Island, like Bay Shore, Brookhaven, Center Moriches, Mastic Beach and Lindenhurst, fell by at least 3 percent. In the Hamptons, prices depreciations in the Sag Harbor, Southhampton, Water Mill, Westhampton and Westhampton Beach zip codes all ranged from zero to 2 percent.)
"It's the old story -- location," Mr. Kaplowitz said. "Jersey City sits right on the PATH train and we have a symbiotic relationship with Manhattan. Paterson, on the other hand, is faurther away. They're not getting the bedroom community crowd and the back-office crowd."
The Case Shiller Weiss study compared sale price differences in pairs of similar homes in the same area that were resold at least once in 1993 and 1994.
The methodology is considered to be more reliable than calculating an area's median home sale price, which can be easily skewed but is, nonetheless, how home sale price data is often formulated.
Mr. Staro noted that one reason median sale price figures have been so negative in recent years was that a disproportionate number of sales were starter homes bought by first-time buyers, which has gradually pulled down the median sales prices in many areas. In previous years, he added, the median sale price may have been biased upward, toward more expensive properties, particularly in wealthier areas.
For the most part, though, there are few large disparities between median sale prices in 1994 as collected by local real estate boards and data computed by Case Shiller Weiss for the Times.
In Westchester, for example, the median price, according to the New York State Association of Realtors, fell 0.6 percent to $356,080 from $358,267. On Long Island, the median sale price fell 1.9 percent, to $177,383 from $180,739; the figures included sales from the Borough of Queens. In Rockland County, median sale prices increased 3.5 percent to $193,078 from $186,535.
Elsewhere, median sale prices dropped from 1 to 5 percent in much of Northern New Jersey, according to the New Jersey Association of Realtors. Exceptions occurred in Bergen County, which increased 8.9 percent to $197,800 from $191,700, and in Sussex, Warren and Hunterdon Counties, in the rural northwest corner of the state, where price increases ranged from 2.8 to 3.8 percent.
In Connecticut, the median price of a home in Fairfield County fell 5.6 percent to $176,000 from $186,500, according to The Commercial Record, a newspaper in Hartford that publishes real estate data. Similar declines in median sale prices occurred in most of the rest of the state.
The declines in Fairfield County represented one of the few places where results from the Case Shiller Weiss survey differed substantially from the median sale prices. The variation can likely be attributed, in large part, to the abundance of low-end homes, particularly in Bridgeport, that sold in the county last year and pulled down the median sales price.
On a more regional basis, the Federal National Mortgage Association, Fannie Mae, and the the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., Freddie Mac, produce a home price index using a method similar to Case Shiller Weiss. The 1994 index shows that home prices in the mid-Atlantic -- New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania -- decreased last year by 0.5 percent and in New England, including Connecticut, by 1.1 percent. Over the last five years, prices in the mid-Atlantic region rose 3.2 percent and, in New England, fell by 9.8 percent.
Nationally, prices rose 3.6 percent last year and by 13.6 percent over the last five years, according to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the nation's two largest underwriters of mortgages.
"The West is expected to be the strongest area of the country, with the Northeast the weakest," said David Berson, an economist with Fannie Mae.
Price appreciation is an important statistic for home buyers and sellers, even more so than sales volume, which is closely followed by brokers and lawyers, who earn fees and commissions from transactions.
Changes in price, after all, measure the performance of a home as an investment. Generally speaking, when the annual appreciation of a house fails to keep up with inflation, a home often underperforms other types of investments -- even taking into consideration tax benefits, like deductible mortgage interest, and the high percentage of leverage inherent in most home loans, which, of course, can multiply losses as well as gains. In some cases, particularly where rents are low, a consistent lack of appreciation may even make renting and investing any savings in housing costs a better deal.
Few home owners or buyers seem to be checking home prices like the stock market, in sharp contrast to the 70's and 80's when double-digit increases -- as much as 30 percent in some years -- produced extraordinary returns and made many Americans wealthy.
"People should be looking at a home purchase for the service the housing provides and comparing the payments to what it costs to rent, factoring in the tax benefits and the psychic benefits," said David G. Hensley, a vice president and economist with Salomon Brothers in Manhattan.
"I wouldn't factor in substantial appreciation to that arithmetic, but I wouldn't expect the value of most homes to erode, either," he said. "Maybe they will keep up with the consumer price index some years -- and maybe not some years."
Mr. Mosca added that the market seemed to be resting in a period of relative normalcy following the boom of the 80's and the bust of the early 90's with price increases and interest rates at moderate levels.
 
 
 
HOW THE MAPS WERE PREPARED
 Data for these maps was based on a survey of 29,456 homes in the metropolitan area -- an average of 44 homes in each of 675 residential ZIP codes. Each home had been sold at least twice over the last 10 years. Half were resold in 1993; the rest were resold in 1994.
The yearly change is produced by comparing prices of homes that have been sold at least twice in the same area. If, for example, a home had sold in January 1980 for $100,000 and was resold in January 1990 for $200,000, the amount that it had appreciated from 1989 to 1990 would be derived by comparing the sale in 1980 and resale January 1989 of another home in the same area, excluding unusually high and low priced homes. The difference between the two resale prices would show the appreciation or depreciation.
To determine the price changes of homes in a specific location, the price differences between numerous pairs of homes in that area are combined using advanced statistical methods.
The statistical method used is the Case-Shiller Index, developed in the late 1980's by Karl E. Case and Robert E. Shiller, professors of economics at Wellesley and Yale, respectively.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Employees Vote to Remain;
General Motors Decides To Stay in G.M. Building

 BODY:
By now, a lot of New Yorkers are ready to scream, "Enough, already!" to the seemingly endless barrage of building name changes: Pan Am to Met Life, Burlington House to Alliance Capital Building, Helmsley Palace to plain old Palace, and so on. So those New Yorkers will be delighted to learn that 767 Fifth Avenue will, for the foreseeable future, remain the General Motors Building.
Against all expectations, the huge automobile company has signed a new lease for some 110,000 square feet in the building at 58th Street. But there's a catch: They are keeping only about 20,000 square feet of the space they have now. 
 Timing, it seems, is everything.
An executive at the Edward S. Gordon real estate firm who works closely with G.M. says that G.M. had talked of moving to Westchester, but had abandoned that scenario when the city offered some tax breaks to stay. But by this time the law firm Weil Gotshal & Manges had already signed up for most of the space G.M. had been expected to vacate.
So G.M. scouted around for comparable space. It found it, on two of the floors that Kidder, Peabody was vacating at 1251 Avenue of the Americas, the former Exxon building at 50th Street. The Gordon executive, who refused to allow his name to be used, says G.M. was very close to signing a lease when word got out that Foote Cone & Belding, the advertising agency, was leaving 126,000 square feet of G.M. Building space to go to the Mobil Building, at 150 East 42d Street. Suddenly, G.M. could stay put if it wanted to.
The company insists it made its final decision in true democratic fashion.
"From an economic standpoint, the two deals were a wash, so we put it to an employee vote," said Toni Simonetti, a G.M. spokeswoman. The approximately 190 G.M. employees who work at 757 Fifth voted to stay where they were.
There's still a question mark surrounding the street-level showroom. G.M.'s lease on that expired on Jan. 15 and the company, thinking it was moving away, cleared out. For a time the Smithsonian Institution was planning to lease the space for a museum store, but that deal is on hold. Now G.M. has reopened talks, and may yet return its cars to the showroom.

HEADLINE: Two Who Cherish Symphony Orchestras

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: SCARSDALE

 BODY:
IN these days of MTV and rock music magazines, symphony orchestras remain curiously anonymous -- the object, it seems, of little curiosity. Yet for those who see behind the scenes, an orchestra -- for all its black-clad sameness at performances -- teems with color and personality.
Few people know this better than Stephen and Elaine Stamas, who between them have connections to much of the classical music played in the Northeast. Mr. Stamas is chairman of the board of the New York Philharmonic, a position he also holds at the Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont. Mrs. Stamas is an active board member of Hoff-Barthelson Music School here, and her brother, Dr. Nicholas T. Zervas, a Boston neurosurgeon, is president of the board of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. 
 The couple, who have lived in the Edgemont section of Scarsdale since 1962, have seen Kurt Masur dance a flamenco, have partied all night with Leonard Bernstein and have toured Russia with Zubin Mehta as Communism was crumbling. The magisterial Mr. Masur did "the most elegant, light-footed dance" in an impromptu performance in Madrid, when he was invited on stage by a flamenco dancer, Mrs. Stamas said. The couple have traveled to Europe, Asia and South America with the Philharmonic on yearly tours sponsored by Citibank.
Mr. Stamas, a tall man with a gentle smile, has held one of the music world's most demanding volunteer jobs for 10 years. He wears leadership gracefully, speaking of his work with the Philharmonic and of his former role as president of the board of overseers at Harvard University, his alma mater, as though everyone has such commitments. Mr. Stamas is also on the board of Rockefeller University and is a vice chairman of Lincoln Center. Mrs. Stamas is also a board member of Colby College in Maine, her alma mater, where she helped to establish a still-active singing group, the Colbyettes. Now retired as a vice president for public affairs of the Exxon Corporation, Mr. Stamas says he plays a limited role in Windcrest Partners, a private investment company in Manhattan.
One recent morning, as students flowed into Hoff-Barthelson to audition for the school's yearly Baroque Festival, which will take place from March 25 to April 2 in Hastings-on-Hudson and Scarsdale, the couple sat in a practice room here and talked about their life in music. Their connection with the school goes back 25 years, Mrs. Stamas said, to when it was housed on a hill in Edgemont. Both of the couple's children, Heidi and Ted, who are now in their 30's, studied the piano here. The Stamases, who will celebrate their 40th wedding anniversary in April, have an unusual punch line to their "how we met" story. "My father delivered him," said Mrs. Stamas, a trim blond woman, referring to her father's practice of medicine outside of Boston, where she grew up. Their families were acquainted -- both were of Greek heritage -- and Elaine and Stephen met as college students. Although both loved music, there was little to predict the role it would play in their marriage.
While his wife plays the piano and sings alto in the Westchester Choral Society, Mr. Stamas calls himself "the family member who listens," the one who can't carry a tune. He remembers hearing radio concerts by the New York Philharmonic as a child, and later going to hear the Boston Symphony play in Cambridge, although "my real love was the Boston Red Sox and Ted Williams," he said. It was during his 26 years at Exxon that Mr. Stamas became a champion of music and the arts. Under his leadership, Exxon began its sponsorship of what would become "Great Performances" as well as "Live From Lincoln Center." Exxon was also an early sponsor of the "MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour" and for 18 years sponsored radio broadcasts of the New York Philharmonic.
Mr. Stamas retired from the company in 1986, well before the infamous Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska. But there were also difficult moments in the 1970's, when gasoline shortages led to long lines at service stations. Mr. Stamas recalled feeling "waves of disapproval" across Central Park, at an Exxon-sponsored concert in the park during that time.
 Exxon, which is now based near Dallas, supported the Philharmonic radio broadcasts until 1988. The orchestra has not yet found another sponsor for the broadcasts, which Mr. Stamas said now would cost "a couple of million" dollars a year. "One of my frustrations is that orchestras are going off radio because of the economics," he said. "It's a great irony that we have so many more technical capabilities with cable and satellite, but today's orchestras can't raise the money or get the air time."
He became president of the Philharmonic in late 1984 and chairman in 1989 and calls himself the orchestra's "chief day-to-day volunteer." He said the Philharmonic's $30 million budget was balanced again after a $2.4 million deficit in the 1991-92 season, and that the orchestra was also on firm artistic ground under the leadership of Mr. Masur and Deborah Borda, the group's executive director, both of whom he helped select. Now, he said, he is concerned about "ticket prices rising too fast" and excluding many interested people who can't afford them. "The burden falls on fund-raising" to balance the books, he said, an effort in which he and his wife take part. "I couldn't do the New York Philharmonic without Elaine," Mr. Stamas said. "She is a full partner. She knows the musicians and their families better than I do."
A measure of the couple's popularity is that when Hoff-Barthelson held its 50th anniversary gala at Manhattanville College in Purchase last October, 13 Philharmonic players -- many of them principals -- contributed their services for a concert. Eighty-four thousand dollars was raised that night for the school, a Hoff-Barthelson spokeswoman said.
The Stamases say they are not party people, but life in the symphonic stratosphere can get hectic. During one recent week, for example, the couple gave a dinner for Citibank officials and Philharmonic patrons, attended a private dinner at the Masurs and went to several concerts. Thursday nights during the season are reserved for Philharmonic concerts, when the Stamases visit the musicians beforehand and keep a watchful eye on the goings on at Avery Fisher Hall.
"You want to be there and demonstrate support," Mr. Stamas said. Whether on tour or at home, Mr. Stamas said, "We like to see the people around us admire our orchestra."

HEADLINE: A Japanese Gambler Hits the Jackpot With Softbank

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
WHEN he was trying to start his software distribution business in the early 1980's, Masayoshi Son rented a huge booth at a Japanese consumer electronics trade show and offered software companies free space to display their products. The booth was mobbed, but the retailers that attended the show dealt directly with the software manufacturers, bypassing Mr. Son, the middleman.
"I probably made back one-twentieth of the cost of the booth," Mr. Son told the Harvard Business Review a few years ago. "After that, many people were laughing at me. They said, That guy's really dumb. He's a nice guy, but dumb." 
 No one calls Mr. Son dumb now. They call him the Bill Gates of Japan. The 37-year-old entrepreneur has built his Tokyo-based company, the Softbank Corporation, into the leading distributor of software and a major publisher of computer magazines here, parlaying it all into a $1.5 billion personal fortune.
Last week, Mr. Son took another gamble on a trade show. Instead of renting a booth, his company agreed to pay $800 million for a business that operates 17 computer shows, including the giant Comdex, which last November had 2,200 booths.
The price raised eyebrows, with some analysts thinking Mr. Son, like so many Japanese businessmen before him, had paid too much for a trophy asset. But Mr. Son discounts that. "As one of the industry players," he says. "I know how important Comdex is."
Mr. Son plans to make himself a key player in the "infrastructure" of the personal computer business, not only in Japan but in America, which he views as the center of the global PC industry. The purchase of the Comdex business from the Interface Group and of the Ziff-Davis trade-show business, for $202 million, last fall are part of that plan.
"A year ago we had five employees in America," says Mr. Son. "Now we have 700, and by the end of the year we will have 1,200." Having made an unsuccessful bid to buy all of Ziff-Davis Publishing last year, Mr. Son allows that he eventually wants to enter the computer magazine business in the United States.
MR. SON is hailed as a rare example of an entrepreneur in Japan, which has had few of the start-ups like Apple and Microsoft that have been responsible for the success of the American computer industry.
For all the adulation, Softbank did not create something new as Apple or Microsoft did. It prospered by distributing products made by others, often American companies. "Bill Gates is a much bigger figure than I am," says Mr. Son, referring to the co-founder and chairman of Microsoft, whom he knows well.
Still, the story of Mr. Son's rise from humble origins has become a legend here.
He was born in a small town on Japan's southern island of Kyushu. His grandparents had come from Korea and his parents were squatters. To try to avoid the discrimination that Koreans are subject to in Japan, Mr. Son's family adopted a Japanese last name, Yasumoto.
At age 16, he moved to the United States, enrolling as a sophomore at a California high school and beginning to use his real name. Later, while studying economics at the University of California at Berkeley, Mr. Son, with the help of some professors, invented an electronic translator that he sold to Sharp Corporation for about $1 million. He made another million by importing used video game machines from Japan, on credit, and installing them in dormitories and restaurants.
Mr. Son returned to Japan and decided to go into software distribution. Softbank, founded in 1981, has grown rapidly. In the fiscal year ending next month, the company expects revenues of about $900 million, up 40 percent from the previous year. Net profits are expected to double to $20 million.
Mr. Son took his company public on the over-the-counter market last summer. The stock, which peaked above 25,000 yen ($250) in October, has fallen steadily since then, in part because price wars are cutting software profit margins. The stock closed Friday at 15,000 yen, down 1,300 yen since the Comdex acquisition was announced Monday. Even so, Mr. Son's 70 percent stake in his company is worth $1.5 billion.
COMPUTER industry executives say Mr. Son is the consummate salesman. He is also doggedly passionate about his work. "I've never seen such an aggressive person before," says Takatoshi Matsumoto, who heads the Japanese arm of Cisco Systems, a maker of networking equipment based in San Jose, Calif. "He never gives up."
From 1983 through 1986, Mr. Son had to relinquish the presidency of the company when he was hospitalized with hepatitis. With a phone, fax and computer in his room, he says, he continued to give advice, returning to the helm after he recovered.
Mr. Son has entered into lucrative partnerships with American companies. Softbank owns about 20 percent of Novell Japan, the Japanese arm of the American leader in networking software. Mr. Son helped convince Fujitsu, Toshiba, NEC, Sony and Canon to invest in Novell Japan as well and to distribute the company's products.
He helped organize an even larger group of Japanese companies, including his own, to invest in Nihon Cisco Systems.
Mr. Son has had setbacks. A joint venture with Ross Perot's Perot Systems to provide systems integration in Japan was quietly disbanded because, he says, the market was not ready. A plan to distribute software on compact disks was shelved after retailers complained that Softbank would be competing with them. Last year, Mr. Son boldly predicted that a joint venture with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation to provide video on demand would gain 10 million customers by the year 2000. Mr. Son now concedes it will take 10 to 15 years to reach that level.
As with Mr. Gates, Mr. Son's success has provoked some envy within the Japanese computer industry. For his part, Mr. Son is reluctant to state the company's market share in the software distribution business -- it is thought to be about 50 percent -- because, he says, it is so large.
As for Comdex, Mr. Son dismissed criticisms that the show has grown too unwieldy and has passed its prime. Exhibit space of next November's show is already 90 percent booked and the business can be expanded by holding Comdex shows in Europe and Asia.
Mr. Son drives a Porsche but says his life style has remained simple. Other than an occasional game of golf (he shot a par 72 once last year), he spends most of his time on work. Married, with two daughters, Mr. Son became a Japanese citizen a few years ago because, he says, it made it easier to get through the immigration lines at Narita Airport. At first, the Japanese Government refused to accept his application, he recalls, because Son was not a Japanese name. Now it is a name recognized throughout Japan.
