HEADLINE: Giuliani Proposes Changes in Zoning To Aid Superstores

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed sweeping zoning changes yesterday that would open New York City's underused manufacturing areas to the cavernous discount retailers and warehouse stores that have shaped the consumer landscape of America's suburbs and small towns for years.
With a dearth of office tower construction and little hope that manufacturing in New York will rebound, the proposed changes would make attracting large retailers a major focus of the city's economic development strategy over the next decade, particularly outside of Manhattan. 
 Under the Mayor's proposal, superstores as large as 200,000 square feet -- roughly the size of five football fields -- could move into light and medium industrial zones without having to obtain a special permit, a slow, costly process that officials say has kept the nation's largest retailers out of the city. The city's current regulations restrict most stores to 10,000 square feet in those areas, which have about 10 percent of the city's land.
The proposed changes would accelerate the arrival of large retailers that began a few years ago, as stores like Kmart, Home Depot, Pathmark and Bed, Bath and Beyond moved into commercial areas, where, in most cases, they are now allowed. Mr. Giuliani's plans would go further, opening areas like SoHo, western Harlem, Long Island City in Queens and Sunset Park in Brooklynto the stores, where they are not now allowed.
"You all know that New York City is the largest consumer market in the United States and that all types of retailers are eager to invest in New York City," the Mayor said yesterday as he announced the proposal in Union Square Park in Manhattan, in front of a 240,000-square-foot Bradlees store that opened last fall. "But the city has erected many, many unnecessary barriers to retail investment. In just makes no sense at all."
Mr. Giuliani and Joseph B. Rose, the director of the Department of City Planning, said New Yorkers spend $3 billion a year driving to the suburbs to shop in the sorts of stores the city hopes to attract. They said that making it easier for the superstores to open within the city limits would keep millions of dollars in the city, raise tax revenues and create thousands of new jobs.
Encouraging still more and larger superstores -- with their huge signs, sprawling parking lots and wide aisles that are so familiar in the suburbs -- could transform the city, its neighborhoods and the sometimes idiosyncratic way that New Yorkers shop.
For that reason, the Mayor's proposal, which requires the approval of the City Planning Commission and the City Council, could prove contentious in the months ahead.
Opponents of the zoning changes said yesterday that the superstores would undermine the special urban character of the city and, with their high volume and lower prices, destroy small merchants in the city's many neighborhood shopping districts.
"The community will disappear," said Alfredo A. Rodriguez, the owner of two small supermarkets in East Harlem, who has been involved in a fight against the opening of a Pathmark supermarket in the neighborhood. "If they take away 20 or 30 percent of your business, you can't survive."
For Mr. Giuliani, a Republican who had broad support among small-business owners during his campaign, the proposal is politically sensitive. To that end, the Mayor took care yesterday to package the zoning changes with other proposals, some old and some new, intended to help existing small businesses.
In addition to reductions in business taxes and eliminating the city's sales tax on clothing under $100 that the Mayor has already proposed, the proposals include easing zoning restrictions on expansions and eliminating tax incentives for new businesses that many small merchants have complained create an unlevel playing field.
"We're sensitive to all of those concerns," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday, "but overall the fact is that developments like this create more small business rather than contract small business."
The effort to revise the city's zoning laws began several years ago amid a realization that there was little prospect of a resurgence in manufacturing jobs, which have declined steadily since World War II.
In 1974, the last time zoning regulations for industrial areas were revised, the city restricted large retailers and other businesses from locating in manufacturing zones unless they obtained a special variance, in an effort to preserve tracts for industrial development.
Even under the current restrictions, many larger retailers eager to venture into the city's vast pool of shoppers have sought the special permits required to open, including Kmart, which has applied to build a 123,000-square-foot store in Long Island City, at the site of an old Ronzoni pasta plant.
Under Mayor David N. Dinkins, in 1993 the Planning Department proposed allowing stores up to 100,000 square feet to move into the manufacturing zones. Under Mr. Giuliani, the department has proposed doubling the limit, reflecting, officials said, that the prototype superstores have grown larger in just the last few years.
While the superstores are allowed to open in some commercial areas, the largest retailers -- such as Wal-Mart, the Price Club or Pathmark -- require large parcels of land, often 10 acres or more, that are scarce in most parts of the city.
Mr. Rose, whose department prepared the proposal and has studied the impact of large retailers in neighborhoods, said that the fear of the giants was "a red herring." He said that with so many New Yorkers driving to the suburbs to shop, the new stores would retain shoppers locally and create new business for smaller businesses.
"We're not talking about taking away from small stores and transferring it to large stores," Mr. Rose said. "We're talking about getting back to New York City jobs, spending, tax dollars, and providing New York City consumers the kind of choice they are already traveling outside of the city limits to get."
The proposed changes face a series of hurdles that could take years to overcome and provoke controversy at each step. Even before going to the City Planning Commission and the City Council, the administration must first conduct an environmental impact study mandated by the state.
Michael S. Clendenin, a spokesman for the Council, said yesterday that the Council would carefully scrutinize the proposal to insure that small businesses are not adversely affected. But some Council members and elected officials, hearing the anxiety of small merchants, have already promised to fight the changes.
The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, said the Mayor's effort should instead be focused on encouraging the retail development already happening in places like Union Square, where Mr. Giuliani chose to announce his plan yesterday. She said the effort to open up manufacturing zones could draw new and existing retailers -- and their shoppers -- from such areas.
"They will put many existing commercial areas at a grave competitive disadvantage," Ms. Messinger said of the superstores.

HEADLINE: Mistake or Modern Marvel? Denver Airport Set to Open

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DENVER, Feb. 16

 BODY:
It has been hailed as a technological marvel and derided as a civic booster's overpriced field of dreams. Whatever it is, the new Denver International Airport is set finally to begin operating on Feb. 28 -- a year and a half behind schedule and at a cost of $4.2 billion, about 50 percent more than the original estimate.
The first passenger flight, United 1062, will depart for Kansas City at 6 A.M. to inaugurate the architecturally striking terminal, which juts up from an otherwise empty prairie 23 miles east of Denver. 
 That departure will also mark the opening of the first major commercial airport built in the United States since the Dallas-Fort Worth field was completed 20 years ago.
Among the luminaries expected at an opening ceremony is Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena, who as Mayor of Denver a decade ago first proposed building the airport. The current Mayor, Wellington Webb, will preside at the ceremony.
Stapleton International Airport, the field that has served Denver since the barnstorming days of 1929 but that city officials have declared hopelessly outdated and congested, will cease operation a few hours before Flight 1062 lifts off.
The terminal, hangars and runways, a 10-minute ride from downtown and easily capable of being expanded and modernized, in the view of the new airport's detractors, will be sold for conversion to office and residential development.
"This time we're really going to open D.I.A.," said Stephanie Foote, chief of staff for Mayor Webb, alluding to four previous opening dates that had to be aborted because of construction problems.
"We've finally ironed out all of the bugs," Ms. Foote promised. "We've now got everything itemized and prioritized, right down to the paper in the restrooms."
The delays were forced mainly by embarrassing problems with the baggage handling system, designed to be the most advanced in aviation history. In early tests of the $193 million system, which features computer-controlled baggage carts dashing on little tracks, some suitcases were crushed and ripped open and others ended up at the wrong plane gates or bag carousels.
Airport engineers say the system now works. But just in case, a conventional baggage system has been installed as a backup, at a cost of $50 million.
The airport was supposed to open in the fall of 1993. City officials had predicted that the 43,000-acre facility, with five 12,000-foot runways and a multipeaked terminal that resembles the snow-capped Rocky Mountains on the western horizon, would not only offer the easiest, safest and most efficient air travel anywhere but also give Denver a strong economic lift after years of recession.
They are still making that prediction.
"The boost always comes with big new airports, and Denver won't be an exception," said Dan Melfi, an airport spokesman. "People will be able to get in and out easier, and D.I.A. also will be a magnet for office parks and manufacturing facilities on the outskirts."
Some aviation experts have doubts. They question whether passenger traffic through Denver, the world's eighth busiest air hub, will ever increase enough to justify the final price of the new airport, whose cost was initially set at $2.9 billion.
They note that airlines have raised fares to help pay higher rents, landing fees and other costs at the new airport. They also contend that the old airport, whose narrowly spaced runways were often tied up by snowstorms, could have been reconfigured and modernized at less cost.
In fact, they point out, the new airport has fewer gates (87) than the old (111), though it can easily be expanded.
"There isn't any doubt that Denver International is one of the world's great airports, the most modern and efficient of all at this point," said Paul Dempsey, the director of the Transportation Law Program at Denver University.
"But in retrospect," he said, "the city made a rush to judgment. It should have looked more closely at whether to dump Stapleton. Just over 32 million passengers fly in and out of Denver every year, and there really isn't much outlook for a big increase in that figure any time soon, especially if fares keep going up. Another recession might even cause the figure to drop."
The critics also note, with special concern, that several agencies are investigating allegations about the airport's construction and the manner in which it was financed with bonds.
The agencies include the Federal Aviation Administration, the Department of Transportation, the United States Attorney in Denver, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the General Accounting Office and the Denver District Attorney.
Airport officials say they know of no wrongdoing.

HEADLINE: New Chief Tells Freehanded Uruguay It's Time to Take Its Medicine

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay

 BODY:
Uruguay has long enjoyed one of the highest standards of living in Latin America, buttressed by a social security system that allows people to retire years earlier than in other countries.
But if the President-elect, Julio Maria Sanguinetti, has his way, those days will soon be over. 
 Mr. Sanguinetti, who takes office on March 1, said in an interview that his first priority would be reforming the social security system, which has become a drain on the budget.
"Our demographics are changing, people are living longer, and we simply cannot afford to maintain the social benefits program as it now exists," said Mr. Sanguinetti, who was President from 1985 to 1990 and was returned to office in a close election in November.
"I fully expect there to be opposition to our reforms, but sometimes the medicine seems worse than the illness, but in the long term it heals the patient," Mr. Sanguinetti said.
The basic problem is the high ratio of people who depend on or work for the state. About 1.1 million of Uruguay's 3.1 million people are registered workers, while 700,000 people no longer in the work force receive pensions. Uruguay has more than one retired person for every two workers, and about 37 percent of the state budget goes to the bankrupt social security system.
Economists and rival political parties agree that reform of the system, which is financed by payroll deductions, cannot be delayed.
A study by the Inter-American Development Bank said that even if Uruguay's gross domestic product grows at a projected 1.7 percent and inflation at 10 percent for the rest of the decade, failure to reform the social security system will mean the deficit will reach 5 percent.
But reaching an agreement on exactly how to reform the system may be Mr. Sanguinetti's greatest challenge, especially since the legislature is divided almost evenly among three parties.
Mr. Sanguinetti said that while he would not "take away any benefits that people currently enjoy, the system will be reformed for future pensioners." He plans to propose a mixed system of minimal coverage by the state and private voluntary individual savings.
Uruguayans have grown accustomed to the system, which allows men to retire at 60 and women at 55. The Government provides disabled workers 70 percent of their salaries and free medical care.
Some Uruguayans are collecting pensions today under laws overturned in the late 1970's, which, for example, allowed a woman with a child to retire after 10 years of work, regardless of her age, or a single woman whose father died to receive a pension for life without working, even if she married.
Highly organized retirement associations have vowed to use referendums to block changes to the social security program.
Complicating matters is the factionalized political system, which was further entangled by the split of votes among Uruguay's three major parties in the last election. The vote ended more than a century of two-party rule.
Since no party has a majority in the legislature, Mr. Sanguinetti, of the centrist Colorado Party, must negotiate alliances with the unseated rightist National Party and the leftist newcomer, the Progressive Front coalition. These alliances will include concessions, particularly in filling Cabinet and commission posts.
President Luis Alberto Lacalle failed to pass welfare and other economic reforms because he lacked the political skills to negotiate and needlessly alienated Congress. Mr. Sanguinetti was one of the Mr. Lacalle's staunchest opponents in Congress, and supporters of the departing leader say he may seek revenge by blocking reform.
While bitter infighting and party rivalry are a way of life, rival party leaders have hinted that they are willing to work with Mr. Sanguinetti, particularly on social security.
"This is a period of fundamental change in Uruguay's history, and whether we are successful will depend on whether the parties realize we are at this turning point," said Danilo Arbillo, director of the weekly political newspaper Busqueda. "But I am hopeful that the parties will recognize the gravity of the situation."
Alberto Volonte, who was the National Party presidential candidate, said in an interview that his faction had reached an agreement in principle to work with Mr. Sanguinetti, but only in exchange for three Cabinet positions.
Tabare Vasquez, the Progressive Front's presidential candidate, said the left was willing to listen to Mr. Sanguinetti's proposals but that "we don't want anything in return for our cooperation."
"These parties have to realize that the problems Uruguay is facing were created by the two parties that ran this country for decades," he added.

HEADLINE: Al Gore, One Vice President Who Is Eluding the Shadows

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO and TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Two years ago, when Al Gore said he wanted to reinvent Government, people listened politely. Or snickered. Or fell asleep. When he took his first foreign trip -- to Poland in April 1993 -- it was assumed that he was trying, like Vice Presidents before him, to fill up his time.
There's not so much snickering now. 
 Mr. Gore's partisans say he is finally coming into his own. But it may be simply that in an Administration plagued by disorganization and indecision, inexperienced aides in some top jobs and power vacuums in key agencies, Mr. Gore's brand of steady dullness seems increasingly appealing, if effective mainly on the margins.
Over the past two years, the man once pegged only as a highly intelligent, eco-techno-nerd who talked too much in meetings has emerged also as the President's most trusted official adviser and his ultimate trouble-shooter, the one most likely to seize opportunities, put out fires and enforce decisions.
Disillusioned by Mr. Clinton, Democrats who once doubted Mr. Gore's ability to sizzle in a national campaign now whisper conspiratorially about his Presidential prospects.
Filling gaps aggravated by Mr. Clinton's uneven management, especially of foreign policy, Mr. Gore has been able to reach selectively into important areas of foreign and domestic affairs. He performs tasks that in other Administrations were the singular preserve of the Secretary of State (like persuading Ukraine's President to dismantle his country's nuclear weapons), or of the White House budget director (like ordering Cabinet officers to shrink their departments).
His range runs from the sublime to the ridiculous. He can sit by the hospital bed of an ailing Boris N. Yeltsin explaining how NATO policy had been misunderstood, or he can cut through red tape to declare a drug-sniffing pig in an Oregon police force a dog so it could qualify for Federal drug-enforcement money.
"In meetings, when a lot of people talk, you'll see the President looking around the room," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman. "When Gore talks, the President is absolutely riveted."
But if Mr. Gore is so good, why is the White House in such trouble? Where was the Vice President when Bosnia flared up, when health care flamed out and the nomination process broke down? Mr. Gore's relentless campaigning on behalf of Democrats last fall did not stop the Republican landslide -- even in his home state of Tennessee, where both Democratic Senate candidates lost.
Blame doesn't stick to him, in part because as Vice President, he is not the day-to-day commander of anything and so does not have ultimate responsibility. Mr. Gore also has the luxury of picking his targets, and he does that so carefully that he does not get involved in issues he cannot control.
He studiously stayed away from the health care fight. And although he argued passionately for more American intervention in Bosnia, he was never held responsible for the policy shifts and failures.
Now, with the Administration scrambling to respond to the blunt message of the midterm elections that big government is bad, the streamlining campaign that Mr. Gore started with little fanfare in 1993 has sailed to the top of Mr. Clinton's neo-centrist agenda. And Mr. Gore is more than ever the President's public hand-holder now that Hillary Rodham Clinton, in political purdah since the health care fiasco last year, wields her influence mostly in private.
For most of American history, Presidents suffered their No. 2's or used them as partisan attack dogs; even strong ones like Walter Mondale and George Bush, never approached Mr. Gore's prominence.
But Mr. Gore's relationship with Mr. Clinton is a delicate walk along a thin line between doing your best for your President and doing your best for yourself, especially when you have your own Presidential aspirations somewhere down the road.
And Mr. Gore is acutely sensitive to the political reality that the higher he rises and the better he looks, the worse his boss may seem by comparison.
Asked in a recent interview where he thinks he fits in Vice-Presidential history, Mr. Gore reverts to modesty. "I don't know how to compare myself with others," he said. "The President is terrific about asking me to share in this, that and the other. And I'm grateful for that."
But Mr. Gore doesn't quarrel with the notion that he is, in Secretary of State Warren Christopher's words, "the most influential Vice President in history."
 
His Role
A Vice President As a Loyal Ally
 "We achieved what I call Gestalt," Mr. Gore once said of his relationship with Mr. Clinton.
In their two years in office, their intimacy has deepened, and White House aides say the President has become so dependent on his No. 2 that he does not make any decision of significance without him.
"I cannot imagine the President making a major decision before talking it through with the Vice President," the Presidential adviser George Stephanopoulos said.
Sometimes, Mr. Clinton has held up big decisions just to get Mr. Gore's say. In December, when Mr. Gore was in Moscow and the President's advisers were reviewing their first round of budget cuts in the wake of the disastrous midterm elections and pondering whether to propose tax breaks for the middle class, Mr. Clinton held off until Mr. Gore returned. All the players had to come back for a second meeting so Mr. Gore could hear the proposals firsthand.
When Mr. Clinton was unsure whether to eliminate the Department of Energy as part of the streamlining of the Government, Mr. Gore pushed him into a decision.
"What if we go and take the Department of Energy sign off the Forrestal building and slap on Department of Defense, and a year later a reporter comes by and sees the same people in the same jobs doing the same thing, and asks, 'What did we accomplish?' " Elaine C. Kamarck, Mr. Gore's chief aide on streamlining Government, paraphrases him as saying. The President decided to keep the agency.
Since November, a White House eager to find an organizing rationale after the Republicans' election victory has eagerly embraced Mr. Gore's campaign for a leaner Government. Under Mr. Gore's supervision, his advisers say, the program has helped shrink the Federal work force by more than 100,000. Program cuts and reorganizations intended to save $65 billion over five years have been enacted, and Mr. Gore is to announce measures this spring aimed at saving another $52 billion. But Republicans deride the Gore initiative as too little too late, and it may not improve the Democrats standing much in 1996.
And Mr. Gore's political touch has not always been so sure. Despite his long experience in the House and Senate, where he was somewhat of a loner, he has been unable to spare Mr. Clinton some of his worst defeats on Capitol Hill.
Now, he's taken on the latest challenge to the White House: the nomination of his fellow Tennessean, Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr. as Surgeon General.
Mr. Gore, who has known Dr. Foster casually for years, interviewed him about a week before his appointment was announced. He voiced support for the nomination, apparently no more alert than anyone else in the Administration of the political pitfalls inherent in Dr. Foster's record as an obstetrician who performed abortions during his long career.
But as the quintessential trouble-shooter, Mr. Gore was called by the White House late last Sunday afternoon and asked to help. He cleared his schedule the next day so that he could go to Nashville to help salvage the nomination.
 
His Accomplishments
Building Power In Foreign Affairs
 Early in the Clinton Administration, Mr. Gore got a reputation in the State Department as a player who had to be reckoned with.
 "I don't do funerals," senior officials quoted him as saying.
 Mr. Gore insists that he never considered the Vice-Presidential duty of grieving deceased foreign leaders beneath him. "I never said that," he said. "That's an apocryphal story. I'm not too proud to go to funerals. I don't remember a time when they've asked me to go to a funeral and I've said, 'Sorry, that's not something I do.' "
But what Mr. Gore does best is fill vacuums.
Mr. Clinton's lack of passion for foreign policy combined with Mr. Christopher's willingness to cede vast swaths of his authority to other agencies have given Mr. Gore the chance to do diplomacy.
"The world is a safer place because of Al Gore," Mr. Stephanpoulos said.
Mr. Gore has established a critical link with Russia outside normal diplomatic channels. Since Mr. Yeltsin is not considered the most reliable of partners, and since he and Mr. Clinton do not have much of a personal relationship anyway, Mr. Gore has developed a close relationship with Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, successfully transforming a modest space-and-energy commission with Russia into the ultimate back channel.
The Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission, which now involves six Cabinet members, has become a way to get the Administration's views through to Moscow and establish a relationship with the man who could someday be President.
 It was Mr. Gore who clinched a deal on oil development in the Caspian Sea with Mr. Chernomyrdin before the United States-Russia summit meeting in Washington last fall. "Let's do it for our Presidents," an Administration official paraphrased Mr. Gore as writing his Russian colleague.
Mr. Gore also used his contacts to negotiate an ultra-secret deal with Russia and Kazakhstan to bring more than half a ton of bomb-grade uranium from Kazakhstan to the United States last year.
And when Mr. Christopher met with Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev in Geneva last month, they barely discussed the contentious issue of Mr. Yeltsin's unfulfilled pledge to disclose Russia's arms deals with Iran. That was the responsibility of Gore-Chernomyrdin, Mr. Christopher's aides said.
 Mr. Gore has replicated his accomplishment in Russia with South Africa's Deputy President Thabo Mbeki. And a Gore Commission with Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak is already at work, even though it will not be created officially until Mr. Gore makes a five-nation swing of the Middle East next month.
The effect of such discreet diplomacy is that Mr. Gore sometimes is filling the traditional operational roles of the President, the Secretary of State and the national security adviser, a characterization Mr. Gore denies.
"No, no, no, I don't agree with that," he said. "I come off the bench to fill in where they ask me to. This President has a very big foreign policy and there is enough work to go around."
As for Mr. Christopher, he insists that he does not feel threatened by the Vice President. After all, it was Mr. Christopher who urged Mr. Clinton after a series of foreign policy setbacks in the fall of 1993 to give Mr. Gore a more active role.
But if a Vice President is ready and willing to conduct foreign policy, then why would a government want to deal with a mere Secretary of State?
 "No Secretary of State can do it all," Mr. Christopher said. "It would be foolish if he thought he could. One reason I'm so confident is that the Vice President is thoroughly reliable."
Sometimes, however, Mr. Gore gets carried away in his role as the Scarlet Pimpernel of American diplomacy.
During a visit to Moscow in December 1993, he demanded that the World Bank and International Monetary Fund lend more money to Russia, saying that he did not care if his statements provoked a "diplomatic incident." They did. The protests that followed caused Mr. Gore to soften his criticism.
In late 1993, Mr. Gore decided to spice up a speech in Mexico City that he thought "lacked a center," one of his aides said, by calling for a hemispheric summit meeting. Although he had consulted with the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, who got the go-ahead from the President, the announcement stunned the Latins and blind-sided most of the State Department.
 Although Mr. Clinton seeks Mr. Gore's advice on foreign policy, the Vice President does not always prevail and sometimes retreats. Throughout the first year and a half of the Administration, Mr. Gore argued passionately for punitive air strikes to force the Serbs in Bosnia into making peace.
When Mr. Clinton would waver at crucial moments, Mr. Gore would stiffen his spine by delivering lengthy soliloquies about morality and the right of the Bosnians to defend themselves. But in the end, the Vice President went all wobbly, concurring with the dominant view in December that the punitive strategy had outlived its usefulness and should be abandoned.
 
His Future
A Delicate Spot In Party Politics
 In the conventional wisdom of Washington, if Mr. Gore is a winner, there must be a loser. Not so, Mr. Gore insists, though he stumbles a bit on the answer.
"No, absolutely not, and, uh, uh, well, I don't perceive any problem of that variety," he said. "Everything I do is according to one simple game plan: how can I best help President Clinton be the best President he can possibly be."
But when Mr. Gore's aides describe how he works, they often end up, however unintentionally, praising the very qualities of discipline and focus that Mr. Clinton's critics complain the President lacks.
"He will set aside large blocks of time and will sit down and think these things through," said Mr. Gore's chief of staff, Jack Quinn. "He doesn't do anything off the cuff. He never shoots from the hip. He is thoughtful, he is prepared, he is careful."
Despite polling data that show Mr. Gore with a far more favorable ratio of approval to disapproval ratings than the President, Mr. Gore is determined not to be seen as upstaging Mr. Clinton. When the House Speaker Newt Gingrich recently asked Mr. Gore to address the Republican caucus, even as the Democrats wanted him to address theirs, Mr. Gore's staff suggested that he combine the two. But Mr. Gore immediately rejected the idea as tantamount to addressing a joint session of Congress, a privilege reserved for the President.
Mr. Gore has said that under no circumstances would he accept the Democratic nomination in 1996, although party leaders say with equal certainty that he would be the best hope in the unlikely event that Mr. Clinton dropped out.
"As the campaign season begins, clearly part of my role will be how can I best insure that Bill Clinton is re-elected," Mr. Gore said. That will involve all the fund-raising and speech-making duties traditional for running mates, and while Mr. Gore is far less stiff in public than he once was, even his closest friends in the White House acknowledge that he lacks Mr. Clinton's instinctive flashes of poetry and command of a crowd.
"Clinton is a natural in a way that Gore will never be," said an adviser who is close to both men. On the other hand, Gore has all the will and determination and discipline that would serve him very well as President."
For now, Mr. Gore said, "I greatly enjoy what I'm doing." What he does not say is that in the year 2000, he will be turning just 52 years old.

HEADLINE: In a Charged Climate, German Union Takes Strike Vote Tomorrow

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 18

 BODY:
After weeks of ineffectual talks with German employers, the country's powerful electrical and metal workers' union, IG Metall, has called a strike vote for Monday that could lead to work stoppages in southern Germany as early as Friday.
The struggle between IG Metall, which has 2.6 million members, and Gesamtmetall, an employers' federation representing almost 8,000 businesses, is an annual event. But this year, the war of words over pay increases and shorter working hours has taken on larger proportions. 
 For the first time since 1992, German industry is not struggling through a recession. Profits are strong, as is the demand for exports, making it harder for employers to say that they would be hurt by substantial increases.
Over the last two years, the metal and electrical workers accepted wage settlements that resulted in a loss of real buying power, giving them strong arguments that they deserve at least modest increases in their standard of living.
Yet Germany is saddled with some of the highest labor costs in Europe and inflexible labor laws, making production costs higher than in almost any other industrial nation. Business leaders say that if they give in to excessive labor demands, their competitiveness with emerging industries like those in Southeast Asia, as well as with established industries in the United States, could be severely hurt.
"This year, the unions have more bargaining power than in previous years, but employers seem still ready to put up a fight," said Gunther Thurman, a vice president for economic and market analysis at Goldman, Sachs in Frankfurt.
IG Metall has called a strike vote for Monday by 730,000 workers in its southern district in Bavaria. Approval for a strike is almost assured, economists here say.
Bavaria was apparently chosen as the initial target because it is home to big industrial companies like BMW, Siemens and Audi whose factories are operating at full or nearly full capacity and would not have the cushion of high inventories during a long strike.
The spillover effect of a strike could cripple most of the auto industry, since Audi supplies many parts to its parent company, Volkswagen, which has plants in central and northern Germany. Volkswagen has announced that it is prepared to slow down production if it cannot get the parts delivered.
More than two months ago, IG Metall announced that it wanted a 6 percent wage increase for its members. So far, Gesamtmetall has frustrated the union by refusing to make a counterproposal.
Before any pay increases can be discussed, the employers say the unions must be willing to discuss ways to cut costs, including eliminating an agreement reached last year to reduce the workweek by an hour, to 35 hours. Employers say the shorter week will increase their costs by 2.8 percent. The union has rejected negotiations on the shorter week, which would take effect Oct. 1.
Both sides feel vulnerable since they are losing members. The union, considered the most powerful in Germany, lost 250,000 members in 1993 and possibly as many last year. The employers' group has also lost 400 members since 1993.
Some analysts expect the talks to turn more serious before the strike vote, because a big strike would hurt both sides.
"There is a lot of noise," said Holger Fahrinkrug, senior economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland in Frankfurt. "But we have a lot of time before we face a strike."

HEADLINE: Holocaust Survivors' Emphasis Is on Life

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Fifty years after their liberation from death camps, more than 3,000 Holocaust survivors gathered here this weekend for a commemoration. But Saul I. Nitzberg, a survivor of Auschwitz, was not among them today.
He skipped the event's first day to attend a relative's wedding. "Our family is very closely knit," said Dr. Nitzberg, 72, of Hollywood, Fla. 
 That Dr. Nitzberg's priorities revolve around life, not remembrances, befits this anniversary of the end of World War II. By now, survivors of the Holocaust have met many times in similar large gatherings. They have told their stories in oral histories taped and stored.
So as they age into their 70's, their reunions decimated by the passage of time, many of those who remain say they do not want to dwell on pain. They say they came to the Fontainebleau Hilton Hotel here to celebrate (although many are reluctant to use that word) accomplishments and what people once fated for extinction regard as their greatest legacy: descendants.
"It's too late to ask certain questions," said Joseph Garay, a 73-year-old New Yorker who lost his parents and six siblings in the camps. " 'Have you seen my brother, my sister, my father?' We went through this already for 50 years. Who knows how many times we'll get together?"
The setting of the event itself attests to achievement. "Gentiles only" signs once kept Jews from buying land or staying in hotels in Miami Beach. But it has become a Jewish tourist and residential enclave that now has its own Holocaust memorial and soon will be home to the state's first Jewish museum, scheduled to open in April in a restored Art Deco synagogue.
After a decline in the Jewish population in the 1980's, when mostly the old stayed, the area is now experiencing a renewal evident in new kosher restaurants and stores along Arthur Godfrey Road and younger Orthodox homeowners to the north of South Beach. Dade County, the metropolitan area that includes Miami Beach, has 166,000 Jews, the sixth largest Jewish community in the United States, demographic studies show.
An estimated 20,000 Holocaust survivors settled in the three South Florida counties of Dade, Broward and Palm Beach. Dr. Nitzberg, a hematologist who moved to Broward County's Hollywood in 1958, said he came seeking economic opportunity.
"I felt it was backward country and there were not too many specialties in my field," he said.
For Dr. Nitzberg and other survivors, there is no better proof that they have transcended the past than the professional success of their children. Four of Dr. Nitzberg's five children are medical doctors and the fifth is a clinical psychologist. He has 11 grandchildren.
A native of Poland whose family was forced into a ghetto and then to Auschwitz, Dr. Nitzberg said he motivated his sons and daughters by example and by lessons drawn from his Holocaust experience. His father, an engineer who was killed after falling ill with dysentery and diarrhea in the camp, was initially spared the crematorium because he knew how to do dental work.
His usefulness, he said, gave him three more weeks of life.
"What you learn, nobody can take from you," said the doctor, who was brought to New York by relatives in 1946 and later attended the University of Georgia and Emory University Medical School.
His American-born wife of 45 years, Mildred, and the couple's children said he attributed other values to his experience in Germany. One is a strong sense of loyalty to family (only a brother survived the war). Another is unwavering direction.
"He took hold of what he wanted out of life and held on to it with incredible vigor," said Laurie Sabra, his 36-year-old daughter. "He has a clear view of what's important -- family, being honest and going to bed at night with a clear conscience."
Dr. Nitzberg, who still works in private practice, said, "I decided long ago that the past is the past and I can't do anything about it."
This weekend's event drew 4,000 people, 3,500 of them survivors. There were reunions of friends and relatives at a "survivors village" in a ballroom, where computers from the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum allowed for tracing names and pictures from a survivors registry.
Scheduled for the event were the presentation of flags of liberating United States Army units and a videotaped address by President Clinton at a Sunday dinner.
Today, a giant screen in the "village" flashed slides of family after family as they are today, mostly portraits of two and three generations at weddings and other celebrations. On the floor below, the happy pictures were tempered by wounds still open half a century later.
"Have you been in Auswitz-Birkenau, Lager D., Barack 30, October 1944. Please contact me," read a sign carried by a woman survivor still looking for information about a sister who was 15 when she last saw her.
"I have no celebration in my life," said the woman, Elizabeth Ungar, 70, a Hungarian now of Highland Beach in Palm Beach County. "All the happiness was always covered by sorrow."
In the group there was also the sense that the living memory of the Holocaust is inexorably fading. About 70,000 survivors remain in the United States, a shrinking group despite expanding families.
As time passes, each reunion becomes the most moving yet, some say.
"When you get older you get a little bit more emotional," said Benjamin Meed, a survivor of the Warsaw ghetto and president of the American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors, which organized this event. Mr. Meed has organized five similar events since 1981.
"We are losing people every day," he said.
But then, as always, the talk turned to the children.
"Our vengeance," Mr. Meed said, "was rebuilding life."

HEADLINE: It's a Hard Job Saving Foreign Aid (but the Job Is Still There)

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
At a time when Government bureaucracies all over Washington are scrambling to survive, J. Brian Atwood is developing a reputation as a master of that particular game.
He is the director of the Government's principal agency for the distribution of foreign aid, a program the public in general regards with distaste and the Republicans in particular rate lower than welfare. 
 As if that were not enough, Secretary of State Warren Christopher joined other critics last month to propose shutting down Mr. Atwood's shop, the Agency for International Development.
But after a passionate round of lobbying, speech-making, letter-writing, log-rolling, string-pulling and plain old pleading that could serve as a model of how such behind-the-scenes battles are fought, Mr. Atwood persuaded Vice President Al Gore to reject Mr. Christopher's proposal, and he and his agency are still standing. At least for now.
Eager to chop foreign aid and to demolish what they view as an outdated, inefficient bastion of bureaucratic self-preservation, Republican leaders announced plans this week to push through legislation to scrap Mr. Atwood's agency and merge it with the State Department.
For Mr. Atwood, this new threat means remounting his lobbying bicycle. It will mean more speeches to foreign policy groups to rally support. It will mean many more one-on-one meetings on Capitol Hill to defend programs like assistance for Africa and population stabilization.
It will also mean more gettogethers with editorial writers and appeals to relief groups to urge Congress to preserve the $13.7 billion foreign aid program. It will require more broadcasts of the agency's public service ads, which describe the agency's efforts to help eradicate smallpox, fight famine, protect rain forests and increase literacy rates -- all while creating hundreds of thousands of American jobs.
Mr. Atwood will once again be taking to the airwaves to respond to Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, who is leading the new drive to abolish the agency. While some Administration officials dismiss Mr. Helms as a cranky conservative who is more bark than bite, his effort has Mr. Atwood's full attention because it is backed by the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, and the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich.
After a month of scrambling and fighting, the strains on Mr. Atwood are starting to show. His words have become more caustic, less tempered.
"Because of the impression that has been created that our foreign aid program is nothing more than an international welfare program," he said in an interview, "it has been possible for demagogues, isolationists and populists, all sometimes in the same person, to exploit that and to exploit people's fears."
Appearing on C-Span this week, Mr. Atwood lashed out at the Helms proposal to eliminate his agency.
"It's mischievous," he said. "It's designed more to pursue an isolationist foreign policy than it is to do something constructive."
A tall, stocky 51-year-old who was once captain of the Boston University football team, Mr. Atwood has won admiration within the Administration for his perseverance.
Those on the other side, however, may credit his skills but are far from persuaded.
"He's a good salesman, but he's selling to some very tough customers." said Charles Bass, a New Hampshire Republican on the House Budget Committee who recently met with Mr. Atwood. "It's not clear to me we need all those aid missions overseas acting like second State Departments."
Mr. Atwood bridles at the suggestion that his goal is bureaucratic self-preservation. Rather, he says he has to protect a program that first flourished when the Marshall Plan provided billions of dollars to rebuild a devastated Europe after World War II.
Defying the current mood, Mr. Atwood insists that foreign aid deserves a new mandate, rather than a retreat. In the post-cold-war world, he argues, the crises that America faces -- and sends troops to -- will increasingly involve not the Soviet Union, but countries like Somalia and Rwanda afflicted by hunger and overpopulation. In his view, aid is essential to prevent those problems from exploding.
"There are more threats coming from societies that are failing than from the threats we used to see," he said. "When societies fail, there are wars and huge flows of refugees, and then the whole world has to spend a lot of money to resolve them. A little more investment earlier on might have helped prevent such crises and saved a lot of money."
As he hunches forward on a burgundy chair in his dark, oak-walled office, Mr. Atwood can scarcely hide his hurt that colleagues in the Administration had proposed abolishing his agency. In January, after Vice President Gore asked the State Department for suggestions on reducing the foreign policy bureaucracy, Mr. Christopher proposed merging A.I.D., the United States Information Agency and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency into the State Department.
Mr. Atwood met several times with Mr. Gore and Mr. Christopher to make his case. An official who sat in on some of those meetings said: "Brian made his case on three fronts: 'I've made major changes in this organization already. My agency has a unique and important mission in support of foreign policy. And don't disrupt my efforts right now when I'm in the middle of our own reinvention efforts.' "
Mr. Gore decided in late January against merging the three agencies into the State Department. In explaining the decision, it was clear that the Vice President was influenced by Mr. Atwood's arguments. He agreed that the aid agency had such a distinctive mission that a merger would be ineffective, and that a merger would undermine the cost-cutting already under way.
Other senior officials, however, said that just as important was the concern that the State Department had management problems of its own.
In an Administration that has talked ceaselessly about reinventing government, Mr. Atwood has shut down 23 overseas missions and cut his agency's roster by 10 percent, to 2,900. He has turned off the spigot to countries like Zaire and Cameroon that have not made effective use of aid. He has replaced the agency's 13 financial management systems and 42 overseas accounting offices with one central office and system. And he has revamped the agency's procurement procedures.
Despite those efforts, some critics view his work as a lost cause.
"He's doing as good a job as he possibly can to run what is essentially a relic of the past," said Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican who heads the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations. "A.I.D. is a dinosaur. It's time to put it to rest."

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Governor Joins Forces With India's Silicon Valley

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Massachusetts announced plans today to forge an alliance with India's equivalent of Silicon Valley in California.
"We hope to have a sister status with Karnataka," Gov. William F. Weld told reporters after opening the India office of the Raytheon Company, a military contractor in Lexington, Mass. 
 Several large computer companies have opened in and around Bangalore, the capital of the southern state of Karnataka, taking advantage of a three-year-old economic reform program in India. Karnataka is home to many of India's top engineers and software professionals.
"Bangalore and Karnataka are a perfect fit because we are the software capital," Mr. Weld said, referring to the 1,800 software companies that are based in the Boston area.
Mr. Weld, who is leading a 22-company business delegation to India, said the details of the planned alliance with Karnataka would be worked out next week, when he is scheduled to hold talks with the recently elected chief minister, H. D. Deve Gowda.
Mr. Gowda, who heads the centrist Janata Dal government, put out the welcome mat for foreign investors after his party defeated Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao's Congress Party, which has championed the free-market policies.
Mr. Weld said his state had worked out similar arrangements with Guangdong Province in China and with the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. Massachusetts signed a memorandum of understanding on Friday with the Confederation of Indian Industry to increase business contacts.
The Massachusetts delegation includes executives from companies representing industries like telecommunications, financial services, environmental technology, engineering, biomedical technology and computer software.
Mr. Weld also said Massachusetts would receive an Indian business delegation in April.

HEADLINE: These Days, the Circus Animals Sneak Into Town

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Feb. 18

 BODY:
When the circus rolled into Richmond five years ago, disk jockeys broadcast live by cellular phone from the backs of the elephants, as they lumbered through downtown in a parade from the railyard to the big top. Globes proclaiming "The Greatest Show on Earth" glittered from the harnesses of the great beasts as children of all ages waved in the streets.
This week, the circus tip-toed into town, an hour after sundown. No riders. No globes. Officials of the circus, Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows Inc., asked reporters not to publicize the arrival time. 
 The circus parade, a 198-year-old tradition that once stopped traffic with clowns and calliopes, has yielded to economics, insurance and animal rights. Ringling Brothers said in a news release, "The animal walk is not a parade, rather, a logistical necessity to move our animals from the circus train to the Richmond Coliseum."
So fans have begun camping out for hours to await the pachyderm procession. In California last summer, a headline in the Long Beach Press-Telegram announced, "elephant hunt tonight."
Some Richmonders tracked down the train by calling the police. Debbie Worten, a homemaker, set out in search of the circus with a former neighbor and their four children at 3 P.M. on Monday. They were four hours early for the caravan of 22 horses, 18 elephants, 5 camels, 4 ponies, 4 zebras, 2 llamas and 1 street sweeper, which zig-zagged from lane to lane.
"We didn't find any elephant droppings, so we knew we weren't late," Mrs. Worten said.
A Ringling Brothers executive called the change a reflection of the time. "Things are a lot more regulated than they were five years ago," said Rodney A. Huey, the vice president of public relations. "Risk management is much more involved."
Dale A. Riker, a former president of the Circus Fans Association of America, said the decision seemed reasonable, because of threats from animal-rights demonstrators and the possibility that an animal would bolt.
Circus promoters also said they were concerned that people watched the parade but then did not come to the show and pay admission. Indeed, at the Richmond animal walk, several parents shivering in the 30-degree chill said they could not afford to show their children the circus any other way.
And Ringling Brothers said unpredictable train schedules had led to complaints from spectators. Many, though, do not seem to mind. A circus spokeswoman said that even at 2 A.M. or 4 A.M., several hundred people line the Manhattan side of the Queens-Midtown tunnel each year as the animals march from the tracks in Long Island City, through the tollbooth, to Madison Square Garden.
Fred Dahlinger Jr., the library director at Circus World Museum, in Baraboo, Wis., said the first circus parade was held in Philadelphia in 1797. "There were really two shows -- the free one as they unloaded, and the formal one in the ring," she said.
In decades past, people munched picnic lunches as they watched the elephants hoist tent poles. Workers at downtown companies brought their children to work on parade day. John Farmer, 79, who watched keepers unload the stock cars this week, remembered being nabbed by the britches when, as a boy of 10, he tried to sneak into the big top. He got a free ticket in return for helping to set up seats.
For decades, parades had been hampered by overhead utility wires, growing suburbs and innovations like electric winches that shrank the number of roustabouts.
In the last two years, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, based in Bethesda, Md., began posting protesters in each of the 92 cities Ringling Brothers visits. The group says the animals are victims of "circus savagery," including rough handling and cramped travel quarters.
"The stealth circus is really a P.R. decision," said Kathy Savory, a spokeswoman for the group. "If people get too close to the animals, they may see the scars, may see them limping."
Mr. Huey said Ringling Brothers had made no changes in response to the campaign, because the animals' comfort and safety had always been the company's top priority. "They make it like we're hiding something," he said. "We display our animals to over 11 million people a year."
The circus still has three rings, and still has a flying trapeze. But the performers are lighted using technology from rock concerts. This year's circus features the "Globe of Death," with three motorcyclists cartwheeling inside a sphere of steel mesh. Music by U2, the stadium rockers, blares during another act, the "Wheel of Death."
Standing beside the train this week, Art Ricker, a regional vice president of Ringling Brothers, adopted a soft, self-mocking tone as he said the 53 cars were "jammed and crammed with wonders from every corner of the earth."
Jim Ragona, 40, who lives in a Ringling Brothers coach car, was ringmaster for 12 years, and now is the performance director. Instead of the handlebar mustache of the old-time ringmaster, he has a master's degree from the Art Institute of Chicago.
Mr. Ragona recalled the 1940's, when John Ringling North, who owned the circus until 1967, would pull into town in a train car.
"His entire advertising budget went to posters," Mr. Ragona said. "He mixed the glue himself. So the most important tool he had was the parade. Now, kids are bombarded with media, and stay home and play Nintendo. It no longer makes sense to pack up absolutely everything you own, and cart it through the streets."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Circus animals were unloaded in the dark on Monday in Richmond, in contrast to earlier years, when the parade of animals from the railroad cars to the circus site was a widely watched event. (Clement Britt/Richmond Times-Dispatch)

HEADLINE: Watershed Fiscal Plan

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
It was both pragmatic fiscal pressure and broad political ideology that combined last week to produce a watershed in New York City politics: a Mayor proposing to make drastic cuts in the city's aid to the poor.
In releasing his preliminary budget for the next fiscal year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said essentially that after five years of budget trouble, the city had run out of easy spending cuts. And so he called for reductions of $1.2 billion in welfare and Medicaid, the government health program for the poor and disabled. 
 Beyond budget problems, the Mayor's decision was also provoked by the remarkable shift in national and state politics that occurred last November, when Republicans committed to shrinking government, cutting taxes and reducing spending for the poor seized control of both houses of Congress and the Governor's mansions in Albany and Hartford.
"A budget is driven by both numbers and values," said Mark J. Green, the city's Public Advocate. "A lot of the Giuliani fiscal plan is driven by sheer numbers, in a way that whether it were Giuliani or Freddy Ferrer as mayor, the reductions would be similar. However, a big chunk of it is values driven."
Finally, the Mayor's decision to seek a profound change in New York City's tradition of magnanimity toward its poorest citizens could not have happened without both the political and fiscal conditions that shaped his choices.
If New York's economy had begun even a modest recovery last year from a deep five-year recession, as many economists had expected, there would have been a vastly diminished need for extraordinary budget cuts. Mr. Giuliani must close a $2.7 billion gap in a nearly $30.5 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins in July.
And if Democrats over the last three decades had confronted the vast inefficiencies of welfare and Medicaid, many proponents of the Mayor's plan say, the program would not have been nearly so vulnerable now.
"It is precisely the failure to prune the Great Society programs, to use them intelligently, that has made them so difficult to trim now," said Fred Siegel, a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute, a research group associated with centrist Democrats.
Mayor Giuliani, who was elected as a fusion candidate in an overwhelmingly Democratic city, had not previously indicated much taste for dismantling automatic benefits programs. As a candidate for mayor in 1993, he did not advocate major reductions in welfare and Medicaid, although he emphasized the need for encouraging welfare recipients to find jobs and for shrinking the size of city government.
Last year, he asked for a state takeover of the city's Medicaid costs, a burden of more than $2 billion a year -- equivalent in size to the city's long-term, or structural, deficit. With George E. Pataki now in office, and the possibility of a takeover eliminated, Mr. Giuliani is still seeking state aid on Medicaid, although his strategy is entirely different. Now he wants the state to help by enabling the city to cut Medicaid.
Mr. Pataki proposed two weeks ago in his budget to reduce spending on Medicaid and welfare by $1.9 billion statewide. The Mayor asked the Governor last week to go much further, to a total of $2.5 billion statewide, which would allow the city to save about $1.2 billion altogether on such spending in its budget. (The state and city each pay 25 percent of welfare and Medicaid; the Federal Government pays for the rest.)
"Unfortunately, the fiscal stability of New York has slipped to the point where we have to take these drastic measures to balance the budget," said the city's Budget Director, Marc V. Shaw.
"The state and Federal government are not going to bail out the city with cash," Mr. Shaw said. "So faced with that reality, the City of New York would be two-faced if it did not treat seriously the chance to consider new ways to slow down spending on entitlements."
Of course, the administration could have made other choices. It could have cut police spending, demanded additional productivity from workers or even raised taxes. But Mr. Giuliani's personal predilections and the national mood apparently ruled that out.
"The climate is so profoundly different since November that people in public life no longer defend things that they once thought were absolute necessities," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University.
"The Republican victory in Congress has basically cleared the way for New York State Republicans, both Giuliani and Pataki, to have carte blanche on budget policy, because whatever they do in New York is still not as mean-spirited as what they do in Washington."
Many advocates of the Mayor's approach say that the city's deteriorating fiscal condition requires deep cuts in programs for the poor. Since almost a third of the city's spending involves service to the poor, in one form or another, they say it should not be surprising that closing a huge budget gap would involve large cuts in aid to the poor.
Some also argue that the city has long spent too much on social services and other aid to the poor, making New York uncompetitive with other regions. A cutback has been long overdue, they say.
"The reason things seem so Draconian now is that decisions that should have been made over a decade have to be made at once," said Mr. Siegel of the Progressive Policy Institute. "In effect, we've used Medicaid as a jobs program. It's a kind of fool's gold, because you mine something that does not develop the local economy."
But Mr. Siegel said he feared that withdrawing so much aid to poor people, and poor neighborhoods, so quickly could have serious consequences. "I think the effect of the Medicaid cuts will be terribly deflationary," he said. "We're draining a lot of money out of the economy. But if we continued down this path, we'd end up in a situation where we would be uncompetitive all across the board."
Other supporters of Mr. Giuliani's plan said that short-term effect might not be so bad. "I think what we're seeing is not a dismantling, but probably the most significant review of the whole social welfare program that we've seen in 30 years," said Abraham Biderman, a former city housing and finance commissioner who is now an investment banker.
"The net will still be there, the cost will still be dramatic as compared to what existed before Lyndon Johnson's Great Society, but the city has never dealt with this segment of the budget this way. We're revisiting things that were sacred in the past."

HEADLINE: Merchants Fear Plans To Attract Big Stores

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Ten months ago James Novak moved his 18-year-old auto parts business from Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights across Flushing Bay to a thriving district in College Point because of what he called a decline in economic conditions.
Now he is being met with a new challenge: a city plan that would allow the opening of a megastore at the College Point Corporate Park just blocks away from his newly renovated business at 14th Avenue and 132d Street. 
 "If I had known about the plan, I would have given more thought to moving here," Mr. Novak said yesterday between sales of quarts of oil and jugs of antifreeze. "It would eliminate the small mom-and-pop shops that make up this community. I'm going to send out a few dozen letters to city officials."
Complaints like these are likely to multiply as a result of a proposal unveiled by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at City Hall yesterday. The plan would open several neighborhoods to discount retailers and warehouse stores that were previously prevented by zoning laws from moving in.
The Mayor said the proposal would create new jobs and stimulate business in local communities.
Since megastore developers began eyeing New York City several years ago for potential sites, Queens has been the center of many clashes because of its suburblike qualities. Last summer residents of Astoria shot down a proposal for a Pathmark to open there and residents of Laurelton and Springfield Gardens are engaged in a bitter battle to prevent Pathmark from opening a branch in their community.
Some community leaders, merchants and members of the City Council reacted strongly against the Mayor's proposal yesterday, saying they would be precluded from waging such battles.
"It's a sad day for the city," Fred Mazzarello, president of the College Point Board of Trade, said of the Mayor's proposal. "The city's not going to get out of it what they think they will. These stores aren't going to generate jobs. They're going to take them away."
While officials with the city's Economic Development Corporation would not say what companies submitted proposals to open in the College Point Corporate Park, Mr. Mazzarello said PriceCostco, a wholesale membership warehouse, has blanketed the community with fliers asking for residents' support to open there. If the large discount store opened, selling clothes, automotive parts, pharmaceutical products, baked goods and groceries, it would be in direct competition with businesses like Mr. Novak's.
To develop the corporate park just off the Whitestone Expressway, the city is trying to attract retail companies and reclaim some of the tax revenue the city is losing to Long Island and New Jersey. The New York Times has signed a lease-purchase option for 32 acres at the site for a printing plant.
Richard Lipsky, a lobbyist and executive director of the Neighborhood Small Business Association, a group that has long opposed the arrival of megastores in the city, said the incentives in the Mayor's proposal to help small businesses are insufficient. The incentives include eliminating the law that requires businesses to sweep the streets, switching one-hour parking meters to two hours and setting up a coordinating agency to centralize the licensing and regulatory process.
Daniel Doherty, 45, owner of Nelco Hardware at 18-08 College Point Boulevard, believes he would be crushed by a megastore's opening at the corporate park and by Home Depot, which is scheduled to open at the old Taystee Bread factory in Flushing. He would be caught in the middle, he said.

HEADLINE: New Position On Rebel Flag In S. Carolina

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 18

 BODY:
A Republican who recently became Attorney General of South Carolina said on Friday that he would reverse the policy of his predecessor and seek to keep the Confederate battle flag atop the South Carolina Statehouse unless the Legislature decides to take it down.
The Attorney General, Charlie Condon, asked the State Supreme Court to either dismiss a lawsuit challenging the flag or allow him to prepare a new brief outlining the state's new position. 
 The court is considering a lawsuit by business and civic leaders, including Mayor Bob Coble of Columbia, who say the flag hurts the city and state's economic growth and is an inappropriate reminder of slavery.
In 1962, the Legislature adopted a resolution that put the flag atop the Statehouse, which with the defeat of recent attempts to take it down gives the banner legal authority to remain in place unless the Legislature says otherwise, Mr. Condon said.
South Carolina is the only state that still flies the Confederate battle flag, which has white stars on a diagonal blue bands with a red background, above its statehouse. Mississippi and Georgia incorporate the design in their state flags, which also have brought protests.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People organized marches against the flying of the flag last summer in Myrtle Beach and in Hilton Head over the Labor Day weekend. The group has also threatened an economic boycott against the state if the flag keeps flying, although it said it would take no action until the State Supreme Court rules on the challenge.
The flag's supporters say it is an important part of the region's heritage that honors those who fought in the Civil War.
Mr. Condon, a Republican who took office last month, said during last year's campaign that he thought the former Attorney General, Travis Medlock, was wrong when he ruled in October that there was no legal authority to fly the flag.
Mr. Medlock, a Democrat, refused to defend the state in the lawsuit. He did not return messages left at his home and office on Friday.
Richard Gergel, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.

HEADLINE: Journal;
A Dropout Returns

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
A benevolent ruler is felled by a mysterious illness and is widely rumored to be mad -- then returns to power months later none the worse for wear. While this happens to be the plot of Alan Bennett's "The Madness of King George," it is also the true story of Neil Rudenstine, the president of Harvard.
Suffering from "severe fatigue and exhaustion of unknown origin," Mr. Rudenstine abruptly vacated the most visible job in American higher education in November, setting off both rumors about his mental state and a national reassessment of the role of university presidents in a stressful age. During his absence, The Wall Street Journal questioned his ability to pass Management 101 at Harvard's own Business School. The Harvard Crimson described him as "a grind," with "few grand accomplishments to show for his hard work" during his three-year tenure. 
 But Mr. Rudenstine is back, defending his record and saying the only ailment he had was indeed exhaustion. On Thursday he officially returns to his office. Last Thursday I visited him at home here, in the forbidding mansion, well removed from the campus, where Harvard has safely ensconced its presidents since tear gas flooded Harvard Yard in the late 1960's.
Wearing a terminally Ivy blazer without a tie, as well as a deep tan picked up in the Caribbean, Mr. Rudenstine looks far too young and fit for someone who just celebrated his 60th birthday. When he describes himself as "very healthy" and his mind as "clicking along," the protestations sound redundant.
Nor has he been much chastened by his sabbatical. Though others may have seen his flameout as a sign that a university president can no longer be all things to all constituencies -- from a high-powered C.E.O. to an avuncular scholar-administrator to a national intellectual force -- Mr. Rudenstine disagrees.
He still believes the presidency of Harvard is a doable job, and one primarily concerned with the university's educational mission, even at a time when he must spearhead an unprecedented $2.1 billion fund-raising drive mandating the raising of $1 million a day. Though he will be delegating some duties to others, he will not disown the operating style that drives him to write staggering numbers of handwritten notes and play a hands-on role in what some critics feel is academic minutiae. His aim "is to be more efficient without being less personal."
Mr. Rudenstine's efficiency does not extend to being on-line. He doesn't use a computer. Which is what's both appealing and worrisome about him. Like George III, both he and the kingdom he runs may be straddling a fault line of perilous historical change.
He sees the crisis as coming from without, not within. Should the 104th Congress cut Federal student aid, he says, it will be "the first major reversal in more than a century" of the goal of making higher education affordable to "all students of talent and motivation from all backgrounds." (Mr. Rudenstine himself was a scholarship student.) Should cuts in research funding follow, so will a decline in "the quality and capacity of the human capital that's actually out there leading and running our society."
But can a Harvard president do anything about it? Mr. Rudenstine says he will speak out in Washington, but realistically adds that "religious colleges" and what he calls "small colleges" -- Kennesaw State, perhaps? -- may make more of a political difference than the culturally elite Harvard right now. Gone are the days when a Harvard president like James B. Conant could command the attention of the nation. Mr. Rudenstine says he must compete not only with far more university voices than Conant did in the 1930's but with a cacophonous society mirroring talk radio.
Besides, he adds, we now live in an era where so much of "the action" has shifted to the economic and political arenas that "education itself has fallen down in terms of the nation's priorities." And if education is not a high American priority, university presidents are not about to be "high on the list of what the nation listens to."
That Mr. Rudenstine is now strong enough to make himself heard is beyond question. Whether anyone listens or not will tell us more about the country's long-term health than it does about his own.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
For Black Coaches, New Direction Needed

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
DURING an interview last August, Rudy Washington, the executive director of the Black Coaches Association, predicted that the next level of dissent in intercollegiate athletics would not come from coaches.
"These students are going to be the biggest fear," Washington said. "Not the coaches." 
 Six months later, Washington's prediction has come true,
At Rutgers, more than 150 students, most of them African-American, walked on the basketball court before the start of the second half in a game between Rutgers and Massachusetts. The students proceeded to accomplish something the coaches' group had threatened but never pulled off: they forced a game to be called off. The students were protesting statements made last November by Francis Lawrence, the president of Rutgers, but only recently made public.
During a discussion of standardized test scores, Lawrence cited statistics showing that blacks scored relatively low. He suggested they were genetically incapable of doing better. "Do we set standards in the future so we don't admit anybody? Or do we deal with a disadvantaged population that doesn't have that genetic, hereditary background to have a higher average?" he said.
Washington applauded the Rutgers protesters for their "courage" and said: "Their fortitude in a very difficult situation exemplifies a true strength of character. Ten years from now we may consider this incident to be the watershed in the fight for educational opportunity."
The protest was actually an evolutionary outgrowth of a protest movement the B.C.A. began on Jan. 14, 1989 when John Thompson, head coach at Georgetown, left the court to protest the passage of a measure he felt would hinder economically disadvantaged athletes in earning athletic scholarships.
Since then, members of the association, especially Thompson, John Chaney of Temple, Nolan Richardson of Arkansas and George Raveling, the former Southern California coach, have been at the forefront of the battle for increased opportunities in intercollegiate athletics for African-American and other minorities.
But this time the B.C.A. missed an opportunity to ignite a movement it actually predicted.
The Rutgers president, in referring to "genetic, hereditary background," put a tangible face on a deeply rooted issue the B.C.A. exposed last year. The association learned that key members of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's data analysis group had strong ties to Beyondism, a eugenics-oriented movement that espouses genetic and racial superiority.
At the time, the B.C.A. had nothing tangible to hang its hat on except the names of faceless individuals who played down their association with Beyondism and remained out of the limelight.
"I began to wonder if maybe I was a little paranoid, then up pops the devil," John Thompson said in a telephone interview yesterday, referring to the attitude reflected in the type of comment Lawrence made. "We've been saying all along that this mentality exists. It exists in the N.C.A.A., in higher education. It exists, of all places, at the presidential level."
Unfortunately for the B.C.A., Thompson made his remarks yesterday, more than a week after the Rutgers incident. There was not a hard, sharp B.C.A. stance on Lawrence's comments.
The most vocal coach was Chaney, who said he supported the protest but at the same time chided the students and said they were "misdirected."
Lawrence later disavowed the remark, saying he had jumbled his words and that he did not believe that hereditary factors determine ability and achievement.
Chaney said he accepted Lawrence's later apology. But Chaney suggested that when Lawrence made the remark, he was expressing his true feelings, and the coach said than rather than replace him with someone who would be less forthcoming, students should work with Lawrence. "Do you want the devil you know or the devil you don't know?" Chaney asked Wednesday after a game with Rutgers.
Thompson said that he didn't want to make a personal attack on Lawrence, but that the more he thought about the comments, the less inclined he was to pass them off as a careless linguistics lapse. "This was not just a slip of the tongue," he said. "This was a deep statement interjected in conversation that was intended to be handled subtly or privately."
In retrospect, Thompson agreed that the B.C.A. would have been better served by a more penetrating response to the larger issue of eugenics and the narrower issue of sustaining broad-based student protests. But from now until late March, a coach's focus is basketball.
"The timing is bad for us," Thompson said. "Everyone is involved with our teams, the various struggles and doing our jobs."
More than anything, the Rutgers controversy dramatically underlines the need for the B.C.A. to appoint a full-time executive director and establish a national office in Washington.
This is an absolute must if the B.C.A. is to avoid being perceived as a stagnant association more concerned with protecting status -- and status quo -- than widening the window of opportunity.
Rudy Washington often points out that the fear of the riot is often worse than the riot itself. But the B.C.A. has run out of threats and, in the case of Rutgers, came up short on providing direction as well.
There was a movement in Piscataway, ready to be ignited. The B.C.A. wasn't prepared to strike a match.
