HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
'Disrespect for Game' A Managerial Lament With Modern Players

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 18

 BODY:
Managers, in the early days of this spring training, don't have players to talk about, at least none they want to talk about, so some of them express their concerns about the players who aren't in Florida and Arizona and aren't expected any time soon.
Tony La Russa of Oakland and Joe Torre of St. Louis spoke not of specific players but of players as a group, lamenting the changes they have seen develop over the years. 
 "The players, especially the ones you need most, are more and more disrespectful to everybody -- other members of the organization, to fans," La Russa said. "They can't be bothered with this request or that request. They're disrespectful to past players. Former players walk into the clubhouse and they look at them like, how good could they have been; they didn't make this kind of money."
Simply put, La Russa said, the players have a "disrespect for the game." The message, he said, "has to go out to them that they've got to change the way they view it."
Torre said the problem is money. He wasn't campaigning on behalf of the owners to induce the players to accept management's position in the stalled negotiations, but he made a point that even people on the players' side of the labor dispute have seen and commented on in recent years.
"I don't think many players are aware of what went on 20 years ago, how this came about," Torre said, referring to the lucrative economic position players enjoy. "They have no idea of where the money came from. They feel they have it coming."
In his time as a player, Torre was intimately involved in off-field developments, first as a club player representative, then as the National League representative. Some people might see his current views as the typical reaction of former players to those playing now, the new generation of players and all that.
But 25 years after Curt Flood and nearly 20 years after Andy Messersmith, a player survey on the relationship of those names to the current players' wealth could produce embarrassing results. Younger players especially act as if baseball history began with them, as if they are entitled to salaries in the millions.
"I have trouble with guys," Torre said, "who are negotiating between four and five million and they don't want four million because, they say, they're thinking of their family. That sort of thing doesn't go over well with the public. Don't flaunt it."
But Bob Gibson, the Hall of Fame pitcher who is back in the game after a 10-year absence, added some perspective.
"I haven't been altogether away from the game that I don't understand that things have changed," the Cardinals' new bullpen coach said. "It's not just players; it's society. I've been involved in society, so players aren't going to be any different."
Torre himself provided a note of perspective showing that it's not only players who have changed. Consider autograph seekers, the manager said.
"I've seen kids get my autograph, then go give it to somebody and he gives him a buck or two," Torre related. "You ask a kid's name so you can write 'To Billy,' and he says, 'Oh no, just sign your name.' Not even 'best wishes.' "
Adulterated autographs don't sell, and autograph seekers no longer seek players' signatures to put in a scrapbook or a desk drawer. If one of the worst modern practices of players is to charge for their autographs and if they need an excuse for doing it, the collecting industry has given it to them.
 
An Innocent Victim
 Sam Mejias, the Seattle Mariners' first base coach, has become an unintended victim of the strike. A resident of the Dominican Republic, Mejias has been unable to get into this country to work, even though he has a P1 visa. Because the Labor Department has certified the players strike, the immigration department won't allow foreign nationals into the country to work with P1 visas at strike sites.
The Players Association pursued the certification, intending to block the clubs from bringing in replacement players from Latin America and elsewhere. Now the Mariners might need a replacement coach.
 
Anderson's Viewpoint
 Sparky Anderson is notorious for ascribing Hall of Fame qualities to untested rookies. Now he has graduated to front office executives. Discussing his decision to step aside as the Detroit manager for replacement baseball, Anderson told of his conversations with John McHale Jr., the Tigers' new president.
"They got something there," Anderson said of the 46-year-old McHale. "I mean they got themselves a catch. If they leave this man alone and let this man go about his business and let him do his work, they finally got a catch. I really believe if they leave this guy alone for two years, McHale is going to clean this mess up."
Anderson publicly disclosed for the first time the real story behind his 16-day leave during the 1989 season. At the time, the Tigers said he was exhausted.
"That thing had nothing to do with anything but my daughter," he said. "My daughter was going through a terrible thing with her husband. That was a very concerning thing. She was seven months pregnant and getting anorexic over this thing. This guy was putting her through the wringer. When I got home, I got that straightened out. Jim Campbell was very good about the way he covered it," he said, referring to the Tigers' then-chairman. "I told Jim, I don't want my daughter brought up in this. Jim, as always, knows how to cover things. He said, we'll say it's fatigue."
Anderson also spoke about his 1995 salary of $1.2 million, though he didn't acknowledge the figure. "This was the first time I asked for the money," he related. "I said a number. I kind of shook when I said it. I heard a couple things what guys were getting, and I said if that guy's going to get that, I should get this. I went to the top very fast."
Anderson said he doesn't want anyone to salute him for shunning replacement baseball. The person to cheer, he said, is Cal Ripken, whose consecutive-game streak could end with the first replacement game.
"Just imagine what he's risking," Anderson said. "Is that character? You think I got character? I got to take a back seat to old Calvin. That is strong character that you cannot buy. It's unassailable. This man does not deserve not to have a legitimate shot at it."
Not only does Anderson not like replacement players, but he also doesn't care for strikers who would return to work before the strike ends.
"You and me play together," he said. "If you're going to suffer, don't I have to suffer? Why are you different than me? Why do you have to take the bow and arrows and I don't have to. We started out on an even playing field. Mine got rocky so now I'm supposed to cry and squeal and run for cover? No. When the field gets rocky. you got to be there. You can't go back and forth. You're not allowed to do that."

HEADLINE: February 12-18: Microsoft;
An Antitrust Settlement With a Glitch

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

 BODY:
Seven months after Federal antitrust officials declared they had reined in the mighty Microsoft Corporation, they saw their work rebuffed by a hard-nosed judge.
Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin refused to approve a consent decree between the Government and Microsoft, calling the deal "too little, too late." 
 At issue is Microsoft's power over the market for personal computer software. The company's flagship programs -- the MS-DOS operating system and Windows -- are used on more than 50 million personal computers. Critics say that Microsoft has employed a host of unfair tactics to block rival operating systems.
The Justice Department, after a year-long investigation, targeted a narrow set of Microsoft's licensing practices for prosecution. Microsoft's investors were relieved that the plan was so mild.
But Judge Sporkin wouldn't go along. "The U.S. Government," he said, "is either incapable or unwilling to deal effectively with a potential threat to this nation's economic well-being."
An appeals court will have to settle the issue. In an odd twist, the Justice Department and Microsoft are now on the same side; both oppose the pugnacious judge.
 EDMUND L. ANDREWS

HEADLINE: Why Can't We Behave

BYLINE: By Anthony Gottlieb; Anthony Gottlieb is an editor at The Economist. He is writing a history of Western philosophy.

 BODY:

THE DE-MORALIZATION OF SOCIETY
From Victorian Virtues to Modern Values.
By Gertrude Himmelfarb.
314 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24. 
THERE are 12-year-olds who were not even born when Margaret Thatcher first called for a return to Victorian values; yet the echoes of that electioneering remark seem to be growing louder. Her cocktail of Victorian virtues consisted of hard work, self-reliance, thrift, cleanliness, self-respect, neighborliness and patriotism. The recipe has changed in a few details since then, and in the United States one version is being served up as "family values." For Gertrude Himmelfarb, an emeritus professor of history at the Graduate School of the City University of New York, the cocktail is still tempting. She argues in "The De-Moralization of Society" that the material, political and social gains made since Victorian times have been blighted by "no less considerable losses in moral well-being." Miss Himmelfarb says she does not want to turn back the clock, but she finds much to admire in Victorian morality, and much to mourn in the loss of it.
Her excellent history of 19th-century ideas ought to raise the level of debate about family values. Yet the polemical heart of her book is just as likely to do the opposite. For although Miss Himmelfarb certainly sheds light on the Victorians, it is not clear that the same can be said for her account of us.
Her argument about the "de-moralization" of today's Britain and United States goes like this: Our problem is not that we have the wrong morality, but that we do not, in effect, have any morality at all. Our age is a "thoroughly relativistic" one, in which we are "constantly beseeched to be 'nonjudgmental.' " The result is a "reluctance to speak the language of morality." Miss Himmelfarb provides dramatic charts on illegitimate births and on crime, both of which show a steep upswing since about the 1960's. This, it would seem, is what you get if you forget "the importance of an ethos that does not denigrate or so thoroughly relativize values as to make them ineffectual and meaningless."
Until you stop to think about it, this kind of thing can sound plausible. But look at the matter another way. What exactly are we alleged to be less judgmental about? Abortion (to take a characteristically modern issue)? Plenty of people think it is plain wrong to have an abortion, and plenty of other people think it is plain wrong to interfere with a woman's right to choose. Neither side could exactly be described as "nonjudgmental" about the values of the other.
Perhaps our overtolerance is more easily found in small issues -- the treatment of animals, factories that pollute, smoking. Hmm. "Nonjudgmental" still doesn't quite catch the spirit of the age here. Maybe these topics aren't serious enough to get to the bottom of our de-moralization. What about the sorts of offenses aggregated in Miss Himmelfarb's crime charts? Is it murder, theft or rape that we are no longer prepared to condemn? Well, no. Moral judgment about these things still seems to be quite popular, actually.
In fact, moral judgment still seems to be quite popular, period, even about consensual sex. One of the few pieces of direct evidence about contemporary attitudes that are cited by Miss Himmelfarb is a National Opinion Research Center survey that says 90 percent of people "believe it to be always or almost always wrong" for a married person to have sex with someone other than his or her spouse.
Ah -- but they still commit adultery, don't they? And look at those charts; look at what people practice, not what they preach. But that would wreck Miss Himmelfarb's argument. For when she defends the Victorians against the charge that their age was ruled by "cruelty, misery, drudgery, squalor and ignorance," she rightly urges us not to confuse moral values with social realities. It is not enough, she says, for critics of Victorian values to argue that many Victorians often violated those values, for "values remain values . . . even if they are not always carried out in practice." If that goes for the Victorians, it goes for us, too. The fact that we (or some of us) commit murder or adultery does not show that our society is nonjudgmental about such things.
So where are all the morality-shy relativists whom Miss Himmelfarb bemoans? It seems they mostly work for government. "You can't impose your standards on someone else," she quotes former Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders as saying. "I don't like to put this in moral terms, but I do believe that having children out of wedlock is just wrong," said the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, who evidently does suffer from an un-Victorian "reluctance to speak the language of morality" (but doesn't seem to mind self-contradiction). Now we are getting somewhere. It all boils down to sex, marriage and children. That is what Dr. Elders was talking about, that is all Miss Himmelfarb offers hard evidence about and that is one of the few areas in which her claim of relativism seems to be right.
We are indeed more tolerant than the Victorians about premarital sex, religion and a couple of other things. Miss Himmelfarb tactfully refrains from inciting us to a Victorian-style condemnation of non-Christian religions or of homosexuality. Instead, she focuses her disapproval on illegitimacy, which now accounts for more than 30 percent of births in Britain and the United States. But it is worth asking what exactly the parents of these illegitimate children are rejecting. Not two-parent family life, on the whole. In Britain, according to the Office of Population Censuses and Surveys, three-quarters of illegitimate births are registered by both parents, a rising proportion of whom already live together at the time of registration. Miss Himmelfarb tries to run illegitimacy and single-parent families together as if they were the same thing, but they are not. Single-parent families are overwhelmingly the product of marital breakdown, not of illegitimacy: in both Britain and America, census data show, the proportion of single-parent families headed by a mother who has never been married is less than one-third.
Miss Himmelfarb admits that unmarried cohabitation "complicates" the issue of illegitimacy, but insists that it is "no substitute for marriage, since such arrangements are far less stable than marriages, only 16 percent lasting more than five years." She continues: "This compares with a 10-year average for marriages that end in divorce -- and, of course, most marriages do not end in divorce." Well, there are lies, damned lies and statistics, but that deserves some sort of prize. Miss Himmelfarb takes her "16 percent" from a newspaper article, which quoted a study, which got it from a British survey. And what the survey actually says is that by 1989 only 16 percent of the unmarried couples in its sample had already been cohabiting for more than five years, which merely reflects the fact that cohabitation was then very new to Britain. Ten years earlier, a mere 3 percent of single women under 50 were cohabiting with a man; by the time the survey was finished, more than a quarter were. Times were thus changing, but not fast enough to show how long such unions would last. Especially not if they involved children.
The truth of the matter? In 1992, Susan McRae of the Policy Studies Institute in London looked at a broad sample of women who had had illegitimate births five years earlier while cohabiting: 77 percent were still cohabiting. And many of the couples had been living together for several years before the birth of the children. So such unions do not seem to be "far less stable" than marriage at all. Besides, after five years of parenthood nearly half of these mothers were married -- though their children, of course, were counted among the illegitimate births that so distress Miss Himmelfarb.
The past, Miss Himmelfarb notes at one point, is a foreign country. What seems to get forgotten in her romp through statistics is that the present is a foreign country, too. It calls for analysis that is no less careful than a study of the distant past needs to be. And that goes for crime as well as for family life.
The police records that Miss Himmelfarb uses to prove an unparalleled rise in crime in recent decades are notoriously hard to interpret. They are affected by all kinds of factors: burglary statistics, for example, rise with the spread of household insurance, which gives victims a greater incentive to report break-ins. Comparisons of police records with the results of victim surveys show that crime in general is underreported, and presumably always has been. This muddies Miss Himmelfarb's neat charts because nobody knows how fast the gap between crime and recorded crime has been closing. If, say, a Victorian servant raped by her employer was less likely to go to the police than a college student is to go to a support unit after being the victim of a date rape, then actual rapes may not have increased in the way the records suggest.
There is just one crime that criminologists can confidently track over long periods. That is murder, and it does not fit Miss Himmelfarb's story of unparalleled contemporary wickedness. Murder rates peaked in the United States in 1980, but at a level not significantly higher than the peak that came and went with Prohibition. Was Al Capone de-moralized by a nonjudgmental ethos? Or did the opportunities and pressures created by that eminently Victorian project of Prohibition have something to do with it?
Come to think of it: if the citizens of Britain and the United States are so tolerant and nonjudgmental, why is it politically impossible to advocate an end to the unsuccessful prohibition of drugs?

HEADLINE: Formal Wear for Expectant Mothers

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
AN invitation to a black-tie dinner or a formal wedding sends most women into a what-to-wear? panic, but when you are five months' pregnant, finding a dress to suit a grand occasion presents a real challenge.
"I needed something smart and fashionable," said Sharon Robinson, who is expecting her first baby in June. "I wanted to do my husband proud at a black-tie dinner held at the Waldorf for Manhattan College, which was his school. But I didn't want to spend a fortune on a one-time-occasion dress, and the few evening things I saw in maternity shops were out of the question. Either they were ugly or they were too expensive." 
 Ms. Robinson, a civil engineer in White Plains, said she solved her problem when she learned about Loretta Chiavetta, who owns Formal Expectations in Pleasantville, a shop that rents dressy and evening maternity clothes.
"I made an appointment to visit the shop after work, and I was thrilled to find the perfect outfit," Ms. Robinson said. "It was a two-piece, floor-length black velvet, with a top that dipped in the back, which was fastened with rhinestone clips. It was perfection. I had a great time at the dinner, probably because I felt I looked good."
And looking good during pregnancy is half the battle, said Ms. Chiavetta, adding that she got the inspiration for her rental business when she could not find anything to wear to the 1989 Emmy awards.
"I was in the corporate fast lane then, working as an international TV sales executive at Sanbow Productions in Manhattan," she said. "My territory was the Far East, mainly Singapore and Hong Kong. I sold existing U.S. animated children's programs to customers there."
In the course of her job, she said, she was required to attend dinners and evening affairs on a regular basis. "When I became pregnant with my first child," she said, "I needed maternity evening clothes, so I went to Saks Fifth Avenue. "They had a big maternity department then, but I was shocked at the prices. Anything really nice started at $500."
As luck would have it, she was out of town for the Emmy awards so that presented no problem. "But the whole occurrence started me thinking about rentals," she said. "Men have been renting tuxedos forever. And shops renting evening dresses for women were around, but I couldn't find one that rented good-looking maternity clothes. I thought it might be an idea for a business but the business was not for me. I was committed to my job."
But when her son Daniel, who is now 7, was 1 year old, "something tragic happened that impelled me to examine my own life and my priorities," Ms. Chiavetta said. "A close friend of mine, who was coming home from a routine business trip in London, died in the Pan Am 103 disaster." She said she then realized she was going in the wrong direction.
"I was missing my life," she said. "My son was already a year old, and I wasn't there when all the important things were happening. I knew I wanted to stay home. I wanted to get off the career track."
Nine months later, in November 1989, she said she incorporated Formal Expectations, a maternity rental service, and she was running the business out of her apartment in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.
 "My husband, David, who is a manager for Kodak, was very supportive," she said. "He agreed that we would invest $10,000 of our savings to start my business. Most of it went to buy clothes, which I got directly from the manufacturers. I sent out press releases announcing the service as the first of its kind in the tristate area, which it was."
But her first and best customers were friends or friends of friends, all successful career women. "They would come after work because I saw them by appointment," she said.
 "They were women with good jobs who not only had to look good but who had no time to shop."
After she made an appearance on WNBC-TV News and placed an ad in a parents' magazine, her business began to snowball.
 "I felt I understood the needs of the market," she said. "But I made my share of mistakes, like buying dresses with fancy skirts that could not be hemmed, or buying styles that could not easily be altered."
A year after the Chiavettas bought a house in Pleasantville, Ms. Chiavetta felt confident enough about the success of her business to open a store. "There is so much more business in the suburbs," she said. "I was amazed. Women here have cars. They have mobility, and they can drop in whenever they please."
The store, she said, stocks more than 300 pieces ranging from mix-and-match separates to elaborate sequined floor-length evening dresses.
Claudia Graham, a nurse who lives in Peekskill, is having her first child at the end of March. Ms. Graham recently visited Formal Expectations and selected a black-velvet pants suit to wear to a business dinner.
"It was a gorgeous outfit," she said. "I was complimented on it all evening. And the price was great. I never could have bought nor would I have bought it for a one-time occasion."
Ms. Chiavetta said: "Women come to me for something extraordinary. I have customers who rent clothes two or three times during a pregnancy. They go to a lot of events, and they want to look different at every one. Some rent outfits for a whole week, like executives who may have to go to company meetings in Florida on short notice. So I stock good-looking summer clothes all year around."
Rental prices at Formal Expectations range from $29 for a dressy shirt or pants to $99 for an evening dress that will wholesale for $600. A security deposit is required with every rental. Ivory and black are the most popular colors, Ms. Chiavetta said, and the shelf life of the clothes is about 10 wearings.
"We take hems up," she added. "We put hems down. I have a wonderful seamstress who does the alterations, but there's a lot of wear and tear. Clothes are dry cleaned before every rental."
Occasionally, she said, she puts on fashion shows at maternity expos, and, she added, it was at such an expo that she became acquainted with owners of similar shops, like one in Washington.
"Now we help each other," Ms. Chiavetta said. "For example, I shipped her 30 outfits for the Clinton inauguration when she ran out of clothes. Now we're exploring the possibility of economies of scale by buying together."
Ms. Chiavetta has already expanded her store by adding christening dresses for babies.
 "All of them are handmade, and beautiful," she said. "We rent them for $40 to $50, which if they were bought would cost at least $300."
She said she was also considering offering another type of rental service. "A lot of women who wear large sizes are coming into the store and looking around," she said. "But they are embarrassed to wear maternity clothes, so many of them have asked me if I would stock evening wear in large sizes for them. And that may very well be my next venture."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kelly Dowd, left, looked at dresses at Formal Expectations, owned by Loretta Chiavetta. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ENDPAPER;
The 13th Sign

BYLINE: By Cathleen Schine; Cathleen Schine is the author of "Rameau's Niece" and a regular contributor to this page.

 BODY:
Saturday. Yesterday I was an Aquarius. Today, I'm lost. A friend called to tell me that Jacqueline Mitton of the Royal Astronomical Society has announced the existence of a 13th astrological sign and the year has to be divided up differently and we've all been dislodged. Who am I? And what is my birthstone?
 
Sunday. Maybe I'll have to go to a singles bar and pick myself up, put my hand on my arm and say to myself smoothly: "Hi! What's your sign?" Do they still have singles bars? I'm too busy to go to a singles bar: I have to watch Court TV. I have an obligation. Should I become a "Citizen for Court TV"? There's a special number to call to become a Citizen for Court TV. "An idea as old as America," says the ad. I'd better call. After all, astrology is even older than America, and look what happened to it. 

Monday. When I was an Aquarius, I was intelligent, zany, iconoclastic, humanitarian, individualistic and unconventional and sought truth and knowledge. Like Lana Turner. Now that I'm a Capricorn I have to be dour, dutiful, driven, tenacious, plodding, persevering, organized, austere, scrupulous, cautious, economical, practical and uninspired. Like Richard Nixon. And Danny Thomas.

Tuesday. My favorite judge, Elliot Wilk of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, has been on Court TV for months presiding over a dramatic and disturbing wrongful-death case. Sometimes I turn to Channel 51, hoping against hope to see his impassive face. But the trial is over. I miss Justice Wilk. I wonder what sign he is. If he's been demoted to Capricorn like me, I would feel a little better. It's exhausting being driven and organized and dutiful. Justice Wilk would be a good role model in this confusing new order. He is my hero, for Justice Wilk is the ideal mother, and I want to be an ideal mother. In his last case, Tom Moore, described by the press as "flamboyant, fiery and determined," was the attorney for the plaintiff. Luke Pittoni, described by the press as "flamboyant, fiery and determined," was one of the defense attorneys. They both bear an eerie resemblance to my children. "Ju-udge, he's talking when I'm talking. . . . Ju-udge, he's doing it again, and you told him not to. . . . Why am I being sanctioned? I didn't do anything." "See you all Thursday," Justice Wilk says calmly in reply. He must have taken one of those Parent Effectiveness Training courses. And he doesn't even wear a robe.

Wednesday. I can't get used to being a Capricorn. I keep having these secret zany and intelligent feelings. They creep up on me. I'm really trying to be a Capricorn, but sometimes I have an almost unbearable iconoclastic urge. I'm sure Justice Wilk is in the same position. I feel a bond. I wonder if Justice Wilk ever leads PET workshops. I want to sign up. I want to sit high above my children, intelligent and iconoclastic once again, listen, nod my head the slightest bit and say evenly, "See you all Thursday." I want my children to call me Judge. But I want a robe, too.

Thursday A.M.: Where do you buy judges' robes? It's not so easy following in Justice Wilk's footsteps. "You may answer," I say to one son. "Do you want me to have to call a recess?" I ask the other, firmly but without anger. Then I remember that I'm now dour, tenacious and plodding, and I sulk in a dour, tenacious and plodding way for a while. But then I start yelling and chasing everyone around the house with a rolled-up newspaper. I'm confused. My new personality is no help at all. What am I going to do?

P.M.: I watched the British comedy "Absolutely Fabulous" on Comedy Central, and I think it's possible that Edina, the outrageously irresponsible mom, might be a little easier than Justice Wilk to emulate, whatever my sign is. Drugs, drink and designer clothes! "Sweetie, darling," I drawl to the children, admirably imitating Eddie's accent, my aching head on the kitchen table. "Get Mummy some coffee."

Friday A.M.: Got the mail. Invited to a reading by William Kunstler. He's written a book of poetry. I bet Justice Wilk is a better poet. I miss Justice Wilk. That O. J. (Battered Man) Simpson is on Court TV again. Maybe in Los Angeles, Judge Ito passes for a maternal role model, but New Yorkers would never attend his PET seminar. Sometimes in the New York trial, the lawyers actually pushed each other. Those L.A. lawyers don't push. Or yell. Not loudly, anyway. They just stand there. Like sticks. Dapper, smarmy, slick defense sticks; droning prosecution sticks. What are they, a bunch of Capricorns? Don't they know how lawyers act? They're from Hollywood! Don't they go to the movies? Don't they know anything about trial law? Maybe they just haven't been notified of their new signs yet. I hope they've all been changed to Sagittarians -- philosophically inclined chatterboxes, boisterous and flighty know-it-alls with big thighs searching for wisdom in a friendly and outgoing manner.

P.M.: Looked through Kunstler's book of poetry. The Hallmark 7? There's even a sensitive rhyming ditty about O. J. The Lana Turner in me is offended. Where are we headed, America? Has our legal obsession really gone too far? I'm frightened. If my kids ever push their glasses up on their heads and write sonnets to the Central Park Jogger rapists, I'll have to adjourn for good and get my own coffee. See you all Thursday.

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
A Sioux Poet Whose Fiery Protests Now Come Packaged in Jewel Boxes

BYLINE: By JOHN MARCHESE 

 BODY:
THERE IS A LINE IN THE title track from the American Indian poet John Trudell's latest album, "Johnny Damas and Me," that would be ironic if it weren't simply dead-on accurate. "We've been laying real low," Mr. Trudell says over the rock riffs of electric guitarists, nearly chanting the lines in a voice once described by the writer Peter Matthiessen as "merry and harsh at the same time." "Laying real low in the shadow of the road to success."
It can be in America's nature to embrace its harshest critics occasionally, even turn a few into stars. John Trudell, 49, a Santee Sioux who headed the American Indian Movement during much of its confrontational and sometimes violent first decade in the 1970's, would be happy to emerge from the shadows. Although he describes his work as "leafleting," and his rhymed rants attack "the industrial ruling class" that presides over the "Nazi Babylon," Mr. Trudell's protests are now packaged in jewel boxes, and he wants to sell a million of them. 
 "If I'm lucky enough to do this," he says, "then I've created an economic base by using my mind, and in some ways my body through performing. They took all our land; I don't have any land to toil. My crops have to grow somewhere else."
Almost a year ago, the large independent record company Rykodisc began distributing "Johnny Damas and Me," Mr. Trudell's second release with the label. It has sold about 100,000 copies so far, twice the number of his 1992 debut record, "A K A Graffiti Man." Mr. Trudell is scheduled to perform at the Bottom Line on Wednesday and at Wetlands on March 2.
Some of his songs take love as their subject, but most are in some way political. "Money and authority/ have their own way of talking/ when it comes to the man/ versus what the woman said," he says in "Shadow over Sisterland," a song from the latest album. In "All There Is to It," an indictment of big business, Mr. Trudell defiantly looks authority in the face and repeats: "We don't believe what you say/ We don't believe what you say/ We don't believe what you say." His unusual combination of words and music, poetry and politics, is perhaps best described by the title of the first track from the album, "Rant and Roll."
"What he does works," says Don Rose, Ryko's president, who signed Mr. Trudell in 1991 after a pitch from the singer Jackson Browne, the executive producer on both albums.
The John Trudell sound is difficult to define, and for that reason it is difficult to market. Because he does not sing, Mr. Trudell seems to be a spoken-word performer. But Rykodisc has refused to label it that way. A number of critics have compared Mr. Trudell to another spoken-word performer, Lou Reed, but while the similarity is obvious, it is superficial. In his two Rykodisc recordings, the music ranges from pop-influenced love songs to heavy metal. Throughout, there are heavy doses of blues guitar and frequent use of American Indian singing. Sometimes, snatches of Mr. Trudell's words are sung by musicians in his backup band. But Mr. Trudell's big speaking voice -- often angry, often sad, only sometimes merry -- is always dominant.
"Words are accompaniment in many forms of rock-and-roll," Mr. Browne says. "That's not true with John. It's compelling as music. But what's there is in the dialogue. It can't be used as background music for conversation. It is the conversation."
Mr. Rose of Rykodisc says: "I felt that John's experience could be translated from a marketing standpoint."
John Trudell was born in 1946 on the Sioux reservation in northwestern Nebraska. His mother died when he was 6, and his boyhood was divided between Omaha (where his father worked) and his grandparents' house on the reservation. After a stint in the Navy, he moved to southern California and took classes in communications at a community college.
In the summer of 1969, Mr. Trudell heard that a coalition of organizations called Indians of All Tribes had occupied Alcatraz Island. He took his wife at the time and their two daughters and headed north.
"It just felt right to me," he says. He quickly became a leader of the occupation, emerging as spokesman for the cause. The occupation ultimately failed, but it galvanized political consciousness among American Indians. The American Indian movement sprang from its wake, and Mr. Trudell gravitated to those young, militant Indians like himself.
His first marriage ended about the time the occupation did, and in 1971 he moved to Oklahoma to work with an Indian agency. There he met a Paiute woman named Tina Manning. They married and had three children. The couple moved a lot, keeping up with the requirements of AIM advocacy. But the Trudells' home base was always Tina's Nevada reservation.
During a protest outside the F.B.I. headquarters in February 1979, Mr. Trudell burned an American flag in a soft snow. The next day, a fire broke out at his home in Nevada, killing Tina, who was pregnant, and their three small children. The Bureau of Indian Affairs concluded that it was accidental, but Mr. Trudell remains convinced that it was not.
"I have experienced within my own lifetime the attack of my winter camp and the killing of the women and children," Mr. Trudell says. "It left me even angrier than I was -- and I was never too calm to begin with. Between the years 1979 and 1984, I drove 250,000 miles. I just ran it out." During this time he began to write what he calls "my hanging-on lines."
Mr. Trudell drifted away from AIM and started working with nuclear energy opponents and environmentalists. At a 1979 rally to protest uranium mining near Mount Taylor, N.M., Mr. Trudell appeared on stage with Mr. Browne, who was performing.
"He was by far the most compelling speaker," Mr. Browne remembers, "very impassioned, with unflinching honesty and a certain good will -- even when he was talking about 500 years of abuses." The two became friends.
"Jackson appearing in my life just opened this door for me and gave me this place to be," Mr. Trudell says. "I knew I had to stop running. I had to be in a place. Los Angeles became that place. Jackson made sure I could survive in L.A."
Something about John Trudell attracts patrons. Mr. Matthiessen, who chronicled the American Indian movement in his book "In the Spirit of Crazy Horse," says Mr. Trudell had the personality to become "a kind of angry jester for the rich revolutionaries of the entertainment world."
Several times during the next 10 years, Mr. Trudell moved into Mr. Browne's home. Over the years, Kris Kristofferson and Bonnie Raitt have given him either moral or financial support. His friend Steven Seagal cast Mr. Trudell in a small role in his 1992 movie "Under Siege."
Mr. Browne says Hollywood people are attracted to Mr. Trudell's poignant personal story and his honesty. "People just took John to their hearts." Which is a good thing, Mr. Browne adds, because Mr. Trudell "is not too interested in solvency."
"He accepts the largess of friends," he says.
BY 1985, MR. TRUDELL, now a poet, met Jesse Ed Davis, a Kiowa Indian known from his work with Bob Dylan and Mr. Browne, as well as three records of his own. Mr. Trudell remembers Mr. Davis telling him, "I can make the music for your words." A collaboration began that lasted until Mr. Davis's death in 1988 and laid the foundation for Mr. Trudell's current work, both by helping to mix poetry with rock and by introducing Mr. Trudell to other influential people. One was Mr. Dylan, who was given a tape that Mr. Trudell had produced and was soon after quoted in Rolling Stone magazine saying that Mr. Trudell had made "the album of the year."
Mr. Trudell recently remembered meeting Mr. Dylan. "He told me," he says, "that what I was doing with music was revolutionary. And he said to stay with it -- don't change a thing, stay after it. That was encouraging because there were definitely some stretches that were like looking down a long tunnel." He has not quite come out the other side. "I'm basically a starving artist," Mr. Trudell says. "But that's got to change."

HEADLINE: MEXICO IS FACING NEW RESTRICTIONS TO GET U.S. HELP

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
After three days of intense negotiations with top Mexican officials, the United States is preparing to announce details of a plan to bail the country out of a continuing currency crisis, including newly toughened restrictions that are likely to send already high Mexican interest rates soaring.
Details of the plan were still being negotiated here tonight between Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin and Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, who has been in Washington since Thursday. A spokesman for Mr. Rubin said that negotiators were making progress, but it was unclear whether any agreement would be concluded on Monday. 
 The new conditions, described by Americans and Mexicans familiar with the talks, pose enormous political problems for President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon.
To get the $20 billion in direct American help that the Clinton Administration announced last month, Mr. Zedillo's Government is agreeing to shrink Mexico's money supply, even if that means interest rates of 50 percent or more on business loans and home mortgages.
Also included in the draft of an agreement here is a toughening of a highly controversial condition that Washington is placing on the Mexicans: The United States would effectively control the flow of the billions of dollars that Mexico earns every year from the export of its oil, starting in the next few months.
Under an earlier plan, the United States would have control of Mexico's oil revenue, its biggest single source of foreign currency, if Mexico defaulted on some of its American-backed obligations.
The newer, even more stringent conditions seem bound to open Mr. Zedillo to charges at home that he has permitted the United States to dictate his country's economic policy, an enormously sensitive matter in Mexican politics.
But Clinton Administration officials, fearful that they will be blamed by both Republicans and Democrats if Mexico requires another bailout later this year, have insisted in recent days that there is no other choice.
Anything short of Draconian fiscal discipline, they insist, will mean that foreign investors continue to pull money out of the country -- and the problem the Administration raced to solve last month could return as a bigger crisis.
If a recession in Mexico follows -- which many Mexican and American economists consider a real risk -- the result could be more social unrest in the country, where a 14-month-long rebellion in a southern state, Chiapas, is already plaguing Mr. Zedillo's weakened three-month-old administration. Last week, his party overwhelmingly lost an election in a big western state, Jalisco, and several more such elections are scheduled later in the year.
At the heart of the negotiations between United States and Mexican officials this weekend was the Clinton Administration's fear that Mr. Zedillo, under growing political pressure, would be tempted to print more money or to lower interest rates before the coming state elections.
The result, in a nation where inflation was running in January at an annual rate of more than 45 percent, could be even steeper inflation. The current level is already a shock to Mexicans, because last year inflation dropped to less than 10 percent for the first time in recent memory.
However, maintaining interest rates at a high level -- they are already more than 40 percent to keep up with the rising inflation -- seems bound to touch off a recession, and with it the possibility of kindling for social unrest.
"This is scary," said Jonathan E. Heath, an economist in Mexico City. "A recession is already unavoidable. The concern for the United States Government is probably that if you start pursuing a very restrictive monetary policy, and things start to get bad, the Mexican Government will want to let up."
That is what Washington says Mexican officials did last year, as the Presidential election neared.
When the Clinton Administration announced its plan last month, Mexican officials knew that it would carry tough conditions that would be difficult to sell at home.
But they were not counting on such a large run-up in inflation in January, making it all the more painful to meet the plan's conditions. Similar conditions apply to about $30 billion in other help promised to Mexico in the last month, including $17.8 billion from the International Monetary Fund.
"Investors are still nervous about Mexico," a White House official said last week, after the value of the peso had again dropped. "And if the markets are nervous, we have to be nervous."
A Mexican finance official familiar with the discussions said tonight that even before Mr. Ortiz left for Washington last week, there was an understanding that with inflation and interest rates above what had been forecast, the Government would have little choice but to tighten the money supply.
"We recognize there's not going to be an easy way out," said the official, who insisted on anonymity. "What they're talking about in Washington now is just a difference of degree."
The official said the Mexican Government recognized the social risks involved in such moves and was preparing several responses, including an emergency jobs plan, using funds from an antipoverty program. The Government will also zero in on areas of high unemployment and political instability with more than 500,000 job-training grants.
The first victims of the tight monetary plan are expected to be Mexico's weaker banks. At least 8 of the 18 major banks are already considered on the brink because many of their clients cannot repay loans carrying variable interest rates that have soared in recent weeks. There are virtually no fixed-rate loans available in Mexico, so everyone from large companies to ordinary homeowners have been hit hard by the fallout from the currency crisis.
Several of those banks seem likely to be merged in the next few weeks, for fear that investors, particularly United States investors, would otherwise remove funds invested in certificates of deposit in the last year or so. The banks are holding about $8 billion in such assets now, and if these are not reinvested, the money is expected to fly to safer havens.
Under previous pressure from the United States, Mexico had agreed to open its banking system to acquisitions by foreign banks.
All this is expected to put great pressure on Mr. Zedillo, an economist by training. In the last few days, he has been on the phone to Mr. Ortiz and to top United States officials, who have tried to lay out the economic and political tradeoffs.
They have told him that while the tight monetary policy would be painful for the next year or so, it was the best hope of stabilizing the economy. At the same time, they are trying to give him some political cover, so that it does not appear he has fully capitulated to American conditions.
One of the provisions carrying the most potential volatility is proposed American control of the revenue from Mexico's oil, a cherished national asset and the source of $7 billion to the Government each year.
When Mr. Rubin described the bailout plan in Congressional testimony several weeks ago -- after President Clinton abandoned any hope of getting Congress to pass the program and acted on his own to provide Treasury funds for loans and loan guarantees -- he said that "in the unlikely event" that Mexico defaulted on its United States-backed loans, foreign purchasers of Mexican oil would be required to remit their payments to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. That money, in turn, would be used to pay American investors.
But members of Congress including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, charged that the plan provided insufficient protection. And Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, told Mr. Rubin it was ludicrous to think that Washington would cut off Mexico's oil earnings, for fear that such a move would cause wide protests.
To mute such Congressional criticism, the new accord would require foreign buyers of Mexican oil to send their payments through the New York Federal Reserve Bank, starting in the next few months, regardless of how well Mexico was paying off its obligations.
It is unclear, however, whether that move alone would satisfy Mr. D'Amato, who, with other members of Congress, introduced a bill last week requiring the Treasury to issue much fuller reports about the details and progress of its bailout effort.

HEADLINE: Mexican Crisis Depressing Brazil and Argentina Stocks

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Two months after the start of Mexico's financial crisis, the shock waves are rippling south, depressing stock markets in Latin America's two other major economies -- Brazil and Argentina.
Despite rallies Friday, the markets in Sao Paulo and Buenos Aires fell almost every trading day in February. Since Dec. 20, the day the Mexican crisis broke, Sao Paulo's Bovespa index has dropped 34 percent and Buenos Aires's Merval index has dropped 37 percent. 
 "There is a lot of potential supply, but virtually no demand," said Alden Brewster, New York partner for Banco Icatu, a Brazilian investment bank. "Speculators and bottom fishers don't want to go into what is perceived as a crisis situation."
While traders joke nervously about "submerging" markets, the steady outflow of capital from South America's largest stock markets is provoked by a variety of factors: rising interest rates in the United States, disappointment over a cautious privatization program in Brazil, and anxiety over a possible devaluation of the peso in Argentina.
Oddly, the sharp downturn in the Bovespa index in Sao Paulo coincides with a surge in long-term factory investment by foreign companies in Brazil. While hundreds of millions of dollars are flowing out of foreign-held stock portfolios in Brazil, foreign companies are pursuing 1995 investment plans in Brazil that total $5 billion, double the $2.5 billion invested last year.
Brazil investments by Ford Motor, Volkswagen and General Motors will total $2 billion through the end of 1996. With Brazil expected to repeat last year's growth of 5 percent, this year's overall investment rate is expected to hit 21 percent, a level not seen here since the "miracle" growth years of the 1970's.
While Brazil's production of color televisions, videocassette recorders and refrigerators is running at double the levels of two years ago, Sao Paulo's stock market, now Latin America's largest, is at its lowest level in 10 months.
Many foreign investors were heavy buyers of stocks in Brazil's state oil, electricity and telephone companies, gambling that President Fernando Henrique Cardoso would privatize these companies. But as a presidential candidate last fall, Mr. Cardoso said only that he would open these state monopolies to joint ventures with private partners. Last Thursday, he submitted to Brazil's Congress constitutional amendments to allow joint ventures.
"In the case of telephones, I cannot open to exploitation by private capital only the filet mignon, leaving the state with only the bones," Mr. Cardoso said when asked about disappointed stock market investors.
Today, stocks in the three state utility companies -- Petrobras, Eletrobras, and Telebras -- are worth roughly half of what they were in late September, a few days before Mr. Cardoso's election. Previously, foreign investment in Brazil's stock markets had soared.
"There is disappointment in the market over Brazil's definition of privatization," said Laurie W. Higgitt, director of Stephen Rose & Partners, a London brokerage firm specializing in Brazil and Argentina.
After Mexico's debacle with the overvalued peso, there also is concern that Brazil's new currency, the real, is overvalued by at least 25 percent. Used as a price anchor, the strong real contributes to Brazil's new low inflation rate -- about 1 percent a month.
Coinciding with an opening to imports, the strong currency has pushed Brazil from enjoying a fat trade surplus into watching a trade deficit run for three consecutive months. In November and December, the United States maintained trade surpluses with only two of its major trading partners -- Hong Kong and Brazil.
"The crisis in Mexico has not created any diversion for us; we are focusing on Brazil as one of the top three emerging export markets in coming years," Jeffrey E. Garten, United States Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said in an interview today in Rio, a stop in a 10-day tour of Argentina and Brazil.
Charles Dusseau, Florida's Secretary of Commerce, said after visiting Sao Paulo last week, "With everything that has happened to the Mexican peso, Brazil will be Florida's largest trading partner in 1995."
But Brazilians are afraid that their 1994 trade surplus of $10 billion will erode to a few billion dollars this year. Liquid reserves are already dipping, hitting $37 billion today, from a high of $41 billion last September.
"We can't keep losing reserves and we can't keep showing foreign trade deficits," said Carlos Langoni, a former Central Bank president.
Fears about an overvalued currency are undermining South America's second-largest stock market -- Buenos Aires.
Although Argentina's peso can be devalued only through an act of Congress, nervous Argentines have withdrawn an estimated $2 billion from banks since the Mexican crisis. That is severely straining the banking system and forcing Argentina into an economic slowdown. In recent weeks, 1995 growth forecasts have been reduced to zero to 2 percent from the 5 or 6 percent level.
"Banks are delaying payments, there is no liquidity," said a Brazilian banker who asked not to be identified. "You have a country that is very much dependent on foreign money, and that spigot is off."

HEADLINE: Egypt Criticizes Israel on Nuclear Arms and Palestinian Talks

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Egypt's Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, said today that after 15 years of relative serenity in relations with Israel, "serious difficulties" had emerged. At issue, he said, are Israel's nuclear weapons program and the "fragile and vulnerable" state of talks between Israel, the Palestinians, Syria and Lebanon.
In a wide-ranging conversation here, he said Arab countries would insist that Israel accept some restraints on its nuclear arms, because of concerns that "Israeli extremists" could come to power and be tempted to use them. 
 Mr. Moussa spoke at his hotel here after attending meetings on Saturday with the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, and the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat. The meetings failed to budge the frozen peace negotiations.
Mr. Peres sounded conciliatory in his response today, saying in a statement, "It is only natural that differences of opinions exist even among friends."
In impromptu remarks to reporters, he said talks on Saturday between Mr. Moussa and Mr. Arafat had softened disagreements over the slow pace of Mideast negotiations. But in an interview broadcast on Israeli television today, Mr. Peres complained about Iran's pursuit of nuclear research, saying, "Why isn't anyone saying anything to Iran?"
An unconfirmed report today in Maariv, an Israeli daily, said that as a conciliatory gesture, Israel was prepared to allow Egyptian scientists to visit their Israeli counterparts to discuss nuclear issues.
Yigal Palmor, a spokesman for the Israeli Foreign Ministry, would not comment beyond saying, "There are talks going on between us and the Egyptians on a possible compromise."
But Mr. Peres insisted that Israel had not wavered in its refusal to sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. Israel's stated position is that it will not sign until it is satisfied that other Middle Eastern countries, notably Iran, Iraq and Libya, do not pose a nuclear threat.
Mr. Peres, Mr. Moussa and Mr. Arafat were in Paris at a conference on the future of the Mediterranean after peace comes about.
Mr. Moussa's remarks came at the end of a tense week during which Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel accused him of leading a hostile campaign to embarrass Israel over the nuclear nonproliferation issue. The treaty to limit the number of countries with nuclear weapons is up for indefinite extension in April.
Israel has also charged President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt with impeding Israel's normalization of relations with other Arab countries and lining them up behind Egypt's stand on the nuclear treaty.
The United States, which supports Israel's position that its acquisition of nuclear weapons is a separate issue from the extension of the nonproliferation treaty, has hinted that it may penalize Egypt by reducing its $2 billion annual aid.
But Mr. Moussa said pressure would not dissuade Cairo, insisting that Israel must give concrete assurances that it would address Arab concerns.
The Israeli complaint against Egypt last week came during what many experts in Middle East affairs considered to be the low point in relations since the two countries signed a peace treaty in 1979.
But the dispute over nuclear disarmament has taken center stage, as a number of Arab countries have said they stand behind Cairo, threatening to deal a blow to Washington's hopes that a majority of countries will renew their commitments to the nonproliferation treaty.
Israel is reckoned by Western intelligence services to have some 200 nuclear warheads. Although it has never acknowledged that officially, Israel has argued that it faces potential nuclear threats from Iran, Iraq and Libya.
But Mr. Moussa said that if Israel did not join a nuclear disarmament program, "the region is certain to slip into an arms race, which to our way of thinking would be a catastrophic development."
The adamant Egyptian position has puzzled Middle East experts, since the issue of Israel's nuclear weapons has not been raised in years and the consequences of American anger could bear heavy penalties for Egypt's hard-pressed economy.
But in recent weeks, several senior Egyptian policy makers said they hoped to reassert Egypt's regional influence, which they charged was being eroded deliberately by Israeli and American diplomacy.
They also noted a growing conviction in Cairo that American financial aid was bound for a substantial reduction anyway as part of an attempt by Washington to downgrade its strategic ties to Egypt.
Asked about Israeli concerns about Iran, Iraq and Libya, Mr. Moussa called the argument untenable in the face of close scrutiny.
"No one seriously believes that Libya threatens Israel," he said. "That's a bad joke. As for Iraq, it is under one of the strictest surveillance and monitoring regimes by the United Nations. And Iran is already a member of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty. Its facilities are open to inspection.
"It is not an exaggeration for us to be concerned about Israel's refusal to cooperate in any form on restraining its nuclear arms production program. Israel also has its extremists, whose political affiliations and names are well known to all. If the democratic process in Israel brings these extremists to power, we cannot rest assured they may not resort to using weapons of mass destruction."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

TRIBE'S LAND IS RICH BUT UNEASY
Eight years ago, Joey Carter was chopping wood for a living, earning $5 an hour and living in a two-bedroom apartment he shared with seven other people. He recalled his grandfather, Clifford Sebastian, a half-blood Mashantucket Pequot Indian who lived on a pig farm with no electricity or running water. The grandfather would spit on the ground in bitterness every time he talked about the fate of the once proud Pequots. But new Pequot stories are about sudden and astounding success. The lives of Mr. Carter and all other Pequots have been transformed by the booming, cash-raking phenomenon of Foxwoods Casino, the tribe's huge gambling development in the Ledyard woods of southeastern Connecticut. A1.
HOSPITALS ARE SPURNING ABORTIONS
Slowly, quietly, over the last 10 years, almost all of New York City's full-service hospitals have backed out of the abortion business, driven away in part by economics and in part by fear. Even as they are rapidly expanding their repertory of treatments in an era of managed care, they are no longer doing many elective terminations or training residents in the procedure and refer patients elsewhere. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
4 IN S.I. FAMILY SHOT TO DEATH
Four members of a Staten Island family died of gunshot wounds in a bloody quarrel that the police said followed years of disputes and numerous police visits to their quiet, working-class neighborhood of Arden Heights.
A 55-year-old Staten Island man surrendered to the police a few hours after the discovery of the bodies of his wife, his stepson and a man and woman believed to be his in-laws. B3.
CHILD KILLED AND 2 HURT IN FIRE
On Saturday night, Catalina Figueroa sat with her granddaughters, 11-month-old Ashley and 6-year-old Shaina, and watched the video "Cinderella" before putting them to bed in their apartment in a Mott Haven housing project.
Hours later, Ashley Figueroa was dead and Shaina Perez and a friend of Mrs. Figueroa's were in critical condition, victims of a fire that gutted the apartment. B3.
MORE COMPLAIN OF ILLNESS FROM FUMES
Six people were taken to hospitals after complaining of nausea and dizziness that they said was caused by fumes in a Brooklyn apartment building, where two dozen residents were overcome on Thursday by poisonous carbon monoxide. But investigators armed with carbon-monoxide detectors said they could find no trace of the lethal fumes. B3.
COLLEGE-HELP PROGRAM FACES AX
Twenty-six years ago, New York created a program to help needy, motivated students attend private colleges. The Higher Education Opportunity Program, or H.E.O.P., is small, relatively inexpensive ($22 million out of a $32.4 billion state budget), and is one of the few such efforts that even critics of government largesse acknowledge is a success. But $22 million is $22 million. The program is headed for extinction in Governor Pataki's budget. B3.
KEEPING FAMILIES INTACT IS HIS GOAL
He cannot console the girl whose mother is dying of AIDS, or promise the frightened young woman that her boyfriend will not hit her again. He cannot replace the father who was murdered, or comfort a child late at night, when the gunfire starts. But on a good day, Carlos Scott can offer a family hope.
Mr. Scott is a social worker at the Children's Aid Society, one of the largest social welfare agencies in New York and one of seven organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Although his field is preventive services, he fights problems that have plagued poor families for centuries: domestic violence, drug abuse, illness and emotional distress. B2.
 
REGION
 
PATAKI FACES A TOUGH CHOICE
In his search for a state environmental commissioner, Governor Pataki has found himself torn between two clashing interests that have long considered him an ally: business leaders and environmentalists.
Mr. Pataki has said his ideal environmental commissioner would blend an understanding and respect for business with a strong sensitivity to conservation issues. His ideal candidate, he said, would have worked in both areas. B5.

HEADLINE: For Health Agency, a Fiscal Wake-Up Call

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Few agencies have ever enjoyed stronger bipartisan support than the National Institutes of Health. Indeed, Congress has lavished billions of tax dollars on the Government's biomedical research enterprise. And until now, the main question was how best to spend more money.
But that has abruptly changed. The health agency is receiving skeptical scrutiny from Republican members of the House determined to cut the Federal budget deficit. This change is most evident in the House Appropriations subcommittee that earmarks money for the institutes, $11.3 billion this year. 
 "There was an acceptance that we were doing the Lord's work," said Alan G. Kraut, executive director of the American Psychological Society, who represents research psychologists. But this year Dr. Kraut was taken aback when he was asked by Representative Jay Dickey, Republican of Arkansas, "Do you understand that this Government is insolvent?"
For his part, Mr. Dickey said that there seemed to be "a conspiracy" among scientists, patients and public health advocates seeking more money to investigate specific diseases and disorders.
He asked Dr. Kraut a novel question: "If we were going to cut 25 percent from what you had last year," how should it be done? Mr. Dickey expressed impatience when Dr. Kraut and other witnesses refused to discuss potential cuts. The Congressman said the scientists were forcing lawmakers to make the difficult decisions without the benefit of their expert advice.
The institutes' budget grew an average of 14 percent a year in the 1960's and nearly 9 percent a year in the next two decades. But these days an increase of 3 percent or 4 percent, just to keep pace with inflation, is considered a major victory.
Most of the health institutes' budget is spent on research grants awarded to scientists at universities around the country. Slightly less than 11 percent is spent on research by health institutes employees. Even before the November elections, this intramural research program was being scaled back as part of President Clinton's effort to reduce the size of Government.
The number of health institutes employees has declined by 1,200 since 1992, to 16,197, and is scheduled to fall to 14,839 by 1999, for a total reduction of nearly 15 percent in seven years. Yet scientists in and out of Government express frustration, noting that the cutbacks come at a time when new scientific techniques and discoveries offer more opportunities for productive research.
Officials say they cannot speak out for fear of seeming disloyal. But Dr. Thomas J. Kennedy Jr., president of the N.I.H. Alumni Association, said, "An exceptionally fine research endeavor, a national treasure, is being severely compromised as a result of the overall effort to reinvent Government."
Like a college campus, where buildings are named for generous alumni, the grounds of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., include many buildings named for members of Congress, Republican and Democrat, who pumped tax dollars into the agency: Representatives William H. Natcher of Kentucky, Silvio O. Conte of Massachusetts and Claude Pepper of Florida, and Senators Warren G. Magnuson of Washington, Lister Hill of Alabama and Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut.
That bipartisan custom may be laid aside for a few years. Members of Congress have told officials at the health institutes that they should not count on much construction money because new buildings can easily be deferred.
The Republicans have promised to cut taxes and to eliminate the Federal budget deficit without altering Social Security or cutting military spending. That implies substantial cuts, ranging from 10 percent to 30 percent, in programs like biomedical research, education and public works, for which Congress appropriates money each year.
Representative John Edward Porter, Republican of Illinois, is chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee responsible for the Departments of Labor and Education as well as the Department of Health and Human Services, of which the N.I.H. is a part.
Mr. Porter, an outspoken supporter of biomedical research, said the subcommittee had "always worked by consensus" and had not taken any roll call votes in 14 years.
"That's undoubtedly over," he said. There will be roll call votes this year, he explained, and "everything, including N.I.H., is at risk."
A Congressional aide said of the panel: "It has never really had a strong conservative element in its membership. Ranking Republicans like Mr. Conte made sure they didn't get any conservative bomb throwers on the subcommittee."
But this year five conservative Republicans have joined the panel: Mr. Dickey and Representatives Ernest Jim Istook Jr. of Oklahoma, Dan Miller of Florida, Frank Riggs of California and Roger Wicker of Mississippi.
Mr. Istook's aide for subcommittee business comes from the National Taxpayers Union Foundation. Mr. Miller's aide used to work at the conservative Heritage Foundation. And a top aide to Mr. Wicker is from the conservative Free Congress Foundation.
Officials at the National Institutes of Health say they are confident that they can educate the new subcommittee members about the importance of biomedical research. The message is simple: such research saves lives, is good for the economy, has given birth to the biotechnology industry and may lead to discoveries that help control health costs.
While the Republicans may not provide much more money, they may give the scientists more freedom to set their own research priorities. Now, lawmakers give detailed guidance to N.I.H. officials in reports that accompany the annual appropriations bill. In addition, several Republican lawmakers said they wanted to reduce Federal regulations that increase the costs of operating research laboratories. As an example, they cited Federal standards for the care of laboratory animals.
This year, as in the past, the subcommittee has heard testimony from dozens of patients, doctors and lobbyists pleading for money to support research on specific diseases and disorders. The witnesses came from such diverse groups as the American Lung Association, the American Diabetes Association, the Autism Society of America, the National Breast Cancer Coalition and the AIDS Action Council.
In an interview, Mr. Dickey said that many experts appearing before the subcommittee were "in a state of denial" and still did not comprehend the meaning of the Nov. 8 elections.
"Voters gave us a ticket to a different train, which may be going in a different direction," said Mr. Dickey. "N.I.H. will have to take some cuts."

HEADLINE: This Week's Debt Sales

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills tomorrow, two-year notes to be auctioned Wednesday and five-year notes on Thursday.
At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate was 5.68 percent on the outstanding three-month bill and 6.98 percent on the six-month issue. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 7.04 percent and the five-year note at 7.31 percent.

HEADLINE: Japanese Deficit to Grow Sharply

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
After years in which it lectured Washington on the need to reduce the Federal budget deficit, Japan is now facing a Government deficit of its own that is by some measures larger than that of the United States.
The deficit is making it difficult to pay for the reconstruction from the devastating earthquake in Kobe last month, a job that will cost tens of billions of dollars and which will only strain Japan's finances further. "The fiscal flexibility is so low now," lamented an official in the budget bureau of the Ministry of Finance. 
 The need to finance Japan's Government deficit and the earthquake reconstruction will also mean that Japanese financial institutions will have less money left for activity in other countries, like buying United States Treasury bonds, economists said. That could contribute to what some analysts say is a coming global shortage of capital and a rise in world interest rates.
Indeed, Japan is expected this year to become the largest net issuer of debt in the world, according to estimates of J. P. Morgan. The investment bank estimated that Japan would be a net issuer of $172 billion in Government bonds this year compared with $130 billion by the United States.
"The Japanese Government is in a worse position than the Government of the United States," said Jesper Koll at J. P. Morgan in Tokyo.
Yet many economists here say Japan's fiscal condition is not as bleak as is painted by its conservative Finance Ministry, which considers any deficit to be a sin.
Most other industrialized countries are running far greater deficits as a percent of economic output than either Japan or the United States. And Japan's budget situation will improve as the economy recovers.
More important, in contrast to the United States, where people spend a lot and save relatively little, Japan has a very high household savings rate. That provides the funds that can be used to help finance the Government deficit without putting too much upward pressure on interest rates. Japan also has huge current account and trade surpluses.
The budget deficit "is rather a secondary problem," said Yukio Noguchi, a professor of economics at Hitotsubashi University in Tokyo. "For the economy as a whole, the important thing is the savings rate."
As recently as 1992, Japan enjoyed an overall Government budget surplus, making it the envy of other industrialized nations. But its financial picture has worsened as a result of a three-year economic slump, which has reduced tax revenues and forced the Government to increase public spending in an attempt to stimulate the economy.
"Japan's public finance just started to deteriorate in the last three years," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, senior economist at Morgan Stanley in Tokyo, who characterized Japan's proposed budget for next year as "borrow now and worry later."
Until recently, the United States and other industrialized nations had pressed Japan to increase Government spending, even by going into deficit, to stimulate its economy, which would in turn help the world economy and reduce Japan's huge trade surplus by increasing the nation's imports.
At the same time, Japan had been urging the United States to reduce its budget deficit, arguing that the Federal Government was competing with American industry for scarce capital. Japanese officials and businessmen have long argued that the big Federal deficit, and not any unfair trading practices by Japan, was responsible for the trade deficit with Japan.
Now to some extent, both sides have done the other's bidding. Japan has cut taxes and increased public spending enough that Washington recently stopped calling upon Tokyo to take further stimulatory steps. Meanwhile, the United States has cut its deficit for three consecutive years, owing to spending cuts and a strong economy and increased tax revenues.
Before the earthquake, Japan was expecting a central budget deficit of 14.9 trillion yen, or about $149 billion, in the fiscal year that ends this March, and a deficit of 12.6 trillion yen, or $126 billion next year, the Finance Ministry official said. By contrast, the American deficit this year is expected to be $192.5 billion.
But since the American economy is larger than Japan's, economists tend to look at the deficit as a percent of the total economy.
Japan had a deficit of 5.7 percent of its gross domestic product in 1994, compared with 2.9 percent for the United States, according to estimates made by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development before the earthquake. Back in 1991, the situation had been reversed, with Japan having a deficit of only 0.8 percent of its economic output while Washington had a deficit of 4.2 percent.
Using a broader measure favored by economists that includes the Social Security accounts, Japan and the United States both had a deficit in 1994 equal to 2 percent of gross domestic product, according to the organization. But as recently as 1992, Japan had a surplus of 1.8 percent of its gross domestic product while the United States had a deficit equal to 4.3 percent.
Because of Japan's high savings rate, some economists do not expect the earthquake reconstruction to be that big a problem.
"There is enough money to invest in fiscal assets, including earthquake recovery," said Hirohiko Okumura, executive fellow at the Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo. He said it was wrong to look only at the balance of the Government budget and to ignore other sources of funds like Government-controlled pension funds and savings accounts.
Indeed, Japan has long drawn upon its "second budget," a vast pool of funds held in savings accounts run by the postal service and in nationally managed pension funds. But even those funds are being stretched thin, some analysts say.
The Jan. 17 earthquake, which killed more than 5,000 people and devastated the port city of Kobe, could significantly increase the deficit, both because of the reconstruction costs and because of a decline in tax revenues from companies and individuals who suffered damage in the quake. The Government has also decided to grant tax exemptions and postponements to quake victims.
To help pay for earthquake repairs, Japan's Cabinet on Friday approved the basic outline of a supplemental budget of 1.02 trillion yen, or roughly $10 billion, for the fiscal year that ends next month. At the same time, it estimated tax revenues would fall 602 billion yen, or roughly $6 billion, in the fiscal year because of the earthquake.
Even larger extra expenditures are expected in the next fiscal year. Japan's total central Government budget is about $700 billion annually.
In financing rebuilding, the quandary is that to avoid increasing the deficit further, taxes might have to be raised, after having been lowered last year to stimulate the economy. But a tax increase would be politically unpopular and would undermine the nascent economic recovery.
To avoid an immediate tax increase, the Government decided Friday to borrow the money needed for the supplemental budget. It will issue nearly $8 billion in construction bonds, tied to the building of public works, as well as about $8 billion of what are known here as deficit bonds, which cover day-to-day operations and which the Finance Ministry tries to avoid at all costs. Deficit bonds have not been issued without securing a revenue source to pay for them since 1989.
Japan had high budget deficits in the late 1970's, but they were gradually reduced in the 1980's. In the late 1980's, when Japan's economy boomed because of rising land and stock prices, the central Government had a surplus, when the social security account was included.
Japan has about 200 trillion yen, or $2 trillion dollars, of outstanding debt. In the budget proposed for next fiscal year and made before the earthquake, 16.4 percent of total expenditures would go for interest payments on the past debt.
Economists say the accumulating debt will be a problem for Japan because the percentage of elderly people in its population is growing rapidly. That will increase the need for social welfare payments.
