HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Simpson Case Gives Cable An Edge on the Networks

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
While jurors and trial watchers ponder the DNA factor in the O. J. Simpson trial, it's the CNN factor that is worrying people inside the news divisions of the three major television networks.
A news story as big and juicy as Mr. Simpson's murder trial would once have attracted huge audiences to the networks' evening news programs. But in the age of CNN, which is available in about two-thirds of the nation's households, the Simpson trial has done the opposite: it has taken viewers away from the newscasts, reducing their weeknight audiences as much as 10 percent.
While specifics are hard to come by, those audience losses, if sustained for a few months, could cost the networks hundreds of thousands of dollars a week.
When a big story breaks -- or unfolds, as with the Simpson trial -- Americans need not wait to get home and hear a brief account of it from Tom Brokaw, Peter Jennings or Dan Rather and Connie Chung. Instead, they can flip to CNN at their convenience for the latest -- often live -- coverage. And they can do so from offices, hotels or airport lounges.
The Simpson case is the most dramatic, and melodramatic, example of this phenomenon to date. Because the trial is taking place in Los Angeles, live coverage on CNN and Court TV continues well into the evening in the East and Midwest -- often as late as 8 P.M., but certainly through the network news time slots.
And the fact that a trial is a continuing defined event makes it easy to know when to tune in. With other kinds of dominant news events -- a foreign war, an earthquake or other disaster -- viewers might be better served by the summing-up coverage offered in a scheduled newscast.
"You just have to look at CNN's ratings and Court TV's ratings," said Andrew Lack, president of NBC News, "especially in the 5 to 7 P.M. Eastern time period, and the correlation is so strikingly clear: O. J. is the only explanation."
CNN's afternoon ratings for the first three weeks of the Simpson trial coverage were 5.1, 5.6 and 6.3 -- far above its 0.7 average for that time period.
And the ratings for Court TV were even higher -- as much as double those of CNN in the 20 million homes that receive both CNN and Court TV. At the same time, the evening news ratings for ABC, CBS and NBC have declined, collectively, nearly two ratings points from the period in 1994, to an average of 9.4 from 11.3 last year.
CNN's ratings do not directly compare with the networks' because CNN is available in about 64 million homes, while all three main networks reach about 95 million homes. A CNN rating point represents 658,000 households, while a Court TV rating point equals 200,000 households. A network rating point represents 954,000 households.
The Simpson trial has aggravated an overall decline in the network nightly news ratings. The collective audience for network news has shrunk from a 77 share in 1979-80 -- that is, network news was on 77 percent of all sets that were tuned to something -- to a 58 share last season and a 54 so far this season.
That shrinkage is costly. In the last year, the three networks have each added a minute of commercial time to their nightly newscasts to make up some revenue.
But it is too early to tell how costly the Simpson-related defections will be. Generally, advertisers buy commercial time in news packages that include the evening news and morning shows like "Today" or "Good Morning America" and prime-time news programs like "Dateline" or "20/20." So as the year progresses, the ratings for these packages may recover enough so that the networks meet their minimum-ratings guarantees to advertisers.
"Still," Mr. Lack of NBC said, "if this trial goes on for four or five months and the audience for it remains undiminished, we'll take a significant economic hit."
A media buyer with many clients who advertise on news programs, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: "I think people will get tired of this trial as it drags on. But if audiences stay down or erode further, and the trial lasts until mid-May or June 1, it could cost a network $1 million or more per week."
David F. Poltrack, executive vice president for planning and research at CBS, said, "Even after accounting for the normal pattern of erosion we've been seeing, the network news audiences are down about 10 percent since the O. J. Simpson trial began" on Jan. 24.
The trial also provides daily fodder for tabloid television, talk shows and local newscasts, as well as radio programs -- all potential competition for the network newscasts.
"It's a relatively recent phenomenon of our business that people have so many choices at any given time," said Mr. Brokaw, the anchor and managing editor for the NBC Nightly News. "I sometimes say, in not entirely mock frustration, that when I started out in the 1960's, there were effectively two network news programs, and at 6:30 P.M. people turned on either Huntley-Brinkley or Walter Cronkite and got their news for the day. And I'd like to have that back again."
The networks will never regain such a near-monopoly. But not all agree that the Simpson trial will accelerate the long-term erosion of the network news audience.
"The O. J. trial is unique in terms of the huge interest in it and the availability of live coverage on a regular schedule," said Lane Venardos, a vice president for news and special events at CBS. "Those two streams converged to make this a larger-than-life event, and I don't think we'll see that again soon."
Mr. Lack seems to agree. "Last year, when we had the L.A. earthquake, for example, CNN's ratings didn't spike up the way they have for O. J.," he said. "Most people still tuned in to us at night to get the major news coverage."
This time last year, intense interest was focused on the assault on the Olympic figure skater Nancy Kerrigan by men said to have been commissioned by her rival Tonya Harding. "With the Nancy-Tonya story, people couldn't get any better or more coverage from CNN than they could get on the network news," Mr. Poltrack said. "But a lot of people would rather watch O. J. itself live, instead of the network news account of it later."
Indeed, figures from CNN show that Simpson-related events have been the highest-rated programs on cable television in the last 14 months excluding National Football League games.
Mr. Venardos of CBS said the network news divisions had offered extended live coverage of the 1989 and 1994 California earthquakes and of the Persian Gulf war. They also covered the opening statements in the Simpson trial live and will presumably televise the closing statements and the verdict.
"Any time there's a big enough event, we can break in and go live," Mr. Venardos said. "CNN does not have the franchise on live coverage of news events."
But CNN, which will celebrate its 15th birthday in June, does not have to worry about pre-empting lucrative entertainment programming. A broadcast network loses money whenever it bumps afternoon soap operas or prime-time shows to cover news live. The same big news story can earn extra money for CNN because its ratings go up.
Mr. Brokaw cautioned those who would conclude that the cable ratings for the Simpson trial were an omen of future decline for network news audiences, because of this story's "soap opera quality."
"In most instances," he said, "a big story will take away from us for 24 hours or so, and then the country gets back to normal."

HEADLINE: Tribe's Promised Land Is Rich but Uneasy

SERIES: Hitting the Jackpot: Casino Money and the Pequots -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LEDYARD, Conn.

 BODY:
Eight years ago, Joey Carter was chopping wood for a living, earning $5 an hour and living in a two-bedroom apartment he shared with seven other people. He recalled his boyhood, growing up poor in Rhode Island, and his grandfather, Clifford Sebastian, a half-blood Mashantucket Pequot Indian who lived on a pig farm with no electricity or running water. The grandfather would spit on the ground in bitterness every time he talked about the fate of the once proud Pequots.
Old stories rooted in the tribe's centuries-long decline into poverty and near extinction abound in Pequot country. New Pequot stories are all about sudden and astounding success. Mr. Carter now owns a rock crushing business, valued -- he volunteers -- at $3.9 million. On his office wall are blueprints for another private business under development for a nightclub restaurant. His sister, Carrie, owns a masonry company that has done well, too, he said. 
 The Carters' lives, along with all other Pequots', have been utterly transformed by the booming, clattering cash-raking phenomenon of Foxwoods Casino, the tribe's huge gambling development in the Ledyard woods of southeastern Connecticut.
While many American Indian tribes have embraced gambling as a way to pay the bills, the 318 members of the tiny Pequot tribe, by the sheer scale of their ambition, have made the business a rocket ride to a new world, building from scratch, in just three years, the most profitable casino in the nation.
So great are the gross winnings -- more than $800 million last year, twice as much as either of the nation's two next-most profitable casinos, the Taj Mahal in Atlantic City and the MGM Grand in Las Vegas, Nev. -- that the Pequots are able to guarantee an upper-middle-class standard of living for every tribe member.
Each Pequot is guaranteed a job with an average salary of $50,000 to $60,000 a year. This salary is also payable to a single Pequot parent who stays at home to care for young children. The tribe will provide a house, built on the reservation or bought in one of the surrounding towns, and will pay for all educational expenses for tribe members or their children, from preschool through a Ph.D.
By the standards of Indian reservations, where poverty is often pervasive, the Pequots have created a promised land. But building this utopia has not been without its stresses. Pequots were scattered across the nation, and those who have returned to the reservation to share in the boom from places like Utah, Indiana and Florida are struggling to adjust. Many of their non-Indian Connecticut neighbors resent their new wealth. There are white Pequots and black Pequots and the tensions between them are no different from those in society at large.
The goal at the casino, which employs 10,000 workers, is to have a tribe member supervising all major departments. But can the tribe do that and still maintain quality?
The Pequots say they are giving their own people opportunities, not free lunches. "If you don't work here, you don't get a dime, you don't get a penny," said Mr. Carter, who as the tribe publicity director, makes $55,000. "You know what your check comes in? Zero, zero, zero."
 
The Return
Wealth and Worry Never Imagined
Everywhere on Mashantucket, as the Pequots call their lands, are stories of Pequots who have returned, and Pequots who have made good, and those who are not Pequots at all, but are simply trying to cash in on the tribe's new-found wealth.
Alan Pearson Jr. returned to Connecticut with his family two years ago from Florida to take part in the Pequot bonanza. "You say you're coming back home and you can have a position and training if it's available and college if it's available and you have medical, and here's a house if you don't have one," he said. "If we don't have a house and you wait a little, here's some place to stay and we'll build you one. That's nice."
Mr. Pearson, who vividly remembers showering and shaving at nearby Ledyard High School because there was no running water on the reservation in the 1960's, co-manages the casino's engineering department.
Bruce A. Kirchner, who 10 years ago was an aide in a nearby psychiatric hospital and did volunteer work at the reservation on weekends, is a casino senior vice president managing 500 people. Tom Christensen, a Mormon who never believed in gambling, retired after 30 years as a Federal benefits officer in Utah and moved here, working now in the casino assessing property accident claims.
It has all happened so fast. In the 1970's the Pequots were officially pronounced extinct by Connecticut, which wanted to convert the 1,200-acre reservation into a state park. To make ends meet, surviving Pequots sold firewood and raised hydroponic vegetables and pigs.
But in 1983, after a seven-year campaign, an act of Congress sponsored by Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. gave the tribe Federal recognition as a sovereign Indian nation. Three years later, the Pequots -- freed by their sovereignty from state gambling prohibitions -- opened a bingo hall, and then in 1992, Foxwoods Casino. Across the nation, 95 tribes conduct or own some gambling business, according to the National Indian Gaming Association. But none have come so far, so fast, as the Pequots.
Gambling industry experts say that Foxwood's location -- particularly its monopoly as New England's only casino -- is responsible for much of the success, but the Pequots themselves say the years of collective struggle, and the vision of the tribal leaders, were just as important.
The tribe is formally a democracy, in which each of the 170-odd adult members get a vote on major issues, and where all are encouraged to speak their minds at the monthly community forums held in the tribal community center. Day-to-day operating authority, however, both to make laws and enforce them, is invested in the seven-member Tribal Council, led by the tribal chairman, Richard (Skip) Hayward.
The Council, tribe members say, has all the stresses of a multimillion-dollar corporation, plus all the headaches that only family can create.
Growth has also brought questions about what role the Pequots should play in the state, economically and culturally. In trying to diversify beyond gambling, the Pequots have bought thousands of acres of land in southeastern Connecticut, including a huge industrial parcel previously owned by the Electric Boat shipyard, and several small manufacturing companies. By this spring, Mr. Carter said, the tribe will be entirely debt-free, with its $300 million in start-up loans for the casino paid in just three years.
Sudden wealth has its burdens. The Pequots are constantly being solicited for money by charities and causes, and there is much pressure on the tribe to invest wisely. In hopes of giving their children a better future they have donated generously to a local private school that was faltering financially, Pine Point, where many young Pequots now study. In hopes of spreading good will, they donated $500,000 to help rebuild a minor league baseball stadium in Norwich.
But many tribe members, stung by local hostility, are wary of opening up to outsiders. Some do not want themselves or their children photographed, and some express worries about robbery and kidnapping.
There is also the nagging question of what comes after the Foxwoods gold rush slows, which may be soon. Both tribe members and gambling industry experts agree that the casino is probably at the apogee of its earning powers. Other casinos, including one about 10 miles away in Montville, operated by the Mohegan tribe, and one about 20 miles away in Charlestown, R.I., by the Narragansetts, are scheduled to open.
 
Cultural Shock
Mormons Adjust To Life Near Sin
Delia Christensen grew up Mormon in Blackfoot, Idaho, on the broad flat scrub land of the Rocky Mountains' western slope, where gambling was seen by her community as a sordid business run by sharpies from Las Vegas and where a reservation was synonymous with poverty. When her husband, Tom, a quarter-blood Pequot, said last year that he wanted to move back east to Connecticut, to the reservation, to work at his tribe's casino, she just about died.
"I told him to come alone," she said.
Mrs. Christensen relented after flying out and looking at the place. She admits she is getting used to what this new Pequot life has to offer: A house, a job for her husband on a career track to management, expensive private schooling free for the three children and a dazzling wood-and-stone community center literally in her backyard, just past the tennis courts, where she takes her morning aerobics class, and where the children compete as members of the Pequot Foxes swimming team.
"They're eating it up," she said.
Still, there are adjustments. In Utah, there was a Mormon church on practically every corner. Here, Mr. Christensen said, he must drive 40 minutes to worship services, and when he arrives he often smells like cigarette smoke from the casino.
It raises eyebrows in church meetings because practicing Mormons do not smoke or drink alcohol.
"I wear suits to work and I wear suits to church and they're the same suits," Mr. Christensen said. "I don't smoke but I smell like I do."
Another thing the Christensens have had to quickly learn is how to negotiate the anti-tribe, anti-casino feeling that permeates towns in this part of the state.
Mr. Christensen, who was born in Providence, R.I., and went west to Utah in 1947 at age 4, recalls sitting in a Ledyard barbershop shortly after his arrival with his son, Clinton, 9.
"The men were talking, and there was a lot of hostility toward the tribe and I'm sitting there with my boy hoping he doesn't blurt out and tell them, 'Well, we're from the reservation,' " Mr. Christensen said.
Even the landscape can seem strange. Mrs. Christensen, sitting in the living room of the house her family was assigned when its name came up on the waiting list -- a four-bedroom ranch built in the 1970's with a Federal Housing and Urban Development loan before tribal prosperity came -- said the narrow, winding wooded roads of rural Connecticut sometimes leave her lost and claustrophobic.
There have been moral quandaries as well. Because of the Mormon Church's vehement stance against gambling, the Christensens hesitated about moving here, however alluring the opportunities, until they got a special dispensation letter from church authorities, saying that Mr. Christensen would still be regarded as a good Mormon. Some family members back home, however, have not been so quick to reconcile.
"I don't know if my mother has accepted the fact yet that my husband works for the casino -- that's just taboo," Mrs. Christensen said.
 
The Races
Black and White Get Used to Unity
The first great familial fact of Pequot life is that nearly every tribe member is descended from a single group of five sisters whose grandchildren and great-grandchildren are now in adulthood.
The second great fact is that some of those descendants married into the black community, while others married into the white, and that elders fought each other long and hard over their racial divide, carving out deep wounds that are yet to fully heal.
"The fences are coming down, slowly," said Judy Bell, a quarter-blood Pequot who moved back to the reservation from Florida three years ago.
Mrs. Bell, 48, a former human resources administrator, now runs the tribe's Indian Preference Office, where her job is to insure that newly arriving Pequots and members of other tribes who have come here looking for work get first crack at casino jobs. Her brother is Mr. Pearson. Her first cousin is Skip Hayward, the tribal chairman.
All are white. In fact, Mrs. Bell said that when her grandmother, Elizabeth George, died in 1976, her descendants -- and so far as Mrs. Bell was aware then, the only Pequots left in the world -- were all light skinned. "That's all we knew," she said.
The ensuing years brought the return of families with darker skins, like the Reels, Sebastians and Carters, who now form perhaps a quarter of the tribe.
Cousins like Mr. Carter recall old hurts. His grandfather, he said, never fully accepted him and his brothers as Pequots because their father was black. And he thinks that much of the local resentment is not truly over huge land purchases by the tribe and the efforts to convert that land into nontaxable Federal trust status, but is really a matter of racism.
"That's what most of this is over," Mr. Carter said. ' "Look at all that money them brown-skinned people have.' "
Shortly after the Christensen's youngest daughter, Kelli, 7, arrived in Connecticut from Utah last year, she dreamed that she had turned black. "She'd never been exposed," Mrs. Christensen said.
Within the tribe, there have been charges of nepotism, and questions about why some get better jobs and bigger paychecks. Tribe members like Mr. Pearson say that this is inevitable, simply human nature.
"Everybody's mixing in and everybody's striving and you're going to have little rumples," he said. "You have people from different backgrounds, all coming together as one, and they're used to this and you're not and you're used to this and they're not -- it's just learning to give and take and I think it's going quite well."
Mrs. Bell said that tensions had declined in recent years, and that things like the community center swimming team were bringing families together. Her grandchildren, she vowed, "will not know prejudice."
Still, it is clear that some of these clans do not communicate much.
Sometimes, Mr. Carter said, the whole tribe will disappear into the woods for 24 hours, drumming and singing and getting back in touch with their Native American roots. When asked if she ever participated in those spontaneous outings, Mrs. Bell said she might, if she ever knew about them.
"Chances are they're not putting signs up at the community center," she said.
 
Identity
What Is Pequot, Not Just Who?
Mr. Carter offers an oft-told tale of modern Pequot life:
"A guy calls up and says, 'Uh, yeah, I'm one of them peacocks.' "
"I said, 'Who?' "
"He said, 'One of you guys, one of them peacocks.' "
"I said, 'It's Pequot, Mashantucket Pequot.' "
"He said, 'No, no, no, you're not pronouncing it right.' "
"I said, 'I don't think I'm pronouncing it wrong because I AM one of them Pequots.' "
"He goes, 'Well, maybe in the past they pronounced it wrong, because it's peacock,' " Mr. Carter said. "This is what we've been going through."
Everybody wants to be a Mashantucket Pequot now, and no small wonder. As word of the tribe's story has spread, there have been thousands of callers from as far as Cuba and Bermuda and England, all seeking membership.
The big problem is that no one, even many Pequots, is quite sure what being Pequot means. Beyond the requirement that would-be tribe members prove genealogically that they are at least one-sixteenth Pequot (and thus descended no more than four generations from a full-blood tribe member), there are no other guideposts.
Some people who have called from the Bahamas, for example, may be Pequot descendants, since members of the tribe were shipped off into slavery there in the 1600's. But none so far has qualified because the link was too weak, too long ago.
Some callers have asked for a spiritual membership. "People said, 'Oh, I knew a Pequot when I was a kid and we cut ourselves and rubbed our hands together so we're blood brothers so that makes me a Pequot,' " Mr. Kirchner said.
The Pequots' language and culture began dying in 1637, after English and Dutch colonists slaughtered most of the tribe. Later colonial laws, which lingered well into the 1800's, prohibited even speaking the Pequot language, now long dead but for a few vestigial words. In local churches in southeastern Connecticut, certain rear benches facing backward are still known as Pequot pews, because tribal worshipers were not permitted to face front.
In homes like the Pearsons', whose living room has American Indian paintings on every wall, the culture is kept alive, but Mr. Pearson is first to admit that it is a generic concept and no more.
"The Pequots were wiped out at such an early age, everything was thrown out the window," he said. "We've picked up many of your Western Indian regalia here, costumes and bells, but that wasn't our people."
Mr. Carter said that much of what he knows of his tribe's history he has learned from talking to anthropologists retained by the tribe to investigate artifacts and old reservation campsites.
The rest he got from his family. From a crusty old Pequot woman he knew only as Aunt Matt, he said he learned of self-reliance. She carried a shotgun wherever she went, even into town -- to kill snakes, she said. His grandfather taught him to kill a pig in the most painless way, neatly severing its spinal cord, and to find sassafras and edible mushrooms in the wild. He now takes Pequot children into the hills on weekends to pass on that knowledge, he said.
Mr. Kirchner, a quarter-blood whose grandmother was Alice Brend, one of the five matriarchs, admits that he does not pay much attention to American Indian traditions. His house, a Government-built home on the reservation that he gutted and remodeled last year, is decorated with few Indian elements. Its open kitchen, hardwood floors and fireplaces could be an upper-middle-class home anywhere.
But with the Pequot rebirth, Mr. Kirchner said his two sons, Myles and Carl, are being exposed to far more Indian culture than he ever was growing up in nearby Norwich. The Pequots can afford culture now, he said; in the days of his youth, culture was a luxury beyond reach.
Next: Through real-estate investments, private schools for their children, charities and even minor-league baseball, the Pequots are using their wealth to reach out beyond the casino, widen their community role and, for the first time, be insiders.

HEADLINE: Strengthening Public Housing

 BODY:
In much of the country, what began as decent public housing for the working poor has degenerated into dumping grounds for troubled families. Federal regulations discriminate against letting in poor people who work while favoring the desperately poor and long-term unemployed.
New York's public housing is well kept and orderly compared to harrowing places like Chicago's Robert Taylor Homes, but it, too, has suffered. So Ruben Franco, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, is wisely taking steps to preserve New York's standing. Last month Mr. Franco unveiled an ambitious plan to persuade police officers to move into public housing in exchange for career incentives. Now Mr. Franco says the Housing Authority will give preference to the working poor over welfare recipients in filling vacancies. 
 Both measures deserve vigorous support. The new preference for working families is an especially important step in the battle to stave off social disintegration. As recently as 1984, nearly half of the families in public housing included at least one working adult. That number has now fallen to 31 percent. Among current applicant families, fewer than 10 percent include an adult who works.
Working families had been shying away from public housing for decades on their own. But government policies instituted in the 1980's encouraged the trend by stipulating that 90 percent of public housing be set aside for the poorest of the poor, among them people who were homeless or involuntarily displaced. The public housing system also let lapse the screening procedures that once insured that new tenants would be responsible neighbors.
The Housing Authority plans to alter the mix by giving working families preferential status for up to 50 percent of vacancies, or about 4,000 apartments each year. Advocates for the poor worry that the change could eliminate a critical housing option for the desperately poor. But it makes more sense to disperse poor families into mixed-income neighborhoods through so-called Section 8 subsidies than to warehouse all of the city's poorest citizens in public housing projects.
The Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development has approved New York's initiative and is encouraging other cities to follow suit. New York's Housing Authority is planning an advertising campaign to recruit working applicants.
The idea looks like a winner. The working poor will find relief from steep market-rate rents while altering public housing's chemistry for the better. The rent they pay will reduce Federal subsidies at a time when every penny counts.

HEADLINE: An Investment Worth Saving

 BODY:
The Senate Budget Committee staff has circulated a proposal to terminate American contributions to multilateral development banks. It is a callous and shortsighted idea that should be disowned by the committee.
The United States contributes money to the United Nations Development Program -- which the proposal also threatens -- as well as several development banks, the most important of which is the World Bank. Other recipients include the Africa, Asia and Inter-American development banks, which lend to poor countries for economic development. 
 The Budget Committee staff apparently thinks the money is wasted. The staff's judgment is myopic. It takes no account of the relatively modest contributions that Washington makes to the development banks, and shows cold indifference to the role that a wealthy and powerful country like the United States ought to play in helping desperate people subsisting on less than a dollar a day. American contributions, multiplied many times over by money from other industrialized countries, has done much to reduce infant mortality in sub-Saharan Africa, raise food production in South Asia and educate children in Latin America.
The World Bank -- the largest recipient of American money -- is far from ideal. Created in the aftermath of World War II, it started off financing huge dam, transportation and other infrastructure projects. Some made sense. Others were environmental and social disasters, uprooting communities and entrenching corrupt politicians. But the bank's tactics have changed, and it is now investing more in people. The bank pours money into vaccine, nutrition, education and clean-water programs that have helped ameliorate horrific living conditions throughout Africa, Asia and Latin America. The World Bank is also an invaluable source of policy advice, helping countries set up judicial, financial and monetary institutions to carry their economies toward democracy and open markets.
The United States spends about $2.5 billion on the multilateral banks and other development programs. In a $1.5 trillion Federal budget and a $6 trillion economy, these sums are small. Yet they loom large to recipients because Western allies chip in more than $10 for every dollar Washington contributes. The expenditures buy a faster-growing third world, which translates into more American exports, less military aggression, fewer refugees and more certain evolution of democratic government and open economies.
Critics of development aid argue that the third world is better off opening up their economies to trade and investment than reaching for handouts from Washington. But this nostrum overlooks a harsh reality: Private investors shun the frailest cases, funneling more than 70 percent of their investment in developing countries to only 10 countries. Sub-Saharan Africa attracts only 2 percent.
The development banks are the only institutions that possess the resources, expertise and will to attack crushing poverty. The United States already ranks last among industrialized countries in the percentage of its income devoted to foreign aid. It should sink no lower.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Back in the Dock

 BODY:
Judge Stanley Sporkin has every right to feel frustrated. After four years of Federal investigation, the Justice Department and the Microsoft Corporation reached an antitrust settlement designed to end unfair, anticompetitive practices by the software giant. But neither Judge Sporkin nor any other outsider has the foggiest idea whether the agreement is adequate or a mere wrist slap when stronger measures are needed.
We still don't know whether Microsoft for the most part competes fairly, in which case it is a crown jewel of the American economy, just the sort of technological and business success this nation badly needs to compete in world markets in the coming information age. Or is Microsoft a predator that uses its market dominance to freeze out the superior products of competitors while insuring success for clunkier products of its own? 
 Microsoft is clearly the dominant powerhouse in providing software for personal computers. It manufactures the basic operating system (MS-DOS) that runs more than 70 percent of all personal computers. It produces Windows, a software program that allows users to manage scores of specialized applications programs. It also produces a powerful array of those applications programs itself, including a huge chunk of the word processors and spreadsheets used in personal computers.
The company's future plans are breathtaking. It hopes to develop its own on-line network and seeks to purchase a company whose personal-finance software dominates that market, opening the way for electronic banking and purchasing.
But as Microsoft has become ever more dominant, complaints about its practices have mounted. The Federal Government has investigated Microsoft for the past four years, first at the Federal Trade Commission, inconclusively, then at the Justice Department, where Assistant Attorney General Anne K. Bingaman has been trying to revive the antitrust division from its torpor during the Reagan-Bush years. Last July, the long Federal probe reached an anticlimactic conclusion -- a narrow consent decree in which Microsoft agreed to change certain licensing practices that seem clearly anticompetitive.
For example, Microsoft had been requiring computer manufacturers who licensed its MS-DOS operating system to pay a royalty for every computer they sold, even if many of those computers did not actually use MS-DOS but contained a rival operating system instead. That put enormous pressure on the manufacturers to shun the rival system altogether. Microsoft has now agreed to abandon the practice, and to stop a few other licensing practices also deemed unfair.
That's a clear gain. But Judge Sporkin, who must rule whether the decree is in the public interest, rejected it last week for failing to address critical issues. The judge complained that, even on the licensing practices, the agreement would simply require Microsoft to "sin no more." It would do nothing to offset the unfair advantage Microsoft had already gained. He is unquestionably right on this point; the only issue is what can be done about it.
Even more important, Judge Sporkin expressed concern that Justice may have caved in on some very big issues that the consent decree does not even address. For example, there are complaints that Microsoft has an intimidating habit of announcing, prematurely, that a new product will be coming out so that customers will not buy a competitive product. Others accuse Microsoft of using its dominant position in operating systems to give its own applications designers an advantage over rival software designers. The judge was particularly frustrated by the Justice Department's refusal to say what practices it had investigated and what findings it made before letting issues drop.
Both Justice and Microsoft are appealing to a higher court, contending that Judge Sporkin exceeded his authority. Justice claims its ability to negotiate consent decrees would be crippled if judges can wade in after the fact and demand that other issues be addressed and investigative findings be revealed. But control of the electronics marketplace is too important to be settled in secret. The public needs full disclosure from Justice to make certain that this fabulously successful company is behaving properly and not setting up roadblocks on the emerging information highway.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Major League Managers Are Making the Best of It

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Baseball's managers are attracting much attention in the early days of baseball's ersatz spring training, not surprising since they and their coaches are the only legitimate connections to major league-caliber baseball having donned uniforms.
So it was easy to understand why one manager, Lou Piniella of the Seattle Mariners, turned a head or two the other day when he said that if he were at the bargaining table, he would have had the players' strike, now in its seventh month, solved long ago. 
 When asked how so, however, Piniella, let go with his patented rat-a-tat laugh, shrugged, then admitted he had no idea.
So it is for every major league manager this side of Detroit's self-liberated Sparky Anderson and the excused Cito Gaston of Toronto and Phil Regan of Baltimore. The rest of the managers have no choice short of unemployment but to work with replacement players. And as they wade into the unknown, they are filled with emotions as confused as their peculiar status as management men as well as dues-paying members of the Major League Baseball Players Association.
Thus, Piniella's forced humor. Thus, the hollow hopes for a liberating settlement held by Dusty Baker. "I still believe in miracles," the Giants' manager said quietly last week.
There are the anxieties of those who were once very active in the union, but are now members of both camps, without a vote anywhere. "I don't feel used, but I do feel frustrated," Don Baylor of the Colorado Rockies said. "If I could make a difference, I would. But I am there with minor league kids. That's what I'm doing."
Then there are the melancholy ones, like the Oakland A's Tony La Russa, who, like Anderson, wrestled the propriety of participating in replacement baseball.
"I thought about it, about the issues, the owners' and the players'," La Russa said. "Then I realized, it's academic. The game comes first; everybody's interests follows. The game is suffering because we're not on the field. I think fans understand that we have to be on the field. So I'm putting on the uniform.
"It's a sad day that it's gone this far, but sadness was not having a post-season, sadness is spring training starting up and you don't have baseball. This is making the best out of a bad thing."
The bad thing could have been worse, because many managers came into spring training not only forlorn, but also angry toward their union. That ire arose from rumors that the striking players might cut licensing funds to managers as well as the trainers and coaches who are also in the union if they worked with replacement players.
"Dusty, Don Baylor, Carney Lansford, Dave Duncan, Bob Boone -- the current major leaguers owe so much to these guys," La Russa said, naming a host of former players who helped build the union. "Then when it came out that they were going to penalize them, I thought to myself, you've got to be kidding me -- that's how far this has gone? Suddenly, we weren't a part of the team anymore."
The union has steadfastly denied that any moves to cut licensing income were contemplated. It reiterated that in meetings with managers, coaches and trainers in Florida and Arizona last week.
"I don't believe that the executive board, the guys who have been members for a while, like Scott Sanderson and Jay Bell, ever intended to take the coaches, trainers and managers off," Baylor said Saturday night after the eight managers stationed in Arizona met with union officials. "But it took a meeting like this to clear the air, without question."
The managers also wanted to hear what the union expected of what is quite possibly the nation's most unusual wing of labor. After all, Baker said: "When you've been around for 25 years, like Sparky, you can do whatever you want. I've only been around for two years. A lot of us are just starting. If I get fired, blackballed, is the union going to give me a job?"
"They are caught between the proverbial rock and a hard place," said Donald Fehr, who heads the players association that pays the benefits, pensions and perks to managers and their staffs. "I have no doubts where their sympathies lie. But you have to remember, it's the clubs that are saying you have to do this or we will fire you."
And what is the union telling the men in the middle? "We are not asking anybody to do what Sparky did," said Fehr, referring to the Tiger manager having taken an unpaid leave of absence. "People have to do what they think is best in their own circumstances."
And, guarantees Baylor, "everybody will do what he has to do."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Economics 101: Baseball Owners' Egos Would Ease the Luxury Tax

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
IT'S almost time for the baseball players to end this thing. Time for them to proclaim: "The war is over. We won." They have outlasted the salary cap, and isn't that why they tipped over their water buckets and marched out of the coal mines last August?
The wonderful owners are no longer demanding an artificial salary ceiling for every club, and isn't that why those jokers killed the World Series? Instead of fighting over a salary cap, the owners and the players are now fighting over something called a luxury tax. 
 According to a noted economist -- that is to say, me -- the players can live with the luxury tax, which is based upon one of life's great certainties: the individual arrogance of the baseball owners.
Oh, I don't think the players should settle just yet. They should keep a militant posture until that raggle-taggle latter-day Coxey's Army of scab players debases baseball in the first week of March. Fans should be exposed to just how low Bud Selig and John Harrington and Jerry Reinsdorf and the Tribune people will sink. Then the baseball players should cut a deal. Announce they are saving America from the owners.
You could see why the baseball players didn't want the salary cap. It gives owners and general managers a legal excuse not to finagle. In basketball, the Phoenix Suns induced Danny Manning to play for only $1 million a year in order to fit under their salary cap, and the poor guy tore up his knee, so now he depends on the generosity of an owner. In football, the San Francisco 49ers cut private deals with players to fit them into the salary cap, and they won the Super Bowl, and all kinds of bonuses kicked in.
Baseball players did not want a future of 28 general managers wringing their hands and saying, tsk-tsk, there was no more money left because of that big, bad salary cap. Now we have Bud Selig, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, who is acting as commissioner, assuring us, "The clubs moved away from a salary cap. The luxury tax is a mechanism to put a drag on salaries, but it must be meaningful to have an effect on salaries."
The mediator Bill Usery Jr. has proposed, apparently just for openers, a luxury tax of 50 percent on all club payrolls above $40 million, the average club payroll. If a club right at the $40 million level wanted to sign one player for $2 million for one year, it would have to pay an extra tax of $1 million. That sounds like a significant jump in cost, but look at the way the owners have fought each other for the privilege of paying fortunes to swaggering mediocrities. You think the owners are going to stop splurging? I don't.
The luxury-tax concept appeals to me because the tax itself would presumably go to the lower-market clubs. The owners are too selfish to openly share their vastly disparate local television revenues, but they could accept playing Robin Hood, robbing from the rich to give to the poor.
And at the risk of sounding like some trickle-down voodoo Reaganite economist, I say that every dollar in luxury tax that helps keep teams in worthwhile towns like Seattle, Pittsburgh, San Diego and Montreal only gets spent again -- in player salaries. So what's the harm?
"We don't believe the clubs should be penalized for going after players, for thinking this is a nefarious activity," said Gene Orza, the lawyer with the Players Association. "We tax cigarettes, but if we taxed them at, let's say, $5,000 a pack, people wouldn't buy them. Why would a club want to pay a tax most Americans wouldn't want to pay?"
The fact is, there are already so-called "sin taxes" on items like cigarettes, alcohol and gambling. People do pay to play. It adds an extra fillip of danger to their habit. The owners can relate.
It is significant that the players are counterproposing a 5 percent tax on payrolls between $20 million and $40 million, 15 percent on payrolls between $52 million and $64 million and 25 percent above $64 million.
Orza said the players support some form of revenue-sharing for the smaller markets. They just want a lower tax, lesser drag, more action from the owners. As David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, always reminds me, it's always about numbers.
Besides, history tells us that baseball owners will never stop spending money. They need a relief pitcher in August, a power hitter in the off season, a one-time superstar to finally produce a champion, they will spend the money.
"I know Freddie Wilpon, I know Paul Beeston, I know George Steinbrenner," Bud Selig said the other day, talking about operators of the wealthy Mets, Blue Jays and Yankees.
Baseball owners have always believed they were smarter than each other. That's how their payrolls got so high. The owners would treat a luxury tax as just some annoying (but in its own way prideful) assessment down at the country club.
The players should take the owners up on a negotiated luxury tax. But first they should rub the owners' noses in the first week of scab exhibitions. That stench would never go away.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Simple Idea for Schools Turns Complicated

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

NATIONAL STANDARDS IN AMERICAN EDUCATION
A Citizen's Guide
By Diane Ravitch
223 pages. The Brookings Institution. $22.95.
A simple message lies at the heart of Diane Ravitch's useful new book, "National Standards in American Education: A Citizen's Guide." If clear and consistent goals of learning could be set for all American children, rich and poor, gifted and ordinary, then all of these children would end up better educated than they now are likely to be. 
 But so fraught with complex implications is this message and so conscientious is Ms. Ravitch, an authority on American education, in acknowledging them, that the thesis of her book is sometimes hard to grab hold of. For instance, in summarizing the case against setting goals for education, or national standards and assessments, as she calls them, she lists nine complaints critics have raised, some of which seem repetitive and others of which seem to mix up apples and ball bearings.
(One objection she cites is, "National standards will be minimal, reduced to the lowest common denominator, especially if they are controlled by a Federal agency." Another is, "National standards based on traditional subject matter disciplines such as mathematics, science and history will narrow the curriculum," as if narrowing was significantly distinct from reducing to a common denominator.)
Weighing Ms. Ravitch's record on the one hand as a writer of lucid histories ("The Great School Wars: New York City, 1805-1973" and "The Troubled Crusade: American Education, 1945-1980) and on the other as a former Assistant Secretary in the Department of Education under Secretary Lamar Alexander, one suspects that the problem here is less a failure to think categorically and more an eagerness to acknowledge overlapping political constituencies. It should not be overlooked that this book is subtitled "A Citizen's Guide."
Still, at the risk of flattening out the tall peaks and deep valleys of her argument, one can sum up the core of her message as follows: American education is failing to fulfill its potential. The few available measures of students' aptitude and achievement have shown a decline in the last three decades. The gap between the top and bottom students has been growing over all. Most disturbingly, most evidence indicates that American students are at best mediocre in achievement compared with those of many other industrial nations.
While such shortcomings are adverse in themselves, Ms. Ravitch adds, they are bound to loom larger as the American economy continues to shift from being labor-based to knowledge-based. Therefore, she concludes, some sort of basic reform in educational techniques will become increasingly essential.
Although many look back to schools of an earlier era as exemplars of academic rigor, the author continues, nostalgia for the past is wrong because a form of elitism was in effect that educated only the best students while the rest were sorted out, or "tracked," and exposed to less demanding curriculums. What a wide range of evidence now indicates, Ms. Ravitch writes, is that "students who take a full program of history, geography, English, mathematics, science, foreign language and the arts are best prepared for whatever lies ahead in their lives."
She concludes, "In other words, a liberal education -- one that opens the mind to new worlds and liberates the individual from ignorance -- remains not only the best education for free men and women but the best preparation for the future, whether one chooses to enter higher education or the work force."
More and more, Ms. Ravitch reports, a system of national standards and assessments is being seen as the key to providing such a liberal education to every student, regardless of ability or promise. The process of developing such standards has even begun with the passage of President Clinton's Goals 2000 legislation in 1994.
But while surveys indicate that the American public likes the idea of higher standards, they also reveal deep skepticism about imposing them on the present educational system. Many feel that neither Congress nor the Federal Government should dictate what children should learn. Others fear the consequences of forcing uniform criteria on schools of unequal merit; they feel the playing field ought to be leveled before everyone is forced to compete on it. Still others worry about what they see as the so-called dumbing-down effect of teaching all students the same material; they assume that the bright students will be held back until the slowest students meet the new standards.
Ms. Ravitch responds to these objections. She concedes that Congress ought not "meddle in the educational affairs of the nation's schools," that it "should remember that the intent of the national goals process is to create academic standards that are national, not Federal." Responding to the level-playing-field argument, she cites an analogy offered by Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers: what if the rules for Olympic competition were not established until all likely contenders had the same opportunities, when the whole point of participation is precisely to define standards against which athletes measure themselves?
And to the question "Does the slogan 'all children can learn' mean that the curriculum will be dumbed down?" she replies: "The goal must be to raise achievement for all students, while narrowing the range from top to bottom. This does not mean dragging down the students at the top but expecting more of all students, especially those who are in the bottom half."
These are just a few of the arguments in a book that is knotty with hopes and fears, proposals and counterproposals, and theses, antitheses and syntheses. The whole does not make for especially smooth reading. But Ms. Ravitch has taken an important issue and examined it in all its snarled complexity.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Diane Ravitch (The Brookings Institution)

HEADLINE: Finances and Fear Spurring Hospitals To Drop Abortions

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The obstetrics and gynecology clinics at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center aim to give poor women one-stop health care, from pap smears to parenting classes to contraceptive counseling. They are widely considered a model of comprehensive medicine. But there is one service that they do not generally provide: a conventional outpatient first-trimester abortion.
Slowly, quietly, over the last 10 years, almost all of New York City's full-service hospitals have backed out of the abortion business, driven away in part by economics and in part by fear. Even as they are rapidly expanding their repertory of treatments in an era of managed care, they are no longer doing many elective terminations or training residents in the procedure and are referring patients elsewhere. 
 "Increasingly, the hospitals have not wanted to be involved," said Allan Rosenfield, dean of the School of Public Health at Columbia-Presbyterian. "That's partly because of the political issues and harassment related to abortion and partly because the freestanding clinics are doing it so well."
Hospitals say that clinics offer more cost-effective care than they can provide.
But critics say that in making this decision, hospitals have cast abortions outside the protective aura of established medical centers, creating delays for women who need abortions and leaving the independent clinics ever more susceptible to violence.
"Abortion ought to be integrated into women's health care, not separated so that it is vulnerable to attacks from people who want to criminalize it," said Alexander Sanger, president of Planned Parenthood of New York City. "Hospitals have not stepped up to solve the problem. They are afraid of losing donors who oppose abortion. And afraid of having pickets on the sidewalk."
Last week, the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education, which sets the standards for doctors' training, announced that residency programs in obstetrics had to teach abortions.
But critics say that hospitals now perform so few abortions that it will be difficult for doctors-in-training to learn. Only about one third of the residency programs in New York offer the option of abortion training, and about half of those send their residents to Planned Parenthood to learn the procedure.
Although the majority of abortions in the state have always been done at private freestanding clinics, until recently hospitals also did a significant share. In 1982, 30 percent of abortions in the New York area were performed in hospitals, but that number dropped to 16 percent by 1988, according to the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a private research organization. And of the 110,435 abortions performed in New York City in 1993, only 9 percent were in hospitals. About 6 percent were at the city's 12 public hospitals, and 3 percent were spread between the dozens of private institutions.
This general trend has been seen across the country, and in some states there are now no hospitals that will perform abortions.
The vast majority of abortions in New York City are performed by a handful of freestanding clinics. There are currently only eight licensed institutions in New York City, each performing thousands of abortions a year. According to statistics compiled by the New York City Department of Health, Eastern Women's Center in Brooklyn is the city's largest provider, performing 19,938 abortions in 1993. Choices Women's Medical Center in Queens did 17,792. In comparison, Bellevue Hospital Center did 331, Columbia-Presbyterian did 152 and Lenox Hill Hospital, 39.
Today, most of the abortions conducted in hospitals are complicated procedures often done later in pregnancy, experts say, and few are the simple elective abortions that account for about 90 percent of pregnancy terminations in this country.
Some doctors applaud the trend. "The freestanding clinics are much less expensive and much more user-friendly," said Irwin R. Merkatz, chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. "The hospital is the last place you want to be providing these services." Montefiore is one of the few hospitals in New York that still performs simple outpatient abortions; it did 152 last year.
But clinic directors, who complain they have been "ghettoized," suspect other motives. "When picketing and violence first began, hospitals gradually began cutting back their abortion services and training, and that accelerated as the violence accelerated," Mr. Sanger said.
For women, the shortage of hospital abortions often results in dangerous delays, as women who rely on a particular hospital for the rest of their health care search elsewhere for an abortion. While abortions in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy are extremely simple procedures that do not require more than local anesthesia, second-trimester abortions are more dangerous and complicated.
In one study by researchers at Planned Parenthood, 25 percent of women who got second-trimester abortions at New York City public hospitals had tried unsuccessfully to get an abortion earlier in their pregnancy and one-third had made four or more visits to hospitals before they had the procedure.
"The main problem was getting an appointment for the procedure," said Mary Ann Castle, who ran the study. "There were many people wanting to have abortions and not enough doctors willing to provide them."
The shortage of in-hospital abortions has also left women who want abortions and the doctors who do them more vulnerable to attacks, abortion rights advocates say. By relegating the procedure to freestanding clinics, hospitals have made it possible for anti-abortion forces to identify and harass doctors and their patients. If abortions were just one among the dozens of procedures performed in a hospital's or health maintenance organization's outpatient clinic, it would be impossible to identify targets.
Representative Nita Lowey, from parts of Westchester, the Bronx and Queens, who has campaigned for abortion rights, said: "The Catholic hospitals don't do it. The municipal hospitals get political pressure not to do it. It's such a hot potato that the medical schools have shied away. And the result is that many of the clinics are isolated and are subject to violence."
Although many hospitals technically offer abortions, they do so in ways that make them inaccessible or unattractive to the women who need them, critics say.
Most hospitals require that they be done in an operating room, for example, with full preoperative testing and general anesthesia; freestanding abortion centers do early abortions with local painkillers in a regular clinic.
"We are not well equipped to take care of medically uncomplicated patients who need an abortion," said Carolyn Westhoff, associate professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. "We are not really on the ball there. Patients who are complicated get taken care of in the O.R. Patients who are not do not get abortions here. We refer them to a variety of clinics."
Also, many hospitals that perform the procedure do so in a very limited way: one morning a week, for example, and so there may be long waits.
The situation is even more difficult for women who need abortions after the first 12 weeks of pregnancy, experts say, since some major hospitals have no one who knows how to perform second-trimester abortions. Abortions are legal until the 24th week of pregnancy in New York State.
"This is basic health care and a service that must be offered," said Representative Lowey, who has campaigned in Congress for abortion rights. "I was visiting a H.I.P. Clinic in Queens and they were bragging about how a person could come in and get the full range of services. And I said, 'What about abortion?' And they said: 'Oh, no, no. We don't do that here.'"
Abortions were one of the first surgical procedures to move outside of the hospital, pioneered by organizations like Planned Parenthood in the early 1970's. As a whole, the licensed abortion clinics became proficient at offering easily accessible, high-quality, low-cost care.
Hospital administrators say that in-hospital abortions are inherently expensive, since they require an operating room and much of the testing that surrounds any surgery. But critics point out that hospitals eager to bring in paying customers have recently figured out how to offer a range of minor surgeries outside the operating room.
"This is the safest surgical procedure in the country," Mr. Sanger said. "I see no reason why it couldn't be done in a hospital outpatient clinic."
Choices center in Queens performed abortions on more than 17,000 patients last year. But Merle Hoffman, the president of the center, is ambivalent about the medical institutions that through their castoffs have made her clinic a success, but still regard her as a pariah.
"The medical establishment has yet to welcome in abortion providers and gynecologists who are committed to women's choices," she said. "Unfortunately, I have not seen much activity by hospitals. Maybe they just don't want to see people screaming 'Don't kill your baby' outside their front door."
Ms. Hoffman and others point out that many of New York's hospitals no longer even train residents in gynecology to do abortions. Only half a dozen of the city's obstetrics training programs teach the procedure.
Since 1993, Planned Parenthood of New York City has offered to train residents in their clinics, with a mixed response. Half a dozen programs, including the one at Columbia-Presbyterian, send residents to Planned Parenthood to learn the procedure. But rather than hospitals paying Planned Parenthood for providing this service, Planned Parenthood pays the hospitals for the lost labor.
"I'm grateful they're doing it, but I think it's outrageous that Planned Parenthood has to educate medical students and residents about this, instead of medical schools," said Dr. Eileen Hoffman, associate director for education of the Women's Health Program at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. "It tells you how insane this whole issue is."

HEADLINE: Bankers Fear New Lending Risks

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Remember the credit crunch, when executives and entrepreneurs around the country squawked that banks had raised standards so high that no one could get a loan?
Well, the only crunch today is the sound of bankers slamming into each other as they race to shower new loans on business and consumers. 
 But now that banks are lending again with gusto, helping to fuel the rebound in the economy, banking officials warn that the industry is getting caught up in another frenzy likely to end badly. The fear is that banks are taking too many risks and losing sight of some cautious practices instituted after the collapse of the commercial real estate market in the late 1980's.
To win all sorts of business -- from loans for corporate takeovers to consumer credit card accounts -- bankers have loosened their rules again. As a result, they are lending more money at narrower margins for less collateral and with fewer restrictions than just a year ago.
"This past year we have really seen a deterioration of standards," said Verne G. Istock, chairman of NBD Bancorp in Detroit. "Banks are planting the seeds of the next wave of problem loans."
Loans at NBD were up 12 percent last year amid the boom in the Midwest. But Mr. Istock says that growth, however welcome, is also a warning sign: "We're reminding our people that bad loans are made in good times."
 NBD is not alone. Despite rising interest rates, lending at the nation's banks is up sharply, as the banks rush to take advantage of the improving business climate. The Federal Reserve says that the nation's largest banks had $1.141 trillion in consumer and commercial loans outstanding at the end of 1994, up a brisk 7 percent from the year before. By comparison, total lending at these banks declined by 9.6 percent from mid-1990 to mid-1993, as they strove to recover from the problems created during the real estate lending spree of the late 1980's.
No bank will openly admit to making bad loans, of course. But many bankers say that competition is forcing them to measures that make them queasy.
 "We find ourselves being pushed right up to the line," said Sloan D. Gibson, the head of corporate lending at the AmSouth Bank of Alabama in Birmingham. AmSouth, which increased its loans by more than 10 percent last year, acknowledges that it was able to do that only by cutting its interest rates and fees and easing its standards.
 For example, Mr. Gibson said the bank would now make real estate loans that do not have the full personal guarantee of the property's owner. It also might make a secured loan of as much as 65 percent of a business's inventory, even though it feels that 40 percent is a more prudent level.
 "The challenge for any bank is to not get caught up in the herd," Mr. Gibson said. "You have to be willing to say 'there is a line I will not cross,' but that's hard to do."
One measure of the gold-rush atmosphere is the interest rates and fees charged to borrowers, which are falling sharply, especially for loans to corporations.
Overall interest rates have risen. But banks set the price of business loans as a spread -- that is, a set number of percentage points above a floating interest rate. For small and medium-sized businesses, interest is tied to their stated prime rate; for larger businesses, rates are tied to the London interbank offered rate -- known as Libor -- which is the interest rate banks pay on large deposits.
The average interest rate on a loan to a big company with a comparatively weak BB credit rating, has fallen from 1.30 percentage points above Libor in 1992 to 0.79 point above Libor at the end of last year, according to statistics complied by Loan Pricing Corporation, a New York consulting firm. Spreads for companies rated A fell from 0.40 point to 0.25 point. And while statistics are not available, bankers say that rates for small businesses are declining at least that much.
Analysts say banks are now charging rates so low they are not really making a profit once money is set aside in reserve for inevitable future losses. At best, they say, much corporate lending is a break-even proposition for banks, offered to attract more lucrative business, such as money transfers or management of corporate pension plans.
 Credit standards are harder to gauge, but there are signs that banks are lending more on looser terms. In the resurgent market for leveraged buyouts -- corporate takeovers paid for largely with debt -- the average bank loan represented 2.9 times the company's cash flow at the end of 1994, compared with 1.8 a year earlier, according to Loan Pricing.
Bankers are also making more long-term loans, which are riskier than loans renewed every year. Last year 39 percent of corporate loans were for five years or longer, compared with 16 percent in 1992.
 Another reason that this lending cycle may get out of hand is that many banks no longer worry as much about future losses because they sell large chunks of their big-loan portfolios to other investors, like foreign banks and mutual funds. To the extent they off-load their loans, of course, the banks will not have to suffer for their mistakes.
For all the current lending enthusiasm, standards today have not slipped as far as they did in the late 1980's. And because banks are still cleaning up past problems, the level of loans in trouble continues to shrink at most banks. Moreover, when losses from the current round of new lending start showing up, banks should have a lot more capital to cushion themselves than they did five years ago.
Still, longtime bankers say that the compromises in standards look distressingly like the start of an apparently inescapable "lend then lose" cycle that has dominated banking for decades. Apart from the commercial real estate disaster, the years since the late 1970's have witnessed the Latin American lending spree; the Southwest oil drillers fiasco; the leveraged buyout frenzy and myriad other seemingly sure-fire propositions.
 Some of the swing in bad loans follows from the ups and downs in the economy. Defaults on credit card balances, for example, rise and fall in lockstep with the unemployment rate. But bankers have a history of amplifying the cycles, as they lend too much in good times and cut back too far when things get tough.
 What is most worrisome today, said L. M. Baker Jr., the chief executive of the Wachovia Corporation, "is that credit seems to be expanding faster than the economy."
Wachovia, which increased its loan portfolio by 13 percent last year, has one of the best records of avoiding bad loans. Still, Mr. Baker says the bank is not immune to today's siren songs. "Somewhere out there somebody in the bank has made a mistake; you just can't make too many of them," he said.
 Other bankers insist that the industry has finally learned its lesson.
 "We remember the trouble that we and many other banks had to work their way through," said Maurice Hastings, executive vice president for commercial lending for National Westminster Bancorp, the American unit of the big British bank. "We don't plan to go through the same kind of pain again."
 Still, NatWest is trying to lend more money to small- and medium-sized businesses in New York and New Jersey, where Mr. Hastings says competition is lowering prices and loosening standards. NatWest hopes to avoid problems by not permitting a big concentration of loans to one company or a single industry.
 Indeed, the one discipline that banks seem to be maintaining is in the size of their loans. For the most part, they have cut the size of each loan they make.
 "In 1988, you could do a $20 billion syndicated loan, because there were so many banks that said 'sign me up for $100 million,' " said Christopher L. Snyder, Loan Pricing's president. "You couldn't do a $20 billion syndication today, because banks won't hold more than $25 million."
 Banks are approaching lending to large companies as if they were underwriting bonds, selling small pieces to investors, typically regional and foreign banks and mutual funds. But, according to Mark Solow, the former head of corporate banking at Chemical Bank, that approach is fraught with peril if banks start to think they are lending other people's money rather than their own.
 "The greatest risk is that people start to compromise on credit quality because they think they can sell the paper," he said. "It looks too easy to people, and when things look easy that's when they get in trouble."
 Banks could be hurt if things turn bad and they hold an unexpectedly high inventory of loans, just as brokerage firms have been caught with holdings of junk bonds and mortgage-backed securities.
 Moreover, somebody else stands to be hurt when things go sour, as is already evident from the collapse of the Mexican peso. The commercial and investment banks that arranged the deals are not the biggest losers in Mexico; instead, it is the mutual funds and pension plans that bought into the program.
 No type of loan has yet emerged to dominate this new cycle so nobody is sure where the next big problem will come from. Many worry about the rise of consumer loans. Others see small business as a potential sinkhole. But as always, the banks will not really know where the trouble areas are until it is too late to do much about them.

HEADLINE: Serb Leader Rejects U.S.-Backed Proposal

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Serbian President has rejected an American-backed proposal offering a lifting of trade sanctions on Serbia in exchange for recognition of Bosnia and Croatia, Government officials said today.
The offer, prepared by the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia, always appeared far-fetched in that the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, has consistently said the status of the Serbs holding 70 percent of Bosnia and 30 percent of Croatia must be resolved before recognition of the two countries is possible. 
 Croatia and then Bosnia gained independence from Yugoslavia in 1991 and 1992. But the Serbian minorities in the two countries, backed by the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army, went to war to contest joining the new states.
"Recognition is almost certainly impossible until the conflicts in Bosnia and Croatia are resolved by the parties there," said one Government official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "When sanctions were imposed, they were not linked in any way to recognition. So why should they be now?"
Responding to the crushing Serbian offensive in Bosnia after war broke out in April 1992, the United Nations Security Council imposed sanctions on Serbia in May 1992. There was no mention in the resolution of any requirement on Serbia to recognize Bosnia and Croatia.
The official news agency of the remnant Yugoslav federation, made up of Serbia and Montenegro, said today that "Belgrade is categorical -- first a lifting of sanctions and then everything else." What that "everything else" meant and when it might happen was left vague.
It appeared highly unlikely, however, that the United States could ever agree to a lifting of sanctions on Serbia without securing Mr. Milosevic's recognition of Bosnia and Croatia. The role of the Serbian army in supporting the Bosnian and Croatian Serbs is generally discreet, but the support is widely viewed as crucial nonetheless.
Mr. Milosevic's position, spelled out this weekend to the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, reflects the overwhelming convictions of most people in Serbia, who would see the recognition of Croatia and Bosnia as the betrayal of the more than one million Serbs who have fought to change the borders of those countries.
Last August, Mr. Milosevic did break with the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, over Mr. Karadzic's refusal to accept a peace plan offering the Serbs almost half of Bosnia. Mr. Milosevic imposed a porous blockade and set about extending the influence in Bosnia of his Serbian Socialist Party.
But the dispute was always more about the best tactics for achieving the unification of Serbs in a single country or confederated states, rather than any other goal. Mr. Milosevic, and most other Serbs, are skeptical about the existence of a state called Bosnia.
Western diplomats say Mr. Milosevic may be closer to a possible recognition of Croatia -- a state that Serbs at least acknowledge exists even if they dispute its size -- but objects to being rushed by the recent decision of the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, to end the mandate of United Nations troops in Croatia at the end of next month. The troops' departure could open the way to a second Croatian war.
In a clear preparation for this, Mr. Karadzic and the leader of the Croatian Serbs, Milan Martic, met in the Serbian-held Bosnian town of Banja Luka today and announced the formation of a joint defense council obliging each to come to the defense of the other if necessary.
The creation of the council merely imposed a formal bureaucracy on a reality that has long existed: Gen. Ratko Mladic, the commander of the Bosnian Serbs, leads all Serbs west of the Drina River and coordinates their military campaigns -- as in the recent Serbian attack on the Bihac area.
Further preparations for renewed fighting have also been evident among the Muslim-led Bosnian Government forces in recent days, with at least 17 helicopters and one mysterious transport plane landing at Tuzla airfield in northern Bosnia in defiance of the "no flight" zone over Bosnia. United Nations officials have been unable to explain the origin or purpose of the flights.

HEADLINE: These Days, The Mark Keeps Rising

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 20

 BODY:
This would seem to be a script for investors to sell the German mark:
Metalworkers in Germany may go on strike Friday, halting much of the nation's automobile and machine-tool industries. Or, there may be relatively generous wage settlements that the financial markets would consider inflationary. Government reports have shown recent levels of economic growth as stronger than previously expected. 
 Today, though, the mark continued its rise of last week against the dollar and European currencies, closing at the highest level since October 1992 against the dollar, and at record highs against a basket of currencies of 18 industrial nations.
As the dollar falls over the feared cost to the United States in rescuing the Mexican economy, as the British pound falls amid lack of confidence in Prime Minister John Major's political survivability, as the lira drops over worry about runaway budget deficits, and as the yen struggles after the Kobe earthquake, the German mark continues to rise.
Analysts said that more than anything else, investors are persuaded to buy marks from their belief that whatever happens with the wage negotiations or economic growth, the German central bank will not let inflation get out of hand.
"It's called credibility," said Adrian Cunningham, senior currency economist for the Union Bank of Switzerland in London. "Ultimately, the strength of the mark reflects the people's confidence in the Bundesbank's ability to maintain stable prices over the medium term."
In trading today, the mark rose early in the day in Tokyo to 1.4710 to the dollar, then declined slightly in the European currency markets to 1.474 to the dollar -- below its 28-month high at the end of last week.
There was very little trading in New York because of the observance of Washington's Birthday.
Trading was light in Europe today, as investors waited to look for more developments in the United States over the rescue package of Mexico and how easily Mexican politicians would be able to carry out the terms of the agreement.
Central to the concerns in Europe is whether the proposed rescue of the Mexican financial system will hinder the Federal Reserve Board from focusing on American monetary policy and on limiting inflation. For weeks, investors here have expressed a lack of confidence in the Fed's determination to stop inflation by raising interest rates further. They worry that the delicate state of the Mexican economy may persuade the Fed not to raise rates again soon.
Economists and traders said the market was waiting until Wednesday, when the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, testifies before Congressional committees on the economy and monetary policy.
"If the Fed says it sees a robust economy, then I think the markets will take it as a signal that the Fed will do everything it can to make sure inflation does not pick up," Mr. Cunningham said. "It is good for the dollar as long as the market believes the Fed is ahead of the curve, moving against inflation before it kicks in."
Here in Germany, the markets obviously do not doubt that the Bundesbank would act to stamp out the earliest signs of inflation, as seen in the confidence expressed in the mark despite the possibility of higher inflation from wage settlements.
Whatever the outcome of the wage settlement, it is now being seen as positive for the mark. If the metalworkers get a significant wage increase, the Bundesbank has made it clear in the last week that it will act decisively against any inflationary effects. And employers are taking a hard line with the big trade union, IG Metall, which has asked for a 6 percent pay increase.
Brendan Brown of Mitsubishi Finance International said, "There is real evidence that the employers are being tough and a settlement of a 2.5 percent increase will emerge, so we can look beyond the wage conflict and see the inflationary impact will not be excessive."
