Dollar Up Against Yen
 TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 21 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- The dollar gained against the yen here today, rising to 97.43 yen in late afternoon trading, up from 97.15 late Monday, but still not far above a record low of 96.10 set in November.
Japanese stocks also traded higher today. Led by semiconductors, other electronics, transportation and auto issues, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 139.77 points, or nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 18,096.25 at the close. On Monday, the Nikkei closed down 64.03 points, or 0.36 percent.
"People are jumping in on the electricals because they think the dollar has bottomed out," a trader at a major brokerage firm said.
The mark's strength did not go unnoticed here either. On Monday, Hidenori Takigawa, a manager at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, said that the German currency had risen even against the Swiss franc, a traditional haven, indicating how much the markets were being driven by the mark's power.
In the past, the Swiss franc tended to gain from a weaker dollar. But the mark is being quoted around 84.60 Swiss centimes, compared with 83.60 at the start of the year.

HEADLINE: Anti-Crime Bill as Political Dispute: President and G.O.P. Define the Issue

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
 Most Americans think that having more police officers on the streets is a good way to fight crime. So do most police officers and both political parties. So why, in the recent House debate over crime legislation, did the matter of providing more police become the central dispute and the magnet that drew President Clinton's first explicit threat to veto a bill?
The basic dynamic driving the legislation that emerged from the House last week was this: Mr. Clinton and the Democrats swiped the crime issue from the Republicans. Then the Republicans got it back, not by any bold move but by relentless criticism of the 1994 anti-crime legislation. With last November's elections having left the Democrats in disarray on virtually every front, the President now finds himself fighting desperately to reclaim the issue. 
 Tony Blankley, press secretary for Speaker Newt Gingrich, summed up the Democrats' situation by quoting an old American position on the Panama Canal: "You can't take it from us, because we stole it fair and square."
Never mind that many criminologists believe that crime cannot be fought with Federal legislation. Never mind that previous efforts from Washington have generally been considered ineffective.
For Republicans, the crime issue has been theirs almost by birthright. It was only when a Democratic candidate for President finally said, as Mr. Clinton did in 1992, that he favored the death penalty -- and allowed the execution of a brain-damaged man to go forward before the New Hampshire primary -- that the Republicans began to lose the issue.
Public opinion polls in January 1994 showed crime overtaking the economy as the biggest perceived problem facing the nation. And for the first time, voters thought Democrats and Republicans could handle it equally well.
Since then, the President has signed into law some popular crime-fighting measures. These include a ban on assault weapons and a three-strikes-and-you're-out provision that imposes life sentences on criminals convicted of a Federal crime after two previous convictions.
The Republicans, who can read polls as well as anyone, did not challenge either the ban or the three-strikes proposal in their Contract With America, their 1994 campaign manifesto.
Nor did the contract directly challenge another major element of last year's anti-crime law -- Mr. Clinton's pledge to put 100,000 additional police officers on the street.
The contract's main thrust on crime was to build more prisons, make prisoners serve longer sentences, prevent criminals from getting off on technicalities and cut the prevention programs that Democrats had stuffed into last year's bill.
While there are deep philosophical differences between the parties over how to fight crime, Republicans in the House did not really object to the Democrats' desire to hire more police officers. Indeed, the contract called for "additional law enforcement," an acknowledgment that this was a good idea.
But they saw the President's pledge for 100,000 new officers as dishonest, saying the bill would not come close to paying for that many and would provide communities with only seed money for five years. They also argued that some communities did not need or want more officers, and that the legislation should have concentrated the new officers in high-crime areas. And they portrayed the prevention programs as wasteful social spending.
So the contract collapsed last year's money for police and prevention into a lump sum, or block grant, of $10 billion over five years for local communities to fight crime any way they deemed fit, including the hiring of more police officers.
Over the last two weeks, this provision became the most contentious in the new crime bill, eclipsing other divisive matters that had blocked agreement on crime legislation for nearly a decade. These included measures to allow officers to make searches without warrants and to speed up carrying out executions, in part by ordering Federal courts to defer to state courts.
The Republican changes brought protests from some liberals and some lawyers, who said the changes were a direct assault on fundamental civil liberties guaranteed by the Constitution. (The Republicans even voted down an amendment, proposed by the Democrats, that contained the exact language of the Fourth Amendment, which protects citizens from unlawful searches.)
But for the most part, the Republican changes sailed through the House. Even Mr. Clinton, who once taught constitutional law, did not put up a fuss.
The fact is that these constitutional safeguards are political losers with a public fed up with criminals getting off on technicalities and tired of waiting years for executions to be carried out. Being against them would put Mr. Clinton on the wrong, "old Democrat" side of crime.
He made his stand instead on the 100,000 new officers and, for the first time in his White House tenure, he pledged to use the veto against a specific piece of legislation. It was, after all, one of the most visible of his campaign promises to become law, and to retreat on it now would have been unthinkable.
"It's one of his few popular accomplishments," said a Democratic aide in Congress. "If he lost that it would be a major blow. The White House has probably already cut their commercials for '96 on the 100,000 cops."
Even Republicans concede, if backhandedly, that the veto threat on the police issue worked to the President's advantage.
"They run an Administration by survey research," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster. And the research shows that governors, mayors and voters believe that more police officers on the beat, along with keeping criminals in prison for their full sentences, is the most effective way to fight crime."
Since the November elections, the Administration has been searching for ways to reassert itself. The crime issue, which Mr. Clinton had turned to his advantage before, provides a logical opportunity.
"There was a feeling that the best way to differentiate himself from the opposition was to make positive pronouncements and to draw lines in the sand," said the Democratic aide. "There was a feeling that he hadn't done a particularly good job with either, and there has been pressure on him to pick a couple of battles."
While the Democrats lost the vote in the House on protecting money for the additional police officers, they had other reasons to rejoice: a vote on a separate amendment indicated that they had the numbers to block any attempt to override a veto.
Moreover, the Democrats appeared to have won the war of words. They were able to frame the debate so that it looked as if the Republicans were eliminating 100,000 police officers -- even though they believed their own bill would provide for more officers than the Clinton measure would if local governments chose to spend all of the money on additional police.
And the veto threat, strengthened by the strong support from House Democrats, also translated quickly into hints of accommodation from Republicans in the Senate, where the bills will be taken up next month.
The Senate seems likely to be more accommodating than the House anyway. Some Republican senators do not like block grants for the same reason that House Republicans once opposed them: the money can easily be diverted from its intended purpose.
But the politics could still prove tricky for Mr. Clinton. The Senate could eliminate money for the 100,000 police officers but send the President an otherwise tough anti-crime package in a single bill.
Mr. Blankley, the Gingrich spokesman, said it would be a bad idea for Mr. Clinton to veto such a measure.
"The way information gets communicated to a general audience is not in multiple paragraphs, but in snippets of headlines, and I don't think he and his party are currently positioned to win in that snippet-information process," Mr. Blankley said. "If he seems to be fighting the Republicans on crime, most people would correctly assume he's wrong. It's been a Republican issue for over 100 years. It's counterintuitive to think that the head of the Democratic Party is tougher."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "POINT BY POINT: The House Crime Bill: What's at Stake"
 
Victim Restitution Act
 Requires that victims of Federal crimes be compensated.
 
1994 CRIME LAW: Limited restitution to victims of sexual abuse and related Federal crimes, and to victims of Federal child pornography offenses.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Supports the Republican bill.
 
Exclusionary Rule Reform Act
 Expands "good faith" exception to allow courts to accept evidence at trial that was obtained without a search warrant, as long as the police believe they were complying with constitutional rules.
 
1994 CRIME LAW: No provision.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Opposes expansion of the good faith exception beyond the Supreme Court holding.
 
Death Penalty Appeals
 Limits the period of time in which death row inmates can file petitions for habeas corpus in Federal courts to challenge the constitutionality of their sentences. Makes the death penalty easier to impose by reducing the discretion of juries.
 
1994 CRIME LAW: Efforts to limit habeas corpus appeals to Federal courts were dropped because of fear that the controversial issue would have killed the overall crime bill.
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Supports limits on habeas corpus if linked to stronger protections of right to counsel than this bill provides.
 
Prisons
 Provides $10.5 billion over five years for new prison construction but tightens conditions on states receiving the money. Puts new limits on prisoner's lawsuits and court orders over-crowding suits. Includes a ban on exercise equipment that enhances fighting strength and curtails other amenities available to prisoners.
 
1994 CRIME LAW: Provided $7.9 billion for 1996-2000 for building prisons but imposed different and to some extent looser conditions on eligibility for the money.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Says the eligibility standards in the new legislation are so stringent that few states will be able to receive state prison funds, and to meet the standards many states will have to spend billions of their own dollars. Generally supports the provisions limiting abusive prisoner lawsuits.
 
Police and Prevention
 Grants for new community police officers and crime prevention programs folded into $10 billion in block grants.
 
1994 CRIME LAW: Provided $8.8 billion to put new police officer's on the nation's streets and $6.9 for crime prevention programs.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Opposes eliminating any crime prevention programs. President Clinton said block grant plan would undermine his pledge to put 100,000 more officers on the street and has threatened a veto.
 
Criminal Aliens
 Further speeds up deportation procedures for criminal aliens and expands the number of crimes for which an alien can be deported. Provides additional funds to reimburse states for incarcerting criminal aliens.
 
1994 CRIME LAW: Expedited deportation for aliens who are not lawful permanent residents. Provided $1.8 billion to reimburse states for incarceration of illegal criminal aliens.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Generally supports the Republican bill

HEADLINE: Skilled Asians Leaving U.S. For High-Tech Jobs at Home

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

 BODY:
Twenty-five years after coming to the United States from Taiwan, David Chiang had all the trappings of the American dream: a job as a jet engine engineer, three happy children and a home in the suburbs with a station wagon in the driveway.
But for all his achievements, he felt as if he was in a rut -- one of hundreds of engineers at General Electric Aircraft Engines vying for the few promotions that would pop up every now and then. 
 In the depths of white-collar anxiety, he took a trip to Taiwan two years ago and discovered that his once struggling country was pushing to create an aerospace industry of its own. As a Chinese speaker with impeccable high-tech credentials, he was the hottest commodity around.
Within seven months, he had put his brick colonial near Cincinnati on the market, packed up his family and returned to Taiwan -- this time on the management fast track at the Government-sponsored Center for Aviation and Space Technology.
"It's been great so far," said Mr. Chiang, who now supervises 12 engineers working on jet engine development. "Of course, there's no place like the States for living, but here, I have a good future and it's a warm feeling to know that you are working for your own country."
Mr. Chiang is part of a rising homeward flow of engineers, scientists and entrepreneurs, following an economic boom in the Far East that has transformed countries like India, Taiwan and Korea into high-tech powerhouses.
For years, the best and brightest of Asia flocked to the United States to pursue advanced degrees and jobs on the cutting edge of business, science and technology.
But with the American recession of the last four years and the development of high-technology industries in Asia rivaling the best of the West, a small but significant number of Asian-born professionals, from aerospace engineers in Los Angeles to financial analysts on Wall Street, have begun moving home.
They are part of a growing emigration that the Census Bureau now estimates at 195,000 foreign-born Americans each year -- the highest number since World War I.
The number parallels the surge in immigration and, demographers say, keenly reflects the fluidity of movement in the expanding global village, the way people move back and forth between countries.
Many of those returning to Asia, in fact, retain their American citizenship or their green cards as a way of keeping their global options open. They are, for all intents and purposes, neither here nor there forever.
The journey is not always smooth -- filled with homesickness and sometimes resentment from co-workers who see them as intruders. Nevertheless, from computer programmers in Bangalore, known as the Silicon Valley of India, to aerospace engineers in Taiwan's high-technology city, Hsinchu, the returning expatriates have found their homelands bursting with new enterprises and optimism.
In Taiwan, the high-tech migration is being called the "rencai huiliu," literally the "return flow of human talent." But for the thousands of American-trained scientists, weaned on late-night pizza at the computer center and shopping at the mall, it is simply called the reverse brain drain.
"It's not just Taiwan, but the whole of Asia is developing so fast," said Li Chen-ching, director of cultural affairs for the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office, which serves as Taiwan's embassy in the United States. "People know that the future is in the Far East."
When David Chiang left Taiwan in 1978 to study at the University of Cincinnati, there was not much opportunity in his native land for a young engineer with an advanced degree.
Taipei was still a steaming city known for cheap clothes and cut-rate electronics; the prestigious National Tsing Hua University was surrounded by rice paddies and rural villages.
A majority of his classmates left for the United States after graduation and few returned after receiving degrees in advanced fields like avionics and computer design.
Like many students who came to the United States, Mr. Chiang always wanted to return to be with his aging parents and have his children grow up among Chinese, although he knew there was no place he could put his advanced skills to work.
It was only two years ago that he realized how much his homeland had changed. Around his alma mater in Hsinchu, a sprawling new technology and industrial park had risen out of the fields. Scattered through the park were tennis courts, swimming pools, new condominiums with all the modern conveniences and even a bilingual school for the children of the returning engineers.
He got an interview with the Center for Aviation and Space Technology and on returning home, weighed his chances of advancing at General Electric against moving into management in Taiwan.
In Taiwan, he saw a new industry sprouting and sensed the opportunities before him. With all the aerospace cutbacks in the United States, he jumped at the chance to go home, even at a 30 percent pay cut.
"The best part is that we can spend all our weekends with my parents and my wife's parents," Mr. Chiang said.
The growth of opportunities in Asia has even attracted a small number of engineers and scientists from those who were born in Asia but grew up in the United States. They are far less emotionally attached to Asia than their parents' generation, but have been drawn home by the opportunities available to them.
Min Choi, a 32-year-old financing specialist from Astoria, came to the United States from Korea with his family in 1976, when he was 12. He went to high school in Flushing and got a degree in economics from Rutgers.
But after working as a commodity credit analyst for Lehman Brothers and an assistant manager for the Bank of Seoul in New York, he traded his American comforts for the harsh life of a "hoesawan," a Korean company man.
His parents were stunned at his decision to return, but ultimately relented and wished him well in his new position as an assistant manager in charge of international finance for Cheil Foods and Chemicals Inc., the largest food company in Korea.
Even with a 40 percent pay cut, he is happy with his decision. "Five to eight years down the line is where I'm looking," he said. "It's a great adventure, that's for sure."
What has been hardest for Mr. Choi is adapting to a society that is, in many ways, foreign to him. He quickly shed his flashy Wall Street cuff links, fancy ties and suspenders for plain dark business suits. He embraced the Korean corporate work schedule of six days a week, 12 hours a day with weekly late-night drinking binges with fellow executives. "I try to keep that to a minimum," he said. "They drink like we do in college -- drink till you drop."
Denny Ko, the president of a high-tech consulting and investment concern in Torrance, Calif., said that adapting to Asian business culture is difficult, even for those who grew up in Asia.
Mr. Ko was recruited three and a half years ago to start a national aerospace company, the Taiwan Aerospace Corporation. He seemed to be the perfect match -- he had grown up in Taiwan, had a doctorate in aeronautical engineering from the California Institute of Technology and had successfully formed several high-tech businesses in Taiwan and the United States.
But before the end of his first year on the job he began to understand how vast are the differences in culture between Taiwan and the United States.
Executives said nothing in meetings; debate was virtually unheard of. Business was often conducted in private, in contrast to the boisterous meetings of American business.
He also sensed a simmering resentment from co-workers that an outsider from America had been put in charge. After two years, his contract with Taiwan Aerospace expired and he headed home for Torrance.
"Even though you are Chinese and you speak Chinese and read Chinese, your work and social experience is all American," Mr. Ko said. "It just got to the point where I couldn't get anything done. It was a mess and I had to walk away."
The biggest problems in adapting to a new culture have been experienced by the children, some of whom do not speak their parents' native language.
Mr. Chiang said he was lucky that all his children spoke excellent Chinese. His two youngest, then 2 and 5, easily adapted to their new lives.
But his oldest daughter, who was then 11, was homesick for America and constantly asked about returning.
Mr. Chiang said he felt it would benefit his children to have grown up in both countries, but he was heartbroken to see his daughter so sad.
Then, several months after the move to Taiwan, a McDonald's restaurant opened 10 minutes from their home in Hsinchu.
For Mr. Chiang's daughter, it was a small but important link that seemed to say that Taiwan and America were not so distant after all.
"That was a real savior," he said. "I'm not a big fan, but they loved it."

HEADLINE: Rates Up Sharply In Mexico

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Responding to pressure from the United States, Mexico's central bank said today that it was raising already high short-term interest rates a further 10 percentage points, pushing the rate on some Government debts to 50 percent.
United States officials have insisted that Mexico tighten its credit substantially and reduce its money supply as part of the conditions of $20 billion in American assistance proposed by the Clinton Administration. 
 An official at the Mexican central bank said today that the decision to increase interest rates "arose from the negotiations between Mexico and the United States" continuing in Washington and the sharp drop in the value of the peso late last week.
Bank officials said the higher rates should help stem the flow of money out of Mexico and strengthen the badly weakened peso by making Government debt and other investments denominated in pesos more attractive to buyers.
The currency markets responded favorably to the central bank's move, and the peso rose to an exchange rate of 5.565 to the dollar, up from 5.725 to the dollar on Friday.
But Mexican stocks fell, with the benchmark index dropping 64.33 points, or 3.51 percent, to close at 1,766.14, a loss that reflected investors' concerns that higher interest rates would hurt company earnings.
Analysts reacted somewhat skeptically to the central bank's rate move, saying that while the higher rates might bolster the peso in the short run, they would hit Mexico's faltering banks hard. The banks' large portfolios of overdue loans will increase, analysts said, and credit will be so costly that bankers will see little new business.
"All we've seen so far has been very weak policy responses to a crisis that is a lot more fundamental," said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, an economist here. "This will have only a limited effect on the market, and the long-term outcome is not necessarily positive."
Mr. Ramirez de la O said the central bank might have raised interest rates today in an attempt to influence the negotiations in Washington over the details of the $20 billion in direct American help.
The intense discussion between American and Mexican finance officials that have been going on since Thursday resulted in a preliminary agreement by the Mexicans to sharply increase interest rates.
Along with the stricter Mexican fiscal and monetary policy, restrictions have been written into the proposed agreement by American negotiators that would make it extremely hard for the Mexican Government to start spending freely if economic and political conditions in the country worsened.
A spokesman for the United States Treasury said the two sides were making "good progress" at the talks led by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz, but could not say when an announcement would be made.
Mexico's state oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, reacted in measured terms today to a report from Washington that the United States was seeking fuller control over the flow of Mexican oil revenue as a condition for the economic help.
"The Government will keep at all times its unrestricted freedom to administer the resources from oil exports," a statement by Pemex said. "The United States Government could only have access to some of these funds on a contingency basis if there had been a prior case of Mexico failing to meet payment obligations."
Pemex did not confirm or deny the reported proposal to channel all oil-export revenue through the American Federal Reserve, but said that both it and the Mexican central bank would "have the use of the funds obtained from oil exports, with every freedom and with no restriction of any kind." It added that in any case, such arrangements were not new, and it called the possibility of a Mexican default on loan payments a "remote eventuality."
Economists and investors have many doubts about Mexico's economic recovery plan, but some of the most persistent arise from Mexico's lack of a viable exchange-rate policy for determining the value of the peso against the dollar. The Mexican Government has let the peso float freely since Dec. 21, and as a result the peso's value has shifted erratically. Before the devaluation, a peso was worth slightly less than 29 cents. At today's exchange rate of 5.565, it is worth a bit less than 18 cents.
In various documents, the Mexican central bank has said that it will continue to allow the peso's value to float. But that creates an uncertainty that has harmed Mexican markets, analysts said.
The central bank, while so far rejecting suggestions that Mexico establish an independent currency board to set the peso's value, is reported close to approving a mechanism that would index debt to the inflation rate. Chile has used a similar system for more than a decade.
A Mexican central bank official said the plan under discussion had "nothing to do with exchange-rate policy," and was only a measure to protect the principal in bank loans from being eroded by inflation. Economists here and in the United States, however, say that such a plan, if adopted, would in effect constitute a new exchange-rate policy.
Under the plan, the Mexican central bank would make regular, even daily, measurements of the rate of inflation. The principal of a loan would be adjusted to maintain the same inflation-adjusted level as before, relieving inflationary pressures to raise interest rates.
Thus, for example, if inflation were estimated to have risen 3 percent, the principal on a loan would also be increased 3 percent. There is a nominal increase in principal, but in real terms it remains constant.
But economists fear that by indexing inflation in this way, Mexico would have a harder time bringing rates back down. "It constitutes almost an incorporation of inflation into economic expectations," said Lawrence B. Goodman of Salomon Brothers in New York. "The implications could be terrible."

HEADLINE: Republicans Skeptical of Its Worth Would Like to Eliminate Education Department

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Terrel H. Bell was on the way to a State of the Union address by Ronald Reagan more than a decade ago when he received a lesson in relativity. His car phone rang and the President's chief of staff told Mr. Bell, who was the Secretary of Education, to turn back and head home.
Someone had realized that it was not the practice to have the entire Cabinet in one place because of the question of succession. "And I ranked dead last," Mr. Bell said. 
 As he watched the speech at home on television, Mr. Bell shared a joke with his wife. "I got sent home," he said. "But don't worry. By the time this is over, I might be President."
Since its creation under President Jimmy Carter in 1980, the Department of Education has had an awkward existence as a bureaucracy under constant fire. Republicans perceived it as a political payoff to the National Education Association, a huge union that historically -- and often energetically -- has thrown its support behind the Democrats.
Now, Speaker Newt Gingrich and a handful of other powerful Republicans have renewed the call to eliminate the department.
"People were always asking me if I thought we even needed the department," said William J. Bennett, an Education Secretary under President Reagan. "I often told them, 'No.' "
The department's primary duty is the distribution of about $30 billion a year in loans and grants through 240 programs. It also sets education policy guidlinees and goals and oversees college accrediting agencies. If the department is eliminated, its critics concede, many of its duties would have to be taken over by other agencies.
Mr. Reagan called for the department's elimination before he took office in 1982. And other politicians, complaining about bloated bureaucracies and Federal meddling, have repeated the call since then.
"When we got here, this department had suffered 12 years of neglect," said Madeleine M. Kunin, the Deputy Secretary for Education. "I wouldn't say benign neglect. It was really very tough neglect."
Files were jammed in cluttered corners. The computer system had hardly been updated in two decades. The loan program that is at the center of the department's duties was a paradigm of bureaucratic mismanagement because of soaring student loan defaults. Conservatives assailed the way the agency carried out its civil rights duties, contending that it followed a liberal agenda.
Even the department's building -- now undergoing a $60 million overhaul -- was a mess, full of asbestos and aged wiring. Morale was so bad, went one story making the rounds, that Mr. Bennett refused to ride the elevators with bureaucrats for fear of catching their malaise.
This week, Representative Steve Gunderson, Republican of Wisconsin, introduced legislation to merge the Departments of Labor and Education. Such a move would eliminate Education's separate Cabinet rank, bring schools and job training under one department and the United States in line with scores of other countries.
Those who would like to see the department eliminated have two former Education Secretaries on their side, Mr. Bennett and Lamar Alexander, a former Tennessee Governor who was head of the department under President George Bush.
In testimony before the House Economic and Educational Opportunities Committee on Jan. 26, Mr. Bennett and Mr. Alexander called for all the important programs handled by the department to be distributed among various agencies.
"Inasmuch as adoption of our substantive recommendations would leave the Department of Education with nothing to do," they said in their joint testimony, "there would be no need to retain it."
Yet eliminating the department would send the wrong message, most education specialists say. Coming at a time of educational crises and when industry needs a well-trained, literate work force, a Federal role is crucial, these experts say, even if it is largely symbolic.
The current Education Secretary, Richard W. Riley, a soft-spoken former Governor of South Carolina who backs giving the states control over policy and spending, has stayed largely outside the debate. But he chafes at its timing.
"I didn't come here to fight for the bureaucracy," he said. "That's not my nature. But it hits me that to do away with the Department of Education at this particular moment in history would be like doing away with the Department of the Army in the middle of World War II."
It would also be like swatting at a fly on the back of Federal bureaucracy. The Education Department spends about one-tenth of what the Department of Health and Human Services or the Pentagon spends and half of what goes to the Agriculture Department each year. Of all Cabinet departments, it has the smallest staff by far, about 5,000, compared with more than 800,000 in the Defense Department and about 100,000 in the Agriculture Department.
Though nearly 70 million Americans are involved in education and the nation as a whole spends about $500 billion a year on it, the Federal Government contributes only about 8 percent. Most school money comes from local property taxes.
Under Mr. Riley, the department has restructured the loan process, backing direct loans managed by the Government in a program that has drawn the ire of the banking industry and conservatives who do not trust the Federal bureaucracy to manage so large a task.
Smaller programs are also under assault, since over the years Congress has hidden its share of pork in the Education Department. For instance, more than a dozen programs that benefit only Hawaii. And at least one program, which uses the arts as therapy with disabled children, is the brainchild and namesake of the Kennedy family.
"We have to cut back," acknowledged Marshall Smith, an Under Secretary of Education. "But what we are cutting back is what Congress put in."
But Mr. Bell, the former Education Secretary, fears that eliminating the department would give states too much latitude in an area that they have yet to prove themselves. "We talk about giving more responsibility to the states and I think we should," he said. "But we shouldn't do it because of their record in education. It's been terrible."
Increasingly, guidance -- not micro-management -- has become the department's central theme. The broadest education legislation passed in years, the Goals 2000 program, was a Republican idea first backed by President Bush but passed only last year. It specifically stays out of the business of dictating policy, relying instead on lump sums, or block grants, to states as they work toward upgrading education levels to meet voluntary achievement standards in everything from music to math.
The department's new strategic plan, a 28-page document intended to map the future, repeatedly emphasizes the need for states to make their own decisions.
"The tendency is always to do things the way they have been done," Mr. Smith said. That, he adds, has led to an odd dichotomy at the Federal level. "What we need now is to tell people to be innovative," he said. Under Goals 2000, he added, that mandate "comes with the force of law."
"We are legislating flexibility," Mr. Smith said. "There is something crazy about that, I know. But if you deal with people used to regulations you need to do more than just do away with the regulations."
But changing old patterns is not easy. And it is not entirely the business of the Education Department since, in fact, many Federal programs already fall to other agencies.
The Head Start program for pre-schoolers, for instance, is operated by the Department of Health and Human Services; the Department of Defense runs schools on military bases; the Department of the Interior deals with education on Indian reservations, and the Department of Energy runs technology programs.
Science projects usually fall to the National Science Foundation and the Labor Department has long had purview over job training programs, though it increasingly shares that mandate with the Department of Education. The Commerce Department finances technology training programs. And student health issues fall to the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.
Representative Bill Goodling, the Pennsylvania Republican who heads the House Committee on Education and Labor, believes that pulling these stray strands together can only help. To that end, he backs the Gunderson proposal to merge the Labor and Education Departments. And he has another idea, too. "Probably adding Health and Human Services to that group would also make some sense."
Then again, God is in the details.
"I honestly don't know how you get rid of the department," said Leo Kornfeld, a former corporate chief executive who runs the Education Department's direct loan program. "I mean, how do you do it? All this stuff has to go somewhere."

 IN NEW BRAIN DRAIN, ASIANS LEAVE U.S.
Twenty-five years after coming to the United States from Taiwan, David Chiang had all the trappings of the American dream: a job as a jet engine engineer, three happy children and a home in the suburbs with a station wagon in the driveway. But he felt as if he was in a rut. And then, on a trip to Taiwan two years ago, he discovered that the country was pushing to create its own aerospace industry. Within seven months, he returned to Taiwan -- on a government-sponsored management fast track. A1.

WHITMAN BUDGET IS CRITICIZED
Some Republicans in the legislative majority are saying privately that the small amount of money to be raised by a half-dozen fee increases, penalties and new taxes in Gov. And as the Legislature begins hearings on budget issues this week, most of the fees and taxes appear dead on arrival. B5.
'LITTLE TERRORS' NOW DOGS OF THE DAY
Until the NBC television comedy "Frasier," life was rurally sweet for Catherine Brown. She and her husband were raising their 10 Jack Russell terriers away from the glare of a nosy world. Now, the phone rings and rings, letters pour in and Ms. Brown gets quoted in supermarket tabloids. Our Towns, B5.

HEADLINE: In Tough Neighborhood, Students Show Courage

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
The walk to school is not easy for any of the children at Junior High School 263 in Brownsville, Brooklyn.
For some, the difficulty begins with the first step from bed, as 12-year-olds pick their way through decrepit apartments, hallways littered with crack vials and buildings riddled with bullet holes. For the children who live in the nearby homeless shelter, the walk is one more trip through one more neighborhood, the latest steps in their odyssey of displacement. 
 Even the many students blessed with dedicated parents have to travel perilous streets to get to the squat brick school that sits surrounded by some of the city's most troubled public housing projects.
"I don't think you could get a more challenging neighborhood for a school child to have to deal with," said Margo Spielberg, the principal at J.H.S. 263. "To come to school, to thrive, it's the truest test of endurance and strength."
The test asks a lot, perhaps too much, demanding that junior high school students find within themselves not only the strength to make the ordinary choices of a child -- difficult enough -- but also to overcome the extraordinary failings of those around them.
Ivy Pearson, 12, walks through the streets of Brownsville every morning, past the grown men who whistle at her and the fourth graders who already hang around on the corners with no intention of going to school.
"It doesn't matter how old you are -- courage can be needed at any age," said Ivy, a sixth grader. "And you can come up with that courage."
It is tough talk, but it is a language of personal responsibility that fills the classrooms of J.H.S. 263. The students speak with an unflinching equanimity about the facts of life in Brownsville, and there is no great reservoir of empathy toward those who cannot seem to make it to school and make something of their time there.
"Whatever is wrong, the kids are supposed to go to school," said Benny Gary, 13, who lives in the Marcus Garvey Houses. "They should be able to do it."
It is, of course, the children who do not brave the daily walk to school who most frequently wind up in the newspaper headlines. Teachers in the neighborhood's schools have grown wearily accustomed to seeing their students on television broadcasts about the latest notorious violent crime.
Last December, three teen-agers, all former students at J.H.S. 263, were arrested and charged with murder. The police have said the three were accomplices in the failed, fatal holdup of a Brooklyn bicycle store that ended with a 26-year-old New York City police officer dead.
The particulars of the lives of the teen-agers were hardly startling: raised in the Brownsville Houses with no fathers in the household, trips to Family Court, neglect, economic hardship and truancy.
What was held out to them at the junior high school on Chester Street, modest but real, was not seized.
"If being from the Brownsville Houses is their excuse, it's not enough," Shatia Simmons, 12, said of the arrested teen-agers. "I've been here all my life. And trust me, I have faced it all."
Shatia lives in the Van Dyke Houses. She said she knows about gangs and killings, about the lethal arbitrariness that can interrupt the life of a seventh grader.
"It can be bad," she said. "People can come up to you thinking you are somebody else, and they can try and stab you. Sometimes, you wish you could just get your mind blank. But I keep coming. Last year, I didn't even know how to spell dictionary. I was the laughingstock of the sixth grade. Now, my books are filled with work."
And so day after day, imperfect morning after imperfect morning, hundreds of students at J.H.S. 263, by whatever means necessary, come up with the required courage.
Teachers at the school, which was termed "wild" by the principal when she took it over in 1990, used to have to carry around their own doorknobs to get into classrooms that had been vandalized. But now the school has recruited young, dedicated teachers and retained its most capable veteran staff members.
There is a new library and two computer labs. Attendance averages 85 percent, no tiny triumph given that a full quarter of students failed to turn up on any given day several years ago. Ms. Spielberg has divided the more than 600 students into four "mini-schools" to foster order and more focused teaching.
The school isn't idyllic. Children are checked for weapons daily. Fights occur; 13-year-olds wind up arrested or pregnant. But reading levels are up, and the district school board is considering expanding J.H.S. 263 to include fifth graders.
"We call it the renaissance," said Martin Brodsky, an assistant principal. "But it's the school that has undergone the renaissance, not the kids. The kids have always been there for us to work with."
One day recently, a dozen of those children gathered to talk about their strong feeling that their neighborhood should not serve as justification for a surrender to violence or defeat.
"To me, Brownsville is not a bad place," said Lakesha Perry, 13. "I've been in worse. It's a place you just have to work harder to do what you want to do. But you can make up your mind what it is you want to do. You can do that."
Almost none of the dozen students had both parents in their homes. All had come to J.H.S. 263 afraid of what they would encounter. Each said they felt fear on their way to and from the building, set against the looming towers of the Langston Hughes Houses. But their conviction that the school offered real rewards was fierce, their belief that children their age could be capable of deciding whether to go to school or to go bad was firm.
"Every day you get up and basically hope you see another day," said Shawn Gladden, 13. "I didn't know what I would find at this school. But this school is everything I was looking for."

HEADLINE: Gambling Helps Tribe Invest In Education and the Future

SERIES: Hitting the Jackpot: Casino Money and the Pequots - Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STONINGTON, Conn.

 BODY:
In July 1990, Margaret Field, headmaster of the Pine Point School left the campus and drove north with the school's banker in tow, to sing the praises of private education to leaders of the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe in Ledyard.
The Pequots were on the verge of striking it rich in the casino business, and the headmaster was hoping to build a connection. 
 Her school was in trouble: enrollment had dropped during the recession, and pledges to pay for a new $1.5 million gymnasium and arts building were not coming in. Three times during the previous school year, members of the board of trustees had dipped into their own pockets to pay faculty salaries.
Ms. Field left that day thinking that she had made a good impression on the seven-member tribal council.
And she was right. The seed planted that day five years ago has borne fruit, for both the struggling private school and the Pequots, owners of Foxwoods, now the most profitable casino in the nation.
Today, one in six students in the lower grades at Pine Point are Pequots -- their entire $9,200 tuition paid for by the tribe. The tribe has its own private Pine Point bus, which barrels up through the woods along Barnes Road to the secluded campus daily. A Pequot sits on the board of trustees. A Pequot, Alan Pearson Jr., has pledged to donate two fully loaded personal computer systems every year until his 7-year-old son, Matthew, graduates in eight years.
And what did the Pequots get in return? Pine Point's 7-to-1 student-teacher ratio is a third that of the local public schools. The suburban private school's curriculum now includes regular programs of American Indian dancers and story tellers.
Less quantifiable but quite crucial, tribal members say, is the chance to be part of the region's network of old-school ties. In the hallways of Pine Point, these parents say, where overstated grunge flannel and Doc Martens boots mix side by side with soft pastel sweater sets, the future of the region is being written. And the Pequots, for perhaps the first time in their history, are insiders.
"A lot of these kids are going to be the next selectmen, the next mayors," said Joey Carter, who heads up public relations for the Pequots, and who has a son, Jared, in the fifth grade at Pine Point. "They're going to understand the Pequots because half of them will have gone to school together."
Tribal officials say that what is happening at Pine Point is also mirrored across a whole spectrum of areas where the Pequots are reaching out beyond the walls of their casino, exploring their role in the community -- economically and culturally, as Indians and as Connecticut residents.
Foxwoods, which earned an estimated $800 million to $900 million last year before expenses, is probably at its pinnacle, they say, its regional monopoly as the only casino in New England almost over. Other tribes are preparing to start casinos and Gov. John G. Rowland has said he is open to the idea of legalizing gambling off reservation lands, which could open the state to many interested parties, including Donald Trump. Diversifying the tribe's economic base will mean reaching out farther still.
"You had tremendous early success and now the question becomes what do you do with that and how does that play out over time?" said A. Searle Field, who was former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s chief of staff until he was hired last year by the Pequots to manage the tribe's noncasino investments. "The tribe has not reached a finish line," Mr. Field said.
 
Charity and Investing
Quick Decisions By Tribal Council
One of the extraordinary advantages the Pequots have is their small size, which eliminates the need for a bureaucracy. They govern themselves with a seven-member tribal council that has been given the power to set policy and make decisions quickly.
Mr. Carter, the tribal spokesman, heard, for example, about a playground near the reservation that was in such disrepair that it could not be used by local children. It seemed like a good cause, he said, so he took it to his council colleagues. He is in the construction business and swiftly calculated how many cubic yards of concrete and gravel would be needed, how many trucks to haul it, and how much labor and how long it would take. The council took about five minutes to say yes, Mr. Carter said. Dump trucks were rolling the next day.
Such efforts have not always been warmly received. Local critics routinely denounce the Pequots as modern-day imperialists, out to colonize and buy up every square inch of land they can.
"They think that putting land into trust is a God-given right," said one nearby town official who would not give his name because he said he feared aggravating already tense relations between the tribe and the town.
Even the tribe's high-profile charity work is seen by such critics as grandstanding public relations.
Complain or not, the Pequots have become a source of major capital investment in Connecticut as they have reached out beyond their borders. The targets of their charity and investment are a real mix, and while council members will not go into great detail in explaining their choices, tribe members say they are open to all comers and willing to consider any reasonable pitch.
Last year, the little tribe gave $10 million to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington for a new American Indian building -- the single biggest contribution ever to the museum. The Special Olympics World Games, to be held in New Haven this summer, got $2 million.
The tribe recently rescued a local minor-league baseball team, the Norwich Navigators, by contributing $500,000 to buy the stadium. Members say that with Foxwoods, the tribe is in the tourist business, and as a policy they try to bolster other local attractions.
The Democratic National Committee received $500,000, and the Old Mystic Baptist Church got $50,000.
When it comes to investments, land has been the focus. In North Stonington, a town adjoining Ledyard, the Pequots were the town's second largest property tax payer in 1993 and have increased their holdings since then, including a silica mine on 315 acres, bought last year.
In Groton, individual tribe members, including Richard Hayward, the tribal chairman, have bought homes and commercial properties. Mr. Hayward, who declined to be interviewed, has invested more than $1 million in the town, including two adjoining residential properties on the waterfront for $920,000 in 1993, according to town records.
Last month, the tribe bought two manufacturing sites, including a printing-press plant in North Stonington, and an industrial parcel previously owned by the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton. Specific plans for those sites have yet to be announced. Earlier this month, the tribe paid $1.4 million for a historic colonial restaurant and inn, called Randall's Ordinary, set on 30 acres in North Stonington.
Mr. Field, charged with developing a diversification plan for the tribe, said that the Pequot investment schedule would be largely focused in Connecticut and that in five years the tribe hopes to be in a position to weather any storm, even if the casino is "not delivering," as Mr. Field put it. High-tech companies are one area of particularly keen tribal council interest, he said.
And things may happen rapidly when they break. "Economic diversification, though in its infancy, can move relatively rapidly, once decisions are made," Mr. Field said.
 
Spending on Education
Student Expenses Paid by the Tribe
But nothing, the Pequots say, takes a higher priority than education. The tribe will pay all members' expenses, from private kindergarten to studies for a Ph.D., law or medical school.
And the inducements have worked. More than a third of the tribe's 140 school-age children are now enrolled in private schools and academies around the region, from the Williams School to the Norwich Free Academy and St. Thomas More, and about a third of the adult tribe members are attending college.
"The future of this tribe is going to be education," said Mr. Pearson, a supervisor at the casino whose son Matthew attends Pine Point. "If we cannot give them the best that we can give them, then we shouldn't be allowed to exist."
The story of Pine Point -- a kindergarten through ninth-grade school that routinely sends graduates to places like Choate, Loomis Chaffee and St. George's in Newport, R.I. -- illustrates what can happen when that kind of determination is backed by immense financial clout.
Although the 17 Pequot students here represent only about 7 percent of the Pine Point student body of 254, the impact of Pequot parents like Mr. Pearson is considerable.
Beyond his own contribution of computer equipment, Mr. Pearson has challenged other tribal parents to match his largesse, and plans to petition the Pequot tribal council to underwrite a $250,000 capital expansion of the school's science and technology lab. He's confident they will go along.
Many Pequots say having the option of a private education has made a huge difference. Sandee Kirchner said she believed that her son, Carl, who started in public school before switching to Pine Point, had been "slipping through the cracks."
"He had 28 kids in his class and one teacher and an aide for half an hour out of the day," Mrs. Kirchner said. "They didn't even know he was there."
Tensions with the public schools in Ledyard have also worsened, tribe members say, as anti-tribe sentiment over land acquisitions and envy have boiled through local towns.
"When you have a choice of having your child either get beat up or talked down to or ignored, and the choice of putting them in an environment where they're treated like other children and they are encouraged to participate, which environment would you put your child in?" said Judy Bell, a tribe member who has two grandchildren at Pine Point and another on a waiting list. "We have a choice now -- years ago there was no choice."
Pine Point, founded in 1948 by a group of local families, is a school where every student of both sexes takes dance every year, and where there is an emphasis on self-expression and art. The curriculum is integrated across every subject, per the teachings of John Coe, the British educational theorist. If the subject in history is ancient Egypt, for example, the students will likely construct pyramids in art class.
It is a school with its own 24-foot boat, which the ninth graders use to study the ecology of Long Island Sound for their science class, and where the winning recitation at a recent poetry contest was Sir Walter Scott's "Lochinvar."
It is a place of great exuberance, where a life-sized papier-mache man, his arms thrown wide, hangs upside down from the front entry ceiling, his long black hair hanging down, his mouth formed into the perfect round O of a shriek -- there just to make you think.
Administrators here say programs in arts, music and dance were already borrowing from American Indian themes before the first tribal enrollment in the school and will do so more in the future, with the Pequots as full partners. Indeed, tribal parents are considered an important curriculum resource.
"They're always asking me questions, can I get us some information or get us in contact with somebody," said Mrs. Kirchner, who married into the tribe and has no Indian heritage. "They wanted to know about the harvest," she said. "That was their latest thing."
Sometimes the Pequots learn about themselves at Pine Point. Tom and Delia Christensen, for example, who moved here from Utah last year to rejoin the Pequot tribe, and the Pearsons, who moved back from Florida two years ago, knew few relatives For them, Pine Point is a place of socialization. The Christensens said that the idea of all-expenses-paid private education was one of the reasons they moved back to the reservation and that Pine Point, in particular, is one of the reasons they would never consider leaving.
 
Forging a Link
How Pequots Join Behind a School
The Pine Point-Pequot connection did not just happen.
Governor Weicker was running for governor in 1990, and the man he later hired as his chief of staff, Mr. Field, now the Pequot investment administrator, was a past president of the Pine Point board of trustees, and a boyhood friend of the Pequot tribal chairman, Mr. Hayward.
Mr. Field said he steered the Pequots toward Pine Point in the interests of the school where he had sent his own children, but also for the tribe's benefit. Mostly white schools like Pine Point were coming under increasing pressure to increase minority enrollment, and here, right in Pine Point's backyard, was a minority group with huge economic potential as well. At the same time, Mr. Field's boss, Mr. Weicker, was pushing a voluntary integration plan in the public schools.
"We were making sure Pine Point didn't become a magnet for white flight," Mr. Field said. "It made sense to reach out to a group that was developing some prosperity but was looking for some quality."
Tribal policies also changed. Under the new tribal rules passed by the council over the last few years, profit-sharing from the casino is directly linked, on a point system, to one's educational attainment.
Pine Point's current headmaster, Barry Bedrick, said the bottom line was that in the 1990's Pine Point could no longer be the closeted, low-profile little school that it had been for half a century. Like the Pequots, the school had to evolve.
"Schools have changed, and this one particularly, has grown up," he said. Before the school's financial crisis, Mr. Bedrick added, "the energy went entirely into the education of the kids in the classroom, and at some point the school had to figure out that we had to do more than that -- have a soundly run business, market itself, reach out to new constituencies -- and not just be an insular place where kids could get a nice education."
 
Higher Education
Special Programs Tied to University
In a classroom on the Groton campus of the University of New Haven, 14 adult Pequots -- or nearly one in 10 in the tribe -- began work this month on an education program that will award them, in two years, a degree unlike any other. The Pequots helped the school create the program and endowed it as a new department of tribal management.
The degrees will be, in their core curriculum, identical to the standard associate degrees in business offered by the university. In place of all cultural studies, however -- in music and philosophy in particular -- American Indian themes will be supplanted. The goal is to have a whole cadre of trained Pequot managers who can take over various tribal business affairs with maximum sensitivity and conformity to American Indian customs.
"It's designed to take a group of individuals through a two-year program as a team, on projects together," said Douglas Johnson. Mr. Johnson is acting president of the the tribe's casino management school, the Pequot Academy, which spawned the new University of New Haven program. The casino academy, with a faculty of eight and a capacity of 1,400 students per term, is geared solely to the casino and is open to all employees. The New Haven program is just for Pequots.
But wealth gives people more choices. A fierce debate has been building within the Pequot tribe about the future direction of its education policies. Should the tribe continue to send its children to established schools like Pine Point? Or should it charter its own school on the reservation, with its own handmade curriculum like the school in Groton?
Tribe members like Mr. Carter are insistent that the Pequots, even if they can afford it, must continue to mix with the outside world and not become insular or inward looking. For many Indian tribes, he argues, that has been a recipe for failure.
"A lot of the reservations in the Midwest, people don't leave there -- 90 years and they've never been off the reservation," he said. "It's very difficult to try to adapt with someone and try to make a business deal if you don't really know who they are."
Other tribe members, like Mrs. Bell, are just as vehement in supporting the idea of a Pequot private school. "The tribe has, right now I feel, an obligation to invest in our children, from the little ones on up and to provide the best education they can even it is creating a new school system on the reservation," she said.
Bruce A. Kirchner, a senior vice president at the casino and a member of the Pine Point board, said that he believes a Pequot Prep of some sort on the reservation will happen and that a decision will have to be made about his two young sons in time. He said he worries how it could divide the tribe and is not certain what he would do.
"I don't know," he said. "We're very loyal to Pine Point."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
For Buffett wannabes, mixed views of his latest strategy.

BYLINE: By Saul Hansell 

 BODY:
THE periodic disclosure of new holdings by the Omaha billionaire Warren E. Buffett is as eagerly awaited by some investors as the new spring styles in Paris are by the fashion conscious. With well-timed picks in such companies as Coca-Cola and Capital Cities/ABC, Mr. Buffett has racked up an enviable long-term record.
So it was no surprise last week that there was keen interest in the shares of American Express and the PNC Bank Corporation, in which Mr. Buffett's company, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., said it had large holdings. Both stocks surged on heavy volume on Tuesday, when the holdings were disclosed. 
 Mr. Buffett's style, of course, is to be contrarian, buying good companies with solid managements when they are out of favor. So would a true Buffett wannabe, trying to emulate the master's no-nonsense approach, buy shares in a company after Buffett No. 1 had disclosed his holding, driving up the price?
One source of confidence for investors is that the current prices of both stocks are probably not that much higher than what Mr. Buffett paid, although it is difficult to tell exactly when he bought his shares and at what prices.
American Express disclosed last week that 42 percent of the 48.5 million shares that Mr. Buffett holds -- a 9.8 percent stake -- were purchased this year. That means he paid between $29.25 and $32.375 for them, not too much less than Friday's close of $33.75, up 87.5 cents.
In the case of PNC, the Pittsburgh bank, all that is known is that Mr. Buffett now owns 19.5 million shares, an 8.3 percent stake, much of which was bought in 1994. PNC's stock closed Friday at $24.875, about halfway between its high and low of last year. The shares hovered around $30 for the first half of last year after rising from a trough of $8 in 1990 that was caused by a bundle of bad real-estate loans. But the stock sank as low as $21.50 in October after the company disclosed that it had made an enormous -- and, in retrospect, wrongheaded -- bet on interest rates that would lock it into low yields on investments for two years.
Rumors of Mr. Buffett's interest in PNC predate its most recent problems, so his investment could well be underwater now, although he has been known to buy more shares of companies he likes when they run into short-term trouble.
What of the companies themselves? Both have well regarded senior managements, who are devoted to ever more stingy bouts of cost-cutting, a quality much admired by Mr. Buffett, who named his corporate plane the "Indefensible."
Yet Wall Street analysts, whose advice Mr. Buffett often disdains, are split on these companies. Most are bullish on American Express, which has mostly recovered from credit losses and a restructuring that shed its investment banking businesses.
David Hilder of Morgan Stanley, for example, rates American Express a strong buy, estimating that the stock will shoot to $40 over the next year. He argues that the company's growth will be driven by new products, a plethora of niche credit cards and a new card for purchasing managers.
But many analysts are shying away from PNC; several have published "sell" ratings on the stock, which is unusual on perennially bullish Wall Street.
One PNC bear is Sally Pope Davis of Goldman, Sachs, who argues not only that the bank's ill-fated investments will hurt earnings, but also that those earnings are artificially inflated. That's because PNC is not adding new money into its loan loss reserve as it makes new loans, a situation that it will not be able to maintain.
So what is a prospective Mini-Buffett to do? There seems to be no harm in buying the shares of American Express; Mr. Buffett said he was asking the Government for permission to buy more. But that company is already trading at an eight-year high.
The true long-term contrarian, then, may favor PNC. It is out of favor and well off its highs, for one. Its problems have apparently been fully disclosed and will not get worse. Moreover, even Ms. Pope Davis sees long-term value in the bank's large and expanding operations in mortgages and money management, two fields that are generally more lucrative than basic banking.
One warning, however: one of Mr. Buffett's most disastrous picks was a huge position in PNC's Pittsburgh neighbor, USAir.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Finding Help to Regain Self-Sufficiency

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
She had a baby girl last summer, but J. Sellers felt no joy. She was just 22, recovering from an anguished childhood and finding that maturity brought its own misery.
"I didn't want to see her or hold her," she said of the infant. "I was all wrapped up in my problems, and I couldn't think about anything else." 
 At the time, Miss Sellers was being evicted from an illegal basement apartment in Brooklyn. Unemployed and estranged from the baby's father, she had no place to go. Her isolation was cripplingly complete.
When she was 12, Miss Sellers said, she was sexually abused. She spent the next three years in foster care, but her foster parents had little time for her. She was placed in a psychiatric hospital for several months, an experience that she said was horrific.
"I wasn't crazy, but they were treating me like it," she said softly. "They really put me through the works."
Her only solace during those years was the journal she kept, which helped make some sense of her suffering. She still carries a poem she wrote at 12, simple words of hopelessness:
Can't call home my own, when I got no place to stay.
Can't call money mine, when I have to give it away.
Can't think, my mind blanked out.
Can't scream or even shout.
She fell in love at 17 and hoped to move in with her boyfriend's family. But they resisted, so the pair spent several months on the street.
"We would ride the subway all night long, or sleep in a park," she said. "I wasn't that scared, because he was with me."
Despite her hardship, Miss Sellers finished high school and received an associate's degree in human services from La Guardia Community College. She had a son in 1991 and continued studying and working part time. But in 1993, her boyfriend was shot and killed. Suddenly, she found herself with nothing again.
She had lost her job because of government cutbacks and could not find another. She and her son depended on welfare checks, and when her daughter was born, Miss Sellers was barely getting by.
While she was in the hospital, a social worker told her about the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, an agency supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. For 83 years, the fund has helped charities assist the city's poor, sick, elderly and disabled.
With her eviction imminent, Miss Sellers went to the bureau's East New York Family Center, where counselors help families handle the stress of poverty. A caseworker, Marcia Young, helped her sort through her problems and set priorities.
"She helped me focus on one thing at a time," Miss Sellers said during a visit to the center, as her children played quietly at her feet. "She really listens to me, and I can count on her."
While Miss Sellers stayed with friends, Ms. Young helped her search for housing. In December, she moved into an apartment in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx. She has decorated the walls with her diplomas and awards, and while it is not her dream home, she is content.
"I'm happy to have a roof over my head," she said.
Ms. Young helped Miss Sellers apply for city-run day care, and her children should be placed in a program soon. At that point, she will devote her energy to job hunting. She hopes to be a counselor for teen-agers, using personal experience as a guide. But she will settle for anything that pays more than minimum wage.
"All I want is to be self-sufficient," she said. "I'd like to go back to school someday, but I can't think about that yet."
Meanwhile, Miss Sellers is lavishing affection on her children, playing with them for hours each day and making sure they feel loved. She writes daily in her journal, a tattered notebook that she carries everywhere. And she practices her counseling skills on neighbors, who seek her out when they need advice.
"They listen to all I've been through, and they can't believe I'm still here," she said. "If I can make it, they can, too."

HEADLINE: The Pitfalls of a Balanced Budget

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The unemployment rate, which peaked at 7.7 percent after the last recession, could have reached 9 percent if a balanced budget had been required, Government and private economists estimate. And a laid-off worker who collected $12,000 in unemployment pay might have received only $7,000 or so.
Such estimates of the potential economic impact are not emphasized very much, however, in the debate over the balanced budget amendment. So far, the battle has focused on its value as a tool to shrink government or to discipline spending. But if the amendment is enacted, the side effect would be huge: a system that has softened recessions since the 1930's would be dismantled. 
 "There are risks associated with a balanced budget, and I don't think anyone should deny them," said William Hoagland, the Republican staff director for the Senate Budget Committee. "Nevertheless, the debate on the floor has been dominated by what we must do to get the budget in balance, not what the risks of a balanced budget amendment might be."
Mr. Hoagland expressed surprise that the biggest risk -- deeper, more painful recessions -- had not figured significantly in the debate, although Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, had called attention to this risk in several floor speeches. "The reason must be that the advocates of a balanced budget see the benefits to the economy as far outweighing the negatives associated with cyclical downturns," Mr. Hoagland said. "That must be what is going on."
No benefit seems to hold more sway than the view that the amendment would shrink the Federal Government by restricting its power to tax and to spend. A dollar not collected and spent by the Government is a dollar left in the hands of the private sector. And the private sector invariably invests money more efficiently than the Government, this view holds.
"The people have spoken clearly that government is too big and we need to do something about it," said Robert Hall, a Stanford University economist who favors smaller government. "The problem is that the balanced budget amendment is a heavy-handed solution and risky."
The biggest risk is to the nation's "automatic stabilizers," which have made recessions less severe than they were in the century before World War II. The stabilizers, an outgrowth of Keynesian economics, work this way: When the economy weakens, outlays automatically rise for unemployment pay, food stamps, welfare and Medicaid. Simultaneously, as incomes fall, so do corporate and individual income tax payments. Both elements make more money available for spending, thus helping to pull the economy out of its slump.
The problem, of course, is that the stabilizers make the deficit shoot up -- by roughly $65 billion as a result of the 1990-1991 recession, according to the Treasury Department. Under the balanced budget amendment, Congress and the Administration would be required to get the budget quickly back into balance, through spending cuts, higher tax rates, or a combination of the two -- perhaps even in the midst of a recession.
"The Government would become, almost inevitably, a destabilizer of the economy rather than a stabilizer," said Joseph Stiglitz, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Many economists share that view.
Absent the stabilizers, every 73-cent drop in national income in the last recession would have become a $1 drop, said Bradford DeLong, deputy assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who as a Harvard economist studied this dynamic and recently updated his research. Of the 27 cents in cushioning, 20 cents came from falling tax revenue and 7 cents from the higher spending.
Economists outside the Government offer similar estimates. Ray Fair of Yale University, for example, said for every $10 billion decline in national income during a recession, the deficit rises by $2 billion, as the stabilizers kick in with their higher spending and lower tax revenue.
"We ought not to give up the stabilizers," Professor Fair said. "That would be very Draconian."
Nearly every economist agrees that the American economy requires, if not stabilizers, some substitute method for offsetting recessions in an era of balanced budgets. And those who favor the amendment are no exception.
"It would be a disaster to lose the stabilizers," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, who endorses the amendment as a necessary step if the nation is to afford the high cost of Social Security and Medicare for the baby boom generation, which reaches retirement age early in the next century.
Mr. Bergsten notes that the amendment, as now worded, would permit Congress to bring back the stabilizers by a three-fifths vote in both houses. The vote would permit the necessary deficit spending to finance the stabilizers.
While a three-fifths vote is a big hurdle, Mr. Bergsten and others argue that Congress would get used to authorizing the necessary deficits during recessions. Nevertheless, he would prefer a different solution. Once through the painful process of balancing the budget by 2002, as required by the amendment, then the Government should run budget surpluses in years of strong economic growth and full employment, Mr. Bergsten said.
The surpluses would cover the rising costs of the stabilizers during recessions. "You could go down to a balanced budget in the hard years, and still give the economy a little stimulus," he said.
The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that the surplus needed to pay for the stabilizers during a recession as severe as that of 1981-1982, the worst since World War II, would be 1 percent of the national income during robust periods of full employment, and perhaps as much as 1.5 percent.
That would mean an annual surplus in today's dollars of $70 billion to $100 billion, rather than the nearly $200 billion of so in annual deficits expected under current policy. Most of the $200 billion is to help pay for programs like highway construction and new weaponry that have fixed costs and do not fluctuate with the ups and downs of the economy, as unemployment pay, food stamps, tax revenues and the other stabilizers do.
Some economists -- including Milton Friedman, a Nobel laureate in economics who is with the Hoover Institute -- hold that the stabilizers, despite the ballyhoo, are no longer so important. The Federal Reserve, through monetary policy, can more than offset their disappearance by lowering interest rates an extra notch or two to give the economy an additional stimulus in hard times.
"I have looked at many episodes in the world in which monetary policy went one way and fiscal policy the other, and I have never found a case in which monetary policy did not dominate," Mr. Friedman said. He favors a balanced budget amendment that would shrink the Federal Government by putting a ceiling on the tax increases that could be enacted to balance the budget.
But the Clinton Administration and even Federal Reserve officials question whether monetary policy could alone handle the task of reviving an economy in recession. The stabilizers, they note, kick in automatically -- before the Federal Reserve and most economists often realize that the economy is falling toward recession.
A recession might be well along and getting deeper before the Fed recognized the problem and began to drop rates. The lower rates, in turn, would not be felt in the economy for a year to 18 months, the traditional lag. And even if the Fed acted quickly enough, the economy would behave in new and different ways without the stabilizers.
"My guess is that we would get it wrong the first time we went into recession, making that recession much deeper than it should be," said a Federal Reserve official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "But we would learn from that experience and do a better job thereafter."
