HEADLINE: Congressional Republicans Take Aim at an Extensive List of Environmental Statutes

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Republicans plan to escalate their war on Federal regulations this week as House debate begins on a series of bills that, taken together, would fundamentally affect the enforcement of every existing environmental law.
The measures would temporarily freeze the Government's powers to make rules in virtually every area of Federal authority and strictly limit those powers in the future. But nowhere would they have greater effect than in environmental regulation, where about 20 major laws generate a steady stream of rules intended to protect health, safety and natural resources. 
 The Republican proposals include a moratorium on new regulations, compensation for landowners when regulations hurt their property values and a requirement that new rules be subjected to elaborate risk assessments and cost-benefit analysis.
President Clinton hinted today that he might veto so far-reaching a package. "The environment is still not able to protect itself," he said in a speech announcing his own package of measures that he said would make regulations less burdensome without rolling back existing laws.
The coming votes will signal how determined the Republicans (and some Democrats) are to rethink a whole generation of environmental laws. Senior Administration officials expect most, and perhaps all, of the package to pass the House, although there are signs that the Senate might modify it.
Even in the House, however, a number of Republicans are hesitant about some of the package's provisions. While the majority party has so far maintained virtually flawless unity in pushing its Contract With America, 15 House Republicans last week wrote to Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, saying they opposed one bill in the package.
Republican leaders in Congress say they intend to rewrite several environmental laws later this year, including the Superfund law, on cleaning up toxic waste dumps; the Clean Water Act, controlling pollution of rivers, lakes and oceans; the Safe Drinking Water Act, governing municipal water supplies, and the Endangered Species Act, protecting the habitat of threatened plants and animals. There are also proposals to repeal parts of the 1990 Clean Air Act and to increase logging in publicly owned forests. And an industry-backed bill to rewrite tolerances for pesticides in food is also likely to move forward, along with farm-bill provisions involving conservation.
In a speech last week, House Speaker Newt Gingrich said the policies of the past 20 years or more "have been absurdly expensive, created far more resistance than was necessary and misallocated resources on emotional and public relations grounds without regard to either scientific, engineering or economic rationality."
"And that," he said, "requires very profound rethinking of what we want to do collectively as a species in order to save the environment."
For the moment, though, the proposals before the House take an indirect route, dramatically restricting the effects of environmental laws without actually rewriting any of them.
"Every person in this Administration is greatly alarmed," said Carol M. Browner, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, discussing the bills coming to the House floor this month as part of the Contract with America.
She said the proposals would fundamentally undermine existing laws by replacing health protection with economic considerations as the determining factor in setting environmental standards.
"The Administration is not going to be a party to that," she said. "Absolutely, positively not. I do know that the Administration will not allow these laws to be dismantled."
At least three bills are ready for action on the House floor, having been approved by House committees in the last two weeks:
*Title III of H.R. 9, called the Job Creation and Wage Enhancement Act, requires elaborate risk assessments to be conducted for any new rules and prohibits regulations unless their economic costs are justified by a cost-benefit measurement.
*A stopgap anti-regulation measure known as the Regulatory Transition Act would halt the imposition of most new Federal regulations dating back to November, and would remain in effect until broader regulatory changes of H.R. 9 were enacted.
*A bill called the Private Property Protection Act would compensate landowners when the value of their property declined because its use had been restricted by Federal regulations.
Although the regulatory moratorium probably will be debated first, it is so likely to be vetoed -- with little chance of an override -- that its importance could be mainly symbolic. As a result, the two other bills will probably be argued over more fiercely.
The bill on private property rights was cleared by the House Judiciary Committee last week. It would require the Federal Government to compensate any property owner whose land values declined by at least one-tenth because of rules restricting how the property could be developed.
That bill is the one that has sparked open dissent among some Republican lawmakers, and prompted them to write Representative Hyde declaring their opposition.
"If this legislation were to become law, the Federal Government could be required to compensate a landowner who is denied a permit to site a hazardous waste facility over an aquifer that supplies drinking water to a nearby community," they said.
The committee voted down a proposal to limit the bill to cases in which land values were reduced because of regulations protecting wetlands or endangered species, but such an amendment is likely to be offered on the House floor. By focusing on two laws that many property owners oppose, it would strengthen the bill's chance of passage.
The biggest fight of all may be over the risk-assessment and cost-benefit provisions, because they would replace health-based environmental standards in existing laws with standards based primarily on economic calculations.
The complex package is likely to get prolonged scrutiny in the Senate, where the votes might not divide entirely on party lines.
"Some of the regulatory reform measures that have been introduced this year go way too far," said Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican who is chairman of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee. He singled out the risk-assessment provisions proposed in the House, saying, "If there ever was a prescription for gridlock, that's it."
Other influential senators, however, are supporting risk-assessment legislation that could be brought to the Senate floor without passing through Senator Chafee's committee. Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat, has a proposal that would affect only the Energy Department, and Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, has a version of his own that would affect all Federal agencies.
Environmental groups are mounting a concerted lobbying campaign in response to the risk-assessment bill, which they call the biggest single threat to their cause in a generation.
In a 120-page report issued today, the Natural Resources Defense Council offered a detailed discussion of how existing laws could be affected by the Republican proposals that will be debated soon.
"We are confronted with sweeping legislation that does not directly amend any single environmental law, but will make efforts to carry out all of them exceptionally difficult, if not impossible," the report says.
A separate analysis issued by the Environmental Protection Agency made the same point. Under existing law, the agency said, it is required to set air quality standards for lead, smog, particulate matter, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide on the basis of health protection alone, not taking costs into account. Nearly 100 million people live in areas where these standards are not being met, and the agency is considering tightening the standards for smog and particulate matter.

HEADLINE: Nassau, Reining In Deficit, Just Misses Breaking Even

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 21

 BODY:
A drop in sales tax revenue at the end of the year and higher social service costs left Nassau County with a deficit of $3.9 million in 1994, county officials said today.
But the deficit was down sharply for the second consecutive year, after peaking at $120 million in 1992. 
 "We're not out of the woods yet," said Frederick E. Parola, the County Comptroller. "However, Nassau has made a remarkable recovery from the height of the recession in 1992."
County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta had anticipated that the county would break even for the first time since 1989, counting on a continued rise in retail sales toward the end of the year for higher sales tax collections. The sales tax provides a third of the county's revenue.
Although sales began to climb shortly after Thanksgiving, they suddenly slowed down just before Christmas. In addition, Mr. Parola said, social service spending was $38.5 million higher than expected, as a population increase put pressure on areas like Medicaid, home relief assistance for the elderly and care for handicapped young children.
Despite the year-end disappointment, Mr. Parola said the deficit of $3.9 million, in a budget of $1.9 billion, sent a positive message to Nassau residents and Wall Street that the county was on more solid footing than it had been.
He said the County Medical Center showed a surplus of $8.6 million, which could affect the debate over whether the hospital should be sold or leased to private operators.
"The center is recovering from the days when the general fund had to subsidize the facility to the tune of over $30 million," Mr. Parola said.
The county had anticipated taking in $625.5 million in sales tax revenue last year but realized only $611 million. Mr. Parola said the sales tax figures were "clear evidence that Long Island's economy is still vulnerable."
Nevertheless, he said that total sales tax revenue showed a 4 percent increase from 1993 and that an additional 5 percent increase had been projected for the 1995 fiscal year.
Mr. Parola cautioned that because of the county's dependence on sales tax revenue, this might not be the time to consider reducing the tax, as the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, has proposed there.
Citing government cost-cutting, lower welfare expenses and improved economic conditions in Suffolk, Mr. Gaffney, a Republican who is expected to seek a second term in November, called last week for a cut of a quarter of a percentage point in the sales tax, to 8.25 percent, which would reduce county revenue by $32 million a year.
In Nassau and Suffolk, as in many counties throughout New York, the sales tax has become an important tool for holding down property taxes. The 8.5 percent sales tax in Nassau and Suffolk is the highest in the state and among the highest in the nation.
Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, the largest business and civic group on Long Island, has long sought to reduce taxes in both counties as part of a drive to strengthen the region's economy.
"Any decrease in the sales tax that would encourage people to buy here on Long Island rather than elsewhere would certainly be desirable from an overall business standpoint," Mr. Crosson said. "But it would have to be done without undermining essential government services."

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Mixed, With Dow Rising 10.43

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday as gains in oil and bank issues tempered losses in shares of tobacco companies.
Stocks were held in check in part by the recent weakness in the dollar, which fell to a 28-month low against the German mark yesterday. A weak dollar makes American stocks and bonds less attractive to foreign investors. 
 In addition, traders were unwilling to place big bets on stocks ahead of today's Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. Stocks surged the last time Mr. Greenspan addressed Congress, when he suggested in late January that the Fed's rate increases had already slowed the economy's brisk growth.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.43 points yesterday, to 3,963.97, its sixth gain in the last seven sessions. On Friday, the average fell 33.98 points in the biggest one-day decline since it dropped 46.77 points on Jan. 19. The market was closed Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.75 point, to 482.72, below its all-time closing high of 485.22 set on Thursday. The Nasdaq composite index fell 2.35 points, to 784.62, its third consecutive decline after rising 11 of the previous 12 sessions.
The rise in bank stocks yesterday came after Fleet Financial Group Inc. agreed to buy the Shawmut National Corporation for $3.7 billion, a merger which would create the ninth-largest banking company in the United States. Shawmut's stock soared 4 3/8 a share, to 25.
"The strength in the bank area is an indication that more mergers could be in line," said Paul Hennessey, head of equities trading at the Boston Company Asset Management Group. "The acquisition talk from a year ago may be starting to resume."
The S.& P. regional banking index of 21 stocks rose as much as 1.71 points before closing up 0.46 at 178.39. Fleet, which will issue new stock to pay for the transaction, saw its shares fall 3 1/4, to 30 3/8. Baybanks Inc. surged 2 7/8 a share, to 63; U S Bancorp gained 5/8, to 25 1/4; Wells Fargo & Company jumped 1 1/8, to 157 3/4; the Mellon Bank Corporation rose 1, to 38 7/8, and Boatmen's Bancshares Inc. added 3/8 a share, to 30 5/8.
Oil issues gained on optimism that energy consumption is not waning and the companies' attractive dividends will draw investor interest, traders said. Separately, Texaco Inc. said it would sign a multimillion-dollar agreement for nine plants in China that convert fuels like coal and heavy oil into clean gas.
"Energy companies are undergoing massive restructurings and as some developed countries recover from recession, there'll be an improvement in oil consumption," Doug Terreson, an analyst with Paine Webber, said. "Dividends will be higher this year as well, so it's going to be a pretty good place to invest."
Shares of Texaco gained 7/8, to 63 1/2; the Mobil Corporation rose 1, to 88; the Exxon Corporation added 5/8, to 64; the Atlantic Richfield Company rose 1 1/8, to 107 3/4, and shares of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation jumped 7/8, to 19 7/8.
The biggest loser among the Dow industrials was the Philip Morris Companies, which dropped 2 3/8 a share, to 57 7/8. The State of Florida sued 17 tobacco companies to recover the cost of treating some victims of smoking-related illness. Last week in New Orleans, tobacco companies failed to head off a class-action lawsuit.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Don't Mess With Moody's

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the 1960's the most important visitor a developing country could have was from the head of AID, the U.S. agency that doled out foreign aid. In the 1970's and 80's the most important visitor a developing country could have was from the I.M.F., to help restructure its economy. In the 1990's the most important visitor a developing country can have is from Moody's Investors Service Inc.
Because we now live in an age when governments are basically broke, the only way for most countries to raise cash for development is either to enforce savings at home or attract investors from the world's major bond markets. Moody's is the credit rating agency that signals the electronic herd of global investors where to plunk down their money, by telling them which countries' bonds are blue-chip and which are junk. 
 That makes Moody's one powerful agency. In fact, you could almost say that we live again in a two-superpower world. There is the U.S. and there is Moody's. The U.S. can destroy a country by leveling it with bombs; Moody's can destroy a country by downgrading its bonds.
Moody's rates the investment quality of countries today just as it rates companies. Those that get their economic house in order will be rated AAA and be able to sell bonds at low interest. Those that don't will be rated C and have to pay pawnbroker interest rates.
If you doubt Moody's influence, ask Mexico and Canada. President Clinton visits Ottawa tomorrow, but all the Canadian papers are talking about is the visit they just had from the other superpower -- the man from Moody's. The Canadian Government was just putting the finishing touches on a major budget overhaul designed to slow the decline of the Canadian dollar, which has lately been dubbed the "northern peso" and is down to 70 U.S. cents.
But before Canada's Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, could even unveil his planned spending cuts and tax hikes, Moody's launched a pre-emptive strike. It declared the proposed cutbacks in the Canadian budget insufficient and put Canada's debt rating under review for possible downgrade. This triggered a big selloff of Canadian dollars and bonds. The Reform Party leader, Preston Manning, told the Canadian Parliament: "When one of the world's largest bond-rating agencies won't wait two weeks to get the minister's budget, they are telling him that his targets are not only unbelievable, they are unacceptable to the markets."
They are also telling him who's boss.
Indeed, Moody's message to both Canada and Mexico is that either you vote the economic pain on yourself -- in the form of deep cuts in government spending and higher domestic interest rates to suppress inflation -- or the bond market will force you to do it by withholding capital. The Canadians couldn't do it on their own because they feared that a tough budget would encourage Quebec separatists by disillusioning people about the federal Government. Mexico's weak, corrupt Government couldn't reform itself because it was too busy buying votes.
So in both cases the bond market is forcing the pain. The U.S. yesterday announced its $20 billion rescue package for Mexico. But the terms of that deal -- both the design of the U.S. loans and the level of Mexican reforms -- were largely dictated by what the two Governments thought the bond market would require to resume private lending to Mexico.
A senior Clinton finance official remarked that it is almost spooky dealing with market powers. At least with the Russians there was a hot line with someone's voice at the other end. But with the bond market, the official said: "You can't argue with it, you can't bargain with it, sometimes you can't even find it. It is an impersonal arbiter, and governments just have to get used to it."
Francis Fukuyama wrote a couple of years ago that democracy and capitalism constituted "the end of history" -- the highest level of human political and economic organization. But I've been thinking that maybe the bond market is the end of history. Moody's and the bond market are now imposing on democracies economic and political decisions that the democracies, left to their own devices, simply cannot take.
I now understand that graffito that reportedly appeared on a wall in Poland last year. It said: "We wanted democracy but we ended up with capitalism." I would refine that to say: "We wanted a parliament, but we ended up with the bond market."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: In America;
Whitman Steals the Future

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Over the past 25 years the State of New Jersey has struggled, under a succession of Democratic and Republican governors, to reverse a social and economic decline that, by the 1960's, had hit many Northeastern industrial areas.
Difficult budget decisions were made, often at significant political cost. But the benefits for New Jersey residents were many. A vastly improved higher education system was developed and state aid to local public schools surged. The environment was cleaned up. Mass transit was improved. The state's budget was balanced without gimmicks and its credit rating was triple-A. 
 There is a strong link between those developments and the fact that New Jersey residents today are among the best educated in the country, and rank near the top in per-capita income.
Now many of the gains made over a quarter of a century are in danger of slipping away because the current Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, has chosen to finance her political ambitions with a popular buy-now, pay-later economic policy that will place a financial stranglehold on future generations of New Jerseyans.
This is best illustrated by Mrs. Whitman's decision to withhold billions of dollars that should be going into the public employee pension funds over the next few years, and using the bulk of that money to balance the state budget. Then, with an audacity that dazzles her supporters and even draws grudging admiration from opponents, Mrs. Whitman smiles and characterizes the withheld funds as savings.
Of course, they are not "savings" -- not in any sense of the word. The pension obligations at some point will come due and future generations will have to meet them.
Not only will the money have to be made up, but future taxpayers will be deprived of the income that the money -- if properly invested now -- would be expected to generate.
Mrs. Whitman's pension maneuvers have not gotten a lot of publicity -- in part because the eyes of reporters and readers alike tend to glaze over when confronted with complex budget details. The changes that she has made have been drastic. According to the New Jersey Education Association, which has filed suit against the state, the employer contributions to the pension system this year will be as much as 96 percent below the amounts contributed in the early 1990's.
By all accounts, the employer contributions have been reduced by nearly $1 billion a year. The Whitman administration insists that this is not a problem. Needless to say, others disagree.
"There is no question but that this is creating future debt," said Richard C. Leone, a former New Jersey State Treasurer who is now the president of the Twentieth Century Fund. "This is just another way of getting around the balanced-budget requirement, a kind of deficit spending. It is the sort of thing that comes back to haunt you."
Until the changes adopted by Mrs. Whitman, New Jersey had been very conservative in its approach to its pension obligations. For example, the state had started to pre-fund the health care benefits of its retirees, building up reserves against post-retirement liabilities. As one state official said: "That was prudent. Health-care costs are a big problem."
Prudent or not, Mrs. Whitman scrapped the pre-funding. She used the reserves that had already built up to help balance her budget. For Christine Todd Whitman, the pension funds have become a budget-balancing machine.
Mrs. Whitman and the long-term interests of New Jersey appear to be at odds. The Governor won election by promising tax cuts, and any further advances in her career will be powered by her ability to "deliver" on that promise. Like most politicians, her eyes are on the short term: today's budget, tomorrow's election. It requires courage to look beyond Election Day to the long-term interests of constituents.
Young men and women who were children in New Jersey 20 or 25 years ago are benefiting from the vision and courage of the politicians in power then, politicians who were not afraid to lead. They weren't perfect but they had a sense of responsibility toward the generations growing up behind them. It's a quality that nowadays is in extremely short supply. And not just in New Jersey.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Beyond the 100 Days

BYLINE: By Newt Gingrich; Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, is Speaker of the House of Representatives.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Believing that a campaign promise is one thing but a signed contract is quite another, House Republican candidates signed the Contract With America last September. Today, we reach day 50 of that historic commitment to change this country. This midway point is a time to reflect on our progress.
As promised, on a memorable first day the House passed legislation that brought Congress under the same regulatory laws as other businesses. To control runaway Federal spending, we have passed the balanced budget amendment and a Presidential line-item veto. To curb Congress's habit of creating a program but leaving the payments to the states, we have enacted reform of "unfunded mandates." To restore credibility to the criminal justice system, we have revised the exclusionary rule, which would end legal technicalities that freed many criminals, and we have established an effective death penalty. And to insure that our military forces are not needlessly put in harm's way, we have voted restrictions on how our troops are deployed overseas. 
 Despite a small majority (230 to 204) Republicans have produced huge bipartisan majorities for bills in the contract. These results show the difference between the last legislative session and this one: a liberal Congress out of touch with the nation created gridlock; a conservative Congress elected to do the people's work creates results. Now many of our initiatives await action in the Senate, where the rules give the minority greater power to slow debate.
The next 50 days will produce tax relief for families and the elderly, job creation bills, common sense legal reform, votes on term limits and welfare reform. The last item will undoubtedly be the most contentious in the contract. But we cannot replace the welfare state unless we change welfare itself. Thus, we will work to end cash payments to unmarried teen-age mothers and create incentives to get people to work while allowing governors to reform welfare at the state level, where change is most effective.
The pace that the 104th Congress has set in getting its agenda completed can make it easy to lose sight of what we are doing.
Republicans were sent to Washington not just to set records of legislative activity, though that's been necessary to fulfill the contract. Setting records is fine; but remembering the lessons of history is a far greater responsibility.
We Republicans must keep in mind that we are heirs to a great legacy. February marks the births of three of our most outstanding Presidents: George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan. After leading the Colonies through the Revolutionary War, Washington displayed rare insight that set the right tone for leading a young Republic. Though easily electable to a third term, he chose to return to his farm; in effect setting a two-term limit for Presidential service (breached only during a national emergency by Franklin D. Roosevelt), he was the true ideal of a citizen-statesman.
During some of our darkest hours, Lincoln never wavered in his belief that America's destiny lay as one unified nation. Despite slavery, despite economic adversity and the Civil War, he fervently believed that the divisions tearing his society apart could be surmounted.
When Ronald Reagan became President, he found a dispirited country that was stagnating economically and embarrassed internationally. His policies, unswerving optimism and vision brought forth a true rejuvenation, including a record 93 months of economic expansion.
The moments associated with these three leaders -- birth, reconciliation and rejuvenation -- will remain with the Republicans as we complete the contract.
While some mourn the death of the liberal welfare state, the nation must, like George Washington, be prepared for the birth of something much stronger -- in this case, a conservative opportunity society. Despite the decay and division around us, Republicans must take Lincoln's example and never falter in our determination to see a society reconciled. And like Ronald Reagan, we must remain committed and optimistic about bringing about national rejuvenation.
Completing the Contract With America is only a beginning -- the start of a program to renew American civilization and to build a true civil society. That is the Republicans' goal for next 50 days -- and beyond.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Several Worries Push Bonds Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday, weighed down by concerns about the weak dollar, the auctions of new government securities and this week's semiannual report from the Federal Reserve to Congress on the conduct of monetary policy and the state of the economy.
Donald E. Maude, chief United States fixed-income strategist at the Scotia McLeod brokerage firm, said that not many traders were showing a willingness to make a big bet on the direction of interest rates ahead of the testimony of the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, scheduled for today and tomorrow. 
 Mr. Maude said that he believed that Mr. Greenspan would continue to emphasize the concerns of the Fed about the potential for a pickup in inflation and its primary worry that the economy was pressing up against full capacity in both the labor force and manufacturing.
"Right now the market has ruled out another Fed tightening at least until May," Mr. Maude said. But he said that "I think Greenspan's views will be a lot more hawkish" than recent comments from other Fed officials and the "market may not be prepared."
"I tend to believe this will be less than friendly for the markets," he said of the Greenspan testimony.
The bellwether 30-year bond fell 9/32 , to a price of 1007/32 to yield 7.61 percent, up from 7.58 percent on Friday.
Today the Treasury will auction $17.25 billion worth of two-year notes and tomorrow will auction $11 billion of five-year notes. In when-issued trading these securities were offered at prices to yield 7.10 percent for the two-year and 7.35 percent for the five-year.
Yesterday the Treasury held its weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, with the average rates at auction down to their lowest levels since late last year. The rate on a three-month bill fell 8 basis points, to 5.74 percent, near the 5.56 percent of Dec. 27, while the six-month dropped 14 basis points, to 6.01 percent, the lowest since the Nov. 28 level of 5.86 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Talk of German Rate Rise Pulls Dollar Down vs. Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled to a 28-month low against the German mark and slumped against most other currencies yesterday after a report from the Bundesbank indicated that German interest rates were poised to rise.
The signing yesterday of an agreement between the United States and Mexico on a $20 billion portion of a rescue plan for Mexico failed to provide much support for the dollar. The dollar has been weighed down by fears over the costs of rescuing Mexico. 
 The mark continued its recent advance against the dollar yesterday after the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, said in a monthly report that the nation's economy showed "undiminished strength" at the end of 1994. Rising commodity and import prices and dwindling industrial capacity added to the risk that inflation would accelerate, the report said.
"The mark is the focus of attention, and if the Bundesbank raises rates, the mark will benefit," said John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange at ING Capital Markets in New York.
The Bundesbank's longstanding top priority is controlling inflation. Raising interest rates -- the bank's most common method of tempering growth and curbing price increases -- would make mark-denominated deposits more attractive.
The dollar fell as low as 1.4690 marks, its lowest level since Oct. 16, 1992. In late New York trading, the dollar recovered to 1.4700 marks, down from 1.4802 marks on Friday. The dollar fell to 1.2430 Swiss francs from 1.2520 francs, and to 97.05 Japanese yen from 97.40 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5862 from $1.5820.
Trading was thin on Monday because markets and many foreign-exchange desks in the United States were closed in observance of Washington's Birthday.
 Germany's report on producer prices also fueled speculation that the Bundesbank would soon raise interest rates. The Federal Statistics Office announced that western German producer prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent in January, the biggest monthly gain since July 1991.
The Bundesbank last changed rates on May 11, when it lowered its discount rate, which acts as a floor for money market rates, and cut its Lombard rate, which acts as a ceiling, by half a percentage point, to 4.5 percent and 6 percent, respectively.
The Federal Reserve in the United States has raised rates seven times since February 1994, pushing the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans to 6 percent from 3 percent. The comparable German rate is 4.85 percent.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Second Childhood Ends: Fantasy Leaguers Suddenly Find They Have to Get a Life

BYLINE: By PAUL BELINKIE 

 BODY:
Dave Pearlstein, a real-estate broker for a company outside Boston, has been playing fantasy baseball for six years and spends 30 hours a week on the game.
Because his league will not play with replacement players this season, Pearlstein will fill the void by exercising and attending replacement games to scout for next year. "Without my Rotisserie fix, I may have to go back to smoking," the 26-year-old Pearlstein said. 
 For more than a decade, an estimated two million fans have competed in Rotisserie Baseball, an arena in which their judgment of talent and the ability to maneuver within salary guidelines has provided a test of baseball knowledge.
But in addition to the thousands of people employed either directly or indirectly in baseball, people who play fantasy baseball and people who earn their livings by supplying fantasy leagues with statistics are also experiencing hardships because of the current baseball strike.
Bob Weiser, 35, the general manager of a Holiday Inn in Atlanta, is a commissioner who spends about 35 hours a week on his league. He now says he will spend more time with his family.
"As a commissioner, the additional paperwork and rule changes would make it impossible to play with replacement players," he said, echoing the sentiments of other frustrated fans.
John Leven, 28, the franchise sales director for Uno Restaurant Corporation, has been playing for three years and devotes 20 hours a week to the game. Leven will fill this void with a more diverse social life and by attending replacement games.
"The game itself is bigger than the players," he said. Leven would like to play with replacement players, but says that no one knows replacement players well enough to play. Leven, however, is looking forward to going to replacement games to see whether some of his old Red Sox favorites come out of retirement.
In addition to fantasy players, the strike has hurt businesses that supply leagues with statistics.
Richard Pike, 34, and his partner, Michael Oliveto, of Allstar Stats, Valhalla, N.Y., worked for the Prodigy on-line service in sales before starting their business five years ago. They currently service 650 baseball leagues and 85 basketball leagues.
Last year, Allstar Stats, like every other statistical organization surveyed, offered leagues refunds or credit for this season. Pike has found that leagues are split evenly between those that will play with replacement players and those waiting for the real players to return.
Pike, who is married and has two children, is concerned that his phones are quiet.
"If this strike doesn't end soon, my wife may have to get a job," he said.
Bill Meyer, a 40-year-old lawyer, runs USA Stats in Baltimore. He supplies 370 leagues with weekly updates and will be starting his seventh year in the statistics business. Although he still practices law in the off season, Meyer says that if the strike doesn't end soon, he may have to return to more legal work or his wife, Lucy, who works with him in the statistics business, may have to resume selling real estate.
Eric Bielawski, 37, of Eric's No Frills Stat Service, in Ontario, provides statistics for more than 200 baseball leagues. A former computer salesman, Bielawski estimates that the strike has cut into his business by 30 percent.
"A lot of my customers are mad at baseball and don't know if they'll return to the game," he said.
Bielawski opposes both sides in the labor issue. "President Clinton summed it up best when he said, 'What we have is a couple of hundred people deciding how to divide $2 billion.' " he said.
But Bielawski is still optimistic about the season getting under way. "As a provider of stats, the strike casts a shadow over what I'm able to do and hoping to do," he said.
Most fantasy baseball players believe the biggest winners in baseball's new economic world will be the young players making relatively small salaries. The biggest losers, they believe, will be the journeymen players who will be forced to play for salaries slightly more than the minimum paid to rookies or players with minor league or make-good contracts.
In other words, there will be no more Spike Owens languishing on a major league bench as an expensive insurance policy in case someone gets injured or a highly touted rookie prospect fails.
Fiscal responsibility, like in any business or a Rotisserie Baseball league, will become the order of the day. Just because Bobby Bonilla is paid $7 million by the Mets or costs $35 in a fantasy league, doesn't mean he will earn it. And if the Brewers, owned by Bud Selig, the acting baseball commissioner, didn't sign Ted Higuera to a four-year, $13 million deal and Franklin Stubbs to a three-year, $6 million contract, perhaps they would have been able to afford to re-sign Paul Molitor when his contract expired.
A common fantasy baseball question has always been which would you rather have, a star player such as a Barry Bonds and a player earning near the minimum salary, or two well-paid players? The answer, which is even more relevant now than ever, will depend on who the other player is.

HEADLINE: America Online Adds Clients

 BODY:
America Online Inc. said yesterday that it had surpassed two million subscribers, and it asserted that it had overtaken both Compuserve and Prodigy to become the largest consumer information service in the United States.
America Online, based in Vienna, Va., said it had added 500,000 members since December. But the growth has come at the cost of deteriorating service, many subscribers have complained. Busy signals, slow connections and electronic mail delays of several hours, or in some cases days, are increasingly common. 
 In some cases, electronic mail "is zapped into never-never land," said Mary Modahl, an analyst with Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. "The degradation of their service is remarkable. They haven't been able to keep up with demand."
Steve Case, America Online's president and chief executive, acknowledged the problems in a letter to subscribers earlier this month, noting that the service was struggling to handle 1.5 million electronic mail messages a day.
America Online's rivals shopped short of disputing the assertion by the company that it was now the largest domestic on-line service.

HEADLINE: New Faces in the Old Masters Trade

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Just as contemporary-art galleries have a uniform look -- antiseptic, spare white spaces and highly polished floors -- so do galleries for Old Master paintings and drawings. Theirs is a more hushed atmosphere where works by Rubens and Rembrandt, Van Dyck and Guardi, hang in a stately cavalcade on richly brocaded walls.
While London has traditionally been the center of the Old Master trade, with dozens of galleries clustered around Old Bond Street, New York has, until recently, had just a few big-name dealers like Colnaghi or the Newhouse Galleries, and business was, for the most part, private and by appointment only. Except for the highly publicized auctions held twice a year at Sotheby's and Christie's, sales made by dealers were kept as quiet as the personalities of the collectors who bought. 
 But times have changed, and the number of dealers specializing in art generally dating from the 14th century to about 1850 has multiplied in recent years. The profile of the Old Master dealer has changed, too. No longer crusty Englishmen who are more at home with books than with prospective buyers, the new breed of Old Master dealers dispels the myth that they are a group nearly as old as the paintings they sell. Today's generation of Old Master dealers range in age from mid-30's to late 40's. Their galleries, most of which are off Madison Avenue on the Upper East Side, are open and inviting.
And business, while far from booming, has picked up over the last year.
"The field is becoming more popular," said Rachel Kaminsky, 33, who left Christie's in October to become the director of Otto Naumann's new East Side gallery. "There are more exhibitions, more antique shows and more publications all geared toward the Old Master market."
Ms. Kaminsky said that in her last few years at Christie's she noticed an increase in buyers entering the field, both new collectors and what she calls "the more mature collector" who were buyers in other areas but opted to switch to Old Masters.
Affordability is one reason for the increase in popularity. Old Masters are still undervalued when compared with Impressionist or modern art. Another reason is that the amount of scholarship in the field has grown over the years, so that there are fewer sticky issues of provenance and attributions. Buyers are seeing less risk than they once did, since more information is now available to the public.
Even contemporary-art dealers are jumping into the field. Larry Gagosian, who has galleries on the Upper East Side and in SoHo, is hard at work on a Rubens exhibition scheduled to open in his Madison Avenue space on April 1. Mr. Gagosian said he thought a Rubens exhibition would be something his clients could relate to, since many contemporary artists look to the Old Master for inspiration. He said he hoped the show would broaden the tastes of people who frequent his gallery.
Old Master dealers, both in New York and in London, think that idea is just fine. In fact, many of them are lending Mr. Gagosian paintings for the show in the hopes of expanding their market. "The more excitement that surrounds Old Masters and the more dealers there are, the more collectors will appear," said Adam Williams, a director of the Newhouse Galleries. "We're all working hard to generate more business."
Mr. Williams, 42, is one of the old-timers, relatively speaking, having come over from London in 1983 to work at Newhouse. His colleague Nicholas Hall, the president of Colnaghi in New York, came to the United States 10 years ago, two years after Colnaghi had opened a gallery in New York.
"Perhaps the biggest change is that most of the newer dealers are American, not English, and all these people seem here to stay," Mr. Hall said. "There are certainly more young independent Old Master dealers than there were."
Ian Kennedy, who was the director of the Old Master paintings department at Christie's in New York for 16 years, opened the New York branch of the Simon Dickinson Gallery in January 1994. "In the 1980's there were a lot of Old Master dealers," he said. "Some of them survived, but a lot of them didn't. Then the recession hit. This new crop of dealers is proof that there is more optimism in the field."
Mr. Kennedy said New York, not London, was the place to be right now in the Old Masters field because America has the greatest potential for making private sales.
Many dealers in this increasingly crowded field would once have been more inclined to enter academic circles or become museum experts. Not anymore. Last year, Mr. Kennedy was a serious candidate for one of the most prestigious jobs in the museum world: curator of paintings at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif. But he opted to stay in New York instead.
"Museum work has become too bureaucratic," said Mark Brady, a dealer who specializes in Old Master and 19th-century drawings and oil sketches. "The great attraction to dealing is that it's entirely object-oriented."
Mr. Hall agreed. "In museums you don't play with paintings; you play with labels and budgets," he said. "The museum world is failing to attract good people for many reasons. Certainly money has something to do with it. So does the fact that the emphasis in museums today is on education, exhibitions, fund raising and politics, and less on connoisseurship and acquisitions."
Mr. Brady also said he saw a change in the way dealers were perceived. "Art dealing has become a respectable commodity," he said. "In a commercial city like New York, the stigma of being in the trade has diminished. Now, being a dealer has a funny respectability to it."
The change that Otto Naumann, another New York dealer, has made in his business recently supports Mr. Brady's theory. After 13 years of dealing privately, Mr. Naumann has renovated the first two floors of 22 East 80th Street and opened them to the public. "I'm trying to run the gallery in a commercial way," Mr. Naumann said. "Being commercial isn't bad."
The dealer said he used to spend two or three hours talking to a client and bring out only one painting, maybe two. "Now it's just just the opposite," he said. "Ninety percent of my stock is on the walls."
The building that houses his gallery has been dubbed "the Old Master mall" by Mr. Naumann's colleagues. Upstairs are two other Old Master dealers, Bob Haboldt and Guy Sainty. "We're trying to do what London does," said Mr. Naumann, 46. "Not only in terms of proximity to each other, but also proximity to the Met. We've installed piped-in music. The point is to put the public at ease."
Jack Kilgore has assumed a higher profile, too, but in a significantly smaller way. Although his East Side gallery is still by appointment only, this year the dealer held his first exhibition for which he advertised steadily in both art and general interest publications. "The market here is better for selling, but in France and England it's better for buying," he said. "From 1989 till 1993, sales for Dutch paintings dropped off. Now it's back, and people are buying again."
Even so, most dealers admit their stock isn't splashy. After all, seeing a Canaletto or a Guardi hanging in someone's living room just doesn't scream "Rich!" in quite the same way seeing a Picasso or a Matisse does. Still, the dealers argue, Old Master paintings are good value. When compared to the Impressionist or modern artworks today, they seem downright cheap. "You can still buy a good Old Master painting for under $200,000," Mr. Kilgore said. "And that says something."

LENGTH: 957 words

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THERE are still some wine enthusiasts in New York who remember the old Ambassador Wine Shop on East 86th Street, in the heart of Yorkville. Ambassador, as might be expected in that once-solidly Teutonic neighborhood, specialized in German wines and stocked hundreds of different labels.
The Ambassador shop has been gone since the late 1960's, and nothing has come along to take its place. With good reason. The interest simply isn't out there. 
 Except for a few enthusiasts here and there, Americans are just not drawn to German wines. It's unfortunate. Germany's best white wines are among the world's finest. And they are perfectly compatible with the way most people think of food and fitness: they are light, refreshing and low in alcohol, mostly between 8 and 11 percent, compared with up to 15 percent in some California chardonnays.
So what's the problem? Accessibility, mostly. It is not easy to win over a casual drinker with a wine called Bodenheimer Heitersbrunnchen Scheurebe Kabinett. And when such names appear on labels in an almost illegible gothic script, as many of them still do, many consumers shrug and move on to something else, like a California chardonnay.
Every decade or so, the Germans take another stab at simplifying their wine laws. But they remain an impenetrable thicket that, like the labels, send prospective customers away shaking their heads.
Then there is the question of when to drink German wines. Hardly anyone, at least in this country, is quite sure what to do with them. Are they food wines, to drink with lunch or dinner? Or are they aperitifs, like sherry and champagne?
The people who make them insist they are food wines, despite the fact that they are slightly sweet. There are, they say, many food and wine combinations based on German wines. They cite smoked fish, pasta, light cheese and even ham, one of the most difficult staples to match with a wine. Bigger German wines, those with an appreciable amount of sweetness, do, in fact, blend well with more pungent cheeses and hold their own admirably with assertive dishes like turkey and roasted game birds.
Nevertheless, in the book "How to Enjoy Wine" (Simon & Schuster, 1985), Hugh Johnson hails German wines as "the most exquisite of all wines for solo sipping."
In seeking a solution for their problems, German wine makers actually made things worse. In the late 1970's and early 1980's, they announced that henceforth they would make dry wines. Their motive was understandable; dry, or at least the perception of dry, was popular.
The most recent appearance of dry German wines -- the German word for dry is "trocken" -- has produced some elegant wines, but they are not what German wine loyalists have come to expect.
In another attempt to improve their economic lot, German wine makers have been experimenting with red wines, mostly pinot noir and a recently developed grape, the dornfelder. The best of these wines are attractive enough, but the chance of them ever finding serious markets outside Germany seems low. Currently, a group of mostly young, innovative wine makers has reverted to traditional styles; the wines display some sweetness but are beautifully balanced.
The writer and critic Stuart Pigott dates the current emphasis on quality and tradition to the vintage of 1983, when wine makers began experimenting with organic methods and getting lower yields to concentrate the flavors in the grapes.
There are 13 wine regions, or appellations, in Germany, all of them on or near the Rhine and Mosel rivers and their tributaries. The best known are the Rheingau, the Mosel-Saar-Ruwer, the Rheinhessen and the Pfalz. The name of a region is always listed on a wine label, along with the name of the town and vineyard, the type of grape and the quality level of the wine.
The important quality levels are kabinett, spatlese and auslese. Kabinett wines come from grapes picked at normal harvest time; spatlese wines are made from late-picked grapes that have more intense flavors, and auslese wines come from particularly ripe grapes picked bunch by bunch.
The jaw-breaking name Bodenheimer Heitersbrunnchen Scheurebe Kabinett becomes a bit less formidable when broken into its components: the town is Bodenheim, in the Rheinhessen region, in the central-west part of the country; the vineyard is the Heitersbrunnchen, the grape is the scheurebe and the quality level is kabinett. The label will show the producer, in this case Kuhling-Gillot, and, of course, the vintage. By the way, in the 1992 vintage, this wine is an excellent buy, at about $10.
To avoid German-label panic, seek out reliable and interesting producers. Among them are Lingenfelder, Selbach-Oster, J. J. Prum, Schloss Vollrads, J. Lauerberg, Weingut Deinhard, Kurt Darting and, for that matter, any producer -- like Darting -- chosen by Terry Theise Estate Selection.

TASTINGS
Guenoc Petite Sirah, California North Coast, 1991. About $13.
 
The vogue for California wines made from grape varieties usually associated with the Rhone Valley in France has made syrah a fairly popular red wine. This gain has been partly at the expense of petite sirah, an old standby in the California vineyards, once used mostly for blending. Petite sirah is sometimes written off as a poor relative of syrah, but it has its champions, like Ridge Vineyards in the Santa Cruz Mountains, Foppiano Vineyards in northern Sonoma County and, in this instance, Guenoc Winery in Lake County. Eighteen months in American and French oak have smoothed out the wine's tannins and added a touch of elegance that's rare in petite sirah. It is a rich, full-bodied wine that goes well with hearty stews and red meat on chilly late-winter nights.

HEADLINE: Agreement Reached On Gas to Balkans

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The sanctions committee of the United Nations Security Council has reached an agreement that could allow a steady flow of Russian natural gas into both the capital of Bosnia and to Yugoslavia.
Providing the natural gas to heat homes, schools and hospitals is intended to forestall a crisis. At the same time, the agreement, which was reached Friday, would maintain the trade embargo against Yugoslavia that has been in place since 1992 to put pressure on the Serbs in Yugoslavia to halt the aggression by Bosnian Serbs in Bosnia. The agreement will extend through April 30. 
 Requests by the Russian Federation to be allowed to send about 130 million cubic meters of natural gas per month to the area had been rejected since last winter by the United States, France and Britain.
The committee's refusal was in part a response to the Bosnian Serbs' interruption of gas shipments into Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital. Bosnia and Herzegovina share a single natural gas pipeline with Yugoslavia. But Bosnian Serbs have been accused of repeatedly shutting off a line at the border carrying the small portion intended for Sarajevo.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: State Universities Reshaped In the Era of Budget Cutting

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
With the nation's new emphasis on cutting taxes and curbing government spending, governors and legislatures are reducing the budgets of state university systems and, in the process, forcing the most radical reshaping of public higher education since its rapid growth in the 1960's.
Universities are raising tuition and cutting staff, as they did in 1992 and 1993 because of deep, recession-driven budget cuts, but this time they are also reducing the requirements for a degree, closing entire departments and adding financial penalties for students taking courses beyond those needed for graduation. 
 Among the publicly supported four-year colleges, the State University of New York would increase tuition, now about $2,500 a year, by as much as $1,800. The City University of New York, which is principally supported by the city, would raise tuition, also roughly $2,500, by $1,000.
California, which now charges about $4,000 for the University of California, and $1,500 for the California State University system, would raise its tuition by 10 percent. Additionallly North Carolina plans hundreds of layoffs; Florida is encouraging students to declare their major freshman year so that they are guaranteed their required courses, and several states are considering a plan to penalize part-time students, many of whom work, by charging full tuition.
"We're living through the biggest change in the financing of public higher education since the rapid expansion in the late 1960's," said Terry W. Hartle, vice president of the American Council on Education, the Washington-based association of colleges and universities.
"I worry about what's happening," he continued, "because when college tuition goes up, enrollment among low- and middle-income students falls, and for those students a very important form of social and economic opportunity disappears."
For their part, university officials are trying to prevent tuition increases by encouraging students to complete their degrees efficiently and move on. Less than half of students nationwide finish in four years.
Kevin P. Reilly, the associate provost for academic programs at the State University of New York system, said: "Time creep -- students staying longer and longer in college -- is not only unhealthy for us but for students who now graduate with higher and higher debt burdens. We don't want to create knowledge factories where you get in and get out as fast as possible, but we think more colleges should make it more possible for more students to accelerate through their degree programs."
The proposed cuts are unusually severe in New York, where Gov. George E. Pataki proposes eliminating nearly half a billion dollars, or 12.6 percent, from New York's public colleges and universities. The heads of the State University and City University systems, as part of their lobbying for a restoration of funds from the State Legislature, have predicted faculty layoffs and tuition increases of $1,000 to $1,800 a year.
Tuition, plus fees, room and board, is now about $9,500 for in-state resident students at SUNY. CUNY, with very few students in dormitories, charges $2,450 for tuition and fees at senior colleges. Out-of-state students pay about $5,000 at CUNY for tuition and fees and about $11,500 at SUNY for tuition, fees, room and board.
More moderate -- and more typical -- is a proposal by Gov. James B. Hunt of North Carolina to increase tuition by 3 percent and to lay off 325 to 375 administrators to save $15 million. But such modest cuts -- or even slight increases -- mask the long-term erosion in financing for many state-supported institutions.
"This is not as heavy a cut as the one in 1990, but heavier than the last two cuts, and that makes it very significant," said Marvin K. Dorman Jr., state budget officer of North Carolina.
In New Jersey, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has proposed a 1 percent increase in support for state colleges and universities. Robert A. Scott, president of Ramapo College in New Jersey, said he "welcomed the turnaround," but that it went nowhere near replacing a cumulative cut of $11 million, or more than 25 percent of state aid, over the last six years. As a result, he said, Ramapo was forced to eliminate four degree programs and withdraw from intercollegiate football.
In California, where today's tax revolt was foreshadowed with the passage of Proposition 13 in 1978, the state subsidy for higher education has gone from deep cuts in the late 1970's to full recovery in the boom years of the 1980's. But during the last five years, the University of California's subsidy has been reduced by 25.5 percent and that of the California State University system by 21.3 percent.
The result, according to a new study by the Harvard University higher-education expert, David W. Breneman, leaves the California system in a state of emergency and ill prepared to meet an expected enrollment surge of nearly half a million students over the next decade.
Last month, Gov. Pete Wilson called for a 2 percent increase in the university budgets -- not enough to meet the governing Board of Regents' recommendation to increase badly eroded faculty salaries nor enough to keep pace with inflation. He has called for a 10 percent tuition increase, to come before the board in July, that would add at least $400 per year to the roughly $9,500 overall costs students at the University of California now pay.
Further enrollment declines are projected. In the five years between 1988 and 1993 when tuition rose steeply, the percentage of high school graduates who went on to the University of California or the California State University system fell from 15.3 percent to 14.6 percent.
 
Proposed Changes Bring Opposition
Because many of the proposed cuts are new, intense lobbying efforts, by local groups as well as the Washington-based American Council on Education, are still in the planning stages. Nevertheless, students and faculty around the country have already begun fighting the proposed cuts.
Last week, after a well-organized student demonstration in San Diego, the Board of Regents deferred approval of the tuition increase. A similar student protest rally is planned for Albany on Monday.
The University of Vermont, which has long been the highest priced state system, charges overall costs of $11,166 for state residents; Connecticut, Massachusetts, Michigan and Rhode Island are just under $10,000, and Maine and New Hampshire are about $8,500. The national average, including room and board, is about $7,500, with Florida at the low end, charging about $6,500.
 
Some Institutions Will Suffer Less
In Connecticut, Gov. John G. Rowland proposed a $6.4 million, or 1.7 percent, cut in the state's $381 million subsidy. Educational leaders say they hope the cut can be absorbed without a tuition hike.
Some public institutions are likely to suffer less than others because they have developed such high endowments and sources of private donations that they are commonly referred to as "state-assisted" rather than state-supported institutions. The University of Virginia, for example, receives only 13 percent of its $903 million budget from the state.
On the other hand, the City University of New York, the largest urban university in the nation, whose students are mostly drawn from low- and lower-middle-income families, has not been able to attract substantial outside income. About 67 percent of CUNY's $1.25 billion budget comes from the city and state. As a result, W. Ann Reynolds, the chancellor of CUNY, told legislators in Albany, the proposed cuts "jeopardize the very notion of access."
Educational leaders at public institutions have responded with steps like faculty reduction by attrition, administrative cutbacks and increasing faculty workload. One of the most talked about of these plans is the effort to increase what educators call "productivity": raising the number of students they educate with the same or a lower subsidy.
The University of North Carolina has imposed a surcharge on courses above 140 credit hours; only 120 hours are required for graduation. Texas and Oregon are discussing the same thing. Montana is charging the steeper nonresident tuition to all students on courses above 170 credit hours. And Colorado is considering a plan to eliminate the state subsidy entirely for students who have taken more than 140 credit hours.
The result of the surcharges, educators say, will be restrictions on the freedom of students to explore diverse fields of knowledge.
Benjeil Edghill, a biology major at the University of North Carolina's Chapel Hill campus, said he feared that the new surcharge would prevent him from pursuing art appreciation, literature and Arabic studies. "I thought college was where you go to obtain as much knowledge as possible, but now I'm not so sure," he said.
Not a few educators argue that the emphasis on productivity is wrong-headed. Sandi Cooper, a professor of history and chairwoman of the University Faculty Senate at the City University of New York, said, "To expect qualitative results measured by quantitative, bottom-line standards is a contradiction in terms."
Some state officials, struggling against the swift currents of the tax revolt, respond testily to such gripes. Anne Barnes, chairwoman of the Educational Oversight Committee of the North Carolina House of Representatives, reflected this attitude when she said, "We saw a pronounced pattern of students hanging around longer and longer to complete their undergraduate degrees, and so we said if you're going to do that you have to pay for it."
 
Pressures On Colleges
Several trends have combined to put pressure on colleges to move students in and out faster. For one thing, the student population is burgeoning. As children of the baby-boomers reach college age, 17 states will see the number of students soar by at least 20 percent over the next decade, according to a recent study by the Western Interstate Commission for Higher Education.
Further, because today's college students are much more likely than their predecessors to hold jobs, have families or need remedial work, they are staying in college longer -- only 43 percent of 1990 graduates received degrees in four years or less, according to the National Center for Education Statistics, a research branch of the Federal Department of Education.
Cheryl D. Blanco, education policy director at the Florida Postsecondary Education Planning Commission, surveyed productivity plans under consideration at state-supported institutions throughout the country last month and concluded that one of the most popular is the so-called block tuition plan.
Under block tuition, students would be charged a set fee for taking 12 to 18 credit hours a semester. (The usual load is 15.) If they took less than 12 credits, however, they would be charged a significantly higher fee. Some educators object to the plan, arguing that it unfairly penalizes students who have other demands on their time.
Dr. Blanco said the alternative was a state-imposed financing cut. "While we don't like to deny students the opportunity to shop around with courses -- which is one of the strengths of higher education in this country -- we would rather figure out how to meet the challenge ourselves rather than have it forced upon us by legislative mandate."

HEADLINE: Argentina's Pressured Press

 BODY:
Argentina has only recently emerged from a long spell of abusive government that left its economy in ruins and democratic political culture paralyzed by fear and cynicism. President Carlos Menem, seeking re-election this year, deserves much of the credit for Argentina's economic recovery, particularly steps that have tamed inflation and attracted foreign investment. But he has been less consistent in his commitment to democratic recovery. Now he is sponsoring new libel laws that threaten press freedom.
In the past few years a revitalized judiciary and press have helped expose the kind of government corruption that used to go unchecked. Such public scrutiny is essential to establishing democratic accountability and discouraging abuses of public trust. But Mr. Menem has not appreciated the role played by the judiciary and press and has repeatedly tried to compromise their independence. 
 Last month he submitted three bills to the congress clearly meant to bring the press to heel. Two of these would sharply hike penalties for libel, requiring news organizations to purchase expensive libel insurance.
In the United States, courts have protected press freedom against libel claims by requiring a show of deliberate falsehood or reckless disregard for the truth. Argentina's proposed laws contain no such protections, and editors reasonably fear they would stifle serious investigative journalism.
Mr. Menem could burnish his credentials as a democrat by withdrawing these dangerous and offensive bills. Failing that, Argentina's congress should vote them down.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Shrinking Menus: G.O.P. Lunch Plan

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
CONGRESS has taken the first steps to repeal the National School Lunch Act, which has fed hundreds of millions of hungry children since 1946. The changes being proposed could affect the lunch choices of every child in every public school, regardless of income.
Many schools may simply get out of the business of offering school lunches. Or if they continue, they may raise prices for many students. For the poorest children, the changes could mean an end to the free meals, including breakfast, that have been linked to improved academic performance. 
 The House Economic and Education Opportunities Committee is expected to finish working today on a bill that would turn the school lunch and breakfast programs over to the states and reduce the amount of Federal financing.
The current bill from the committee's Republican chairman, Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania, is a modification of legislation that had been offered by the House leadership.
"The Congress is taking a huge gamble with a program that has a proven record of success for almost 50 years now," said Marshall Matz, the legislative counsel to the American School Food Service Association, which represents food-service employees across the country. "No one has ever testified that this program doesn't work. This is one of the first implementations of the Republican Contract With America that really changes a Government program we've all grown up with."
"This was not a Roosevelt-Lyndon Johnson program," he added. "It was signed by Harry Truman because so many guys failed their physicals during World War II, and it was expanded by Richard Nixon."
Kelly Presta, a spokesman for the House committee, said the goal of the change was to make the program more efficient and to reduce administrative costs in Washington.
Ninety-five percent of all schools participate in the federally financed lunch program, which feeds 25 million children each day; more than half the children get a free lunch or pay just 40 cents. During 1991-92, the last year for which data are available, the rest paid, on average, about $ 1.15. Most of the almost six million children who eat school breakfasts receive either free or reduced-price meals. Meals for all children, including those who pay full price, are subsidized by the Federal Government.
Under the proposal, poor children would no longer be guaranteed free lunch or breakfast, and Federal nutrition standards for the meals would be replaced by state standards. In addition, the programs would no longer get extra money if they had to provide additional free meals because of a local recession.
The draft legislation would give the states block grants, and at least 80 percent of that money would have to be used to provide "free or low-cost meals or supplements to economically disadvantaged children.
"There is no requirement in this bill we can find for free lunch or free breakfast," said Ellen Haas, Under Secretary of Agriculture for Food, Nutrition and Consumer Services. Mr. Presta, the committee spokesman, said that the grants would have to be used for poor children, but he would not specifically say that free lunches would continue.
The remaining 20 percent of the block grant could be used for other programs unrelated to school lunches or breakfasts, further reducing the money available to schools for meals.
The legislation calls for freezing the 1996 budget at the 1995 level. The block grants for 1996 are $ 300 million less than the Administration's proposed budget, which considered higher food costs and greater participation. Over five years, there would be a $ 2 billion decrease in funds.
If a state chose not to subsidize meals for children who pay full price, it would have to raise prices, which would probably mean schools would drop out of the program, because participation would drop. Every time the cost of meals goes up by 1 cent, participation drops by 1 percent. When the budget for school meal programs was slashed during the Reagan Administration, participation dropped to 23 million students, from 26 million students, and more than 2,000 schools dropped out. School officials say that because of certain fixed costs, they cannot reduce expenses in proportion to the income lost when students drop out.
Patty Morris, executive assistant to Ms. Haas, said states would be able to do what they chose, nutritionally. "What you will probably see is all the fast-food chains serving school lunches because it's easier and it's cheaper."
The current program must adhere to standards set by the National Academy of Science, which require that children get one-third of the Recommended Daily Allowances for certain vitamins and minerals. New standards were to take effect next year requiring school lunches to adhere to United States Dietary Guidelines that set limits for fat.
"With 50 different states setting 50 different standards, from historical experience we know some states will want to economize," Ms. Haas said. "That's what happened when the food-stamp programs were run by the states."
What has physicians, antihunger advocates and directors of food-service programs so concerned is the potential impact a greatly reduced and nutritionally inadequate school-meal program could have on the health of the poorest children.
Studies have demonstrated the benefits of school feeding programs. In 1987, researchers at Boston and Tufts universities looked at achievement test results of children for a year before and a year after the breakfast program began. The program was credited with causing significant improvements in attendance and standardized achievement test scores.
Dr. Larry Brown, director of the Center on Hunger, Poverty and Nutrition Policy at Tufts University, said the budget cuts and the block grants were coming at a time when "researchers have learned that the young child is even more susceptible to mild undernutrition than science previously knew."
"If more poor children don't get school lunch and school breakfast, which is inevitable, we are cutting off our nose to spite our face," he said.
Dr. T. Barry Brazelton, the pediatrician, was also gloomy. "You'd hope that states would take responsibility about nutrition, but our experience in the past is that the states with the largest group of people in poverty and the highest risk people are the states that are more whimsical about how they use their nutrition programs."
The final House bill is not expected to differ substantially from the bill being worked on today. The chance to make some changes may come in the Senate with Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, who has been a strong advocate of Federal nutrition programs for the last 30 years.
So was President Nixon, who said in 1969: "A child ill fed is dulled in curiosity, lower in stamina, distracted from learning."

An entry last Sunday in the calendar of cultural events in the New Jersey Weekly, about "Collecting African-American Art," an event today at 7:30 P.M. in Montclair, misstated the type of program, its sponsorship and its location. It will be held at the museum, not the Blooming Grove Theater.

HEADLINE: Income Gap Persists for Blacks and Whites

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Despite public policies intended to forge a measure of economic equality between races, little progress has been made in recent years in narrowing the income gap between whites and blacks, according to two reports issued by the Census Bureau today.
The reports said that in 1993 the median income for black men employed full time was $23,020, about three-quarters of the $31,090 that white men, a proportional disparity that improved only slightly since 1979. 
 Among women, a narrower income gap between blacks and whites widened slightly in the same 14 years, the reports said. In 1979, the median income for black women was about 92 percent of white women's; in 1993, the last year for which the Census bureau had complete data, the median income for black women, $19,820, was 90 percent of the $22,020 earned by white women.
Some blacks seized on the income gaps as evidence of continuing discrimination and the need to maintain affirmative-action programs, which are under increasing attack in the new Republican-controlled Congress and elsewhere.
"It has a made a critical difference," said Eddie N. Williams, president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a policy research institution specializing in issues related to African Americans.
In light of data showing that the income gap between whites and blacks had not significantly improved, Mr. Williams said, "Do we continue to need some effort on the part of government to address disparities which are, in part, based on racial discrimination?"
But while the census buttressed the arguments of those who favor maintaining preference programs based on sex or race, it also offered evidence of why some white men contend they are getting a smaller slice of the economic pie.
According to the report, the median income for men dropped from 1979 and 1993, adjusted for inflation, while the figure for women increased during the same period. White men experienced the largest drop in income, about 10 percent, while the median income for black men dropped about 8 percent.
In contrast, while still lagging behind white men, the median income for white women rose by 10 percent, and by 8 per cent for black women.
Income disparities aside, the two reports -- "The Black Population in the United States: March 1994 and 1993" and "Characteristics of the Black Population" -- include some surprisingly upbeat findings on the state of African Americans, who often are defined by their problems.
For example, the data showed that 28 percent of college-educated black men who worked full time in 1993 held executive, administrative or managerial jobs, nearly identical to the 30 percent of white men in that same category.
The reports also indicated that the high school dropout rate among blacks had improved, to about 5 percent in 1993, nearly identical to the white rate of 4 percent.
In contrast to many reports indicating widespread out-of-wedlock births among blacks, the report said 90 per cent of black girls from the ages of 15 to 17 were childless, and that 76 per cent of those aged 18 and 19 had no children.
Indeed, the rate of babies being born to unwed black teen-agers -- about 80 per 1,000 unmarried teen-agers -- remained virtually the same from 1970 through 1990, the report said. Consequently, what had been described as the sharp increase in the number of black children born out of wedlock resulted less from an increase in the percentage of single women giving birth and more from declining birth rates among black married couples, said the chief of the Racial Statistics Branch of the Census Bureau, Roderick Harrison.
Moreover, said Margaret C. Simms, director of Research Programs at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, the data also indicate that, contrary to the image of a population locked into welfare dependency, more than three-fourths of single black mothers held jobs.
"The data present a fuller picture of the African-American population," Ms. Simms said, "one that shows them, for the most part, in the mainstream of American society -- large numbers working, young people doing the right thing, in school, completing school, not having children. So it reflects a portrait that looks like a group trying to achieve the American dream, just like other portions of American society."
