HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
The Federal Reserve may be done raising interest rates. The chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, told Congress that there was evidence that the economy "may finally be slowing" and suggested that if it sank too fast the Fed would move quickly to reverse course and even cut interest rates. [Page A1.]
A proposed ban of contractors that use replacement workers drew fire from Congressional leaders and business groups. [D2.]
House Republicans began writing tort legislation that would bring sweeping changes in the role of Federal and state courts in lawsuits involving consumers and manufacturers. [A19.]
Union members involved in three labor struggles in Decatur, Ill., pressed A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders for help. [B8.]
 
Companies
 
Hanson P.L.C. plans to spin off 34 American subsidiaries into a new company that would start with $1.4 billion in debt. [D1.]
A top multimedia company is finding itself squeezed by the industry it helped create. More computers are sold with multimedia built in, so Creative Labs is trying to increase sales to computer makers and broaden into new areas. [D1.]
The battle over a videodisk standard has flared anew. Sony and Phillips said they would move ahead with a new format that would compete with a standard proposed by Time Warner and Toshiba. The announcement surprised many industry executives. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Mexico Said to Promise Some Political Steps to Get U.S. Loans

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Despite the insistence of Mexico that it would not accept any political conditions on $20 billion it is to receive in loans and loan guarantees from Washington, officials said today that it did agree to sweeten the deal with new measures to control undocumented immigration into the United States and drug trafficking.
Mindful of the sensitivity of Mexico to the notion that it acted under American pressure, United States officials noted that its commitments grew out of discussions begun before the loan talks and reflected longstanding concerns of President Ernesto Zedillo. 
 But the Americans also acknowledged having pressed Mexico for quick results -- first to avoid more stringent political conditions on a $40 billion plan that the Administration ultimately abandoned, then to try to mollify Congressional opposition to the $20 billion agreement signed on Tuesday.
"There was clearly a commitment by the Mexicans before the financial crisis to work in these areas," one American official said. "But we've definitely made an effort to get some of these things more quickly and in writing."
In at least some areas, Mexico's promises appeared to be neither binding nor particularly specific. For instance, while the Zedillo Government pledged to crack down on the leaders of a notorious cocaine-smuggling organization, the so-called Gulf Cartel, American officials said their private agreement included few details about how Mexico would do so.
Still, the accords were focused deliberately on some of the most contentious issues on the bilateral agenda. And officials said the Administration had already begun presenting them to legislators who have complained for weeks that the United States was getting little in return for its sizable efforts to rescue Mexico's economy.
"There's a lot of politics involved," the United States Ambassador to Mexico, James R. Jones, said in an interview today. "A lot of U.S. congressmen wanted to claim credit for forcing Mexicans to do things that they didn't want to do. I always felt that if you put these things into a package, it would undermine what we are trying to do."
Under draft legislation proposed last month by the House Banking Committee, part of the package called for Mexico to halt the debt-for-equity swaps under which the Government has forgiven hundreds of millions of dollars in Cuban debt in exchange for equity given to Mexican investors in Cuba, said officials who saw the draft.
A senior Mexican official said such conditions were rejected as "totally impossible."
Yet the accords that were finally reached appear to overlap closely with proposals that the State Department made to Mexico as part of a side letter that was intended to keep political conditions out of the loan-guarantee legislation itself.
Steps that Mexico agreed to take on undocumented immigrants included new measures to break up immigrant-smuggling rings, the expansion of a border anti-crime force and a promise to shut down a network of water tunnels in Nogales that are often used for smuggling immigrants.

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS BEGIN DEEP BUDGET CUTS IN 5 HOUSE PANELS

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
 Setting the tone for promised reductions in the Federal budget, House Republicans today began moving on the first of up to $15 billion in cuts to the current budget, marking for elimination many social programs championed by Democrats for decades.
Calling the action a first installment on their promise to balance the budget by 2002, Republicans approved cuts in job training and education, assistance to homeless youths and veterans, foreign aid to Russian republics, money for United Nations peacekeeping operations and Federal subsidies to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. 
 If they stand, the cuts approved by five subcommittees today -- and those to be made by eight other panels in the next few days -- will eliminate many of the social programs that conservatives have criticized as wasteful and redundant.
But the Democrats, with President Clinton in the forefront, have already begun to fight back, and many of the midyear cuts in the 1995 fiscal year budget are expected to run into resistance in the Senate, which will not take them up until the House has completed its work.
After a strategy session with Democrats on Capitol Hill today, Mr. Clinton emerged to lambaste the Republicans for a proposal to replace the Federal school lunch program in the budget for the 1996 fiscal year with block grants to the states, calling it "a terrible mistake."
The most influential of the subcommittees -- Labor, Health, Human Services and Education -- proposed cutting $4.3 billion, affecting 142 programs, including 84 that were marked for elimination.
Among them were dozens of youth-training and education programs, like the Clinton Administration's Goals 2000, which sets national standards for secondary education. The Republicans would also reduce the $3.5 billion Head Start program by $105 million, eliminate $1.3 billion for the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance program that provides fuel oil to the needy and would mark for termination a host of grants, like the National Science Scholars ($4.4 million) and the Javits Fellowships ($7.5 million).
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting's $285.6 million budget was not marked for cuts this year, but in 1996 its budget would be cut by 15 percent, or $47 million, with an additional $94 million, or 30 percent of its current budget, pared in 1997. Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the panel, said, "It represents the first whack in what the Speaker has said will be the total elimination of funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting."
The Republicans' spending plans for this year would sharply alter some foreign-aid policies. They would cut $47.7 million of a promised $850 million in assistance to the independent states of the former Soviet Union, and $4.5 million of the $75 million that the United States had pledged to contribute this year to United Nations peacekeeping operations. A last-minute appeal from the White House preserved intact aid to Egypt and Jordan.
Also facing elimination are the drug-free schools program ($481.9 million), an education program for homeless youth ($28.8 million), job training for homeless veterans ($5 million), and a program to provide high-school equivalency diplomas to migrants ($8.1 million), as well as a college assistance for migrants ($2.2 million).
"There's too much money and too much personnel to administer -- we have to cut something," said Representative John Edward Porter of Illinois, chairman of the Labor, Health, Human Services and Education subcommittee, noting that his panel had 163 Federal job-training programs and 240 education programs under its jurisdiction alone.
The cuts, known as rescissions, are part of a midyear review that is a common occurrence on Capitol Hill. But the Republicans' proposed cuts, which could total $15 billion, are more sweeping than usual -- President Clinton proposed only $1.1 billion -- and are designed to give the Republicans both fiscal and political mileage.
The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, called the proposed cuts "monumental." He said that the rescissions would have to be large enough to pay for all the supplemental appropriations requested by the White House, to cover the cost of the Republicans' proposed $500 per child tax credit and to provide a down payment toward the Republicans' goal of balancing the budget by 2002.
"The total rescission bill will amount to $10 to $15 billion," Mr. Livingston said.
With majorities in both the House and the Senate, the Republicans think they can get the cuts through Congress. But President Clinton could veto them, and the Republicans would then need significant help from Democrats to achieve the two-thirds majority -- 290 votes in the House and 67 votes in the Senate -- to override a veto.
Led by Speaker Newt Gingrich, the Republicans held a flag-festooned gathering on Capitol Hill today to mark the midpoint of their 100-day pledge to act on the provisions of their Contract With America.
There were rock and roll music, tiny American flags and copies of the Contract for everyone in the audience. Business representatives and crime victims also appeared, to offer testimonials about the strides made so far in what its adherents regard as a Republican revolution.
Democrats observed the day with the sort of oratorical bashing that has become their prime weapon against the Republicans. "Halfway to nowhere is still nowhere," the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said the day represented. "The fact is, the Contract With America does absolutely nothing to address the problems most Americans face in their daily lives -- good jobs, affordable health care, access to quality education, and a rising standard of living."
The five subcommittees of the Republican-controlled House Appropriations Committee that reported rescission bills today were Agriculture; Energy and Water Development; Foreign Operations; Interior; and Labor, Health, Human Services and Education. Mr. Livingston said that five more subcommittees would reports on Thursday and the remaining three would complete their work by next week.
About half the spending cuts proposed today, including those for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, were outlined by the Labor, Health, Human Services and Education subcommittee. The panel met late into the nigh, with Democrats offering dozens of amendments to try to save programs from cuts, and Republicans systematically voting them down.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting receives $285.6 million of its annual $1.8 billion budget from Washington. By Federal budget standards, it is a small amount of money. But in political terms, it has long been one of the biggest targets of conservatives, who have accused the corporation's leaders of using the money to promote a liberal agenda and programming with a liberal bias.
The corporation was created by Congress in 1967.
 The Republicans proposed dropping $191.6 million from programs that fell under the jurisdiction of the Foreign Operations subcommittee, including $152.6 million from the $5 billion budget for economic aid distributed by the Agency for International Development. They also outlined millions of dollars in cuts to dozens of domestic programs -- many of them agricultural and others involving regional authorities -- that have long been popular pork-barrel items for members on both sides of the aisle.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Faces Issue of Economic Spying

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
It was so much easier during the cold war.
Once, the Central Intelligence Agency's station in Paris stole secrets about the French nuclear arsenal and the local Communist Party chief. Now it is trying to steal the French position on trade talks with the United States. 
 As the balance of terror becomes less important and the balance of payments more so, the intelligence agency has struggled with the question of economic espionage. Are the risks, amply demonstrated by the embarrassing request by France that the C.I.A.'s former station chief in Paris and at least four of his undercover officers leave the country, worth the rewards? Should it be done at all?
"That is the real crisis of American intelligence -- what is the clandestine service supposed to be doing these days?" said Thomas Polgar, a retired C.I.A. officer and former station chief in Bonn and Saigon.
"In the good old days, when the Soviet Union was a going concern, learning the intentions and capabilities of the enemy had a potential impact on the national security of the United States," Mr. Polgar said. "The question of whether or not the French allow fewer Disney movies into their country does not affect the national security of the United States."
France's position on the import of American movies and other "cultural goods" nearly derailed the final talks last year on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The orders to the intelligence agency's Paris station to steal economic data from the French and the entrapment of the agency's officers by French counterintelligence reflect the fact that the C.I.A. thinks that the risks of stealing trade secrets are worth the potential payoff.
"The agency for last five years or so has been wrestling with the question of whether it has a role in support of American industry," said E. Norbert Garrett, a former C.I.A. station chief and a managing director at Kroll Associates, a leading international risk management company.
"It may sound crazy, using an intelligence apparatus to find out the French position on how many American movies we can import," he said. "But if it was of sufficient importance to the American side in the trade negotiations, you could make a case that there's a role."
The United States has many ways to steal information from foreign countries, including spy satellites and electronic eavesdropping, but the officers of the clandestine service of the C.I.A. contend that only they can obtain certain secrets.
The agency has boasted to Congressional intelligence committees for the last two years that it is able to obtain scoops on trade talks, diplomatic negotiations and foreign nations' compliance with their obligations under treaties.
But if only the C.I.A.'s spies can steal these secrets, they are also the only ones who can get into real trouble.
"When you engage in espionage, you engage in activity that is completely illegal," Mr. Polgar said. "You are engaged in a conspiracy to commit a crime. Whatever the target was in this case, it had to be worth a lot to take that kind of risk, although I imagine that you could get the French position on GATT without spying on them."
Allies spy on allies all the time. After Japan, France ranks among the allies and economic competitors that attract the most scrutiny from the C.I.A.
For instance, France's state-owned telecommunications giant has aggressively pursued contracts to build advanced telephone networks in developing countries. United States officials contend that unlike American competitors, which have to weigh profits and losses carefully, the French company will grab for everything it can, knowing that the Government can absorb losses.
American officials also maintain that the French are willing to bribe foreign officials -- and in fact tried to last year when bidding against an American consortium to develop a satellite surveillance system for the Amazon basin. The United States won the bid, but only after exercising political pressure.
The question is whether any of these issues rise to a question of national security, or indeed whether the C.I.A. is equipped to handle them, Mr. Polgar said.
"Maybe there are economic issues that are important," he said. "But the question that is unanswered is, what can the C.I.A. do about them that the rest of the American Government cannot?"

HEADLINE: Democrats Assail G.O.P. Bill to Change School Lunch System

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
With President Clinton in the vanguard, Democrats today began a campaign of guerrilla warfare against House Republican proposals to scrap the Federal school lunch program and give states a lump sum of Federal money to feed children.
"An old conservative adage used to be, 'If it ain't broke don't fix it,' " Mr. Clinton said after a strategy session with Democrats in Congress. 
 Republicans appeared to have the votes needed to approve the legislation in the House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities, which is responsible for the child nutrition programs, including school lunch. But Democrats predicted that the Senate would not approve it and said that the President would veto it if it did.
Although he did not go quite that far, Mr. Clinton said it would be "a terrible mistake" to end the program. He added: "Here's a program that isn't broke, that's done a world of good for millions and millions of children of all races and backgrounds all across our country, and I think it would be a terrible mistake to put an end to it, to gut it, to undermine it. And I hope that my party will stand against this."
Representative Bill Goodling, the Pennsylvania Republican who heads the committee, said he had hoped that the panel would vote today to approve the bill, a keystone of the House Republicans' legislative agenda for the first 100 days of the new Congress.
Although he is a longtime defender of the school lunch program, Mr. Goodling said he was under a mandate from House Republican leaders to change the school lunch program. These changes, he said, will not destroy the program, but will improve it "by cutting out layers of regulations and paperwork, and by allowing states far more flexibility."
The bill would not only cut the amount of money that states get now, but would also give states vast new discretion to design their own food programs in place of the school lunch program and the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children, or WIC. The two programs serve more than 30 million people.
Under the Republican proposal, money for these and other nutrition programs would be consolidated in two lump sum payments, or block grants, providing states with a maximum of $11.3 billion next year. Democrats asserted that the bill would cut $7 billion, or 10 percent, from the amount that would otherwise be spent on such assistance over the next five years.
The ranking Democrat on the committee, Representative William L. Clay of Missouri, said the changes "will potentially starve hundreds of thousands of children and imperil the health of their mothers."
Representative Major R. Owens, a Brooklyn Democrat, said there was no guarantee that in the future Congress would appropriate the full amounts allowed by the bill or provide any extra money in times of recession.
"These programs took years and years to create," Mr. Owens said. "Now this committee will, in a barbaric way, wipe it all out."
Representative Tim Roemer, Democrat of Indiana, said it was virtually certain that Congress would provide less than the authorized amounts if the Constitution is amended to required a balanced Federal budget. Moreover, he noted, the bill would allow states to use up to 20 percent of their food assistance money for other purposes like welfare, child care and social services.
The Democrats said there was abundant evidence that the school lunch and WIC programs were achieving the purposes for which they were created, to improve the health and nutrition of children and pregnant women. Democrats said the Republicans had cut a political deal with Republican governors, ignoring the needs of poor people.
Farm groups, including the National Milk Producers Federation and the Sun Diamond Growers of California, which sells fruit and nuts, said they objected to the block grant proposal. They like the current school lunch program, in part because the Government buys surplus commodities, keeping prices higher than they would otherwise be.
Republicans said governors wanted the authority to design welfare and food assistance programs to meet local needs. But Sheri E. Steisel, a policy analyst at the National Conference of State Legislatures, said: "We have never suggested a block grant for nutrition programs. We have never asked for consolidation of the school lunch and WIC programs in a block grant."

HEADLINE: House Moves to Kill A Penn Station Plan

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The House voted today to take back $40 million that had been set aside to rebuild Penn Station in New York City, a cut that would effectively kill the $315 million project if it is not restored in the Senate.
The action was part of an effort to finance $3.2 billion in military programs by pulling back on money appropriated for other uses last year, taking $1.5 billion from within the military budget and $1.4 billion from other programs. 
 But some New Yorkers in Congress said the 262-165 vote was a slap to New York, which under the bill would also lose money intended for a technological reinvestment programs that would have helped ailing Long Island defense firms transform their operations.
In addition, New York would lose money for job training programs for young people and for school improvement construction, an area considered especially important since a recent General Accounting Office report on conditions in schools found New York State had a pressing need to rebuild schools.
Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat who represents parts of Westchester County, the Bronx and Queens, spoke in support of the Penn Station project on the House floor, saying, "There is no good reason why this project was singled out for the budget ax, except for the fact that New York bashing is always in season."
She said Penn Station is important to the regional economy because 75 million people pass through the station every year. It is Amtrak's busiest station and the hub of the city's transit system, the Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit.
Some New York Republicans in the House, including Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island, said they would like to support the Penn Station project but think that insuring military readiness is more important.
Now, the fight will move to the Senate, where the Penn Station project has bipartisan support from Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato. The project is to receive $100 million from the Federal Government, $100 million from the city and state, and $115 million from Amtrak bonds and private investors. A total of $10 million in Federal money has already been spent.
The project is intended to transform Penn Station into a commercial as well as transportation hub along the lines of Union Station in Washington.
"This fight is not over," said William T. Cunningham, Senator Moynihan's chief of staff. "This is not at the expense of our servicemen and women. It was appropriated last year for a very worthwhile project. This station will hit gridlock in six years if nothing is done, and you could get a world-class station, a facility worthy of the region."
"It is not just about New York City," he said.

HEADLINE: Congress Presses Russia, And Clinton, Over Iran Deal

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The Administration is struggling to resolve differences with Russia while leading Republicans threaten to withhold aid unless Moscow cancels a nuclear energy deal with Iran.
In recent days, a number of Republicans in Congress have said that Russia's $1 billion deal to build four nuclear reactors would speed Iran's quest for nuclear weapons and that they were prepared to use aid as a weapon to stop it. 
 The move reflects a growing sentiment in Congress that the Administration has been too solicitous of President Boris N. Yeltsin and too tolerant of uncooperative behavior by Russia on other issues as well, including its continued military siege of Chechnya, its failure to give a full accounting of its arms sales to Iran and its uneven efforts at political and economic reform.
But clearly the most contentious issue -- and the one likely to evoke the greatest response in Congress and among Americans -- is Russia's nuclear energy deal with Iran.
"I would like the message to be very clear: this deal threatens Russian aid, period," Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who is chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee for foreign aid, said in an interview.
Mr. McConnell, who has charged that the Administration became "cheerleaders" for Mr. Yeltsin, added: "This is not the kind of behavior we expect of a country that purports to be an ally and aid recipient. This thing could really be a deal-breaker."
On Tuesday the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, issued a similar threat to "cut off all aid to Russia" if reports of its nuclear energy deal with Iran were true. "We cannot tolerate Iran getting weapons of mass destruction," Mr. Gingrich said in an interview with The Washington Times.
Even some Democrats who have staunchly supported aid to Russia predict that the nuclear deal could lead Congress to slash the $269 million aid request for next year.
"The political reality is that aid may well be cut off because of inexplicably stupid moves on the part of Russia," Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, said in an interview. "The Russians could try the patience of a saint."
For more than a year, the Administration has asked Russia repeatedly -- and to no avail -- not to complete plans to sell Iran nuclear power plants. The issue took on new urgency on Monday when Russia's Nuclear Energy Minister said that the deal had been concluded and that about 150 Russians were already working on a reactor site at Bushehr on the Persian Gulf.
The Administration has also failed to persuade Russia's leaders to end the offensive in Chechnya.
In addition, senior State Department officials are unhappy with a trip to Belgrade last weekend by the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, during which he advised the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, to demand that international sanctions be lifted before he made any concessions.
Finally, Mr. Yeltsin has given the United States an incomplete accounting of Russia's current conventional arms deals with Iran, contrary to a pledge he made to Mr. Clinton at a summit in Washington in September. Russia's refusal to halt its arms sales to Iran are delaying the an international treaty aimed at stemming the spread of weapons and arms-related equipment and technology to potentially dangerous nations.
The Administration finds itself in the awkward situation of defending aid to Russia even as Moscow is ignoring American protests.
In the first of two days of meetings today with Georgi Mamedov, Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister, the Deputy Secretary of State, Strobe Talbott, focused less on the problem areas and more on the issue of the expansion of NATO, a senior Administration official said.
Despite tensions, the United States is eager to create a special relationship between NATO and Russia, including a high-level Washington-Moscow dialogue, senior Administration officials said.
In a subsequent meeting today with Mr. Mamedov, Lynn Davis, the Under Secretary of State for arms control, stressed the importance of canceling the Iran nuclear deal.
Secretary of Defense William J. Perry made the same point in a meeting on Tuesday with Russia's First Deputy Defense Minister, Andrei A. Kokoshin, explaining that the matter was urgent because of the Republican-dominated Congress.
The Russians have argued that they have every right to sell such technology to Iran, particularly because the United States and its allies have agreed to supply North Korea with nuclear technology free.

HEADLINE: 5 Americans Are Called Spies By France and Told to Leave

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 22

 BODY:
 France has accused five Americans, including the former C.I.A. station chief here and his deputy, of political and economic espionage and asked them to leave the country immediately, French officials said today.
The other Americans who were asked to leave were two other C.I.A. agents, who are listed in diplomatic jobs on the roster of the United States Embassy, and a woman working as an undercover C.I.A. agent who lacks diplomatic status, according to an article published today in Le Monde and confirmed by diplomats. 
 The Americans were accused of trying to bribe high-ranking French Government officials into disclosing France's negotiating position on movies and entertainment in recent global trade talks, secrets about French domestic politics, and telecommunications.
The spectacle of one ally publicly demanding the withdrawal of another's diplomats for spying plunged relations between France and the United States into one of the strangest crises of their history.
Pamela Harriman, the United States Ambassador to France, visited the office of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur to discuss the affair this afternoon, American Embassy officials said. She emerged impassive after 30 minutes and said she would make no comment.
In an unusual joint statement, the French Interior Ministry and Foreign Ministry said that the French Government had never intended the affair to become public. But they said the American Embassy had been asked to withdraw the diplomats for activities incompatible with their status here.
The statement did not say how many diplomats were involved, and some French reports said there may have been as many as six.
In Washington, the State Department described the allegations as unjustified and said it was reviewing the incident. It spoke only of the accusations in the French press.
"We regard allegations in the French press, citing French Government sources, concerning purported official U.S. activities, as being unwarranted," a department spokeswoman, Christine Shelly, said.
"The handling of this matter in France is inconsistent with the approach that allies have taken to resolve sensitive matters in the past," she said. "There is no reason for expelling any Americans, nor is the French Government calling for it."
Other State Department officials, saying that the French planned no expulsions, added privately that the American officials would be moved out of France according to their regular rotations.
A spokeswoman at the American Embassy in Paris, asked how many of the four embassy diplomats were still in France, said only, "All of them are working or have worked at the embassy." She gave no further elaboration.
Earlier in the day, Prime Minister Balladur tried to treat the matter lightly. "The French people are friends of the American people and the French Government is a friend of the American Government," he said. "Events like that occur regularly on both sides of the Atlantic."
But seldom, if ever, have there been such spectacular sparks between allies, according to old C.I.A. hands and diplomats. Many said they could not recall anything to match the incident since the height of the cold war, when Moscow and Washington periodically cleaned out each other's spy networks. This time, the protagonists were officials who presumably dealt with each other regularly on such common threats as international terrorism and organized crime.
A senior Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said tonight that the French Government had fed the spying story to the news media in a background briefing. He speculated that the main aim was to move the spotlight away from a wiretapping scandal that has embarrassed the French Government.
The French Interior Minister, Charles Pasqua, has been under fire this week for authorizing secret wiretaps, and the stir has set back Prime Minister Balladur's campaign to succeed President Francois Mitterrand in elections this spring.
"We're not speculating, but the issue may be related to Pasqua's political fortunes," the senior Administration official said. "In France, the speculation is exactly that, in relation to the timing and the handling of the incident."
The official said the French Government's background briefing with the news media about the accused spies was "totally unprecedented."
"We're declining to get into the substance of the allegations except to say they're vastly overblown," the official added.
Le Monde also speculated that Mr. Pasqua, who is in charge of the counterespionage service, would not be displeased by a report that distracted attention from the wiretapping scandal.
That friendly countries also spy on each other's economic and business secrets these days is taken for granted. It is also assumed that friendly diplomats occasionally have privately been asked to leave after getting into mischief.
Two years ago, French officials themselves were embarrassed by the disclosure of a 21-page Government document that targeted 21 American aerospace companies for industrial espionage. Yet a scandal of this dimension between allies has few, if any, recent parallels.
The French struck back this time, according to official accounts cited by Le Monde, because the Americans broke the rules of the game -- offering bribes, in 500-franc (equivalent to $100) bills, to at least three high-ranking officials since 1992.
"The clandestine research detected concentrated essentially on French domestic politics as well as on the broad economic and commercial policies of our country, in particular in the audiovisual domain and in telecommunications," according to a counterespionage report quoted by the newspaper.
Among the pieces of evidence gathered by the counterspies, the newspaper reported, were photographs of clandestine meetings between the C.I.A. agents and their French contacts, hotel registration papers and credit card imprints proving the use of false identities by American agents, and the serial numbers of 500-franc bills paid to one of the French officials.
The newspaper's report detailed three approaches made by the Americans. In the first, a woman "acting for the C.I.A. in Paris," approached an unnamed conservative Member of Parliament close to Mr. Balladur's Government.
He informed counterespionage officials of the approach and was told to go along with it to try to trap the Americans, the report said. He was later approached seven times "by a known C.I.A. officer coming from Brussels and operating under false identity," according to the report, and was offered bribes to disclose the French negotiating position on the global trade talks in 1992 and 1993.
France compromised in response to Washington's demands to lower agricultural subsidies worldwide, but only at the last minute, at the end of 1993. The United States agreed to drop its insistence that Europeans stop trying to keep American movies and television programs from flooding their markets, but it demanded on quotas and subsidies for European-produced entertainment.
The second approach, Le Monde said, was to an unnamed high official in the Ministry of Communications who was in charge of audiovisual policy. He, too, was offered bribes, the report said, for information about French strategy on audiovisual policy and on telecommunications. He, too, pretended to cooperate until very recently, the report said.
The third person allegedly recruited by the C.I.A., according to the report, was a technician, also not named, for the international network of France Telecom, the country's telecommunications network.
Until last Jan. 27, the report said, the technician pretended to work with the C.I.A., turning over "documents and technical details on the structures and international networks of France Telecom, in exchange for remuneration and valuable technical materials."
The previous day, Jan. 26, Mrs. Harriman was summoned by the Interior Minister, Mr. Pasqua, to his office. Mr. Pasqua told the American Ambassador what the counterespionage service had discovered, Le Monde said, and asked her to see to it that the five accused Americans left the country immediately.
Mr. Pasqua repeated this demand in a letter sent to Mrs. Harriman on Feb. 1, Le Monde said.
On Feb. 3, according to the newspaper, she replied to Mr. Pasqua that she would report the accusations to Washington. The Interior Minister summoned her again on Feb. 10, according to Le Monde, again asking her to get the accused diplomats out of the country soon.
Mr. Pasqua informed President Mitterrand of the affair on Feb. 18, Le Monde said. The newspaper's publication of the report today immediately replaced the scandal about the Government's authorization of wire taps.

HEADLINE: A Struggle to Deal With a $20 Billion Precedent

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
As the United States and Mexico argued about the last details of a $20 billion rescue plan last week, one of the Clinton Administration's top economic officials fielded the same question time and again in his travels through Brazil and Argentina: If Mexico's ills spread, is the United States prepared to bail out its other big trading partners?
Much like other Administration officials, from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin to Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Jeffrey E. Garten, the traveling Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade, hemmed and hawed a bit in response to the question. 
 "Of course, I told them Mexico was a very special case for us," Mr. Garten recalled replying, "because much more was at stake here than just trade. But honestly, no one can answer this question. And if we could you could never signal the answer in advance."
It is an uncomfortable question because it cuts to the heart of the emerging American post-cold-war role in the world. American troops have been stationed in Europe and Asia for decades as the guarantors of territorial security and protectors of United States interests abroad. But in Mexico, the United States has just stationed billions of dollars of capital and an elite unit of financial police, declaring that otherwise hundreds of thousands of American jobs might be lost and a financial panic could spread through emerging markets around the world.
It is compelling if unpopular logic. But it has left many in Washington wondering where to draw the line: What countries are now so vital to the new American economy that they cannot be allowed to fail?
Moreover, doesn't the Mexican bailout send an unwanted message to countries and those who invest in them around the world? Overborrow, overspend and fear not, because in the new international economy, everyone is so interdependent that there is always a bailout around the corner.
Not surprisingly, the message that the Administration is trying to send to the markets these days is a simple one: Don't count on it.
"Mexico was unique," Mr. Rubin said. The reason, of course, is the porous border with the United States. The financial turmoil in Mexico City, the White House kept reminding Congress, would be measured by the number of illegal aliens flowing into California and Texas. And then there are the 700,000 jobs the Administration contends are dependent on exports to Mexico, including 130,000 created in the last year.
Indeed, Mexico has virtually matched Japan as the second-largest market for American exports behind Canada. Through the third quarter of last year, Mexicans bought more than $51 billion in goods from the United States, compared with $51.7 billion by Japanese and $112 billion by Canadians.
Mexico had other special characteristics. More than most other big emerging-market countries like Argentina and China, it has been heavily dependent on short-term financing from abroad. That is the kind of investment that mutual fund managers can redirect with a few clicks on their computer keyboards, calling their money back to the United States or sending it elsewhere.
One lesson of the crisis is that it is safer to follow the example of countries like China and Indonesia, which have depended more heavily on foreign direct investment to build roads, factories and other necessary supports for economic growth. It takes a lot longer to move a car factory out of the country than it takes to get a short-term bond out.
And finally, as Mr. Rubin has said many times, Mexico has been the prototype economy, an exemplar of the way to privatize big industries, open markets and create a growing middle class eager to buy imports. If the prototype failed, he argued, it would discourage countries like Russia or even South Korea from following the same path.
But in one respect, Mexico was hardly special. It was one of the many emerging markets outside the United States, Europe and Japan in which Americans had dived headlong in recent years through mutual funds, lured by projections of huge profits and apparently unconcerned that they had only a vague idea of what made those economies tick.
Mr. Rubin feared that if investors decided to bail out of Mexico, they would bail out of everything that vaguely resembled Mexico in what he termed a "catalytic effect." There are suggestions that he was right. When Mexico's stock market declined, it took much of Latin America with it many days, and it was blamed, rightly or wrongly, for plunges as far away as Poland and Hong Kong.
That could have happened 20 years ago as well, of course. But as the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, pointed out in recent testimony, now it can happen so much more quickly. "In today's world," he said, "Mexico became the first casualty, if I may put it that way, of the new international financial system."
Mr. Greenspan is among those warning that the bailout, which he heartily supported, could create what economists call a "moral hazard." That is, investors looking at emerging markets could factor in the prospects of a bailout if everything goes bad. That, in turn, could keep the markets from accurately assessing the risk of investing in, say, Argentina or Indonesia.
As a result, Mr. Greenspan urged that any bailouts must emulate the Mexican rescue and carry such high costs and rigorous terms that investors worry that they would pay a price, as well.
Now the bailout theory has a new wrinkle. Because this one cost the United States so much, there is a new drive to overhaul the International Monetary Fund and other international organizations so that the United States Treasury does not become the World Market-Emergency Fund. Here, too, the fear is that such an overhaul might encourage more countries to live at the edge, knowing that there are bigger institutions around to save their necks.
The issue will be among the key topics at the Group of Seven meeting of leading industrial nations in Halifax, Nova Scotia, this summer. But in the meantime, the United States is saying anew that no one should expect to be treated the way the Mexicans were.
"It would be very foolish if we didn't learn from this," Mr. Christopher said last week to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. "It was fortunate that the President had available $20 billion in a stabilization fund that he could bring to bear on this particular crisis."
But $20 billion does not grow on trees, he noted, and "the United States probably could not handle a second crisis like that."

HEADLINE: Still Married to Christ, and Never Happier;
As Fewer Women Become Nuns, Sisters Say the Calling's Rewards Have Expanded

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

 BODY:
Elaine Roulet smiled back in time at her own sense of girlish idealism as she recalled the white bridal gown of 46 years ago, when she followed the chapel aisle straight toward the perceived will of God.
"It was so exciting, so romantic, to walk down that aisle as a bride of Christ and come back as a nun," said the 63-year-old woman, a Sister of Saint Joseph, stylishly gray now in checked suit and earrings as she survives as one of the toughest and most adaptive in the modern Roman Catholic church's rapidly dwindling ranks of the sisterhood. 
 "You were enshrined in these wonderful robes and had all this mystery about you and felt and even smelled holy," Sister Elaine continued, finally laughing out loud at such innocent conceits as she sat a lifetime later in a Queens ghetto convent depleted of nuns but bursting with the lives of female ex-convicts and their children.
The nun savored a wisp of nostalgia as she conceded having saved some of the veil and wimple pins that once kept her bedecked securely in the perfect black-and-white order of the past. "There was such a purity about it," she said. "It was so uncomplicated, you know?"
"And now it's so complicated, but so much better," she added, happier as a nun than ever before even as she exemplified the bittersweet paradox of the modern sisterhood. Here she is, freelancing amid God's poor in a truly creative spiritual life that seems to be evaporating around her as fewer and fewer young women replenish the ranks.
Once the glory of the striving postwar second-generation wave of immigrants from Catholic Europe, the American church's sisterhood has been halved, to fewer than 100,000 nuns in the last 30 years. And it continues dwindling and aging: 97 percent of nuns are 40 or older and the median age at 65 and rising.
Yet those like Sister Elaine who have remained, prevailing in a continuing period of turmoil, and suffering what many of them consider gross sexism, report they have rarely been happier. The anomaly has been underlined in a study in the Feb. 11 issue of America, the Jesuit magazine, in which 9 out of 10 nuns surveyed registered strong satisfaction with their lives.
They did so even as they showed majority support for various proposals for change that are hardly at hand, including ordained women, married priests, elected bishops and greater tolerance of doctrinal dissent, according to a survey of 1,041 nuns by The Los Angeles Times.
Sister Elaine, the embodiment of the crosscurrents of individual joy and vocational extinction, is puzzled that so few young women are enlisting at a time when her generation is breaking beyond authoritarian walls to find creative peace.
She has been inducted in the Women's Hall of Fame in Seneca Falls, N.Y., for originating programs for the growing population of imprisoned mothers. She has built a chain of postprison church sanctuaries, called Providence House, for them and their babies by taking over parish buildings bedimmed since the simpler years of immigrant faith in the city.
"Our changed lives might be the only gospel some people will ever read," she likes to say, relishing the upheaval about her even as she fails as a walking advertisement for the sisterhood.
There were 65 other brides at Sister Elaine's novice ceremony in 1949. But now the order attracts at best one or two newcomers a year.
Its once-grand network of resources is dissolving, with the novitiate in Brentwood, L.I., being used for antipoverty programs.
"This is an unusual way for a group to face its own demise," said Sister Elizabeth Johnson, also of the St. Joseph order, commenting on the richness of the modern nun's life even as it fades. A professor at Fordham University, she was one of the first female theologians permitted to receive a doctorate by the church authorities in the liberalization decrees that capped the Second Vatican Council three decades ago with an often traumatic wave of change.
But in the view of another pioneer nun theologian, Sister Sandra Schneiders, those changes may have helped undo the real anomaly of the modern nunnery, "the false inflation" of vocations from the 1950's and 60's, when tens of thousands of Catholic girls entered the sisterhood.
Sister Sandra is a professor at the Jesuit School of Theology in Berkeley, Calif., who finds the novice shrinkage normal, not troubling, in the church's larger historical pattern, in part because so many options beyond the traditional sisterhood have opened for religiously inclined women in a church increasingly short of male clerics.
"To me the present situation is the more normal one," said Sister Sandra, who has spent 40 years as a member of the Immaculate Heart of Mary order of Monroe, Mich. "One reason why it looks disastrous is because we're still thinking of the ministry of religion being the staffing of large enterprises."
Some younger women are church rectors or wives of the new generation of married deacons, jointly involved in executive parish roles. Some are free to be canonical lawyers. One sister, Gloria Garcia, is a civil executive at the United Nations.
"The religious life has always been meant to be countercultural and prophetic," Sister Elizabeth said.
Sister Sandra added, however, that she constantly met gifted young women who seemed perfect for the changing sisterhood, but were repelled by a sense of sexism and "institutional oppression" in the church.
"They'll say, 'I'd love to be a Sister of Mercy, but I don't want to publicly be a Roman Catholic,' " Sister Sandra said. "The only way to change this is to address the oppression."
Sister Elaine, for all her feminist dedication, worries that there will not be enough hands-on nuns when the suffering and the poor cry out for help. "The idea of sisterhood means so much to me, especially when I hear my black women friends talk of being 'sisters,' " she said.
"I pray in the chapel every morning from 4 to 5 with Sister Margaret," Sister Elaine said of her life at the Presentation parish convent in Jamaica, Queens, one of the Providence House sanctuaries where needy women and babies outnumber the few nuns. "I light the candles, and Margaret gets the coffee."
"It's wonderful," she said of the morning routine of a liberated nun -- reading, poetry writing, swimming at a women's club and attendance at Mass before driving to her job running the infants' nursery at the women's prison in Bedford Hills, N.Y.
But she reminds herself not to neglect the deepest constant in her life as a nun, daily prayer, even if she seems compelled to be ever busier creating programs like a thrift shop or tutoring convict mothers.
"That mystery and romanticism of 1949 is still there for me," she conceded. "That uncomplicated early religious time had a clarity of purpose that stays with me," she said, describing her way of forging new programs based on an idea but no money. "Don't ask, just presume that after prayer, this is what God wants you to do. Refuse to think about all the complications."
Forty-four years ago, Sister Elaine was a young nun at a parochial academy for the wealthy, and she leapt at the chance to switch to what was called "a colored mission" in Brooklyn. "The poor have shaped my life," she said. "I knew right away where I belonged. The prisons have become the permanent housing of the poor."
After Vatican II, life in the convent fractured, with the iron-handed world of a mother superior who yielded to "team government," rapid change and a blur of departures. Sister Elaine jettisoned most traditions except her core religious vows, and a parochial-school passion for gold-paper stars that she still awards herself in her diary for maintaining her prayer regimen.
"I can't help it," she said. "I love ritual, love ringing the little bell in the chapel."
Sister Elaine smiled at her tinkling indulgence at the morning ritual, in which she and Sister Margaret make a near-silent litany of a mystical chant, "Be still and know that I am God."
It has been decades since Vatican II left Sister Elaine to slink off to the public library for a book on basic fashion to learn about makeup and scarves. "All of a sudden the veil was gone," she recounted. "There's something about what you wear -- prisoners in stripes, zoot-suiters with their key chains -- that's very important. The trauma was we didn't know how to dress. It's true that our bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit, but earrings take a while."
A friend, Sister Pat Lucas, recently returned from eight years' frustration as the sisters' specialist in recruiting and encouraging novices. "A lot of us still out working on the margins are white middle-class women who are not attracting newcomers from the cultures and people we're working with," said Sister Pat, a 35-year veteran.
She is happier now in her new job as pastoral assistant at St. Leo's Church in Corona, Queens, one of the newer roles that amid the dearth of priests, offers more executive responsibility to nuns.
"I'm convinced religious life is going to continue to happen, but in a whole new way that can't yet be seen," said Sister Pat. She noted that her order was founded 350 years ago in France by six women in ordinary dress dedicated to just the sort of tangible charity that Sister Elaine pursues, not the extensive parochial-school teaching that American Catholics prized 40 years ago. "Maybe this is a moment of refounding for us; who knows?" she asked.
Sister Elaine said that she hoped so but that she prayed that the traditional identity of the nun would not become lost. "I think people see that for me, not having a family and not having obligations frees you to take on the sufferings of the world," she said as the convent rang with a baby's cry. "And that's not poetic. People know you have that freedom, and it's not a burden. It's just wonderful to be a guest in people's intimate lives."

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid Plan Is Hardly A Cure-All

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The $20 billion in American aid announced yesterday goes a long way toward resolving Mexico's immediate debt crisis, but by all accounts here it stops well short of addressing other serious problems afflicting the battered Mexican economy, which many economists believe is slipping into a recession despite the rescue.
Over the next four months, Mexican finance officials say they plan to use roughly half the $20 billion loan package signed in Washington to retire most of the outstanding short-term Government bonds that nearly forced Mexico into default. 
 The bonds, called tesobonos, are denominated in pesos but payable according to the exchange rate of the dollar when they mature, and have become far more costly as a result of the peso's devaluation. The Mexican Government wants to reduce their outstanding value from $30 billion two months ago to just $5 billion by the end of this year.
The other $10 billion from the United States will be held for contingencies, the officials say, including bailing out Mexican private banks that run into trouble paying off depositors.
That $20 billion directly from Washington is part of a larger package of assistance that includes $17.8 from the International Monetary Fund, $10 billion from major European nations, $3 billion from commercial banks, and $1 billion each from Canada and a group of South American countries. Mexican officials said some of the short-term money from the I.M.F. would be used to stabilize the peso's exchange rate and to assist the Mexican banks.
To regain control of its economy, Mexico must stabilize its wildly erratic peso -- which has dropped more than 40 percent against the dollar in little more than two months -- by raising interest rates to previously unknown levels and entice investors to hold more assets in pesos. That is part of the medicine prescribed by the United States and the International Monetary Fund.
The risk to Mexico's economy is that such harsh medicine could all but kill the patient, sending Mexico into a period of deep recession and prolonged inflation that would produce an epidemic of unemployment and business failures.
In a clear sign that the Mexican central bank would keep its promise to the United States and the monetary fund and keep interest rates high, the rates on benchmark treasury certificates, called cetes, were allowed to rise today to 59 percent -- the highest level in seven years. The 28-day certificate generally establishes the trend for consumer and business credit rates.
Interest rates had to soar to compensate for Mexican inflation now running above 40 percent on an annual basis, and to reward investors for the risk involved in holding peso assets. The central bank governor, Miguel Mancera Aguayo, has predicted that the high rates will lead to the peso's stabilization in "a matter of a few weeks," after which rates can be gradually lowered to a level the economy can live with.
But analysts and investors already burned by Mexico's peso devaluation on Dec. 20 and 21 seem unconvinced that the Government's recovery plan will work.
"If by 'work,' you mean to help stabilize the currency and bring down inflation in the medium term, then I'd say the chances of working are positive," said Alejandro Hernandez, an economist at the Autonomous Technological Institute of Mexico. "On the other hand, the plan's impact on economic activity and employment are without a doubt going to be severe."
The degree to which the $20 billion pledged in assistance from the United States addresses only Mexico's debt problems was shown in a lackluster performance today on the Mexican stock exchange and a decline in the peso barely a day after the deal was signed in Washington.
The peso closed at 5.845 to the dollar, down from Tuesday's close of 5.605. Mexican stocks gained a modest 29 points, or 1.73 percent, and ended the day at 1,708.28, reflecting a lukewarm reaction by investors on Mexico's economic future.
In a speech in Mexico City today, President Ernesto Zedillo conceded that because the country's economic problems were worse now than at the beginning of the year, "the effect on every Mexican will be more harmful," and the previous emergency plan he announced on Jan. 3 would have to be adjusted.
Mr. Zedillo responded directly to criticism that by accepting the $20 billion, he had ceded a degree of control over Mexico's finances to the United States. The loan came with strict economic conditions, including a requirement that revenue from the state oil monopoly, Pemex, be channeled through an account at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
"Those who think that in exchange for the financial backing, the economic policy of Mexico has been given to the authorities of another country are mistaken," Mr. Zedillo said.
The Government's emergency stabilization plan of Jan. 3 had been based on a peso exchange rate of 4.5 to the dollar and foresaw an inflation rate of 19 percent and economic growth this year of 1.5 percent.
However, with the peso remaining at 5.5 to the dollar or worse, inflation will be substantially higher and most economists expect to see a recession.
A document from the Finance Ministry, which discusses the use of the $20 billion from the United States, indicates that as soon as the first draw-down of the $20 billion becomes available in about a week, the Mexican Government will start using $2 billion to buy back tesobonos as they mature.
The central bank will continue to exchange the tesobonos held by private banks for other forms of debt.
Mexican officials hope that by the end of June, investors will have regained enough confidence in their country's economy that the remaining $10 billion from the American rescue package will not be needed.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Some analysts think now is the time to invest in Japanese stocks.

BYLINE: By Andrew Pollack 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
THESE are bleak days for the Tokyo stock market. Following a big fall after last month's earthquake, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks has been hovering at a low level of around 18,000. There are widespread fears that it may fall further in the coming weeks.
"Right now, sentiment is at it's very worst," said Jeff Bahrenburg, strategist in the Tokyo office of Merrill Lynch & Company. "Bearishness is at its extreme." A rally yesterday fizzled out at the end of the day as the Nikkei closed at 18,106.65, up 10.40 points. 
 But when things look worst, some analysts, like Mr. Bahrenburg, think it is time to buy. The market, these analysts argue, seems to be ignoring the fact that Japan's economy is recovering from a three-year recession and that corporate earnings are improving. Even if the market drops sharply in the next few weeks, they say, it should quickly recover and rise.
"In the long run you can't stop the fundamentals," said Tom Hill, head of research for S. G. Warburg Securities (Japan), who sees the Nikkei rising to 24,000 by March 1996. "I don't know what will happen in the next three or four weeks. What I do know is the market is undervalued."
 There are many good reasons for the current gloom in the market. Foreign investors, who buoyed stocks last year, have turned into net sellers. Selling pressure will increase in the next few weeks as Japanese companies cash in some holdings before the fiscal year ends on March 31.
Damages from the earthquake could still set back the nascent economic recovery, although many economists believe the rebuilding will stimulate growth in the long run. The quake also showed Japan to be a much riskier market than had been perceived before and showed the Japanese Government to be weak and ineffective.
Beyond the quake, the yen has been strong against the dollar in recent days, which threatens to hurt Japan's export-oriented companies. The strong American economy, which spurred increased exports of cars and computer chips from Japan, is cooling a bit.
And a scandal over the Government-backed rescue of two credit unions that had made huge amounts of questionable loans is drawing renewed attention to the mountains of bad debt held by Japan's banks and other financial institutions.
"The market depends not so much on short- and medium-term earnings power," said Alexander Kinmont, a strategist with Morgan Stanley & Company in Tokyo. "It depends upon a sense of confidence that things are being done to clean up the mess" in the banking sector, he said.
When Sumitomo Bank wrote off a big chunk of its bad loans last month in an effort to clean up its books, the stock market soared in reaction. The current scandal is having the opposite effect, Mr. Kinmont said. He predicted that the Nikkei would not rise above 20,000 this year and might sink as low as 16,000. The index last surpassed the 20,000 mark in October and fell below 16,000 in November 1993.
Bulls agree that the market is ignoring earnings prospects, but say it won't stay that way forever, providing the buying opportunity. "The market is almost immune to fundamentals," said Kathy Matsui, vice president and chief strategist in the Tokyo office of Goldman, Sachs & Company. "It's almost numb." She predicted the Nikkei could reach 23,000 in the next year.
Demand in Japan for some products, such as cars, is improving. And capital spending is also showing signs of increasing after several years of decline. This week alone Matsushita Electric, Honda and Canon all reported sharply higher earnings for the December quarter as a result of cost-cutting and improved demand.
"We're at the threshold of a long period of growth," Mr. Bahrenburg of Merrill Lynch said, adding that the market could gain 50 to 60 percent in the next five years, with much of the increase coming in the next year.
"Selling the stock market now is like walking into a fully loaded mousetrap," Mr. Hill of Warburg said. "If you are lucky you might be able to steal the cheese but you're much more likely to find yourself decapitated."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Surge On Remarks By Fed Chief

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, indicated that the central bank might be finished raising interest rates for the time being.
The yield on the closely watched 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to a five-month low. The bond rose 27/32 , to a price of 1014/32 for a yield of 7.53 percent, down from 7.61 percent on Tuesday. 
 Shorter bill rates were also sharply lower, but some market analysts said they thought the rally was overdone because the Fed could still raise interest rates again.
"What matters most for bond yields is inflationary expectations, and it's hard to imagine inflationary expectations rising in the face of an economy that is slowing," said Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities.
"While it is true that the actual rate of inflation is likely to pick up over the near term, it is expected to be contained within acceptable limits," he added. "And while the Fed could certainly lift rates another notch in May, the market is beginning to get comfortable with the idea that we may be approaching the end of the Fed's tightening cycle."
Analysts started thinking that the Fed might not raise interest rates further after hearing Mr. Greenspan's semiannual report to Congress on monetary policy. He said there were signs that the economy "may finally be slowing" and suggested, "There may come a time when we hold our policy stance unchanged, or even ease, despite adverse price data, should we see signs that underlying forces are acting ultimately to reduce inflation pressures."
Mr. Greenspan's comment on cutting rates came just after the Fed's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, suggested on Friday that the Fed might be near the end of this cycle of tightening and even thinking about pre-empting cutting rates to avoid a recession. While Mr. Greenspan was not quite as explicit, traders said the the two together had made the possibility of no more rate increases for now more likely.
But there are still market participants who think the Fed needs to raise rates at least once more to slow the economy's rate of growth to 2.5 percent. Many economists say that is the fastest growth the economy can sustain without risking an increase in inflation.
"Based on Mr. Greenspan's words," said Jay Goldinger, market strategist at Capital Insight of Beverly Hills, Calif., "he didn't say they were going to ease and he didn't say they'd stop tightening. He said he thought that maybe the Fed would start to slow from its recent pace.
"I think," he added, "the market is way ahead of itself."
Mr. Greenspan himself noted that while the economy was perhaps slowing from its "torrid and unsustainable pace, the jury is out" on whether higher interest rates would contain inflation.
Riding yesterday's investor enthusiasm, $17.25 billion of new two-year notes sold well at the Treasury's auction. Traders said the auction showed good demand as the yield came in at 6.999 percent, only slightly above the 6.98 percent the market had expected. The yield was the lowest since Oct. 25, when it was 6.88 percent.
Tomorrow, the Government will auction $11 billion of five-year notes. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.19 percent.
Peter J. Canelo, chief investment strategist at NatWest Securities, said "bonds rallied because investors heard what they wanted to hear." He added, "They heard the Fed chairman confirm a slowing of the economy, but they ignored the caveat that the economy will continue to expand."
Mr Canelo said he thought that investors heard that inflation was reasonably well behaved, but did not pay much attention to Mr. Greenspan's comments that there were still significant concerns about capacity utilization and unemployment, which may suggest rising inflation.
The market only wants to hear that the Fed is done raising rates for now and maybe even never gain, Mr. Canelo said. "But that's a little extreme."

HEADLINE: Fed Chairman Hints at an End To Rise in Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said today there was evidence that the economy "may finally be slowing" and suggested that if it sank too fast the Federal Reserve would move quickly to cut interest rates.
Mr. Greenspan's comments in Congressional testimony, taken along with remarks by the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve last week, is the strongest indication to date that the Federal Reserve may be finished raising interest rates for the time being. 
 It can be difficult to interpret the Federal Reserve chairman when he testifies before Congress because he keeps his options open by not saying specifically what the central bank is going to do next. But the bond market rallied during and after his testimony, with the yield on the 30-year bond falling to 7.53 percent, its lowest since Sept. 2. [Page D1.]
"While the Fed could certainly lift rates another notch in May, the market is beginning to get comfortable with the idea that we may be approaching the end of the Fed's tightening cycle," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities.
The Federal Reserve raised interest rates seven times in the last year, doubling short-term interest rates to 6 percent to head off inflationary pressures. The last increase was in January, when the Federal Reserve raised its target for the Federal funds rate by one-half of a percentage point. At the time, many analysts thought the Federal Reserve would still have to raise interest rates again later in the year because signs of economic growth were still strong. But since then both Government statistics and the slowdown in automobile production have indicated that the economy may be slowing.
Testifying before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan said that the Federal Reserve would consider lowering interest rates even if inflation continued to rise, if it suspected that over all the economy was slowing sufficiently.
"There may come a time when we hold our policy stance unchanged, or even ease, despite adverse price data, should we see signs that underlying forces are acting ultimately to reduce inflation pressures," Mr. Greenspan said.
He gave no indication that any relaxation was imminent, however, declaring at another point in his twice-a-year presentation to Congress on the economic outlook and Federal Reserve strategy that "the jury remains out" about whether the interest rate medicine will be powerful enough to keep inflation at bay.
The remarks about possible cutting of interest rates -- believed to be Mr. Greenspan's first such public comments -- came in the context of the Fed's having learned from experience that by the time new trends are unmistakably reflected in the traditional statistical gauges they have become too powerful to be countered easily.
It was a desire to mount a drive against inflation before any such price outburst occurred that prompted the Fed to begin raising short-term interest rates last February.
On Friday, Alan S. Blinder, the Fed's vice chairman and one of two board members appointed by President Clinton, told an audience in Richmond that he and his colleagues should be as prepared to make a pre-emptive strike against recession as it did against inflation.
Mr. Greenspan seemed to concur today, stressing the need to be flexible in the making of monetary policy, which he called an "uncertain enterprise" that has become even more difficult in recent years as some traditional yardsticks for gauging policy have become less reliable.
What the chairman cited as "indications" of a slowing economy in recent weeks were slackened growth of jobs and retail sales and "some softness" in the interest-sensitive housing industry. He said, however, that growth continued, reporting that most members of the Federal Open Market Committee projected a rise in gross domestic product this year of 2 percent to 3 percent, little changed from the narrower range of 2.50 to 2.75 percent that they projected last July.
But while noting the "signal accomplishment" of holding inflation at under 3 percent for three consecutive years -- and having reduced it in each business cycle since the 1970's -- Mr. Greenspan found "reasons for some concern," particularly in coming months.
These, he said, "relate primarily to the fact that resource utilization rates have already risen to high levels" by recent standards, with the unemployment rate, for instance, only slightly above the average of the late 1980's, a time of significant price acceleration. He said the same held true in the industrial sector of the economy, where factories operated at 85.1 percent of capacity last month, just below the recent cyclical peak of January 1989.
And while Mr. Greenspan said that the pace at which the economy can grow without setting off sharp price increases may have risen "a few tenths of a percentage point annually or even more," last year's 4 percent growth was still far to high.
It was not clear whether Mr. Greenspan, who today cited "some indications that the expansion may finally be slowing from its torrid and unsustainable pace," had gleaned new data to change his views since last Wednesday when, addressing a banking convention in Honolulu, he said the evidence of slowing "remains mixed."
During a spirited question-and-answer period, Mr. Greenspan spoke on a number of other topics as well. He expressed profound disappointment at lack of Government action to address the growth of entitlement spending; agreed with Republicans who argue for abolition of the minimum wage; favored "sunset" provisions for all Government programs and agencies, including the Federal Reserve, and reaffirmed his long-standing interest in re-establishing a link between the dollar and gold.
When quizzed about whether the Fed believed itself handicapped in fighting inflation by requirements it pursue other goals as well, Mr. Greenspan said this was less of a problem than it once was because "vague" language and mounting empirical evidence have allowed it increasingly to cite price stability as necessary for other goals, such as high employment.
At one point, responding to a question about the risk of recession, Mr. Greenspan said with a sigh that monetary policy was a never-ending job, one whose outcome is never certain except in retrospect.
"It's like a luggage carousel at the airports," he suggested.

HEADLINE: The New Espionage Game?

 BODY:
In an odd way, the espionage contretemps between the United States and France that roared into view yesterday may be a sign of progress for the Central Intelligence Agency. If the French accounts are correct, at least the agency was spying on something that matters, specifically French efforts in 1993 to block an international trade agreement and to thwart the marketing of American movies and television shows in France. At a time when American national security is increasingly defined by economic interests, it is reassuring to see the lumbering intelligence apparatus in Washington turning away from the obsolete work of monitoring Russian military forces.
But the methods reportedly involved, including efforts to bribe French officials, were wrong. While it was clearly acceptable during the cold war to pay Soviet informants for secret information about Moscow's nuclear forces, it is not appropriate to bribe French officials for political or economic information. 
 No one should be shocked to discover that the C.I.A. may have been spying on an ally. Even in the bleakest days of the cold war, Washington collected information about political developments in NATO countries. There was always suspicion between Washington and Paris, rooted in de Gaulle's nettlesome independence. The French Government was chagrined two years ago when it was disclosed that Paris had targeted 21 American aerospace companies for industrial espionage.
Now it is Washington's turn to dance and dodge. The daily Le Monde, which broke the story, reported that five Americans, including the C.I.A. station chief in Paris, had offered bribes to French officials to obtain information about the French position at the trade talks and the Government's resistance to the import of American movies and television shows. Until the last minute, France threatened to scuttle the GATT trade agreement by refusing to reduce subsidies for French farmers.
It was undoubtedly not a coincidence that this story happened to become public just as Prime Minister Edouard Balladur's presidential campaign was in danger of being derailed by disclosure of a questionable wiretapping operation authorized by Interior Minister Charles Pasqua. Nothing changes the subject faster than a juicy espionage case, especially one involving Americans.
How much financial and industrial espionage is appropriate for the C.I.A., and how the information should be used, are serious questions the Clinton Administration and Congress need to explore as part of their review of American intelligence operations. The C.I.A. owes Congress a full accounting of this mission, if the French accusations are true.
