HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher, Then Eases On Fed Chief's Rate View

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied overseas yesterday but fell back in New York trading, after the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, suggested that American interest rates had peaked.
The dollar ended little changed against most leading currencies, hovering at a 28-month low against the surging German mark. The mark advanced broadly as investors, seeking a haven from political and financial turmoil in Europe, continued to put funds in German banks and securities. 
 "The Deutsche mark is the currency of choice right now," said Tom Benfer, director at the New York foreign exchange desk of the Bank of Montreal. "I think it's more of a case of mark strength than dollar weakness."
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar edged up to 1.4710 marks from 1.4700 marks on Tuesday, and to 1.2490 Swiss francs from 1.2430 francs. The dollar slipped to 97 Japanese yen from 97.05 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5883 from $1.5862.
Traders said the dollar rose in Asia and in early European trading on unconfirmed reports that the Bundesbank was buying dollars in an effort to stem the dollar's slide against the mark. The dollar has fallen 5.2 percent against the mark since the beginning of the year.
But the dollar plunged from its highs after Mr. Greenspan, in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, said there was evidence that the economy "may finally be slowing," and suggested that if it began slipping toward recession the Fed could cut interest rates.
The Fed has raised short-term interest rates seven times since February 1994 in an effort to prevent inflation from accelerating.
Higher rates make short-term deposits and assets more attractive, driving up the demand for a currency. Reinforcing such trends, investors tend to flock to the financial markets of a country whose currency is expected to rise, as the value of assets denominated in that currency will increase in relative terms.
That appears to be the case with Germany and the mark.
While United States rates currently are higher, favoring the dollar, "the market senses that Fed tightening is less likely and Bundesbank tightening more likely," said William Dudley, currency analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony came after a report on Tuesday in which the Bundesbank pointed to rapid economic growth in Germany and emphasized that it was prepared to raise rates to dampen price pressures.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: After the Strike: Fairness

 BODY:
President Clinton's plan to issue an executive order that would forbid the hiring of permanent replacement workers by Government contractors has the whiff of politics. Mr. Clinton needs to shore up his support with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., now meeting in Florida. No surprise, then, that he flirts with intervening in the baseball strike and threatens to veto pro-management bills making their way through the Republican-controlled Congress.
There is logic, too, in using a Presidential order to get some movement on an economic issue that is important to both business and organized labor. Last year, the House passed a blanket ban against allowing companies to hire permanent replacements for striking workers. The measure died in the Senate, where Republicans and some Democrats rightly viewed it as too sweeping. Businesses have the right to stay afloat during a strike, just as workers have the right to seek other jobs. But that can be done in almost all strikes with temporary replacements. No one's career is ended; the damage to both sides is short-term. 
 But overly rapid moves to replace workers permanently raise troubling issues about labor law. Congress never intended that employees who have worked at their jobs for a lifetime would have to choose overnight between their unions and their careers. Yet that is how the practice has evolved since President Reagan crushed the 1981 strike by air traffic controllers. The use of replacement workers is legal, and at some point is defensible. But it needs to be fair and uniform.
To hire permanent replacements within hours of a strike violates the promise of the 1935 National Labor Relations Act, the foundation of labor law. It established the right of workers to strike without the threat of being fired, or other employer retaliation. Permanent replacements, the Supreme Court has ruled, do not violate that right because strikers are first in line to fill job openings. But if replacements are permanent, there cannot be many openings -- creating a specious distinction between being fired and permanently replaced.
In this regard, an executive order that applies only to Federal contractors does not represent a long-term solution. The problem needs to be fixed through legislation. But the correction that Mr. Clinton has supported in the past -- blanket prohibition of permanent replacements -- is not the best way. An all-or-nothing approach is neither sensible nor required, and is sure to be rejected by a Republican-controlled Congress.
The important question is not whether employers should have the right to hire permanent replacements, but when. There is a sensible middle ground here, as proposed by Prof. Paul Weiler of Harvard Law School, that balances the rights of labor and management. He would outlaw the use of permanent replacements for, say, the first six months of a strike. By that time the outcome of virtually all strikes is known. Forewarned, strikers could reasonably decide between reclaiming their jobs or losing them.
Mr. Clinton can start moving the issue in a positive direction by issuing an executive order that allows Federal contractors to hire permanent replacements -- but only after the first six months of a strike have passed. This nuanced approach could serve as a model for a new law capable of winning bipartisan Congressional support.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Rises After Greenspan Supports a Link to the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Gold prices rose to their highest levels in more than three weeks yesterday after the chairman of the Federal Reserve said that he favored restoring some link between the dollar and gold.
The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, has spoken favorably of the gold standard in the past and has shown enthusiasm for using gold prices as a barometer of inflation. While there is little chance of a return to the gold standard, which was officially abandoned 24 years ago, Mr. Greenspan's comments drew buyers to the moribund gold market. 
 In other commodity markets, cotton prices rose again but stopped just short of $1 a pound, and heating oil and gasoline prices advanced. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities gained 0.31 point, to 235.74.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, gold for April delivery rose 90 cents, to $381.50 an ounce, after earlier reaching a high of $382.40, its highest since Jan. 27. March silver rallied 9.7 cents, to $4.835 an ounce.
Mr. Greenspan's comments give "this concept of gold in portfolios legitimacy," said Dinsa Mehta, vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank, adding that a return to the gold standard would be "like legislating to believe in fairies."
Few analysts believe a return to the gold standard is likely. The gold standard was dropped and the Federal Reserve closed its gold window in 1971.
Cotton prices continued to rise on the New York Cotton Exchange. March cotton hit a session high of 99.95 cents a pound, before settling 1.31 cents higher at 99.79 cents.
Cotton prices have risen sharply on the prospect for shortages later this year created by booming exports of last year's record large United States cotton crop. Export sales have also been helped by poor crops in China, Pakistan and India.
The previous record high price was 99 cents in September 1973, the highest price for cotton since it began trading on the exchange in 1870.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Selig, Fehr Take Part In Civilized Exchange

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 22

 BODY:
Two days of "candid," "civilized" dialogue that culminated in a feast of corned beef, pastrami and tongue at Jake Levine's deli in Milwaukee today set the tone for the resumption of serious bargaining in the baseball strike next week.
It remains to be seen, though, if harsh charges leveled at the union by an owner who wasn't in Milwaukee undermine the positive tone Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, believes was established in his meetings with Donald Fehr, the union leader. 
 "I don't know what this means in the overall scheme, but it was rational, very civilized, very sensitive, I think quite candid," Selig said by telephone from Milwaukee. "I don't want to read too much or too little into it, but there was a candor in the past 24 hours that I have never seen before."
Can the meetings produce progress in the negotiations that are stalled on the issue of a luxury tax on payrolls? "I guess we'll know that about a week from today," Selig said.
Representatives of the owners and striking players scheduled a new round of talks to begin Monday in Scottsdale, Ariz.
However much good will and wishful thinking emerged from the sessions in Selig's hometown and led to three joint meals, climaxed by lunch at the delicatessen Selig owns, could be buried by the words of Jerry Reinsdorf, the owner of the Chicago White Sox.
Reinsdorf, who has been portrayed as a leader of the owners' hard-line stance by players and some people in management, was severely critical of the union generally and Fehr specifically in an interview published today in The Chicago Sun-Times.
Asked if there was any hope of saving the 1995 season, Reinsdorf said: "The only hope is if the players come to the realization that they are being misled by Fehr. My perception of him is that he is obsessed with the antitrust exemption and that he has no real interest in the welfare of his players. Donald Fehr has a pathological hatred for baseball owners."
Reinsdorf also said that he didn't understand why the union "is setting me up" as the person dictating the owners' policy, adding: "It's a good way of holding people together, if you have a common enemy. And for whatever reason, they've created me as that enemy."
Reinsdorf declined further interviews on the subject, but to a question posed through his secretary about whether or not his comments could undermine the talks, he replied, "Only if Fehr wants them to."
Selig declined to comment on Reinsdorf's comments, saying: "We've got too many issues to focus on. I'm not going to be distracted by any comments on either side. The only person I can hold totally accountable is myself and you don't read those comments from me."
The divergence in their verbal stances is interesting because Selig and Reinsdorf long have been viewed as the developers and leaders of the owners' labor strategy. It was they who, in 1992, asked then-Commissioner Fay Vincent to relinquish his authority in labor matters; and when he declined, they were the ones who led a move to oust him as commissioner.
Fehr was reserved in his reaction to Reinsdorf's comments. "Few things do more good for my credibility among my membership," he said, "than to be criticized in this fashion by Jerry Reinsdorf."
The Milwaukee meetings were attended by smaller groups than has been the case. Joining Selig, Fehr and Bill Usery Jr., the mediator, were Lauren Rich, a union lawyer, and two club officials, John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox and Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies.
The negotiators still must traverse the great gulf that separates their positions on the central economic issue. The owners, who earlier tried to implement a cap on payrolls, want to levy a steep tax on payrolls over a certain threshold, and the players contend that such a tax will have the same effect as a cap.
Two weeks ago, Usery, at the request of President Clinton, proposed a 50 percent tax on the portion of payrolls over $40 million. The owners said they would accept it, but the players angrily rejected the idea, saying it was far too favorable to the owners.
Neither the Usery ideas nor any others were discussed in Milwaukee. "We agreed to stay away from the issues," Selig said.

HEADLINE: Money-Back Guarantee if Conditions Are Poor

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
It may seem odd to think of snow in terms of a money-back guarantee. But increasingly, ski resorts are marketing their slopes the way department stores deal in housewares. At most retail outlets, you have at least 30 days to return an item. At ski areas, you have about an hour.
A growing movement is afoot to give skiers their money back if snow conditions aren't right. In a winter like this one, with its mercurial ups and downs, skiers may want a refund. 
 "Ski conditions, especially in the Northwest, can be very changeable," said Bill Mullane, spokesman for Schweitzer Mountain Resort in Sandpoint, Idaho. "In one day, it might turn from sunshine to overcast, or be pouring rain. If people know that if they don't like it, they can get a ticket for another day, they're more likely to come here. My philosophy is suit up and show up."
Indeed, according to the National Ski Areas Association, an industry trade group, at least a dozen ski areas among the more than 500 that belong to its association have a snow guarantee policy.
Some resorts, like Stowe, Vt., are likely to refund a skier's ticket with a voucher if there is a complaint. But there isn't a guarantee policy. "We don't hype that," said Bob Gillen, Stowe's director of marketing. "We won't open a trail unless the snow is deep and skiable anyway. If it's open, it's good."
Schweitzer, which has had the program for five years, limits its refund policy to lift ticket vouchers. Of the 175,000 ski tickets sold at Schweitzer last year, about 5,000 came back as "snow checks." Skiers had an hour from the time printed on their ticket to decide whether they wanted to stay.
Loon Mountain in Lincoln, N.H., started a similar plan two winters ago. "I think we had a couple of bad weeks of weather," said Brenda Kneeland, guest service manager at Loon. "We still had good skiing, but people didn't want to believe it. The guarantee was our way of showing our confidence in the skiing."
At Loon, skiers have until 11 A.M. to decide. The mountain opens at 8 A.M. That essentially gives a skier three hours to test the snow. "It's a very generous program," Kneeland said.
Much of the confidence in refunding tickets comes from the ability to make snow when nature holds back. "If you're not making good snow, you're dead," Gillen said about the economics of a ski area. "Otherwise it's farming, it's not skiing. You might as well be betting on the commodities market."
The science has become precise, with resorts being able to lay snow almost anywhere they want it. "Right now, I can look out my window and not see a drop of snow," Kneeland said about a day in early February. "It looks like early October. But out my other window, there's three feet of snow. I look at it and say, 'How'd they do that?' "
In California, where heavy rains battered coastal communities in January, snow fell in the mountains. At the Boreal Ski Area northeast of San Francisco, management gives cash back to disgruntled skiers, despite the fact that snowmaking covers only 30 percent of the area's 380 acres.
"We don't really see it as a risk," said Sheila Walsh, director of marketing for Boreal. "We see it as a service. If people buy a $33 lift ticket and feel they got skunked, then we're happy to give them their money back. It's more important to make sure people had a good experience."
For Boyne Highlands, a ski area near Harbor Springs, Mich., management is looking farther down the road. "The kids are getting older, and we're trying to adapt," said Kathleen Ballard, a sales assistant, about the area's voucher guarantee. "In the past, we've catered to the baby-boomers. But now their children are getting older, so the policy that fit in 1960 doesn't fit in 1990."
 
MOGULS
 As many as 6,900 skiers are expected to participate Saturday in the 1995 Dyno American Birkebeiner, the nation's largest cross-country ski race. The event begins at Telemark Lodge in Cable, Wis., and finishes on Main Street in Hayward, Wis., a distance of 52 kilometers or about 32 miles.
More than 200 military veterans are expected to participate in the National Disabled Veterans Sports Clinic March 26-31 at Crested Butte, Colo. The learn-to-ski sessions are open to service veterans with spinal cord injuries, orthopedic amputations, visual and neurological impairments and other disabilities. Information can be obtained by calling (303) 242-0731.

HEADLINE: Look Who's Caring For the Caretaker

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
JOHN SCHNALL easily remembers the hands that raised him -- that baked the cookies, wiped away the tears and showed him how to pray. They were those, he said, of his "mother, father and best friend."
In fact, they belonged to none of those people, but rather to his nanny, Margaret Lauman, who lived nearly all of her adult life in service to his family. 
 "All the feelings that normally go to a mother went to Lauman," Mr. Schnall, 42, a freelance copywriter, said of the German woman he called by her last name. She came into his family's New York home in 1951, migrated with them to Florida and stayed there with them until the end of her life in 1988.
Those feelings are what inspired him, he said, to take Miss Lauman on a vacation to Hawaii in the 1970's, to fly to Florida to nurse her after she had a stroke and to continue to arrange for her care until the day she died. As far as family was concerned, Mr. Schnall said, "I would have chosen her over anyone at any point."
Mr. Schnall is one of a number of people who are seeking out a lifelong relationship with a former caretaker. In some cases, grown charges are the ones willingly assuming the burden of care, often in ways usually reserved for an aging parent, providing health benefits, help around the house or a place in the family home for the rest of their lives.
John Revson, a 52-year-old international trade consultant (and son of Charles Revson, the founder of Revlon), said about his childhood nanny, Katie Lowery, "If something ever happened to her, I'd take care of her forever, because she has given virtually her whole life to us." She now lives in retirement with Mr. Revson and his mother in Palm Beach, Fla.
Still others are seeking out childhood nannies years after the care-giver relationship has ended, the way they would a lost parent or estranged relative, assuming, perhaps naively, that the nanny remembers them just as wistfully. They frequently refer to their nannies as family members, albeit relatives with no apparent histories of their own.
Twenty years after women began flooding into the workplace, some two million children under age 5 are now cared for in their homes by someone other than a parent. The concept of "help" has come to include everyone from a daytime adult baby sitter to a teen-age apprentice to an au pair.
But it was only a few decades ago that a nanny's job was much more formally defined. The nannies of the 1940's and 50's worked well before 9 A.M. and long after 5 P.M., not just feeding, clothing and bathing their charges, but also seeing to their spiritual and emotional well being. They became intimate with children in ways their parents often did not (as these grown-up children are quick to remind parents in later years) -- giving advice, attending school plays and even doing the tucking in.
"My parents were nice enough people, but they were not equipped to handle children in any way," said Mr. Schnall, who remembers the cookies that Miss Lauman dutifully shipped off to him at summer camp.
Jean Lang, an economist in Washington, put it another way. "I just don't remember playing with my mother the way I did with Clemmie," she said of Clemmie Koopman, the nanny who played endless games of canasta from her rocking chair.
Given such depth of feeling, perhaps it is only natural that some adults should provide financial support for their former nannies as they grow old, while others stay close through weekly phone calls and frequent invitations to family gatherings, including weddings.
Carol Goralnik, an artist in St. Louis, oversees the care of Clara Sahm, 89, in and out of hospitals, doing her grocery shopping and often preparing her meals.
"Clara never married and has no children, so I serve as her surrogate child," said Mrs. Goralnik, 42, who has three children. "It isn't always fun. But she raised me and she's real important to me. She took care of me, and now I take care of her."
Those few who can afford it may even offer nannies an approximation of "lifetime employment," which may include bed, board and full health benefits.
"We are seeing that more and more people are looking into long-term benefits and retirement packages for their nannies," said Marla Sanders of Bethesda, Md., who owns several employment agencies throughout the country that place nannies. "People are starting to realize that they have to give back the love that was given."
Often, the nannies will remain with families as companions to parents who are alone, with minimal duties for which they are still paid full salaries, said Barbara Ettinger, a film maker who, with Jyll Johnstone, explored the relationship between nannies and their adult charges in the recent documentary "Martha and Ethel."
The film makers allowed the camera to wander through the lives and memories of their two distinctly different nannies -- Martha Kneifel, a German-born baby nurse who ruled the Johnstone roost with a wooden spoon, and Ethel Edwards, a Southerner who appeared to be the greatest source of affection for the Ettinger children.
Ms. Edwards still lives with Ms. Ettinger's mother. "It's odd," Ms. Ettinger said. "Ethel is still paid, but the relationship is no longer really professional. She and mom share the household duties."
Both film makers were approached after screenings of the film in various cities by people who strongly identified with relationships depicted in the film. "One woman told me that she had never known how to talk about nannies, because there is so much stigma attached to them," Ms. Ettinger said.
Part of that stigma may revolve around the inequity that exists in even the warmest of employer-employee relationships.
"There are lines of demarcation," said Elizabeth Clark-Lewis, a history professor at Howard University and the author of the book "Living In, Living Out: African American Domestics in Washington D.C. 1910-1940" (Smithsonian Institution Press, 1994).
"There is a genuine concern the employee has for her job, and that job entails rearing and nurturing these children," she said. "They care about them, but they are not under any illusions. There is an expected deference, and they know that."
While there may be many cases of genuine mutual affection, "the person on the non-nanny end tends to imagine that the relationship is a lot more meaningful and rich for the nanny than it really was," said Nicholas Lemann, the author of "The Promised Land" (Knopf, 1991), about black American migration between 1940 and 1970. "One tends to engage in this fantasy that the nanny is deriving deep pleasure out of being their servant."
In spite of the fact that nannies are loved as much as aunts, grandparents and sometimes even mothers, many adults who were their charges are often strikingly unaware of the lives of these women. Often, they cannot quite recall which states the women migrated from, how many children they have, whether or not they were ever married.
"It's weird, you don't really know about their other life," said Trisha Shiland, 33, of New York, whose nanny, Mattie Pelham, lived with the family for 20 years.
In some ways, Professor Clark-Lewis said, the employees are comfortable with that lack of knowledge. "It means that they put a limit on this unequal relationship," she said. "They don't want employers intruding on all aspects of their lives."
It may well be that the perceived intimacy on behalf of the charges is based on the ongoing demands and needs of the grown child -- which may now include care of an aged parent.
Elizabeth Johnson, now 84, spent six years caring for the five Frymier children in Pittsburgh. After 10 years without contact, one child, Sydney Frymier, now 45 and a clinical social worker in Chevy Chase, Md., sought out her former nanny and put her back on the payroll to care for the Frymiers' bedridden 78-year-old mother. "Elizabeth knows just what to do with her," Ms. Frymier said. "My mother would definitely be in a home if Elizabeth were not there."
For their part, nannies say they tend to remember families fondly because children were well behaved and the parents were kind.
Nina Mae Henderson spent 31 years in St. Louis with the family of Virginia Rice, who is now a multimedia designer in Washington. Ms. Rice, 45, called her "the rock of the family."
Miss Henderson, who still lives in St. Louis, seemed a bit startled that the care she gave Ms. Rice and her sister, Callie, should have such emotional resonance.
"I think a whole lot of the girls," Miss Henderson said. "I don't feel like I'm related to them, though. I love them in a sensible way."

HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW;
Big-City Mores and Big-Band Swing

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF 

 BODY:
The Ohio Ballet, directed by Heinz Poll in Akron, remains the engaging company it has always been. Judging by the first of its two programs, anyone who ambles into the Joyce Theater this week stands a chance of having more than a good time.
The highlight of the troupe's opening on Tuesday night was a polished, lively revival of an important sociopolitical gem. Kurt Jooss, best known for his 1932 antiwar masterpiece "The Green Table," choreographed "The Big City" the same year. In a few cinematic strokes, the German choreographer painted a picture of human character engulfed by forces beyond any control. On the surface, this short ballet was a vignette about a poor youth losing his girl to a swell, who deserts her. But on the eve of Hitler's rise to power, Jooss's picture of class divisions and urban alienation in "The Big City" had a deeper meaning. 
 The German-born Mr. Poll trained at Mr. Jooss's school after the war and danced in Chile under the direction of charter members of Jooss's original company. Nonetheless, the rest of the program at the Joyce (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea) has none of the Expressionist style represented by Jooss and is more typical of the Ohio Ballet's eclectic repertory.
Lucinda Childs's "Trilogies," one of the local premieres, exemplified Mr. Poll's hospitality to experimental modern-dance choreographers. The second program will feature works by Charles Moulton and Laura Dean. "Trilogies" shows Ms. Childs extending herself with an unexpected use of a commissioned jazz score by Paul Schwartz and also remaining true to her signature style of meticulously repeated patterns.
Mr. Poll's choreography was represented by his new "Eight by Benny Goodman," a cliche-free big-band ballet in which Xochitl Tejeda de Cerda is a knockout as a torch singer, and by his 1974 Chopin double adagio, "Summer Night," danced outstandingly by Ms. Tejeda de Cerda, Yumelia Garcia and their partners, Kyongho Kim and David Shimotkahara.
The dancers, in fact, have never looked more mature and assured. Even "The Big City," which requires the kind of dramatic projection that Americans are rarely taught, was a tribute to their versatility, and especially to the principals. Luc Vanier, as the Workman, knew how to telegraph dejection through stillness. Head bowed to one side, hands in pockets, or leaning forward in a standard ballet position, he became a distilled image of heartbreak and yearning. Stephani Achuff, as the Young Girl, understood the differences in gait and phrasing. Innocent in her white beret, midinette appearance and scurrying steps, she seemed transformed not only by the evening dress she received from Paul Ghiselin as the top-hatted Libertine but also by the jazz age rhythms of her ballroom dances.
Jooss was dealing in stock characters. But in Europe in 1932, the working-class men really did wear caps, and their clothes set them apart from rich men in capes. Similarly, there is a touch of Kathe Kollwitz's drawings of working-class life in a remarkable and terse scene: four wide-eyed children (Kara Davis, Joe Roesner, Linda Hymes and Edward Augustyn), curve their backs to fit under the protective arms of their mothers (Amy Hayes and Susan Lodise) and reprovingly watch the Young Girl.
What is so stunning is the economy with which Jooss makes his points. The Charleston dancers in Hermann Markard's costumes are replaced in a filmic dissolve by a bal musette. This difference in social dances (the workers hold their women close and revolve across the floor while the rich folk are more frenetic and modern) tells the story of "The Big City."
The ballet, a must-see, looks just as fascinating as when it had a short-lived revival with the Joffrey Ballet in 1975. Anna Markard, Jooss's daughter, and Airi Hynninen have conveyed the spirit of Jooss's body language to the dancers, and Lois Rova Ozanich and David Fisher, live at two pianos, play Alexander Tansman's infectious atmospheric score. The neo-Romanticism of Mr. Poll's "Summer Night" gains mightily from Mr. Garcia's and Ms. Tejeda de Cerda's boldly projected arabesques and line. Ms. Childs, for her part, makes the dancers (the women are in toe shoes but don't always rise on point) look somewhat awkward as they snap into positions. But there is also a kaleidoscopic dazzle to the way she moves three quartets of dancers in color-coded costumes around in her stamina-demanding patterns, partnering and mirror dances.
"Eight by Benny Goodman" uses recordings from 1939 to 1946 in a suite. The company, mainly in formal dress, mixes ballroom and ballet. The whole thing is exhilarating.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stephani Achuff and Paul Ghiselin of the Ohio Ballet in "The Big City." (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

WHO DECIDES WHO WILL DIE? IT DEPENDS
As New York prepares to restore the death penalty, just how it will work remains an open question -- both because some details of the legislation are not final and because, in practice, the use of the death penalty depends as much on prosecutors and juries as on the letter of the law. A1.

2 FEUDING FAMILIES AND A MURDER PLOT

HEADLINE: Bank Merger Is Challenged By Governor

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Gov. John G. Rowland today threatened to block the proposed merger of the state's two largest banks unless the banks took steps to soften the impact of the deal on Connecticut's economy.
The highly unusual move -- states traditionally rubber-stamp such mergers -- comes one day after Fleet Financial Group of Providence, R.I., agreed to purchase Shawmut National Corporation of Hartford and Boston. The $3.7 billion deal would create the nation's ninth-largest bank. 
 In this city, where both banks have large offices, the announcement has been greeted as grim economic news. It could mean as many as 1,200 layoffs for the banks' 7,844 Connecticut employees, along with the closing of as many as one-third of the banks' 250 branches across Connecticut. The new bank's headquarters would be in Boston.
"The state has a lot to say about whether this merger can take place," Mr. Rowland said at a news conference this afternoon. "We will be looking at it very, very carefully. We're doing all we can do within our authority to protect jobs."
The state will negotiate with the banks in the coming months to try to extract concessions and guarantees about jobs and local lending, Mr. Rowland said, declining to offer specific goals.
It is unlikely that the state could actually scuttle the deal, though it certainly could slow the approval process and force the banks into a costly legal battle.
The merger requires approval from various Federal departments and agencies, as well as from the State Banking Department. Bank officials said they are optimistic about their prospects.
Federal and state agencies must examine whether the merger would violate anti-trust provisions, economic impact requirements and other measures. The state uses the same guidelines as the Federal Government. If any branch of government rejects the merger, the banks may appeal the decision in Federal court.
Mr. Rowland held his news conference after he and legislative leaders from both parties held an hourlong meeting with the banks' two top executives, Joel B. Alvord of Shawmut and Terrence Murray of Fleet.
"They were shocked," the House Speaker, Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat, said of the reaction of the two bank executives when they walked into a roomful of angry elected officials.
After the meeting, Mr. Alvord said the banks had looked into the legal ramifications of the deal before they announced it and believed it could not be halted.
Regarding the possibility of regulatory stumbling blocks, he remarked, "I feel confident that any such problems can be avoided through discussions."
But Mr. Rowland was clearly striking a tough bargaining stance. "No job loss is acceptable," he said, noting that the state had lost 200,000 jobs over the last seven years.

HEADLINE: Wright's Hometown Finally Sees Its Future

BYLINE: By RON McCREA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 22

 BODY:
For more than half a century, this capital of the split-personality state that produced both the La Follette Progressive movement and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has been passionately divided over Frank Lloyd Wright.
If many here in Wright's boyhood hometown recognized him as one of the century's great architects, there were plenty of others who reviled him as an autocrat, a womanizer and, perhaps worst of all, a habitual deadbeat whose real genius lay in bouncing checks and dodging bill collectors. 
 Wright, who lived here from age 11 to 19, planned 32 buildings in the city during his career. Of the nine that were built, eight remain, including a Prairie House, the Unitarian church and the first Usonian, Wright's prototype economy house for the American middle class, built for a newspaper reporter in 1936 for $ 5,000.
But one plan for Madison stood out not just for the ambition of its design but for the legendary battles it created. Monona Terrace, a project unveiled in 1938, was a grand vision of towers, fountains and terraces rising from the shores of Lake Monona in the shadow of the Capitol.
Time and again, Wright's admirers persuaded voters to approve bonds for the construction, only to be thwarted at every turn by equally dedicated Wright foes, largely businessmen who complained about the building's cost and despised Wright's politics.
Finally, last month, after 57 years of false starts, political sabotage and dashed hopes, construction teams drove the first pilings for the project that had bedeviled the architect through the final decades of his life.
The key to resolving five decades of hostilities lay in changing the building's purpose. Instead of the civic and cultural palace Wright had envisioned, Monona Terrace is being built as a convention center -- with the sudden, enthusiastic support of Madison's newly converted business interests.
Despite its newly defined function, the 4.4-acre complex, which is scheduled to open on July 4, 1997, will embody Wright's vision of "a great civic expression" that leaps the 60-foot bluff at the southeastern approach to the State Capitol and fans out over the Monona waterfront, linking the city's heart to one of its four lakes.
The 1938 design would have incorporated city and county government offices and chambers, a railroad station, courts and a jail. But the building now under construction follows the design Wright updated in 1958, by which time it had been redefined as a civic auditorium.
It will include a 68,000-square-foot rooftop garden park accessible from the street; spiral parking ramps at either end that strongly resemble his design for New York's Guggenheim Museum and 250,000 square feet of interior space, including a ballroom, an exhibition hall and an 8,500-square-foot auditorium.
In addition to stone and bricks and mortar, "there is all the water of Lake Monona to play with, to throw up as decorations in the form of columns and fountains," Wright told a Madison audience in 1941, promoting his plan for the second time.
Robert D'Angelo, the center's interim director, said: "At every level of the building there is floor-to-ceiling glass facing the lake. As you walk out, you enter a curved lobby that arcs over the lake front right at the waterline." Dinner cruises and garden receptions are planned for warm months.
Anthony Puttnam of Taliesin Architects of Phoenix, who worked on the original Monona Terrace plans as a teen-age apprentice, is now the project's chief architect. "It's a courageous building," he said of the 1997 version. "And in the context of Madison it is a very courageous building."
Much of the city's new-found courage may lie in the fading of old scars.
"Madison could dig into its pocket and pay something for the charm nature has given it," Wright fumed when challenged on the $ 17 million price of his 1938 civic center plan ($ 50 million less than the current project). "But maybe Madison can't look ahead 10 years. It is too provincial, backwater, smug and satisfied."
Mayor Paul Soglin says the Monona Terrace curse was finally broken by forging a new coalition of supporters. "In the past, if it was a Frank Lloyd Wright facility, the business community was against it," Mr. Soglin said. "If it was a convention center without a Frank Lloyd Wright design, the critical center of the city was against it."
By dusting off the Wright design and persuading George Nelson, a local broadcasting executive, to head the development commission, Mr. Soglin said, "You had the chief executives of utility companies and labor leaders working with art students and university professors to make this thing happen."
The most interesting player in the final act may have been Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a conservative Republican who is also leading state efforts to restore Taliesin, Wright's Spring Green estate 40 miles west of Madison. When Mr. Soglin proposed the project, Governor Thompson immediately offered $ 18 million in state funds to pay for the parking portion of the project.
"It was a tremendous partnership," the Governor said in an interview. "When we came forward, it was the anchor that said this was doable. When I came out for it, the business community said: 'Well, this can't be all bad. You got Nelson from the business community; you got Soglin, the Mayor, who's more on the Democrat side, and you got Tommy Thompson pushing from the conservative Republican side. That's a pretty formidable force.'"
Unlike previous attempts to build Monona Terrace, the current plan distributes the financing of the project's "guaranteed maximum price" of $ 67.1 million: $ 18 million from the state; $ 12 million from the city; $ 12 million from Dane County and $ 8 million from private donors. The remaining $ 17 million is to be raised over 20 years from hotel taxes.
The largest private contribution was a $ 3 million challenge grant from the William T. Evjue Foundation, named for the late publisher of The Capital Times, the city's afternoon newspaper, a longtime Wright champion in the Monona Terrace wars.
Despite legal action by some environmentalists to stop the project, work continues. Mr. D'Angelo said he had already booked a number of "major, major" conventions, some as far in advance as 2002, and florists, caterers and other vendors are already lining up for part of $ 15 million to $ 20 million in annual revenue that Monona Terrace is expected to generate.
"The money that the city will make off of this -- in the economy and the jobs created -- will be enough to pay every bill that Frank Lloyd Wright stiffed people for many times over," Mr. Nelson said. "People said he never paid his debts. He's paying them now."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 24, 1995, Friday

HEADLINE: French Official Demands Inquiry on Spy Leak

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Foreign Minister Alain Juppe said today that he was shocked that France's accusations of economic espionage by the former C.I.A. station chief and four other Americans here had been leaked to the French press.
"I am scandalized that a delicate problem between us -- and this is not the first time that such a problem has arisen -- could be dragged out into the open this way," Mr. Juppe said. He called for a thorough public inquiry into how the daily newspaper Le Monde had obtained Government intelligence documents on the case. 
 Despite reports on Wednesday that France was insisting that the five Americans leave the country immediately, the former station chief was still in his office at the American Embassy today. French diplomats said that apparently none of the others had left either.
If there was ever any doubt that the revelations had more to do with the French presidential campaign than with a grave dispute between France and its traditional ally, the remarks by Mr. Juppe, a supporter of Jacques Chirac, Mayor of Paris, seemed to dispel it.
"There is no crisis whatsoever between France and the United States," the Foreign Minister said. "We had no intention to go public on this affair." The implication is that someone else did -- the chief of the French counterespionage service, Interior Minister Charles Pasqua.
Mr. Pasqua is the Cabinet's leading supporter of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur's, whose lead in the presidential race is evaporating. Mr. Balladur is now running neck and neck with his fellow conservative Mr. Chirac and a Socialist, Lionel Jospin, in public opinion polls.
One reason for Mr. Balladur's loss of momentum was the disclosure early this week that he had approved a telephone tapping operation recommended by Mr. Pasqua on grounds that later turned out to be legally insufficient.
If there was any way to divert attention from the wiretapping scandal, partisans and nonpartisans agreed today, throwing the spotlight on the big power the French love to hate -- the United States -- was perhaps the obvious course.
"In an election campaign, diversionary maneuvers are part of the game," said Philippe Vasseur, another supporter of Mr. Chirac's in the presidential race.
It is Mr. Pasqua who has held most of the strings in the investigation since 1993. On Jan. 26, he took the unusual step of summoning Pamela Harriman, the American Ambassador here, to his office to discuss the allegations.
Usually it is the Foreign Ministry that deals with foreign diplomats, or the Prime Minister or the President, diplomats noted.
According to the report in Le Monde, Mr. Pasqua told Mrs. Harriman that his counterspies had caught her C.I.A. station chief, three of his embassy colleagues, and a fifth American red-handed in the act of trying to buy French economic and political secrets from high officials, and that she should see to it that all five leave France as soon as possible.
He followed up this demand with a letter Feb. 1, and with a second summons to his office on Feb. 10.
Mrs. Harriman apparently argued that her diplomats had just been doing their jobs, making contacts with French officials and gathering information on politics and the French position on trade issues, and that there was no reason to send them packing.
Mr. Juppe, the Foreign Minister, tried to sound relaxed about the accusations during a news conference at the Foreign Ministry today.
"What we have to do now is to continue to discuss this sensitive issue with our American friends," he said. "I am confident that we will soon find a way out."
The "recommendation" that the alleged C.I.A. staff members leave, he said, "was made in the spirit of trust that exists between our two countries."
"It was not intended to be made public."
Mr. Juppe refused to answer questions after making his statement, and Mr. Pasqua left today on a five-day tour of African countries.
Since the candidates the two support, Mr. Chirac and Mr. Balladur, are both members of the neo-Gaullist Rally for the Republic party, the campaign battle between them has been particularly rough. The first round of voting on a President to succeed Francois Mitterrand will be April 23, with a runoff in May if no one wins more than 50 percent.
The news of the alleged American espionage pushed articles about Mr. Pasqua's telephone tapping operation off the front pages of French daily newspapers today.
Le Monde followed up with interviews with three of the unnamed French officials the Americans supposedly approached for information about French domestic politics, industry and trade matters. One of them, recalling conversations with one of the five Americans, told the newspaper:
"She was quite a bit older than me, and not very pretty. The banalities I told her about French politics, and France's concern about not being isolated in the negotiations on GATT, et cetera -- all that seemed to interest her passionately."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Le Monde's coverage of assertions about U.S. spying may be an attempt to divert attention from a wire-tapping scandal involving the Interior Minister, Charles Pasqua, who addressed a political rally Wednesday. (Photographs by Associated Press)
